From the Club Gascon people, an oddly Proven√É¬ßal incursion into the heart of legal-land; staff are charming, and the bright interior is pleasant enough, but we‚Äôre not at all sure that the formula is right for such a businesslike part of town.

Chancery Lane, the high street of the London legal world, was until very recently, maintaining the English high street tradition of not having restaurants of any note. The situation has improved a bit in recent years, with the arrival in the immediate area of Chancery, and also the very wine-led basement bar and restaurant 28-50.

This essentially English setting has now seen a very Gallic incursion. A restaurant once known by the suitably stolid name of Hodgson‚Äôs has now been taken over by the Club Gascon folk, and given a very French name indeed. Cigalon strikes us as an odd choice, though, echoing as it does that of a Marcel Pagnol movie whose eponymous hero was a Proven√É¬ßal chef whose restaurant remained defiantly empty. Perhaps the French have a sense of humour after all?

Further evidence of such humour is the dress of the largely male staff. We don‚Äôt normally comment on attire, but the dress here is too ridiculous to pass without comment: a uniform for the chaps that renders bizarrre the idea that France could be the home of chic. Clip-on braces are a sartorial solecism at the best of times. Why make all the (perfectly charming, French) male staff wear them? We felt as if were were extras in sitcom set in a tacky menswear shop.

And then we progress to the vexed question of d√©cor. The light and bright premises of character (originally the premises of a Georgian auctioneer) have been given a Proven√É¬ßal-pastel make-over ‚Äì as our lunch guest commented, ideal for ladies who lunch. But ‚Äì hello! ‚Äì we‚Äôre spiritually in the ECs, darling. The ECs are where the husbands of ladies-who-lunch venture out, mainly with other chaps, to keep the ladies-who-lunch in the Ws and SWs with their white wine spritzers. Who‚Äôs this d√©cor for? How‚Äôs it going to feel in still semi-Dickensian Legal-Town in the deep midwinter? We shudder ‚Äì almost literally ‚Äì to think. (And the summer is traditionally a quiet time around the inns of court.)

The food is not bad, but ‚Äì like the d√©cor ‚Äì we couldn‚Äôt help wondering if it is ‚Äòright‚Äô. The bread, a selection, was OK, if not at all remarkable, but the overwhelming impression of a bowl of Proven√É¬ßal vegetable soup was that it was rather a lady‚Äôs portion. Our guest‚Äôs small portion of marinated sardines similarly failed to cause much excitement.

Main courses were a strikingly bronze-plated dish of red mullet (plus some impressively twiddled-with courgettes), and a relatively substantial veal chop, which our guest ultimately touted as the highlight of the meal. Puddings included a pleasant (if rather could-do-this-at-home) m√©lange of citrus fruits and sponge, and a very delicate chocolate tart, somewhat peculiarly presented on a slate platter with what looked like a small deboned fish, but which turned out to be a fancy smear of curd. Our guest pronounced it a moderate success, which was also his view of the coffee.

So what are we to make of a ladies‚Äô restaurant in the heart of legal london, without either the boho appeal of Club Gascon, or the chic of its Sloane Square satellite, Le Cercle? We sometimes fear we must be missing something.

At Lagom, ElliotCunningham‚Äôs ‚Äúsemi-permanent pop-up‚Äù in the Hackney Church brewery, there‚Äôs chunkypicnic tables crowded with twentysomethings, a ‚Äúsmall, smoky open kitchen‚Äù anda gravelly urban garden with ‚Äústrings of glowing bulbs overhead‚Äù.

This might well sound ‚Äúuncomfortableand noisy and chaotic‚Äù, as it clearly did to Jay ‚Äì but the food made up for it.Avoid Lagom and risk ‚Äúmissing out on some bold live-fire cooking that throbsuncompromisingly with flavour‚Äù ‚Äì the ‚Äúexceptionally good‚Äù meat dishes includedbone-in pork belly (‚Äúa plate of caramelisation and melting fat‚Ä¶ an awful lot oftop pig action for ¬£10‚Äù), Sutton Hoo chicken and a smoked beef bun withfermented chilli.

Impressively, the ‚Äúthe non-meat dishes‚Ä¶ are more striking‚Äù; thinly sliced golden roasted beetroot was ‚Äúwas the best plate of the stuff I have eaten in years‚Äù (and he‚Äôs eaten a lot of beetroot), closed-cap mushrooms ‚Äúsmoked to an almost meaty intensity‚Äù and white coleslaw ‚Äúfull of crunch and salt and vinegar‚Äù. Cherry pie for dessert is only available at weekends (unless you‚Äôre Jay) but is ‚Äúdesigned to serve two, even if one of them is me‚Äù.

Kala is in a ‚Äúnondescript‚Äù glass building in the city centre; the restaurant is upstairsfrom the bar, giving it a ‚Äúcosy bunk-bed aesthetic‚Äù, with ‚Äúlittle wooden tablesand an eerily calm-looking open kitchen‚Äù.

Main courses included a slightly ‚Äúbaffling‚Äù combination of haddock and chicken, and braised featherblade (‚Äúthe beef so dark and tender that you can cut into it with the side of your fork‚Äù, served with ‚Äúfrighteningly fat, indulgent truffled parmesan chips‚Äù and followed by a ‚Äúperfect‚Äù custard tart.

Kitty and her friend had an ‚Äúamazingtime‚Äù, admiring the fact that ‚Äúfood is served without fanfare‚Äù but ‚Äúeach dishis an event‚Äù, with ‚Äúmultiple ingredients and‚Ä¶ delicious, fiddly embellishments‚Äù.

Kala is effectively owned ‚Äúby thepeople who actually go for dinner there‚Äù, which feels ‚Äúlike a much moredemocratic way to eat‚Äù ‚Äì or ‚Äúperhaps it‚Äôs all part of Usher‚Äôs long game to stopus behaving like jerks‚Äù.

magazine was at Norma, having been pipped to the post last week by his colleague and fellow critic Marina O‚ÄôLoughlin with a review of The Clove Club. It‚Äôs fine for new places ‚Äì ‚ÄúI‚Äôve‚Ä¶ reviewed quite a few places after she‚Äôs done them‚Ä¶ and nobody‚Äôs noticed. Literally nobody.‚Äù (We did, Giles, but we were too polite to point it out.) ‚Äì but ‚Äúa reliable ten-year-old, suddenly exhumed by both of us in the same week‚Ä¶ would look weird‚Äù.

He loved The Clove Club, having never reviewed it before (‚Äúsuch precision, such imagination, such intensity of flavour‚Äù) but couldn‚Äôt publish his review (or boast at length about how he dined with Gary Lineker) ‚Äì and now needed a replacement‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúLuckily, just around the corner from my new office, there‚Äôs Norma‚Äù, from the team behind The Stafford hotel, including ‚Äúthe great Ben Tish‚Äù (and not apparently not ‚Äúa misspelt homage to the famous ‚ÄúNordic kitchen‚Äù gaff in Copenhagen‚Äù).

This ‚Äúlittle jewel of a restaurant‚Äù (‚Äújust so, so pretty‚Äù with ‚Äúromanticnooks and supersweet service‚Äù) is ‚Äúon totally-coming-back-up-gastronomicallyCharlotte Street‚Äù, wasn‚Äôt technically open to the public when he visited, buthe needed a review so pressed ahead anyway. And was glad that he did, for Normaserved up a ‚Äúincredibly thrilling and unfamiliar‚Äù menu of Sicilian-inspireddishes. He only visited at lunchtime so had small meal with no wine; we‚Äôll haveto rely on the other critics to give us a full picture. Plus √ßa change‚Ä¶ (24/30)

As the name suggests, The Small Holding ‚Äúboasts the type of thriving, working kitchen garden with added pigs, geese and chickens for which addled city dwellers yearn‚Äù ‚Äì this ‚Äúformer pub‚Äôs single acre heaves with courgettes, kale, fennel, peas, beans and approximately 200 other varieties of veg, fruit and herbs‚Äù. And from it they have created a ‚Äúbrilliant example of self-sustaining, fun fine-dining‚Äù ‚Äì like Gareth Ward‚Äôs Ynyshir in Wales ‚Äì offering ‚Äúskilful cooking that retains joy, pace and mischief throughout‚Äù.

The 11-course menu (with briefdescriptions like ‚Äòsweetcorn, egg, mushroom‚Äô) provided more than one ‚Äúmagicalmouthful‚Äù and was served by swift and ‚Äúcheery service‚Äù. It does what the ‚Äúbestsort of fine dining does: it shines light into corners of your brain thatyou‚Äôve not used for decades. Flavours you thought were no longer possible‚Äù.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still a realsense of the thoroughly unpretentious, 90s-style country pub about The SmallHolding‚Ä¶ Please go‚Ä¶but preserve and conserve their normal-ness. They‚Äôre just agroup of folk growing amazing things‚Ä¶ then cooking and serving them. It‚Äôsperfectly imperfect, and I wouldn‚Äôt change a thing.‚Äù (27/10)

was inspired to visit St John Bread & Wine after ‚Äúconstantly hearing contented murmurings‚Äù ‚Äì and also after she wrote a lengthy quote for the dustjacket of the new St John Cookbook that wasn‚Äôt used.
Her dining companion (a newcomer to St John‚Äôsvirtues) praised the ‚Äúthelet‚Äôs-not-make-a-meal-of-things while-we-make-a-meal-of-things vibe‚Äù.

Innes Log cheese melted over roasted tomatoes and cabbage was a ‚Äútriumph‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúcreaminess contrasting with knuckled-under acidity and eat-your-greens virtue‚Äù, while Welsh rarebit was ‚Äúas inviting to get into as a neatly, freshly-made bed on a chilly evening‚Äù and the ‚Äúdesserts are particularly, you might say surprisingly, alluring‚Äù.

visited Tom Griffiths‚Äô¬†‚Äúlong-term kitchen residency‚Äù at The Print House in Stratford (on a ‚Äúwindblown, oddly deserted stretch of E15‚Äù), he had a ‚Äúpre-visit fondness for the food‚Äù (thanks to its high profile on Instagram), and now wishes he ‚Äúhadn‚Äôt let reality rupture the fantasy‚Äù.

All the dishes he orderedarrived at once on a ‚Äúcomically large tray‚Äù, meaning that ‚Äúyou are forced todecide which dish you are most happy to eat slightly cold‚Äù. Those dishesincluded distinctly unsmokey smoked cheese croquettes with ‚Äúeerily flavourless‚Äùdip, and over-smoked barbecued cabbage that was ‚Äúoverpowering to the point ofinedibility: a forceful exhaust-belch that tasted synthetic‚Äù. ‚ÄúFurtherwaywardness‚Äù included ‚Äúlimp, timidly fired naan‚Äù and ‚Äúcloying barbecue glazedpig head and trotter patties in stiff mini sub rolls‚Äù.

And then ‚Äúblessedly, someglimmers of hope‚Äù in the form of a mini double cheeseburger, a ‚Äúfine-crispedpotato gratin‚Ä¶ drenched in a fragrant, gutsy pan stock‚Äù and a deep-fried appleslice (‚Äúa riff on the famed McDonald‚Äôs mouth-stripper‚Äù).

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think Flank‚Äôspopularity at its Market Hall Victoria and Spitalfields berths is a totalmirage‚Äù but ‚Äúenticing gastronomic trigger terms ‚Äî ‚Äòbeef fat‚Äô this and ‚Äòsmoked‚Äôthat ‚Äî don‚Äôt amount to much without careful, focused execution‚Äù. (5/10)
is the latest in a long line of critics who‚Äôve tried out Swiss restaurant Heritage on a hot summer‚Äôs day (‚Äúit comes as no surprise that the place is totally empty‚Äù).

The ‚Äústaffare charmingly cheery‚Äù (or just ‚Äúhappy for something to do‚Äù?) but the room itself‚Äúis hardly cutting-edge, a hotch-potch of styles that would have seemed datedat the start of the millennium‚Äù.

Despite a ‚Äúratheroverpriced and pretty mean bottle of Swiss white‚Äù, Tom and his companion (whobought him in a charity auction) ate ‚Äúimmaculate r√∂sti‚Äù and raclette ‚Äúlovinglyscraped on to a pile of boiled potatoes, pickles and good charcuterie‚Äù (althoughthe portion was a bit small for him).

The cheese fonduearrived with bread and even more meat, although he wasn‚Äôt impressed with the additionof Fourme d‚ÄôAmbert (a French blue cheese). ‚ÄúThere simply isn‚Äôt a placefor blue cheese in Swiss fondue.‚Äù A ‚Äúboozy chocolate fondue‚Äù fordessert came with brownies for dipping, making Tom feel like he needed ‚Äúto liedown somewhere dark and cool for a few years‚Ä¶ and moan gently‚Äù.
declared that Noto, the second project from Aizle‚Äôs Stuart Ralston, is ‚Äúthe capital‚Äôs most exciting restaurant in a while‚Äù.
It‚Äôs ‚Äúless conceptual‚Äù than Aizle, ‚Äúwith small andlarger √† la carte plates‚Äùfrom a menu that‚Äôs ‚Äúrelatively short and easy to navigate‚Äù.

Gaby and her companion hadNorth Sea crab that was ‚Äúperfect as a starter‚Äù, a shell ‚Äúfullof a fragrant mixture of hot melted butter, soft white meat‚Ä¶ chives and dill‚Äùwith sourdough ‚Äúto sweep up the liquid seaside sunshine‚Äù and Berkswell cheesecroquettes (which ‚Äúcould be a new currency. Iwould be happy to be paid in them‚Äù) alongside Jerusalemartichokes and a ‚Äúheadily strong¬†negroni‚Äù.

Bigger plates included a lobster¬†dish that was ‚Äúratherexcitingly mad-cap, like a comforting Japanese take on the recent trend forlobster mac ‚Äòn‚Äô cheese‚Äù and fried buttermilk chicken (‚Äúthigh meat in a looseparka of batter‚Äù) served in a golden bao with ‚Äúmushroomyumami mayonnaise and a mildly spicy kimchi‚Äù.

was in King‚Äôs Sutton near Banbury, which has two pubs ‚Äì one proper boozer, and this one, which is ‚Äúreally a restaurant, rather than a pub‚Äù, with ‚Äúdesigner lighting, lots of waitresses buzzing about, everything spruced up and sand-blasted‚Äù.

Pudding was his favourite dish ‚Äì ‚Äúa gently oozing chocolate fondant in‚Ä¶ a pastry case made ofchocolate‚Äù. Before this, he‚Äôd eaten a ‚Äúperfectly pink piece of fillet steak with crunchy, fatchips and a perfect example of how to cook savoy cabbage‚Äù and ‚Äúa small free bowl of soup‚Ä¶ made ofcheddar and ale‚Ä¶ as enchanting as it was unexpected‚Äù.
There were some less impressive dishes, however ‚Äì ‚Äúcrispy pig‚Äôs head with black-pudding starter was too dry‚Äù for example. But they ‚Äúleft happy nevertheless‚Äù. (***)
in Belfast, where ‚Äúan unusual collaboration has created a resoundingly successful Thai restaurant‚Äù, run by ‚Äúthe most unlikely restaurateur I have ever met‚Äù.

relies on her ‚Äúspidey sense‚Äù to truffle out fabulous new restaurants to tell us about, and this time that ‚Äútingling in the fingertip‚Äù was spot on. And so it was off to rural Northumberland and The Hadrian Hotel.

The hotel has always been a pub stop on the ‚Äúhikers‚Äô trail near Hadrian‚Äôs Wall‚Äù, it still looks just like you‚Äôd expect (dogs and all), but visitors for Hjem are led ‚Äúthrough a side door into a small culinary Narnia‚Äù (‚Äúall light and open, yang to the pub‚Äôs yin‚Äù). It‚Äôs the ‚Äújust-weeks-old baby‚Äù of the hotel‚Äôs new owners, chef Alex Nietosvuori from Sweden and his partner, Ally Thompson.
There‚Äôs no menu,‚Äújust a choice of six or 12 courses‚Äù, and ‚Äúeach small course isso elegant, so light, so delicate that there‚Äôs never the slightest suggestionof grande bouffe‚Äù.

‚ÄúThis is food to make you beam with delighted surprise‚Äù ‚Äì with ‚Äúa sense of fun, too‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe couple‚Äôs background in big-name Scandinavian restaurants informs a lot of the technique, but produce is firmly local. It‚Äôs that whole British ‚Äúnew northern‚Äù vibe: exciting and wildly creative.‚Äù Presentation is both austere and exquisite (a peek at their social media shows inventively presented dishes, using carved, wand-like spoons, hand-turned apples and upside-down earthenware pots).

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a longtime since a restaurant has moved me as much as Hjem does ‚Äî probably not sinceInver on the shores of Loch Fyne, a similar tale of a fiercely independent teamcreating extraordinary food in unusual locations. It has made me properlyemotional.‚Äù

; the owners (a ‚Äúcharming and chatty‚Äù front-of-house presence) have perfected the ‚Äúart of leaving things the hell alone, allowing an ingredient‚Äôs inherent goodness to shine forth‚Äù ‚Äì Tom‚Äôs first dishes of anchovies and charcuterie were ‚Äúnot so much cooking as putting together, but damn it‚Äôs good‚Äù.

Starters include slow-cooked hogget (with Tom‚Äôs trademark farm noises, ‚Äúheavy on the baa and bleat‚Äù), asparagus with squeaky Cheddar curds (‚Äúa clever dish, packed with different textures, yet all bow down to the asparagus. There‚Äôs a fine balance here, a precision and an absolute control of acidity‚Äù) and barbecued ox tongue (‚Äúsensationally rich‚Ä¶ tempered by a tart salad studded with pickles‚Äù).

There was no room for pudding after the main courses of more barbecue (‚ÄúChef sure likes his smoky flavours‚Äù), this time pork collar with a too-‚Äúoverwhelming‚Äù citrus sauce, and ‚Äúpristinely fresh and pristinely cooked‚Äù brill, a ‚Äúgently understated dish, but expertly and knowingly put together‚Äù.

got to Maremma first. It‚Äôs a hotly awaited Brixton Italian named after the ‚Äúcoastal, southernmost area‚Äù of Tuscany, and is a ‚Äúlabour of love devoted to the region‚Äôs food and wine‚Äù (and ‚Äúthe dedication‚Ä¶ is impeccable‚Äù).
Thecorner site is ‚Äúwelcoming,light and open to the street‚Äù ‚Äì but ‚Äúeven on soft opening, with‚Ä¶ the winebar area below not quite finished, but the cooking was already polished‚Äù.

From the ‚Äúshort, carefully considered menu‚ÄùDavid and his compaion had aquacotta that was ‚Äúas simple as it is meant to be, albeitpeppery ‚Äù and ‚Äútentacle ofchargrilled polpo‚Ä¶ was definitely yum‚Äù. Next, there was ‚Äúan appealingly different vegetarianoption‚Äù in the ‚Äúexcellent torta di ceci, almost a chickpea¬†pizza‚Äù and ‚Äúa sumptuous piece of wood-baked hake‚Ä¶ confident in itssimplicity‚Äù.
Forpudding there was a torta di nonna with a ‚Äúrichly eggy custard, bedecked with pine nuts‚Äù and a ‚Äúperfectlyjudged cheese plate‚Äù.

dropped in to visit ‚Äúex-MasterChef finalist Larkin Cen‚Äôs third Bristol restaurant‚Äù. She has strong opinions on the rise of the shipping container restaurant (this one is sited in Wapping Wharf‚Äôs second Cargo development) ‚Äì it‚Äôs ‚Äústrangely unhospitable hospitality‚Äù, but chefs seems to love them (cheap and sustainable, what‚Äôs not to like?)

-style cooking, which is a term that defies neat explanation.‚Äù With ‚Äú40 covers, a noisy working kitchen, a sit-up bar, half a dozen staff and a queue out of the door‚Äù it‚Äôs ‚Äúnothing remotely romantic‚Äù, but enjoyable to a point.

‚ÄúPlump, delicious duck meatballs on skewers seared over Binchotan charcoal‚Äù, ‚Äúoutstanding plates of Korean fried cauliflower laced with lemongrass and served with an assertive sriracha mayo‚Äù and ‚Äúa deceptively simple bowl of tender, robata-grilled shiitake caps sitting in a puddle of roast garlic soy‚Äù were ‚Äúworth a detour alone‚Äù from the ‚Äúbrief‚Äù menu that‚Äôs ‚Äúlow on carbs‚Äù.
The two most expensive dishes were katsumonkfish, which ‚Äúlacked much pizzazz or panko breadcrumbs‚Äù and braisedbeef short-rib, ‚Äúa lesson in softening, blackening and stickifying‚Äù.

The ‚Äúlevel of cooking is very high‚Äù but the overall experience, for Grace, was let down by the ‚Äúpasscode‚Äù-accessed shared toilets (which ‚Äúhad no loo paper and felt like no one‚Äôs responsibility‚Äù) and the service (‚Äúwe sat in a blind spot, cluttered by dirty plates, our glasses empty‚Äù). ‚ÄúIt was all a bit day three at Glastonbury ‚Äì jolly, but directionless.‚Äù (19/30, with 8/10 for food)

is quite right. ‚ÄúMayfair isn‚Äôt the first place you‚Äôd think of going for an Indian meal.‚Äù He also makes a decent point that ‚Äúthere‚Äôs already too much pointless gilding‚Äù in the area, when protesting about the silver leaf that embellished his cauliflower dish.

Precious metals aside (‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like eating things which serve no nutritionalpurpose‚Äù), there‚Äôs also the important point to be made that there‚Äôsno reason there shouldn‚Äôt be an Indian restaurant in London‚Äôs most expensiverestaurant quarter. Just because you can eat Indian food for‚Äúbuttons‚Äù on your local high street ‚Äúdoesnot mean food from the Indian tradition should never cost as much as that fromFrance, Italy or Japan‚Ä¶ the foodjust needs to be worth it‚Äù.

Lucknow 49, the secondrestaurant from Dhruv Mittal is a ‚Äúvery comfortable restaurant‚Ä¶ stackedwith throw cushions and bolsters‚Ä¶ olive green paintwork‚Ä¶ ¬†hand-printed decorations‚Ä¶ a self-conscioustake on the domestic, the sort of relaxed style that costs proper money‚Äù.

Jay‚Äôs double lamb chops ‚Äì central to the royal Mughal cuisine ‚Äì were ‚Äúbig, meaty beasts, with a fine char, hot, crisped fat, and the rising scent of newly roasted spices‚Äù. Chicken thighs ‚Äúmarinated in a saffron-flavoured cream before being charcoal grilled‚Ä¶ are buttery and rich in all the right places‚Äù and the raan masala (slow-roasted leg of lamb) was ‚Äúa boisterous bit of overtly butch cookery‚Äù. Sides of patties and stuffed flatbreads ‚Äúmake up the numbers rather than thrill‚Äù, but the perfectly timed cauliflower (‚Äúif you can ignore the silliness of the silver leaf‚Äù) had ‚Äútension and bite‚Äù.

‚ÄúUnderstand Lucknow 49 asa relaxed Indian restaurant in London‚Äôs Mayfair that will only occasionallyknock your socks off, but will still show you a nice time along the way, andyou won‚Äôt be disappointed.‚Äù

Not that it was a hardship. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not Corbin and King but it is Lander and Morgenthau, which is coming to mean every bit as much to London diners.‚Äù They may ‚Äúskew more to serious modern cooking than C&K, less to opulence and period chic‚Äù but their portfolio is strong (Quality Chop House, Clipstone and Portland) and Giles‚Äôs dinner at their new Bonhams opening was ‚Äúreally quite unfeasibly delicious‚Äù; ‚Äúthe kitchen, run by Stuart Andrew from Clipstone, is on absolute fire‚Äù.

His table ordered ‚Äúall the antipasti‚Äù; along with the ‚Äúwonderfully cakey focaccia‚Äù, it was enough to make Giles repeat ‚Äúdelicious‚Äù four times. There was ‚Äúa really extraordinary plate of lardo and watermelon‚Äù and juicy, meaty courgette fritti. Primi included ‚Äúa sort of pig trotter spring roll that was shatteringly crisp and greasy in all the right ways‚Äù (‚Äúa massive fat piggy snog‚Äù), a ‚Äúmarvellously ferrous and dense‚Äù vitello tonnato (but made with Belted Galloway beef, not veal) and ‚Äúthe most ridiculously moreish fried gnocchi‚Äù.

Forthe pasta course, they ate the ‚Äúdaintiest eel (or‚Äúsnakefish‚Äù) tortellini‚Ä¶ in an angelically clear and slippery brodo‚Äù,‚Äúbig, buttery ravioli full of walnuts and ricotta‚Äù, ‚Äúrich meatyrabbit‚Äù tagliatelle and ‚Äústupendous‚Äù lobster spaghetti.

was the first reviewer to brave the outdoor barbecue terrace from the owners of Barrafina. It‚Äôs set in Coal Drops Yard, ‚Äúthat space-age retail and dining gorge, lurking in an unexpected corner of King‚Äôs Cross like a gigantic ¬£100 million secret‚Äù and will hopefully draw the hoped-for crowds this summer. On a sunny day it certainly looked like ‚Äúthe idealised vision of a particularly deep-pocketed Spanish tourist board‚Äù.

The tables under the covered terrace have ‚Äúboxy, miniature charcoal grills ‚Äî the parrillas that give the place its name‚Äù for you to barbecue your own dinner (‚Äúplatters of meat and vegetables‚Äù). Jimi declares up front that ‚Äúinviting people to pay handsomely for the privilege of cooking their own meal is, on the face of it, fairly brazen‚Äù, but the ‚Äúvividness‚Äù of the experience more than makes up for it.

And it‚Äôs not all ‚ÄúDIY‚Äù ‚Äì there‚Äôs other, pre-cooked nibbles too, like charcuterie and a pan con tomate that was ‚Äúgently world-rocking‚Ä¶ oil-glistened, chive-sprinkled and clean, fresh heaven with each crunching bite‚Äù.
‚ÄúWith some half beers and a couple of glasses of wine, the bill lurched up to almost ¬£140; high enough to register on my personal Richter scale of surprise expensiveness.‚Äù
Coal Drops Yard may seem ‚Äúlike a work in progress‚Äù but Parrillan ‚Äúhas arrived fully formed, burning with purpose and alluring, char-edged fun‚Äù. (9/10)

enjoyed people-watching and Chanel-handbag-spotting at the new brasserie at The Bruntsford; the hotel was taken over last year by InterContinental, but those four handbags (costing over ¬£3000 each) were ‚Äúproof that this place hasn‚Äôt lost its draw for the spangly folk of Glasgow‚Äù.

A substantial refurbishment hascreated a barisland as a‚Äúfocal point‚Ä¶upholstered in green fish scale tiles‚Äù (and promoted Gillian Matthews to being ‚ÄúScotland‚Äôs firstfemale five-star hotel executive chef‚Äù) .‚ÄùTables are pale marble,banquettes leather, the light-fittings look like art installations, and the unofficial dress code isPrada/Moschino/Gucci.‚Äù

Starting the evening with the signature cocktail, a ‚Äúratherspecial‚Äù gin-based concoction enhanced with an ‚Äúiridescent peacock feather pegged to the side of the glass‚Äù, Gaby embarked onto the ‚Äúbistro with a twist‚Äù cuisine.

Mains include ‚Äúupmarket takes on macaronicheese, steak, risotto or burger‚Äù but Gaby tried the St Bride‚Äôs chicken (with‚Äúthreestubs of herby gnocchi‚Äù) and an ‚Äúexciting‚Äù line-caught cod with‚Äúsome struts of char-lined leek‚Äù (‚Äúlovely‚Äù). A large side of¬†Shetland sea-buttered Jersey Royals
‚Äúgreased up and dotted witha confetti of dulse, like they‚Äôd tried to swim the Channel‚Äù. She finished with a saltedcaramel pudding that was ‚Äúmore than enough for two‚Äù.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still a hot destination for the Glasgow glamazons, though they will permit the occasional Edinburgh house sparrow.‚Äù (80%)

found The Woodsman to be ‚Äúa den of pleasure that gives gratuitous feasting a good name‚Äù; it‚Äôs a new ‚Äòhotel-adjunct‚Äô gastropub with ‚Äúwood panelling and beams, some of which date back to the 15th century‚Äù from ‚Äúoccasional TV chef and co-owner of a posh pub in London‚Äôs Fulham‚Äù, Mike Robinson.

Nothing was too much trouble for the staff; ‚Äúthey were all focused on the earnest endeavour of creating pleasure‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt find a single member of staff who didn‚Äôt smile, make us feel welcome and give us the impression that we had every right to be there‚Äù. Even the chefs ‚Äúlooked up, smiled and offered cheery greetings‚Äù when he peered into the kitchen.

The menu is ‚Äúfilled with words like fallow deer, muntjac, pigeon, seaweed, faggot and bone marrow‚Äù and the style is very much one where ‚Äúthe chefs push bits of animal into charcoal and wood-fired ovens‚Äù.

A ‚Äúmighty fine‚Äù charred leek‚Äù was followed by a T-bone of fallow deer that was ‚Äúunappealing-looking‚Äùbut ‚Äúquite the most beautiful piece of venison I have tried‚Äù‚Äì shame it wasn‚Äôt his dish. His own main of Hereford beef was ‚Äúperfectalong with some marrow bone topped with breadcrumbs and a lovely faggot‚Äù.
William has ‚Äúvowed to return for another dose of welcomes and charred flesh from this gastro-pleasuredome‚Äù ‚Äì and for his own plate of fallow deer. (****1/2)

in Port Isaac, Cornwall: ‚Äúfish cooking with finesse‚Äù, and lamented the loss of appetite for London‚Äôs traditional pie and mash shops, as the ‚Äúnew wave of wealthier professionals turn up their noses at traditional working-class staple‚Äù.

reviewed Manchester‚Äôs German-themed restaurant Albert‚Äôs Schloss where the ‚Äúwaiters aren‚Äôt wearing lederhosen and slapping each other‚Äôs thighs manfully, but they might as well be‚Äù‚Ä¶

‚ÄúIf you didn‚Äôt pay proper attention, you might dismiss¬†Albert‚Äôs Schloss¬†as Dante‚Äôs third circle of hell, only with less glamour.¬†The music is so loud it could dislodge a filling‚Ä¶¬†boy do they lay on the Germanic schtick. The waiters aren‚Äôt wearing lederhosen and slapping each other‚Äôs thighs manfully, but they might as well be.

‚ÄúAlbert‚Äôs Schloss is brilliant, and it‚Äôs not just the booze, or the blistering music from the Sunday Best Jazz quintet, or the 9ft 7in drag queen impersonating Joan Crawford. Although obviously all of those things helped.¬†They could have called up some dismal food service company, signed a contract based on massive volume and opened the delivery doors. The kitchen could have been nothing but the ping of microwaves and the fizz of the deep fat fryer. Instead they‚Äôve gone for it‚Ä¶¬†the menu is eclectic: a confit duck leg here, a bit of hummus there‚Ä¶¬†knock-offs of cronuts ‚Äì they‚Äôve put a K on it ‚Äì which are better than anything I‚Äôve tried from¬†Dominique Ansel.

‚ÄúCroquettes are made with ham and cheese‚Ä¶ crispy shelled, golden and pouting gusts of hot cheesy, piggy air at you as you bite in‚Ä¶¬†the best Schweinshaxe I‚Äôve had since the one with which I comforted myself in Munich 25 years ago, after having lunch with a neo-Nazi‚Ä¶ a long-roasted pork knuckle, with enough meat on it to serve two of me or three of you. It‚Äôs a monumental plateful.

‚ÄúA skin-on fillet of pearly hake gives its all to a heap of Proven√É¬ßal lentils.¬†It‚Äôs food to get you through a siege, in a good way.¬†Better, by which I mean it could stand comparison with anything coming out of Britain‚Äôs grandest kitchens, is their burnt Alaska. It is served at a perfect temperature so your spoon doesn‚Äôt hit a boulder when you get through the gorgeously singed meringue. Inside is soft raspberry sorbet, at the bottom a crisp base. Bravo.¬†I really should hate it. I should want to be anywhere but here. But I don‚Äôt. Albert‚Äôs Schloss is a class act.‚Äù

‚Äú[In January] I ¬≠prefer to shuffle off to a Great Local Restaurant ‚Äì the kind of near-mythological venue that welcomes you and¬†your slippers with open arms and an uncorked bottle of something¬†suitably soothing for under thirty quid‚Ä¶¬†at Llewelyn‚Äôs in Herne Hill, London SE24 ‚Äì at the end of a road that I happen to know houses at least two national newspaper restaurant critics‚Ä¶¬†blow me down ‚Ä¶walking past the ¬≠window ‚Ä¶ the esteemed writer and broadcaster Jay Rayner, who then enters the restaurant blowing air-kisses ‚Äì not to mention what passes for my cover.

‚ÄúLlewelyn‚Äôs is double-fronted and airy, all blonde wood and white walls and, on our visit, clearly a destination of choice for the daytime buggy-wielding brigade‚Ä¶¬†deep-fried squid and aioli delivered the three necessities ‚Äì springy squid, crunchy batter and a garlic sucker-punch ‚Äì entirely successfully‚Ä¶¬†tender and delightfully gamy braised rabbit with bacon, pumpkin mash and salmoriglio made for at least one very happy bunny‚Ä¶¬†each successive course ¬≠improved on its predecessor ‚Äì which happens rarely‚Äù ‚Äù I practically vacuumed up a sublime rice pudding with crab apple jelly‚Ä¶¬†one of the most pleasing quasi-suburban lunches I can recall.¬†In short, it was the perfect pick-me-up, carry-me-home and leave-me-on-the-sofa-until-February.‚Äù
heads to The Old Butchers in Stow-on-the-Wold,¬†Peter & Louise Robinson‚Äôs Cotswolds restaurant which espouses the¬†nose-to-tail ethos‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThe room is small, comfortable and unpretentious, the whole place infused with a mildly chaotic, genially higgledy-piggledy charm‚Ä¶¬†this is a restaurant where pleasure comes before prissy interior design, and the only commerce that really seems to matter is the serious business of eating.

‚ÄúWith a broadly European menu, lusty with seafood and steak, there is just the occasional jaunt across to Japan (tempura oysters) or the USA (crab roll)‚Ä¶¬†smoked haddock and Parmesan omelette‚Ä¶ as serious, rich and smoky as an Edwardian gent, lavished with great chunks of fish, and a centre that oozes with unapologetic delight‚Ä¶¬†raclette‚Ä¶ [a] puddle of slightly browned, melted cheese is attended by tiny potatoes, pert cornichons and slivers of air-dried ham. Just as it should be.

‚ÄúOx cheek bourguignon of pure bovine brilliance‚Ä¶ The sauce is deep and dark and glossy, furiously reduced and gloriously sticky‚Ä¶¬†testament to a kitchen that is capable of producing the most diaphanous of fritto mistos.¬†The service, as you‚Äôd expect, is lovely.¬†The Old Butchers is too good to keep to myself. It‚Äôs one of those rare local restaurants that combines charm, comfort, value and damned good cooking too. Plus, the bill arrives with a handful of pink foam prawns.‚Äù
‚ÄúParsons, London: a very English fish restaurant.¬†I surrendered to a brilliant confection that made me want to storm the kitchen and snog the beard off the pastry chef.‚Äù

Hidden-away inside Bond Street‚Äôs only hotel, a grand new dining room for an ex-Marcus Wareing chef of whom we suspect we‚Äôre going to be hearing a lot more; our lunchtime visit offered invariably high quality, and extraordinary overall value.

Half way up our grandest shopping thoroughfare, this hotel dining room certainly has a handy location. Not that you‚Äôd know it was there from external appearances. Perhaps why, when we visited for a midweek lunch in the second week of opening, it was at best sparsely occupied.

Undistracted by punters, we had plenty of opportunity to consider the d√©cor. Well, let‚Äôs just say that, though the place reeks of money, it‚Äôs been spent with more discretion than at the same hotel‚Äôs tart‚Äôs-boudoir-like number two restaurant, opened a few months ago, which trades under the name of The Gallery (of what, Bad Taste?). In short, this is a suitable setting for an emerging name who was until recently head chef at Marcus Wareing‚Äôs equally plush Knightsbridge joint.

The set lunch menu was presented almost apologetically, but surely few are the people who ‚Äì especially in the early days of a restaurant ‚Äì are particularly likely to want to embark on the full works? We certainly didn‚Äôt. Between us, however, we were able to sample the entire carte du jour.

Fish dishes seem a particular highlight. A starter of escabeche of gurnard, for example, was notable for the perfection of its timing, as was piece of hake presented on seaweed butter with grilled whelks and truffle. Presentation throughout was of a very high standard. And even the wine prices were not so high as to spoil the experience. Wareing, with his Lancastrian roots, famously has a gift for puddings, and that strength is echoed here in desserts both British (jelly, charmingly presented) and more classically French in style.

As it turned out, it would have been difficult to imagine an occasion when most people would want to lunch much more splendidly than we did for our ¬£24 a head! The set lunch here is an incredible bargain.

‚ÄúMackerel tartare with fresh mint and ajo blanco was a mixture of textures and tastes you might not expect to march in step with each other. But the slippery, coppery fish worked brilliantly with the velvety roughness and garlicky kick of the soup.‚Äù

Miller wasn‚Äôt so enamoured by the tartare ‚Äì he dubbed it ‚Äúless of a triumph‚Ä¶ a little bundle of raw chopped beef with slow-burning horseradish mayonnaise and crispy, violently salty shallots.‚Äù

He continued: ‚ÄúCourgettes came in a sort-of risotto with toothsome barley kernels, tomato and tapenade, which all played nicely together but tended to gang up on a timid scattering of shiso; chicken with Jersey Royals (just the two of them, as if we were living through some post-apocalyptic catastrophe of root vegetable cultivation, a Spud Event Horizon ‚Äì and who knows, perhaps we are), braised rainbow chard and a wild garlic pur√©e that had lost much its fresh-foraged zing in the cooking and tasted, we thought, of nettle soup.‚Äù
At least Miller found solace in the cheese: ‚ÄúCheese was a good, unfussy mixture of British and French‚Äù. And he noted too the lack of other dining options in the area.

‚ÄúThe eating-out options along West End Lane are dowdy and chainy: a Gourmet Burger Kitchen, a Rosa‚Äôs Thai, a Banana Tree. HƒÅm ought to do well in such a setting, and deserves to: even if the cooking‚Äôs not flawless, it‚Äôs done with verve and originality.‚Äù
He wrote: ‚ÄúMy ideal restaurant table is number 32, along the window of the Miramar restaurant in the Catalan resort of Llan√ß√†, just up the coast from its better-known neighbour, Cadaqu√©s.
‚ÄúThe restaurant is no more than 20 metres from the sea. In the distance stand the Albera mountains, the foothills of the Pyrenees.‚Äù

The locale was clearly impressive. It matched the Catalan cuisine: ‚ÄúMy wife went for a tartare of oysters topped with caviar and apple foam, a dish created in 2000, followed by tempered prawns with a morel stew. I opted for hake cheeks with asparagus and a pil-pil sauce, followed by a lobster rice dish with lobster roe and intriguing sounding ‚Äòmarine sprouts‚Äô.

Lander enjoyed the take on Caesar salad ‚Äì ‚Äúa crisp tube of thinnest¬†wafer, beautifully decorated and stuffed with herbs, which we consumed after spooning out a particularly well-seasoned iced lettuce soup from a lettuce-leaf-shaped egg cup‚Äù ‚Äì and the various types of pepper. Sorbets also got the nod, as did ‚Äúa cockle submerged under a heady Bloody Mary.‚Äù
The cooking, Lander explained, was complex and intriguing. Simplicity is in vogue ‚Äì but that doesn‚Äôt mean complication and sophistication has no place in today‚Äôs dining rooms.

‚ÄúMiramar‚Äôs menu and wine list open with a quote attributed to Steve Jobs: ‚ÄòSimplicity is the ultimate sophistication‚Äô. Yet, while the food and service at the Miramar are certainly sophisticated, they are far from simple.‚Äù

Dim sum is one of the most unique and entirely accessible experiences in food. The literal translation for dim sum is ‚Äòtouch your heart‚Äô ‚Äì a term chosen to describe the style which is suppose to be small, packaged, and dare I say ‚Äòbite-sized‚Äô to‚Ä¶

A smart and understated international-crowd Mayfair Italian, with some similarities to La Petite Maison (with which it shares a co-owner); it‚Äôs a high-quality operation all-round but, at least in the early days, we found it somewhat unengaging.

Mayfair these days is not for the likes of you and us (NFLYU). Sorry, that‚Äôs presumptuous. Perhaps you have a yacht? And a supercar which, in bored moments, you drive up and down South Audley Street? And as to your tax domicile? Well, who‚Äôs asking?

This new Italian restaurant is, technically speaking, not really in the NFLYU southern stretch of Audley Street. It‚Äôs on the wrong, northern, side of the social and financial chasm which is Grosvenor Square. (In the distance, you can see ‚Äì horrors! ‚Äì Oxford Street.)

The punters, though, still mostly give the impression of just having stepped off their yachts. (But, hey! This was during the Olympics: perhaps they had.) As Mr and Mrs Ordinary Englishpeople, we did feel a bit out of place. For the most part, though, the staff tried not to make us feel as if we Stood Out Horribly, and mainly succeeded. (The sole exception was one of the ma√É¬Ætre d‚Äô types who ‚Äì as he took our order ‚Äì found something much more interesting to concentrate on, on the other side of the room.)

The room itself ‚Äì not actually betraying many traces of the banca it formerly was ‚Äì has been done out in a comfortable, no-expense-spared sort of way which, entirely like the crowd, looked as if it belonged everywhere-and-nowhere. Unless hanging out with the rich is regarded as an end it itself, this is rather unsatisfying. You‚Äôre paying ‚Äòdestination‚Äô prices, yet there‚Äôs no feeling that you actually arrived anywhere. (Unless of course the establishment comes complete with a human zoo, like C London, say, and this place doesn‚Äôt.)

It would be satisfying to end by saying the cuisine here is comfort food of the banal type which the international rich seem to like, but that would unfortunately be entirely untrue. Indeed, a starter of peaches and lobster presented on a glass plate was one of the most unexpectedly beautiful and delicious dishes ‚Äì utterly satisfying in its simplicity of both presentation and taste ‚Äì that we‚Äôve had for a very long time. The two pasta dishes which we‚Äôd ordered (did we mention we felt poor?) were also very commendable. Pasta is often satisfying but rarely interesting ‚Äì these dishes were both.

And so the time came to join the ordinary people in places outside Mayfair. We paid the not inconsiderable bill (service charge added), and the credit card machine kindly gave us the opportunity to add a tip too. We‚Äôre not that stupid you know!

A relaunch, under unchanged ownership, of a dud former Shoreditch bar-restaurant (Beard to Tail, RIP) which looks set to become a handy all-day destination; our early-days visit was an all-round success, though the ‚Äònew look‚Äô may not fully be realised till Christmas.

Under unchanged ownership, but new management, the Shoreditch premises once known as Beard-to-Tail still look rather as they did when we reviewed that informal bar-restaurant a year ago, not especially kindly. (Occasionally, we get things right!)

This is still, it seems, a work-in-progress, and we were, on our visit, told that the woody (and, by night, rather glum-looking) rear dining room of the establishment would not be fully ‚Äòtransformed‚Äô till Christmas. Watch that space then!

Some of the important things, though, already seem to be going very much in the right direction: this struck us as a very handy sort of informal all-day restaurant‚Äô even if it still does have a bit of work to do to impress the locals. We lunched pretty much alone. The welcome is warm, and the food ‚Äì if not especially ambitious ‚Äì was in a different league from our former visit.

From the daytime menu ‚Äì essentially a cut-down selection from the evening offering ‚Äì we were able to try most of the types of dishes on offer. Tasty tomato bread, for example, made a good complement for a fresh-tasting assemblage of peas, beans and Feta-type cheese, and the brace of mini cheeseburgers were very decent too. Star of the show, though, was the tuna tataki ‚Äì a nicely balanced small (but quite generous) plate and, in accordance with the fashion du jour, attractively florally enhanced.
The drinks selection was inviting, and quite reasonably priced too. For lunch, a pint of Brooklyn ‚Äì what else, round here? ‚Äì made a very good accompaniment.

A couple of minutes walk from Borough Market, a very welcoming Indian restaurant, offering fairly standard fare consistently realised to a high standard; the only real downside is that it is rather noisy.

A business meeting took us ‚Äì late in the day, in restaurant-reviewing terms, as it opened in the spring of 2007 ‚Äì to this Indian restaurant, just round the corner from Borough Market. (Go out the Neal‚Äôs Yard Cheeses way.) The menu is fairly standard, but quite long, so we asked the charming waiting staff to choose. They promptly brought us a succession of dishes, all of which ‚Äì albeit in pretty ‚Äòstandard‚Äô style ‚Äì were very good.
For an informal business meeting, then, the venue was pretty much perfect. For schmoozing, or for an intimate t√™te-√É¬†-t√™te, it might be too hard-edged and noisy.

headed to Manchester to try out the latest jewel in Gary Usher‚Äôs crown. He wasn‚Äôt welcome, of course ‚Äì when Usher opened his very first restaurant, Sticky Walnut in Chester, he actively discouraged critics, saying it was ‚Äúa local bistro for local people‚Äù ‚Äì but Jay went anyway.

The group of restaurants, all individually named, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt serve ground-breaking food‚Äù anddon‚Äôt try ‚Äúleap boundaries, or draw attention‚Äù. Usher‚Äôs ‚Äúdeft cooking‚Äù provides‚Äúthe kind of classy, appealing food you‚Äôd like to eat repeatedly, and at areasonable price‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs not the journalistic hook Jay prefers, but he dealtwith it manfully.

Kala (Usher‚Äôs sixth restaurant) wascrowdfunded like three of his others, and broke ‚Äúthe world record for crowdfunding ¬£100,000 in just 11 hours‚Äù.It‚Äôs a ‚Äúfirst-floor space‚Äù with a ‚Äúpolishedconcrete floor‚Ä¶ emerald green banquettes‚Ä¶ shell- shaped wall lights‚Ä¶ an openkitchen‚Äù, staffed by ‚Äúinked and eager waiters‚Äù.

Jay ate a ‚Äúfaultless‚Äù,‚Äúpleasingly pink‚Äù chicken liver parfait and ‚Äúsnowy burrata‚Äù, followed bya ‚Äúrugged leg of crisp-skinned duck confit‚Äù served with ‚Äúa neon orange sweetpotato pur√©e‚Äù (‚Äúa root vegetable transformed into an act of kindness and care‚Äù)with touches that create ‚Äúa plateful which both makes sense, and is achinglypretty‚Äù.

He thought the ‚Äútorched‚Äù plaice was a little over-salted (‚ÄúI know, Gary, I know; bloody restaurant critics‚Äù) but had ‚Äúdeep, intense love for a side dish of charred little gem, sprinkled with deep-fried capers‚Äù and the ‚Äúsizeable chips which are really just superb roasties‚Äù. Pudding ‚Äúlaughs in the face of summer‚Äù with Yorkshire parkin and a passion fruit choux bun (‚Äúyou‚Äôre in Manchester and here, they take the sweet end seriously‚Äù).

mused that he‚Äôd ‚Äúnot fully appreciated that this connective strip of south-east London ‚Äî which takes in pizza‚Ä¶ Xinjiang cuisine‚Ä¶ and new-wave Nigerian ‚Äî is now so well stocked with varied, inexpensive places to eat as to be almost ridiculous‚Äù.

review of a few weeks ago, and was equally entranced, not just with the ‚Äúsneakily cool‚Äù ambience or the ‚Äúseductive origin story‚Äù but the whole package: it‚Äôs ‚Äúa restaurant of such vividness, heart and unassuming dexterity that I‚Äôm struggling to conceive of anyone stepping through its doors without falling in love‚Äù.

The food is a ‚Äúrollicking primer on theways Kurdish food pulls from neighbouring regions (Iran, Turkey, Syria) whilehonouring its own traditions of sour, multilayered flavour‚Äù, culminating in ameal that was a ‚Äúprolonged blur of torn bread hunks, messy forkfuls and indecentgroans of pleasure‚Äù.

also reported on an interview with Marco Pierre White published in the Irish Independent in which he stated that ‚Äúwomen are more emotional in the kitchen‚Äù. ¬†Neil Rankin (chef-owner of the Temper restaurants) took to Instagram to describe the comments as ‚Äúnauseating baseless antiquated bulls***‚Äù and called MPW a ‚Äúrambling dinosaur‚Äù. magazine. He chose his review targets using a map of the UK‚Äôs foodie sites of interest, which reminded him ‚Äúwhat a rich hunting ground Shropshire is‚Äù.

century‚Äù. The ‚Äúoverengineered‚Äù car park was the only thing he could find to complain about. Chef Lee Westcott (ex-Typing Room) makes ‚Äúfull use of the 1,200-acre estate‚Äù and ‚Äúgood-sized kitchen garden‚Ä¶ self-sufficiency can‚Äôt be a million miles away‚Äù.

After drinks and snacks (including a pig‚Äôs head croquette that was ‚Äúsweet piggy heaven‚Äù) on the terrace (with a ‚Äúbewitching view‚Äù), Tony embarked on dinner. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in set menu territory here‚Äù, sensibly priced at different levels during the week from ¬£27-¬£75. And ‚Äúall of it absolutely perfect and brought to the table with a mix of professionalism and charm‚Äù.

The next dayfound him at The Coach House in Norbury, an ‚Äúattractive inn‚Ä¶lightly Farrow andBalled but retaining its historical charm‚Äù, where yet more ‚Äúexcellentsourdough‚Äù heralded ‚Äúthe chef‚Äôs intent‚Äù. was not impressed with Arcade Food Theatre at Centre Point, no matter how many Instagram feeds it has featured on (she thinks they must have all attended the launch party and got food delivered to them on trays, for free).

Was it the result of a ‚Äúchaotic blue-sky-thinking meeting gone awry‚Äù? None of the stalls do drinks (apart from coffee), there‚Äôs almost no way of knowing when your food is ready (‚Äúthere is nothing as gauche or functional as a buzzer‚Äù here) and everything is ‚Äúpunchily priced‚Äù ‚Äì on her second visit (nothing was open at her first), Grace ‚Äúwhipped through around ¬£33 in about half an hour‚Äù. Tou‚Äôs Insta-famous pork katsu sando is ¬£14, and it‚Äôs more of a snack than a meal. (We‚Äôve seen it, it‚Äôs genuinely tiny; Marina O‚ÄôLoughlin in last week‚Äôs

Grace ate ‚Äúdelightful, definitely decadent‚Äù Black Sea pide from Oklava (¬£12), ‚ÄúLondon‚Äôs best almond croissant‚Äù and coffee from Pophams and the tofu and egg version of Tou‚Äôs sando, ‚Äúclearly someone, somewhere‚Äôs idea of a delicious sandwich, and I thoroughly respect that‚Äù (¬£10.50).

tried out the new-ish evening offering from Farmer J, the City and Canary Wharf mini-chain that has ‚Äúplenty of daytime fans already‚Äù ‚Äì especially ‚Äúgiven the desolation that is lunchtime for office workers most days‚Äù, it‚Äôs ‚Äúa welcome addition to life‚Äù with ‚Äúright-on-trend delivery of Mediterranean/Middle Eastern‚Äù food.

In the evening, this branch is called The Fancy Fork, and dishes out sharing plates from Galilee-raised chef Shuli Wimer, who spent half a decade at The River Caf√©. Although the bread was disappointing, dishes of stuffed zucchini flowers (‚Äúdelicious‚Äù), bone marrow toast (a ‚Äúcushy adaptation of the St John classic‚Äù with ‚Äúa big bone on the side made for glutinous, happy spooning‚Äù), chicken shwarma (‚Äúspicy and hot, just as this easy dish should be‚Äù) and squid freekeh ‚Äúrisotto‚Äù (‚Äúmore ambitious‚Ä¶ another successful tweaking of a more familiar dish‚Äù) were well received, but left no room, or enthusiasm, for dessert. (****)

handed out his latest four stars to Borough newcomer Flor, ‚Äúthe new place from the fellas behind Lyle‚Äôs, an East London restaurant of near-legendary allure‚Äù. It‚Äôs ‚Äúnot exactly breaking new ground‚Äù ‚Äì at this point, Tom lists all the places around the world where he‚Äôs seen the exact same ‚Äúopen kitchen and small plates, natural wines, bare brick walls and endless jars of pickles (home-made, of course)‚Äù concept, but Flor is ‚Äúa cut above the quasi-industrial norm‚Äù.

He lunched with a grumpy Sam Hart (more name-dropping); together theydined on ‚Äúpristine‚Äùrock oysters, red prawns (‚Äúa dish already spoken of in hushed tones bythe food illuminati‚Äù, which gained the Hart approval ‚Äì Barrafina being one ofthe first to serve them), and ‚Äúdeep brown and deeply flavoured‚Äùanchovies and lardo on toast, ‚Äúan inspired pairing, richly seductive, with themerest wink of filth‚Äù.

A ‚Äúdelicate‚Äùtomato tart (‚Äúmore classic, but no less wonderful‚Äù) was followed by lambribs, ‚Äúsoft nuggets of serious meat nestled among a charred mass of exceptionalfat‚Äù (‚Äúwe gnaw the bone clean‚Äù). Puddings included ‚Äúa sort of Mr Whippy madefrom ricotta‚Ä¶ smooth and exquisitely salty‚Äù and ‚Äúa hunk of beautifully keptComte‚Äù.

She and her companion enjoyed Tobermory smoked haddock (‚Äúcreamy, deep and rich, toasted and buttery on the top‚Äù) and ‚Äúcomforting‚Äù farfalle, followed by ‚Äúskinny and crispy chips‚Äù and raspberry chocolate cheesecake brownie, which gave the ‚Äúpleasingly palate squishing effect of doing a dental impression‚Äù.

Mayfair‚Äôs Wild Honey, from chef Anthony Demetre, was ‚Äúa narrow space with booths and a feeling of intimate conspiracy, fuelled by¬†French-inspired cuisine‚Äù for a decade until its closure a few years ago. Now it‚Äôs been reborn in a Sofitel, as is ‚Äúnot the Wild Honey we know and love‚Äù, says
‚ÄúIt didn‚Äôt feel anything like Wild Honey‚Ä¶ the ceilings are vast. Swirling lights on lines of metal hang from the ceiling‚Ä¶ and the menu itself is a magic-carpet ride across Europe.‚Äù

It‚Äôs fair to say William was not enamoured so far, but the food changed his mind; his dining companion Emily had an ‚Äúincredibly good‚Äù ‚ÄòAndalusian-style‚Äô gazpacho, while he tried the cacio e pepe, and was served the ‚Äúmost extraordinarily, bravely almost uncooked but just perfect macaroni‚Ä¶ a moreish dream. I could have eaten six times the amount on the plate‚Äù.

A deconstructed bouillabaisse followed, which was ‚ÄúDIY heaven‚Ä¶ the sum of theparts just gloriously epic‚Äù ‚Äì so much that he didn‚Äôt even want to taste Emily‚Äôs‚Äúfantastic‚Äù Cornish cod. (****)

Eat&Read is a weekly round-up of yummi-news from around london and the blogosphere, every Sunday. In the month of January, I ate at ten places in London, discovered a one man bossa nova jukebox, garnered 15000 page views and finally tasted ‚Äòthat‚Äô Great British pudding‚Ä¶

Our expectations on entering this new establishment behind Debenhams were frankly not very high. Its setting ‚Äì occupying a small block which is otherwise entirely a multi-story car park ‚Äì is about as uninviting as you‚Äôll find in the West End.

The site‚Äôs history is not particularly encouraging either. For nearly half a century, it‚Äôs been owned by members of the ‚ÄòSpaghetti House‚Äô family, and, in recent years, had traded as Vecchia Milano. After the recent re-launch, Milan is still the theme (‚ÄòBrera‚Äô being the name of the oldest part of that city). Now, however, the aim is a sort of discreet, contemporary chic previously foreign to the Spaghetti House group (or, indeed, to the related Getti establishments).

The low-lit interior is intriguing, with a single row of dining tables encircling an attractive, slightly sunken bar. Offering an extensive cocktail list, the bar aims to become a destination in its own right. We see potential tensions here. The Miami Beach hotel-lobby music playing the lunchtime we visited, for example, was rather at odds with a restaurant menu whose prices signify serious intent. As the bar fills up on a busy night, the conflict may become stark.

On an early-days lunchtime, however, with the bar empty, the main emphasis was on the food, which fortunately measured up to the prices. Leaving aside a nice-looking basket of home-made breads ‚Äì which disappointed on the taste front ‚Äì what was notable was consistent quality of both preparation and presentation of this rich cuisine, even if there was nothing you could call earth-shattering. Service was amiable and efficient too.
All in all then, a useful hide-away in an unlikely location. Be prepared to pay, though, and ‚Äì if visiting by night ‚Äì hope that the bar hasn‚Äôt become too much of a hit.

A press announcement arrives, proclaiming the virtues of a new chef at this South Kensington address, which, as Bistrot 190, was a thriving early-‚Äô90s scene. More recently, the place has faded from prominence, however, so we ventured along to see if the new man ‚Äì who has spent the past two years cooking for the trenderati at Soho House‚Äôs NYC outpost ‚Äì has injected a bit of pizzazz.

It turns out that this appears to be another of the false dawns to which this place seems periodically prone. That‚Äôs not to say the food is bad. A starter of scallops with braised peas was really quite good. But otherwise dishes varied from OK (a terrine and a risotto) to a total non-event (seared organic salmon salad). If you were staying in the adjoining hotel ‚Äì which would not be a bad choice, if you‚Äôre looking for a bit of OTT English style ‚Äì you‚Äôd not have much cause to complain. This is not food worth crossing town for, however.

The dining room itself is quite grand, and furnished in a bohemian country house style ‚Äì complete with large chandelier and mirrors ‚Äì that makes it a pleasant rarity in town. The ambience never quite ignites, though. Perhaps if they ditched the paper napkins, and stopped sorting the cutlery so noisily, it might start to approach its potential.

The best feature of this address is, mercifully, unaffected by the passing of the years. Before or after your meal, you can still enjoy a drink in one of the most characterful panelled cocktail bars in London. On this front, the PR-burble ‚Äì ‚Äòracy, raffish and oozing with intrigue‚Äô¬ù ‚Äì  really does seem to have it about right. The prominent Tory MP we bumped into certainly seemed to fit in very nicely.

A classic MPW-French operation decorated in subdued nightclubby style, rather unpromisingly located by the entrance to Chelsea FC; the style of the operation is arguably a little pass√©, but the food is of high quality.

London‚Äôs restaurants have come so far over the past 20 years ‚Äì and particularly the past 10 ‚Äì that the mere fact that a place offers good food doesn‚Äôt necessarily make it of particular interest. How else to explain why we found the latest addition to the Marco Pierre White empire to be both thoroughly competent and completely pointless?

But, first, let‚Äôs do the ‚Äòcompetent‚Äô bit: the cooking is generally very good. Highlights of a lunch included an unctuous crab bisque, a light and delicious kipper p√É¬¢t√©, a beautiful and generous piece of cod and some splendid rib-eye steak. Marco‚Äôs signature lemon tart was also well up to standard. Further to accentuate the positive, the restaurant is handsome and solidly furnished ‚Äì with that slightly sub-nightclub level of glitz the French often do well ‚Äì and service is friendly and tries hard.

And yet‚Äô The going here is going to be tough. This is, after all, a ‚Äògraveyard‚Äô site (two or three times in living memory). Unglamorously situated by the entrance to Chelsea FC, it benefits from significant pedestrian traffic on perhaps 20 days a year. The only natural source of ongoing walk-by business is the faceless adjoining hotel: presumably most people who stay there, however, are well aware that Chelsea proper is only five minutes away by cab.

If you were launching a restaurant on a site like that, you‚Äôd probably make darned sure that it had a Unique Selling Proposition ‚Äì some compelling reason to seek it out. If there is one here, however, it passed us by. It‚Äôs almost as if Marco hasn‚Äôt noticed that a lot‚Äôs happened in the restaurant world since he built up most of his empire in the ‚Äô90s.

The menu, for example, is high-class, generic, modern French. Even in a more obvious site, we wonder if that formula wouldn‚Äôt seem a bit pass√© in a city where the trends are ‚Äògrazing‚Äô, local sourcing and regionalism. It‚Äôs arguably a style that‚Äôs fine for business dining, but would anyone actively seek it out? And, if so, wouldn‚Äôt they be looking in Knightsbridge or Mayfair? Or Smithfield? And wouldn‚Äôt business diners expect a decent wine list? The one here verges on perfunctory.

So perhaps Marco‚Äôs got one eye to the locals? Well, the set lunch menu is exceptional value (2 courses for ¬£16.50), but weekday business is thin out West (even in Chelsea proper). The weekend could perhaps be a opportunity, but the affluent folk who live round here often have kids. The carte, however, is mainly not child-suitable ‚Äì oddly, as the place is named after one of his children ‚Äì and no thought has been given to a kids‚Äô menu or portions.

It was early days on our Saturday lunchtime visit, but the attendance rather bore out our concerns. Precisely three tables were occupied: one by the great man himself, one by us, and the last by another restaurant critic. There were, in short, no ‚Äòreal‚Äô people there at all. It looks like it will need a lot of very positive reviews to drive enough traffic to make this place a success.

Forza Wine, London SE15 Jimi Famuwera for The Evening Standard encourages readers to ignore any ‚Äúsniffiness‚Äù they might feel about Forza Wine, on the fifth floor of ‚Äúa shiny new multi-level co-working complex that looms above Rye Lane‚Äù; yes, it [‚Ä¶]
is always ‚Äúquestioning the entire point of modern haute cuisine‚Äù ‚Äì especially lengthy tasting menus ‚Äúoften done badly: too pompous, too many petals, too few carbs, not a lot of laughs‚Äù.

This week she had to eat her words alongside the 10-course tasting menu (‚Äúno shortcuts‚Äù) from Xier (‚Äúupstairs at chef Carlo Scotto‚Äôs new dual project‚Äù), which was packed with ‚ÄúBritish produce being cooked by an Italian who‚Äôs clearly influenced by Japanese flavours‚Äù.

The room is ‚Äúsingular, spacious yet intimate and rather romantic‚Äù;‚Äúa lot like how I hope heaven willbe; a sort of tasteful, pale VIP room, away from the riff-raff, with a nookfull of vintage cognacs‚Äù.

Comparison with the Ledbury was almostinevitable: ‚ÄúXier has all theplates spinning at once. It‚Äôs surprising and challenging, but you‚Äôre still atthe reins‚Äù. Combine that with ‚Äúsome of the greatest, magical front-of-house service in London right now‚Äùand you‚Äôre onto a winner.

A red prawn crudo was ‚Äúuplifted‚Ä¶ with teases of raspberry, red caviar and yuzu‚Äù while the arancino on ‚Äúa sticky, compelling kohlrabi jus‚Äù was ‚Äúorgasmic‚Äù. Her favourite course was ‚Äúa rich bianchetto truffle risotto deftly laced with sumac‚Äù.

‚ÄúI want eternity to be somewhere where‚Ä¶ when it‚Äôs time, stafftriumphantly appear with not one, not two, but five separate desserts,contrasting but complementing each other.‚Äù (She mentions the baba twice)

), he visited Matt Healey‚Äôs new place at The Foundry, also in Leeds, where he encountered ‚Äúa precision engineered number, sliced so that every angle is at 90 degrees, bronzed in all the right places and filled with the punchy, paunchy umami of blue cheese and caramelised onions‚Äù that accompanied steak tartare ‚Äútopped with the sunshine promise of an egg yolk‚Äù.

in 2016‚Äù; his restaurant is all ‚Äúraw brick,concrete floors, filament light bulbs and nowness‚Äù, and the food is ‚Äúacollection of well-trodden paths, walked with precision and care, and all at anextremely good price‚Äù.

There‚Äôssharing platters and nibbles, small plates, main courses and (‚Äúthe most cheffymoments‚Äù) desserts ‚Äì ‚Äúa proposition that can work in many ways‚Äù.
