‚Äù before he finally visited ‚Äì and then when he did go, ‚Äúit took me all of 30 seconds to fall in love‚Ä¶ to a hopeless, obsessional degree,‚Äù with its ‚Äútwinkly, contagious magic‚Äù.

Co-founded by Charlie Boxer (‚Äúson of cookery writer Arabella, dad of new-wave culinary princes Jackson and Frank‚Äù), Italo has maintained its ‚Äúdishevelled uniqueness‚Äù for over a decade, and seen many now-famous faces at the stoves. The current chefs produced food that ‚Äúpossessed a kind of Rochelle Canteen-grade, European simplicity‚Äù; Jimi detected ‚Äúan unwavering core philosophy of delivering hearty, affordable pleasure‚Äù.

Ordering almost everything on the menu, Jimi and his friend indulgedin ‚Äúbalanced and bright‚Äù confitgarlic and burratina on toast, ‚Äúgently gamey‚Äù orecchiette in spiced rabbit raguand then ‚Äúduelled over proper grown-up scoops of La Grotta grappa and damsonice cream‚Äù.

The ‚Äúcramped, pasta-piled shop interior‚Äù only has a few inside seats, so you‚Äôre best to head there on a sunny day, or take away: ‚Äúyou‚Äôd have to acknowledge that Italo‚Äôs appeal dwindles sharply in bad weather‚Äù. (9/10)

was hesitant to visit Bath (‚Äúnever top of my cities for playing gastrotourist in‚Äù) without a seriously good reason. (Mind you, as she quite rightly pointed out ‚Äúmy esteemed predecessor trolled the whole of Wales, so as far as creating outrage, I‚Äôve still got training wheels on‚Äù.)

So when she received not one, but two, hot tips for Bath, she took the opportunity to fill a column without having to resort to too many paragraphs about the ‚Äúfull Palladian beauty of the place‚Äù. She also took a young friend from ‚Äúculinary upstart‚Äù Bristol, and quoted his snarky comments throughout (the best being ‚ÄúAll the shops should be called Buns & Fudge‚Äù).

Eight, her first stop, was a ‚Äútiny, thoroughly upholstered dining room in an equally tiny boutique hotel of ancient uneven floors and wonky staircase‚Äù, serving eight seasonal not-quite-small plates (it also has eight rooms, do you see what they did there?). The concept ‚Äúsucceeds in muddling me‚Äù ‚Äì do you have two plates (too much) or just one (not enough)? Her first dish, a ‚Äúhefty‚Äù courgette number, was ‚Äúso try-hard, haute vegetarian that it makes me want to gnaw on a T-bone in protest‚Äù left no room (or willpower) for the ‚Äúexcellent slab of hake on a black squid-ink risotto‚Äù.

Noya‚Äôs Kitchen, on the other hand, was ‚Äúto be celebrated‚Äù ‚Äì a supper club turned caf√© and cookery school, everything here had ‚Äúthe pleasing, hand-knitted quality of a talented Vietnamese home cook‚Äù. Starters in particular were ‚Äúa joy‚Äù (although mains were ‚Äúless endearing‚Äù); all ‚Äúfresh and vibrant and done with love‚Äù.

The roomwas ‚Äúcaptivating‚Äù, with its ‚Äúdark blue walls, floral wallpaper and sepia familyphotos‚Äù, staff ‚Äúcouldn‚Äôt be lovelier‚Äù and ‚Äì especially for this city ‚Äì it‚Äôs ‚Äúterrificallywell priced‚Äù.

tried out the dining space at The Mandrake ‚Äì what was Serge et Le Phoque (RIP) has become Yopo. Telegraph readers should firmly ignore the ‚Äúweird and sexy art‚Äù in the doorway (as well as the fact that Yopo is named after a South American hallucinogen).
Inside, there‚Äôs a ‚Äúmenuof fantastic inventiveness delivered with authentically enthusiastic service‚Äù;this is fusion, not confusion, food ‚Äì ‚Äúa new and beautiful order‚Äù.

Oysters were served ‚Äúsurroundedby not ice but champagne granita‚Äù, sourdough toasts with anchovies were‚Äúachingly, beautifully, naughtilymoreish bites of salty paradise‚Äù and duck with quince and braised endivewas ‚Äúharmonious‚Äù.

The design is loosely jungle-themed; ‚Äúthe whole place feels a bit like anAmazonian trip‚Äù (the toilets are a ‚Äúsort of Indiana Jones temple of mystery‚Äù,and just as hard to find). William found Yopo delightfully ‚Äúwacky‚Äù: they ‚Äúwilltake you by the hand and lead you on a path of enlightened discovery‚Äù. (****1/2)

once again beat everyone to a hot new opening; this one, from chef Richard Wilkins in the ‚Äúdiminutive‚Äù spot that was formerly Marianne (RIP, although the ‚ÄúFarrow & Ballsy decor‚Äù lives on) opened completely under the radar. She was tipped off by Zeren Wilson, sommelier and writer of the

‚ÄúScrupulous buying‚Äù was ‚Äúevidenced throughout‚Äù their meal from the ¬£55 set menu, with ‚Äúuplifting‚Äù wines. A scallop ceviche starter came with sides ‚Äúin pale green shades of spring‚Äù and the dessert of Chocolate moelleux with passion fruit sorbet was ‚Äúa shiny dark log of pure contentment‚Äù. Only the roast lamb failed to inspire, although the side dish of Ratte potatoes Grenobloise with the cod was ‚Äúthe star of the assembly‚Äù.

A second visit with her late husband Reg‚Äôs daughter (who liked the ‚ÄúAlice in Wonderland room‚Äù) saw them dine alone (not surprising given the lack of publicity), from a similar menu (sadly it‚Äôs the duck this time that isn‚Äôt quite right) but with equally ‚Äúheavenly‚Äù desserts. (***)

just loves the hipster food movement ‚Äì although he once derided it for being all ‚Äúqueues, beards, tats, mateyness, drinks in jam jars and a general sense of the staff having a better time than the diners‚Äù. He now embraces it, loves ‚Äúthe loud music and shocking acoustics‚Äù, loves ‚Äúthe short menu and sharing principle‚Äù, admires all of ‚Äúthe home curing, drying, pickling, baking and fermenting‚Äù and firmly respects the ‚Äúresponsible sourcing, wines by the glass, recycling and waste management, inclusive hiring‚Ä¶ urban regeneration‚Äù.

review of Gloria, has a thing to say about older diners; Giles is now almost 50, and is no longer one of those diners ‚Äúwho want mad new shit to blow their minds‚Äù ‚Äì he‚Äôd rather have ‚Äúa bit of peace and quiet, a nice glass of something, a smackerel and somewhere soft to rest‚Äù. And there‚Äôs not many new places opening that cater to those needs these days.

Until now: Jackson Boxer ‚Äúsexpot hipster king of east London, whose polished concrete and fire-food‚Ä¶ St Leonards, is right at the epicentre of all that is good and new‚Äù has opened up Orasay in west London, of all places. It‚Äôs a ‚Äúclassic, old-fashioned, small‚Ä¶ restaurant‚Äù ‚Äì but it‚Äôs also a bit different‚Äù. Yes, it‚Äôs ‚Äúwell lit and cosy‚Äù, the chairs are ‚Äúsoft and comfy‚Äù, staff are ‚Äúgentle and friendly‚Äù and the food is ‚Äúmodest and humble and mostly very good‚Äù, but it‚Äôs also ‚Äúhipsterish enough to feel relevant (but nothing to scare the horses)‚Äù. In ‚ÄúPortobello it feels new and relevant and youthful and British and thus almost revolutionary‚Äù.

Gilestook his mum along, and was clearly so relieved to find somewhere she likedthat he waxed lyrical about ‚Äúthe northward creep of spring through Europe‚Ä¶represented on London restaurant plates‚Äù (or as he said, ‚Äúfoodwank‚Äù).

Grilled fish dishes were ‚Äúdelicious and spring-feeling‚Äù, his pasta dish ‚Äúless thrilling‚Äù; there‚Äôs some serious meat on the menu, too, and even the ‚Äúexotic east London specialty known as roast cauliflower‚Äù.
Orasay is ‚Äúyoung and new and lovely‚Äù ‚Äì let‚Äôs ‚Äúhope the well-heeled multilingual locals in their sparkly mansions and expensive shoes speak enough basic hipster to understand it‚Äù. (21/30)

has been busy on our behalf, with two reviews published this week. Her first trip was to Kent farm and restaurant The Small Holding; a ‚Äúpleasingly ambitious little‚Äù place in the ‚ÄúA21‚Äôs Britcheese/Britfizz Corridor‚Äù offering ‚Äúfield-to-forky‚Äù fare in a range of tasting menus.

‚ÄúHaiku-lite minimalist menu descriptions were compensated forby smiley Will Devlin‚Ä¶ chefsplaining everything tableside.‚Äù ‚ÄúFlavours and textures (notably ‚ÄúBroccoli,Blue Cheese, Yeast‚Äù and ‚ÄúPork, Onion, Mustard‚Äù) were pleasing without pushingthe envelope.‚Äù A local cheese course made Kathryn very happy.

was a visit to Gloria, the Shoreditch newcomer which ‚Äúlooks as though it‚Äôs been sitting comfortably on the cornerof Great Eastern Street‚Ä¶ since about 1968‚Äù; it‚Äôs a ‚Äústunningly staged backdrop‚Äù thatpays homage to London‚Äôs first trattoria, Spaghetti House on Goodge Street.

Despite being (and feeling) ‚Äúdemographically at least two decades outside Gloria‚Äôs customer comfort zone,‚Äù Kathryn and her lunch companion India Knight demolished their starters; mains, named with ‚Äúfaux-naff playfulness‚Äù were also ‚Äúvery good without in any way being intrusive‚Äù ‚Äì the ‚Äô10 level lasagne‚Äô was both ‚Äúdensely delicious‚Äù and so ‚Äúsubstantial‚Äù that she took half home in a doggy bag.
‚ÄúIn modish, binary fashion, Gloria turns out to be not onlythe perfect place in which to embrace 2019, but also to escape it.‚Äù

Any other critic posting a steak review containing the word ‚Äúsublime‚Äù and phrases ‚Äúabsolute consistency‚Äù, ‚Äúgentle carnivorous worship‚Äù and ‚Äúnever lets you down‚Äù would be doling out top scores to match. Not so
, who served up yet another four-star review to Hawksmoor‚Äôs Air Street branch (they‚Äôve been open since 2006 in Spitalfields, so he‚Äôs not even reviewing anywhere new, he just fancied a steak).

As is usual with a TPB review, especially a meaty one, therewas plenty of ‚Äúkick and honk‚Äù and ‚Äúdeep bovine base notes‚Äù. He enjoyedhis steak (actually a ‚Äúa vast 120g slab of Chateaubriand‚Äù), but thefish there is excellent too (‚Äúthe turbot is a thing of piscine beauty‚Äù) and his beeffries were ‚Äúa touch undercooked‚Äù. (****)
visited the deliciously named Cheese Lounge, at the back if IJ Mellis‚Äô Morningside cheese shop (he‚Äôs run the business or over 25 years and now has five stores across Scotland)

The ‚Äúwhiffof le fromage‚Äù hits you instantly as you enter, but ‚Äúyou could be in a bar in rural France‚Äù onceyou‚Äôve passed through the glass door. Within the ‚Äúbijou room‚Äù, she sampled aveggie Scotch egg (‚Äúlayered treasure‚Äù) with Cashel Blue, ‚Äúspot on‚Äù French onionsoup, roasted feta (‚Äúsoftly yielding and‚Ä¶ delicious. This is a dish that Iwould return for.‚Äù) and finished with ‚Äúa flaky, buttery delight‚Äù of a pastel denata.
‚Äú‚Ä¶the retro romantic strikes back.¬†Though new, or newish‚Ä¶ La Cave is a full-blown specimen of the Retro-Romantic French Bistro.
‚Äú‚Ä¶the traditions being honoured aren‚Äôt maybe those of Escoffier and Brillat-Savarin so much as those of Sixties and Seventies Britain.

‚Äú‚Ä¶almost sitcom-worthy form of duck √† l‚Äôorange.¬†Puddings were slight simplifications or distillations of retro archtypes‚Ä¶cooked with precision, confidence and minimal fuss; and served with warmth and charm.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe smoked cod‚Äôs roe starter was whipped up light and piped in thick cylinders along fingers of toast. This is one of the hidden delights of the Brat menu.
‚ÄúIf you ever need to lose hours of your life, dive down the rabbit-hole of toast-fancying on the internet, where people with time on their hands obsess about toast in its infinite variety.

‚ÄúThese zealous loons agree on little save that toast made in front of a real fire is the real deal. It is this magical product, a scorched shell encasing steamed crumb and redolent of the smoky hearth, on which the primped pink roe reclines like a sated odalisque on a fauteuil. No‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâseriously ‚Äî this is some bomb-ass eggs on toast.‚Äù

always heads to Ondine, and its ‚Äúpitch-perfect seafood‚Äù; you can imagine how delighted he was to discover a sibling restaurant, ‚Äúa collaboration between Ondine chef Roy Brett and his long-time suppliers¬†Welch Fishmongers,‚Äù on the docks at Newhaven.

At Fishmarket there‚Äôs a ‚Äúclassic metal takeaway counter‚Äùwith ‚Äúa simple dining room‚Äù beyond, ‚Äúwalls tiled in jade greenand white‚Äù. No ‚Äúview down the Royal Mile here,‚Äù just the ‚Äúglitterand ripple of the harbour waters at night‚Äù.

The takeaway does ‚Äústandard chippy‚Äù fare, but in thedining room, ‚Äúthe menu is more expansive,‚Äù but it‚Äôs ‚Äúnotquite Ondine in trainers‚Äù. The prices are ‚Äútoo punchy for that, butthen the good stuff still costs‚Äù.

Crab claws made for a ‚Äúsatisfying plateful‚Äù; langoustine and ‚Äúspoon-coatingly thick‚Äù smoked haddock chowder followed: ‚Äúthis is butch farmhouse cooking, pursued with acute attention to detail‚Äù. It all ‚Äúbears the fat thumbprints of Ondine‚Ä¶ seafood cookery of the first order, executed by a kitchen which understands that timing is everything‚Äù.

And then the fish and chips arrived, and things turned ‚Äúabit weird‚Äù: ‚Äúbecause the Fishmarket is the love child of OndineI want to dribble and rave and cheer. But I can‚Äôt‚Äù. The fish was‚Äújust fine‚Äù (‚Äúgiven the lineage and the price, you need to beable to‚Ä¶ leap to your feet and applaud‚Äù) and the chips were‚Äúpale and uninteresting‚Ä¶ just disappointment, fashioned from dry matter‚Äù.They were ‚Äúa promise, broken. If you‚Äôre going to eat chips, you need tofeel that the calories are worth it‚Äù.

Greatdesserts almost saved the day, but couldn‚Äôt erase the memory of those chips.Fishmarket ‚Äúweirdly misfired on the most important bit. If it‚Äôs possible fora restaurant to be both hugely enjoyable and utterly baffling all at once, thenthis really is the place.‚Äù

felt ‚Äúintrigued admiration‚Äù for Xier and XR before he visited ‚Äì in this climate ‚Äúit feels as though it is difficult to open one restaurant, let alone two‚Äù (especially with a name that sounds like a ‚Äúprovincial escape room‚Äù).

Jimi tried the ‚Äúmore casual, modern European XR‚Äùrather than the ¬£90+ ‚Äútaster menu-only,¬†Michelinstar-baiting Xier‚Äù upstairs; his midweek lunch was ‚Äúcapablebut only briefly spectacular‚Äù, and his ‚Äúlasting impression was ofimaginative cooking shackled somewhat by a compromised, overly finicky set-up‚Äù.

‚ÄúTerrific‚Äù sourdough and oddly Nordiccanapes started the meal, followed by ‚Äúoozy, unctuous‚Äù enokimushroom and truffle arancini, mains that were ‚Äúnot bad necessarily. Justa bit of a slog‚Äù and ‚Äúan amazing corpse-reviver of a coffee ice cream‚Äù.

Naples-born head chef Carlo Scotto describes Xier as‚Äúthe story of his travels from Naples to Scandinavia and Japan‚Äù‚Äì Jimi imagines that ‚Äúthis upstairs chef‚Äôs table represents a purermanifestation of Scotto‚Äôs vision‚Äù, while XR ‚Äúfeelsauthentically personal but hazily rendered‚Äù. (6/10)

is looking for answers. She stayed at Mollie‚Äôs hotel while reviewing restaurants across the Cotswolds, and stopped in at the diner three times. Despite it being ‚Äúall a bit weird‚Äù ‚Äì there was ‚Äù literally nothing‚Äù to do apart from visit the BP garage ‚Äì she‚Äôd stay again. ‚ÄúThe biggest customer gripe I noted‚Ä¶ was that it‚Äôs so popular, it is almost impossible to get in.‚Äù

‚ÄúMollie‚Äôs is a cool blast of fresh air‚Äù for regular travellers, families and locals alike; the menu is ‚Äúthoughtful, modern and slightly glamorous, and the food decent‚Äù. The ‚Äúbartender will make you a very good old fashioned or even an espresso martini,‚Äù too (good enough that you won‚Äôt notice you‚Äôre sitting in the lobby).
Her meals at Mollie‚Äôs included a buttermilk chicken sandwichwith chipotle mayo that was ‚Äúhot, fresh and alluring‚Äù and‚Äúwaffles‚Ä¶ the sweetest, crispest and freshest I have ever tasted‚Äù.
It‚Äôs ‚Äúa riddle wrapped in a mystery inside a soft, sweet burger bun‚Äù on ‚Äúthe road to nowhere‚Äù. But it‚Äôs by Nick Jones, and ‚Äúthere is clearly a method in this madness‚Äù. (23/30)

was ‚Äúdarkly cheerful‚Äù at The Fife Arms, a luxury Cairngorms hotel that‚Äôs been bought and gothically refurbished by ‚Äúsuper-gallerists‚Äù Hauser & Wirth. ‚ÄúFrom outside, the hotel may look like the typical Victorian pile‚Äù ‚Äì inside, it‚Äôs ‚Äúpossessed of an altogether more subversive agenda‚Äù.

Picasso and Lucien Freud artworks decorate the walls, a drawingroom ‚Äúceiling is painted in loud, dreamlike swirls by Zhang Enli‚Äù,‚Äústairwells sprout taxidermy‚Äù and ‚Äúin the back garden looms aBourgeois spider‚Äù.

The food in The Clunie Dining Room was ‚Äúquite odd too‚Äù; there were ‚ÄúScottish-isms on the menu, as you‚Äôd expect‚Äù but ‚Äúthe chef has clearly travelled beyond the Highland confines and is going all nouveau-northern: fermented kohlrabi, celeriac pur√©e and shaved raw cauliflower with the langoustines, poor things‚Äù. One deer dish is ‚Äúa curious mash-up between Neapolitan ragu and Sunday roast‚Äù ‚Äì Marina detected ‚Äúlittle care whether individual ingredients sing to each other or just squabble‚Ä¶ ¬†Perhaps it‚Äôs art‚Äù?

It doesn‚Äôt help that the food was ‚Äúprobably the least interesting thing about the Clunie Dining Room‚Äù ‚Äì there‚Äôs a whole stuffed stag watching you eat, a mesmeric hand-painted mural painted on the walls with a ‚Äúvast original Brueghel‚Äù.

clearly wishes he was still in New York, so much so that instead of moaning about Midtown NYC restaurants, he created an entire article around the fact that he‚Äôd never head of the Midtown minker for London‚Äôs Holborn/Bloomsbury area (‚Äúthe concrete basin between the City and the West End‚Äù).

Giles was ‚Äúwowed by the huge bright space and the views and all the light and colour‚Äù of VIVI, at Centre Point (in Midtown), but didn‚Äôt enjoy the ‚Äù retrospective menu‚Ä¶ dishes were not only visibly drawn from the old days but were every bit as nasty as they used to be, too‚Äù.¬† ‚ÄúTerrific wine list, though.‚Äù (6/10)

He didn‚Äôt fare any better at Baptist Grill: ‚Äúit‚Äôs not nice‚Ä¶ loud 1980s disco music from the bar downstairs,‚Äù with lighting ‚Äútoo dark to let you see the menu‚Äù and ‚Äúlittle green cheese and onion macarons served up unbidden that taste like wet sugary Pringles‚Äù made for a bad start. He described the cuisine as ‚Äúthat style of fancy things concocted on paper by an offsite executive chef‚Ä¶ just phoning this one in‚Äù. ‚ÄúFancified starters‚Ä¶were a waste of time,‚Äù and the English veal T-bone ‚Äúhad a sweet fillet but was tough as a boxer‚Äôs elbow on the sirloin side‚Äù. With no wine, there was not much change from ¬£200 for two ‚Äì and far too much ‚Äúflapdoodle‚Äù. (6/10)

Luckily for his mood, Midtown also boasts Master Wei, where ‚Äúthe wonderful Guirong Wei‚Äù and her husband serve ‚Äúindescribably perfect little plates of Chinese food‚Äù. He‚Äôs a huge fan of their other place, X‚Äôian Impression (‚ÄúI‚Äôve never taken anyone there or written about it. It‚Äôs cheap, quick, unlicensed and far, far too good to share.‚Äù)

Here, there‚Äôs also alcohol to help wash down the ‚Äúexcellent pot stickers‚Ä¶ sour and spicy pork dumplings in soup, or those wide, seemingly endless belt noodles Xinjiang-style‚Äù. Master Wei has a ‚Äúfun and local feel‚Äù with ‚Äúrelaxed and jolly‚Äù staff and food that‚Äôs ‚Äúas fresh, homemade and refreshingly different as ever‚Äù.
after a few weeks away with a review of the refurbished, refreshed and re-opened Momo (and a few mentions of all the famous people she was with).

The ‚Äúnewly beauteous space‚Äù has been ‚Äúdesigned as an idealised glittering oasis‚Äù, the staff are ‚Äústill attractively laid-back and keen to serve‚Äù, and there‚Äôs also a new menu (Mourad Mazouz has brought over Herv√© Deville, the head chef from his ‚Äòother place‚Äô, Sketch) in which the ‚ÄúNorth African inspiration is honoured‚Äù with ‚Äúcohesion and an awareness of tradition that comes as a blessing and relief in the current flourishing of culinary gobbledegook‚Äù.

Starting perfectly with harira, the ‚Äúhauntingly spiced lamb andlentil broth‚Äù Fay‚Äôs meal included ‚Äúclassic Momo couscous‚Ä¶ pale,feathery, seductive, a basic elevated to a high level of sophistication‚Äùand a lamb tagine to ‚Äúrevel‚Äù in. (****)

was at Beaverbrook, ‚Äúa hotel that nestles in 470 acres of beautiful Surrey countryside,‚Äù a little confused by the homely decor of the Japanese grill restaurant (until he found out it‚Äôs also where breakfast is served). This made it already ‚Äúa few chopsticks short of authentic‚Äù in his mind ‚Äì which only ‚Äúput more pressure on the food‚Äù.

The hotel, named for former owner Lord Beaverbrook, has had an ‚Äúexquisite facelift‚Äù to the tune of some ¬£90million. Overall, William decided that the food did not match the lavish surroundings in more than one way ‚Äì it was just ‚Äúnot good enough‚Äù; ‚Äòyellowtail tiradito‚Äô was served with a ‚Äúdistracting yuzu foam‚Äù (‚Äúa beautiful piece of fish covered in washing-up lather‚Äù) while his monkfish was just ‚Äúfeatureless bits of fish hidden in slimy mushrooms‚Äù and the sashimi selection ‚Äúwas not as good as a respectable local lunchtime sushi bar‚Ä¶ memorable only for how many you had to get through‚Äù.

A few nice dishes aside, the meal was mostly rescued by former Annabel‚Äôs sommelier Giovanni Tallu (‚Äúa more charming, entertaining and helpful sommelier you will be hard-pressed to find‚Äù) who ‚Äúdelicately, nimbly, unobtrusively, wisely‚Ä¶ brought us a fabulous selection of wine and sake‚Äù. (***)
visited The High Dive for ‚Äúfull flavour pizza and maximal decor‚Äù. Formerly The Maltings pub, ‚Äúthis place has changed an awful lot‚Äù and is now run by the team behind Edinburgh‚Äôs Civerinos.

It sounds like a sensory overload, from the interior design that‚Äôs ‚Äúthe antithesis of the pared back pale wood aesthetic‚Äù to the pizza ‚Äòpies‚Äô with ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù toppings (‚Äúif the bases are a canvas, think magical realism, rather than a boring still life of flowers in a vase‚Äù).
Her ‚Äúsloppy and satisfying‚Äù pizza was accompanied by a ‚Äúmassive portion‚Äù of cheesy fries, and washed down with an equally huge portion of hot zeppole doughnuts.
doled out another four-star rating to The Royal Oak, a Cotswolds pub now run by Richard and Solanche Craven, previously at The Chef‚Äôs Dozen in Chipping Campden.

TPB included The Royal Oak in his Christmas 2018 round-up of top pubs, so he‚Äôs clearly been before. Maybe he couldn‚Äôt bothered to research somewhere new? We‚Äôd be happy to offer up a few suggestions. (Amusingly, he used the phrase ‚Äúhopeless sense of d√©j√† vu‚Äù in this article, referring not to The Royal Oak, but to most gastropub food ‚Äì and unwittingly also his reviewing style?)

Starters ranged from ‚Äúlusty farmyard fat‚Äù to ‚ÄúNordic purity‚Äù: a ‚Äúmasterclass in simplicity and restraint‚Äù. Main courses had flavours that were ‚Äúbig and bold‚Äù ‚Äì pig‚Äôs head and black pudding lasagne was ‚Äúa symphony of softness‚Äù with a ‚Äúsharply sweet cider reduction‚Ä¶ a discreet, elegant, beautifully thought-out dish‚Äù ‚Äì and side dishes added ‚Äústellar support‚Äù.
, Tim Hayward was at Credo in Trondheim, ‚Äúa cathedral to hospitality‚Ä¶ at no point does any course ‚Äî and there are 20 ‚Äî drop below exceptional‚Äù.

reported on the opening of south American BBQ specialists Low and Slow and also Woky Ko in Bristol‚Äôs ‚Äúiconic‚Äù foodie St Nicholas Market. Woky Ko (which already has three outlets in the city) replaces the troubled Grillstock (RIP), and will serve up robata sticks as well as other Asian fare.

reported on the sad closure of Leeds veggie Indian stalwart, Hansa‚Äôs: Hansa and Kishor Dabhi ‚Äúare retiring after 33 years at the helm of what is thought to be the city‚Äôs longest running independent Indian restaurant‚Äù. After closing the restaurant with a party, they ‚Äúare looking forward to a night out of their own‚Äù. Fans should note that they ‚Äúcan still have a taste of Hansa‚Äôs cuisine as she will continue with her cookery schools as her retirement activity‚Äù.

, which was soundly praised for its ‚ÄòPie Sundays, ‚Äúdedicated to the deliciousness that is pie‚Äù, its ‚Äúvery welcoming and attentive host‚Äù, ‚Äúheavenly‚Äù aligot (cheesy, herby mash), ‚Äúamazing gravy‚Äù and ‚Äúone of the best pies I‚Äôve ever eaten‚Äù, all topped off with great desserts and a ‚Äúcharming, cosy and pleasant‚Äù atmosphere.

Harden‚Äôs weekly update of where the critics are eating, recommending and avoiding, for the week ending 25 August 2019. The Yan, Lake District Grace Dent for The Guardian loves the Lake District, and visits a lot, but is constantly ‚Äúin search of a big, reasonably priced and, above all, welcoming place to take normal folk‚Äù [‚Ä¶]
Review of the reviews: Jay Rayner finds a ‚Äòweird‚Äô menu in Devon, while Nicholas Lander travels to Catalonia for the Financial Times

A rollercoaster week for our intrepid reviewers: bad starts (including a hellish brush with Bicester Village for Tom Parker Bowles), off-kilter locations and misfiring menus. ¬† Jay Rayner in The Observer experienced the ‚Äútroubled adolescence‚Äù of newly-opened, crowdfunded Thomas Carr Seafood & Grill in Ilfracombe, Devon. His initial impression left little to hope for, with [‚Ä¶]

Jay Rayner in The Observer¬†is the latest critic to fall in love with Tomos Parry‚Äôs food at Brat. The place itself is perhaps to achingly Shoreditch, but the cooking is utterly lovely‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúShow cooking may be tough, but trickier still is the seemingly effortless; the edible equivalent of, say,¬†Anthony Hopkins‚Äôs performance in¬†TheRemains of the Day‚Ä¶. Rusk & Rusk, the Glasgow-based restaurant team behind¬†The Butchershop Bar & Grill, Hutchesons City Grill, and The Spanish Butcher, have announced its latest venture: ‚ÄòSo L.A.‚Äô Situated in the city centre, Rusk & Rusk said the new all-day venue is ‚Äúinspired by the vibrancy and diversity of the West Coast‚Äôs drinking and dining scene.‚Äù It [‚Ä¶]
Review of the reviews: Jay Rayner finds a ‚Äòweird‚Äô menu in Devon, while Nicholas Lander travels to Catalonia for the Financial Times

A rollercoaster week for our intrepid reviewers: bad starts (including a hellish brush with Bicester Village for Tom Parker Bowles), off-kilter locations and misfiring menus. ¬† Jay Rayner in The Observer experienced the ‚Äútroubled adolescence‚Äù of newly-opened, crowdfunded Thomas Carr Seafood & Grill in Ilfracombe, Devon. His initial impression left little to hope for, with [‚Ä¶]

Situated in the city centre, Rusk & Rusk said the new all-day venue is ‚Äúinspired by the vibrancy and diversity of the West Coast‚Äôs drinking and dining scene.‚Äù It will, the group said, be the first of its kind to land in Scotland. That much is certain.

With an ‚Äúurban walkway, sweeping charcoal leather booths, and neon-rimmed light backdrops‚Äù the design sounds ‚Äúso London S.E.1‚Äù.¬† There will also be a concrete-topped bar, antique mirrors, and an indoor garden.

In the press release, co-owner Louise Rusk said: ‚ÄúWe are incredibly excited to open the doors to So L.A. and cannot wait to welcome the first of our guests over the coming days.¬†We are deeply committed to bringing the best, progressive cuisine‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúCalifornia has always been a real pioneer when it comes to the culinary arts ‚Äî from its extraordinary use of fresh produce to its rich and moody neon-lined interiors,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúSo L.A. is a new concept that channels all of this and pushes the boundaries of our current offering, and we‚Äôre incredibly excited that it‚Äôs finally here.‚Äù
But wait. We‚Äôve tracked down some menu details. Signature dishes include a Szechuan duck doughnut, sauteed chickpea panisse, and miso glazed beef fillet.

is a lobster and crayfish roll with celery mayo, a ‚Äòsmashed‚Äô lamb burger, tuna tataki, BBQ octopus, boneless chicken wing tacos with peanut salsa and celeriac (on the left), Togareshi oysters, and something called ramen noodle mac ‚Äòn‚Äô cheese.
Cocktails will be centred on tequila though will be just as adventurous and globetrotting as the culinary remixes, dining continues up to 1am at the weekend, and there will, of course, be brunch.

Our reviews are based on an annual survey of ordinary diners which runs in Spring each year. But this establishment has not yet gathered enough feedback for our editors to write it up.

Write a quick review now using our restaurant diary service. That way it might catch our attention. Next survey, you can transfer your diary entry into our survey system. Everyone who contributes 5 or more reviews in our survey will qualify for a free guide.
For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.

A relaunch, under unchanged ownership, of a dud former Shoreditch bar-restaurant (Beard to Tail, RIP) which looks set to become a handy all-day destination; our early-days visit was an all-round success, though the new look may not fully be realised till Christmas.

Under unchanged ownership, but new management, the Shoreditch premises once known as Beard-to-Tail still look rather as they did when we reviewed that informal bar-restaurant a year ago, not especially kindly. (Occasionally, we get things right!)

This is still, it seems, a work-in-progress, and we were, on our visit, told that the woody (and, by night, rather glum-looking) rear dining room of the establishment would not be fully transformed till Christmas. Watch that space then!

Some of the important things, though, already seem to be going very much in the right direction: this struck us as a very handy sort of informal all-day restaurant even if it still does have a bit of work to do to impress the locals. We lunched pretty much alone. The welcome is warm, and the food - if not especially ambitious - was in a different league from our former visit.

From the daytime menu - essentially a cut-down selection from the evening offering - we were able to try most of the types of dishes on offer. Tasty tomato bread, for example, made a good complement for a fresh-tasting assemblage of peas, beans and Feta-type cheese, and the brace of mini cheeseburgers were very decent too. Star of the show, though, was the tuna tataki - a nicely balanced small (but quite generous) plate and, in accordance with the fashion du jour, attractively florally enhanced.
The drinks selection was inviting, and quite reasonably priced too. For lunch, a pint of Brooklyn - what else, round here? - made a very good accompaniment.

With the Scottish independence referendum imminent, who knows what the future may hold? Perhaps the next time we travel to visit our northern neighbours we will need to go armed with passports? Edinburgh is a particular highlight for those who love eating out, being the best-provided dining conurbation outside the Smoke. So just in case [‚Ä¶]

Another slice of Americana is set to hit our shores in the form of US pizza chain, Project Pie. And where has this company chosen to plant its first European restaurant? Why Dundee of course! But Project Pie isn‚Äôt stopping there, Scottish domination is on the agenda with five more sites planned over the next [‚Ä¶]

(a pub conversion that, despite being a holder of one of the tyre mens‚Äô stars, garners mixed reviews from our survey) and
‚Äì the Leith fixture that‚Äôs ‚Äùconsistently near perfection‚Äù; with its ‚Äúwonderful‚Äù dishes and ‚Äúfirst-class‚Äù but ‚Äúunobtrusive‚Äù service.

Kohli has collaborated on the menu for VDeep with head chef Ruairidh Skinner (who formerly headed up the kitchen at The Vintage), serving up a fusion of British and classic curry dishes like: Bangras & mash, cauliflower cheese curry and pork cheek vindaloo. The offers a range of ten craft keg beers and three craft cask beers, including the limited-edition Vindabrew ‚Äì a cardamom-infused IPA.

The group, which also has emerging pizza powerhouse Franco Manco in its armoury, has been defying a tricky and widespread downturn in the casual dining sector, joining the likes of Dishoom and Rosa‚Äôs Thai in pursuing expansion despite a troubled market.
will launch in Bridgemaster‚Äôs House, Propel first reported, and follows two other new restaurants in Covent Garden this year.
Elsewhere, Fulham Shore opened its 50th Franco Manca branch last week. The Edinburgh site is the first of many more, Harden‚Äôs understands. Northern cities are on the hit list.

This new restaurant and private member‚Äôs bar has been likened to ‚Äúa gothic Claridges‚Äù. But aside from a quirky line in animal skulls (which make up a chandelier, wall lights, and just sit around on the bar), its airy d√©cor fits firmly into the vaguely Manhattanite style that‚Äôs so familiar in the area. With its dark wood floors, steel pillars, and chocolate brown just about everything else, it‚Äôs classic Shoreditch.

On my visit, the jovial barman was sporting a frilled ‚Äúbuccaneer‚Äù shirt. With his flowing locks, he looked a bit like a survivor from an early ‚Äô80s heavy metal band and added some much-needed raffish charm to what at lunch is still a pretty dead scene. At night-time, he told me, things are becoming much more happening (and on cue as he said this, someone poked their head round the door to nab a table for twelve at 9pm).

The lunch menu is longer than the evening one, and classic modern British stuff. It didn‚Äôt put a foot wrong. Cauliflower soup was just the job for a cold day, and the slightly unusual addition of shrimps made a successful contribution to it. The preparation of a main dish of tuna (so often poor) was well judged, and its Japanese-y accompaniments which included seaweed, soy sauce and clean-out-your-sinuses wasabi were convincingly realised. Pudding was good, if not earth shattering: a combination of poached pears and chocolate goo (I‚Äôm sure it wasn‚Äôt called that).

It‚Äôs no criticism of this good addition to the area that (though tempted to award four stars) we felt that to break our recent run of three-star awards might risk over-egging it. For a ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô city lunch or a funky evening hang out, this seems a useful alternative to the nearby Great Eastern Dining Rooms.

Here we go once again. This month, the famous Ms Marmite Lover finally enters the fray, Lizzie Mabbot dethrones Chris Pople to go top and the highest climber is The Graphic Foodie to number 13, up by 12. Congratulations to all. Isn‚Äôt it more exciting watching the list change leaders now that the all powerful WOM (it is still all powerful, and no list is going to change that right?) has vacated the top spot?
Tweets that mention London Eater ‚Äì London food blog and restaurant reviews and restaurant guide ¬ª Wikio Gastronomy Rankings Preview July 2010 -- Topsy.com
That‚Äôs kind of weird. I wrote to them recently asking why my blog was number 950 in the rankings and a couple of weeks later it‚Äôs in the top 20? Something a bit nefarious about this‚Ä¶

I wrote to them because to be frank, I found it odd that my blog was so low down in the rankings and much lesser known blogs were in the top 20. My other blog The English Can Eat was something like number 5,500!!!
Ultimately it‚Äôs all rubbish. You write and photograph and tell your stories because you want to, you have something to say‚Ä¶

msMarmitelover ‚Äì Yeah I‚Äôm not entirely sure how it works to be quite honest. I am led to believe that in addition to counting the feasible beans‚Ä¶there are also ‚Äòmagic numbers‚Äô which Wikio uses in their algorithms to determine the rankings. Although to be fair, all ranking methods are abit wonky anyway as they can vary widely depending on which they view carries more/less weight. Like for example Compete.com , Alexa and even Google‚Äôs own PageRank algorithms all vary differently.

Yeah, ultimately this is all for jokes really, I suppose people write because they have an opinion to voice, but also I think more importantly, that they feel they have something of value to add to the public domain.

From the leading Muscovite restaurateur, a very large pan-Asian dining room that looks set to become a popular Mayfair destination, perhaps mainly for business; the smoothness of the operation on our early-days visit was impressive.

If a success, this 400-seat Mayfair newcomer could quite possibly end up biggest-grossing restaurant in London. Comprising large dining rooms both Italian and Asian and an enormous basement bar, it‚Äôs roughly a third bigger than the D&D (‚ÄòConran‚Äô) group‚Äôs Quaglino‚Äôs or Ramsay‚Äôs Bread Street, which are as big as quality London restaurants currently get.

The Conran comparison is particularly apposite, as Arkady Novikov is the Sir Terence Conran of Moscow, just much bigger. Claiming 50 restaurants in the Russian capital, his empire is at least twice the size of D&D‚Äôs. That‚Äôs the sort of success that buys you toys such as Gianni Versace‚Äôs former house on Lake Como, as well as a handy townhouse in Knightsbridge.

The new restaurant occupies a site where others have tried and failed, so the obvious question is: is Mayfair going to be Mr Novikov‚Äôs Waterloo? Initial impressions are indeed that the Italian restaurant feels like a bit of a ballroom ‚Äì how is that going to work in a city where upmarket Italians are invariably on an intimate scale? The panelled basement bar, however, is a great space, which we suspect will become a popular rendezvous; let‚Äôs hope it doesn‚Äôt end up ALL Russians and their striking nieces.

But our mission that day was to check out the on-your-way-in Asian restaurant. With its unadorned dark wood tables, and the glazed-in kitchen visible in the distance, it has a somewhat Identikit quality about it ‚Äì not unpleasant, but not a particular attraction in its own right either. Pretty much ideal, then, for the sort of informal business lunching which had already drawn quite a good crowd by the time of our early-days visit.

Service was notably on the ball. Perhaps Jamie and Gordon ‚Äì home town boys both nominally responsible for major-early-days-service-fiascos in recent times ‚Äì could learn a bit from the guys from Moscow?

The real surprise, however, was the food ‚Äì which was, with one exception, consistently impressive. The quality comes as more a shock, because a pan-Asian menu ‚Äì by definition ‚Äì lacks any sort of coherency. From a reviewing point of view, that makes it curiously easy, as you just have to order one of everything ‚Äì sushi, skewers, dim sum, barbecue. All of the above were just very good, with the surprise highlight being a dish of truffled duck. The only dish that didn‚Äôt quite live up to its price tag (¬£45!) was some tempura lobster ‚Äì not bad, just not really worth the expense. Otherwise, the prices seemed pretty reasonable. For Mayfair.

Last week The Times‚Äôs Giles Coren was drooling over his keyboard at the very thought of another meal at Brad McDonald‚Äôs new Deep South-influenced Soho haunt Shotgun. This week his colleague AA Gill over at the Sunday Times takes said shotgun and fires both barrels at the place in his Table Talk column‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúThe first [‚Ä¶]

Claiming to be London‚Äôs most eco-friendly restaurant, a pioneering, if obscurely located, Shoreditch brasserie with a nice atmosphere and pleasant, informed service; on our visit, though, the cooking was in undoubted need of tightening up.

The team behind Acorn House, and now this Shoreditch newcomer, have a mission, and a laudable one too. They aim to demonstrate that restaurants don‚Äôt have to be the energy guzzling monsters too many of them are (and also that eco-sensitivity is not inimical to creating restaurants which will keep the punters coming back).

Either they‚Äôre mad, or they‚Äôre on to something.  Tending to support the former view, the place was empty on our Monday lunchtime visit. Tending to support the latter, it had apparently been full for much of the weekend. Either way, we learnt on our visit that a site for venture number three has already been identified.

In a grungy bit of Shoreditch, it must be credit to the power of the press (though early reviews have been mixed) that this place ever has any customers at all. The idea of surfing the Zeitgeist obviously appeals, in this part of town at least.

So what do these surfers find? A harmonious modern bistro, nicely lit and comfortable, with linen napkins but no tablecloths. A canal-view too, of sorts. A friendly place, where everyone is very pleased to be involved in creating a better world. It‚Äôs even, √É¬† la Fifteen, something of a training-restaurant too.

With all these other virtues, it would perhaps be a surprise if the food were particularly remarkable, and we would have to record that ours was not. Nothing was unpleasant, but many dishes had a slight feeling of something missing. Bread was unremarkable. Starters of soups and antipasti didn‚Äôt quite make the grade.  A risotto wasn‚Äôt quite right, and a dish of lamb and roast potatoes lacked taste. Towards the end, however, things picked up. A foodie guest raved about the ice cream, and the chocolate tart with it really did melt (in the very best way), and the espresso was excellent.
This is, we suspect, a place which really shines at brunch, in which, we understand, they are already doing very good business.

will return for the fourth year in a row to raise money for the restaurant industry‚Äôs charity of choice, Action Against Hunger. This time around the event will be held at the new Street Feast venue Hawker House in Canada Water where top chefs will cook up street food style dishes.

Tickets to this year‚Äôs event go on sale at 11 am on 17 March and are ¬£60, which includes¬†entry to the event, six dishes from the menu before 8 pm (and free for all after!), pint-sized cocktails from the Hawker House bars, and even more¬†drinks from¬†Wondering Wine Co,¬†Kamm & Sons¬†and¬†Sipsmith Gin.¬†All proceeds from ticket sales go directly to the charity.

Some of Britain‚Äôs best chefs including Francesco Mazzei¬†(Sartoria), Hamish Brown (ROKA), Jack Stein (The Seafood Restaurant), James Lowe (Lyle‚Äôs), Jos√© Pizarro (Pizarro Restaurant), Lee Tiernan (Black Axe Mangal), Neil Rankin (The Smokehouse), Nieves Barrag√É¬°n-Mohacho¬†(Barrafina), Nuno Mendes (Chiltern Firehouse), Robin Gill¬†(The Dairy),¬†and Shaun Searley¬†(Quality Chop House) come together with the capital‚Äôs most talented street food traders including B.O.B.‚Äôs Lobster, Born & Raised, Breddos, Rola Wala, Smokestak, and Yum Bun.

Over the past four years, Auction Against Hunger has raised over ¬£320,000 to help support Action Against Hunger‚Äôs work saving the lives of malnourished children and providing families with access to safe water and good nutrition.

visited Hot Manchester Newcomer Tast Cuina Catalana, one of the ‚Äù¬†delicate, thoughtful, educational places‚Äù that is aiming to bring a true taste of Spain to Britain. It‚Äôs ‚Äúforward-reaching‚Äù, ‚Äúhigh-end, imaginative, occasionally edgy‚Äù ‚Äì and huge: there‚Äôs three ‚Äúcapacious‚Äù floors to fill, each offering a different level of formality and adventurousness. Will it work?

One way to get the punters in, is, of course, Instagram bait. Here, in the ‚Äòpinya‚Äô (small bites) level on the ground floor, they are serving ‚ÄòDuck‚Äôin Donut‚Äô, ‚Äúa small doughnut filled with foie gras mousse, dipped lightly in white chocolate and dusted with vivid powdered raspberry. It costs ¬£3.80 and tastes like a satanic Quality Street‚Äù.

Red pepper croquetas from the same menu are ‚Äúfantastic: fluffy, crunchy and with heavenly, sweet innards‚Ä¶ a true work of art‚Äù. But not all of the dishes work ‚Äì after almost an hour of eating, Tast feels ‚Äúdainty and somewhat muted‚Äù. Redemption comes with the desserts; ‚Äúwhere glory lies‚Äù, mostly in custard-and-pastry form.
Grace‚Äôs summary of Tast is that it‚Äôs ‚Äúimportant, uncompromising, at times lost in translation and possibly not all that much fun‚Äù. (22/30)

magazine spends at least half of his review bemoaning an experience in √éle de R√©, where he turned up too late to get a table, and his celebrity status failed to help him ‚Äì but all the (English, Times reading) customers knew who he was and chortled merrily at his distress.

Back home, licking his wounds, he ventured to ‚Äúunexpectedly fashionable‚Äù Stoke Newington and Perilla, and was delighted to find that it was ‚Äúclose to home, elegant, casual and beyond excellent‚Äù. The first two courses on the tasting menu ‚Äúfair blew me away‚Äù with their beauty, soul and vision: ‚ÄòYesterday‚Äôs bread soaked in moules marini√®re‚Äô tasted ‚Äúlike the perfect last bite of all shellfish suppers‚Äù.

‚ÄúIt sounds simple, almost dull, but it so, so wasn‚Äôt‚Äù ‚Äì service has a ‚Äúsaucy twinkle‚Äù and the whole experience was ‚Äúknowingly, almost comically instagrammable‚Äù. In fact, he hails it as ‚Äúright up there‚Äù with the ‚Äúburning stars in the new London restaurant firmament‚Äù. (26/30)
restaurant critic‚Äù visited The River Cafe in order to establish ‚Äúa bedrock for my future forays into London‚Äôs freshest culinary ventures‚Äù. Whatever the excuse, he

Famous for over thirty years now, since its origins as a staff canteen, The River Cafe was filled on his visit with folk ‚Äúfor whom a lavish, Britpop-era lunch was still a viable reality‚Äù. There remains ‚Äúmore than a hint of Nineties boom to the insane prices, with mains mostly clocking in above ¬£40‚Äù.

But ‚Äúa fair bit of scepticism dissolved‚Äù during a shared starter, and evaporated with half-portions of pasta, mains and dessert : ‚Äúsome bucket-list places truly live up to the hype‚Äù. ‚ÄúHere is a place that can still teach you things about simplicity, care and beautiful ingredients singing in perfect, full-throated harmony‚Äù. (8/10)
awarded a rare five stars to her two meals at Coal Office, the new ‚Äúnew Israeli‚Äù in Coal Drops Yard, London‚Äôs latest foodie mecca near King‚Äôs Cross.

Despite being unable to find the place (‚Äúsignposting in the area is crap or, to be more precise non-existent‚Äù), Fay was delighted from the start by friendly front-of-house staff: ‚Äúan atmosphere of camaraderie among chefs, waiting staff and customers that is tangible yet seemingly unforced‚Äù.
The food (‚Äúsmall, in-between and big plates‚Ä¶ ranging in price from ¬£8 to ¬£23‚Äù) includes dishes from chef-patron Assaf Granit‚Äôs Jerusalem restaurant Machneyuda.
Why five stars? Because two visits ‚Äúdelivered what can be only be described as the untrammelled joy of enlightening, healthy eating out not undermined by a depressing bill‚Äù. (*****)

investigates the ‚Äúextravagantly named‚Äù Xi‚Äôan Biang Biang Noodles in Spitalfields, part of the ‚Äúglorious flowering in the variety of Chinese food available in Britain‚Äôs cities‚Äù as a result of the opening up of China.

This spot serves the noodle-based cuisine of northwestern China, apart from a few Cantonese dishes that are an ‚ÄúEssex tan shade of orange‚Ä¶ specifically targeted at people who don‚Äôt really want to be here‚Äù. But for those who do ‚Äì including our esteemed critic ‚Äì the dishes are ‚Äúa brilliant slap around the chops‚Äù with chilli and fire and heat. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a nine-napkin job.‚Äù

This ‚Äúnoisy, fighty food‚Äù is served in a ‚Äúbig, brightly lit canteen‚Äù that‚Äôs perfect for crowds or solo diners like him (‚ÄúI always think better of restaurants where people feel comfortable eating alone.‚Äù). Cold dishes are an ‚Äúalarm clock for the tongue‚Äù, to be followed by ‚Äúabsurdly satisfying‚Äù noodles and ‚Äúluscious and compelling‚Äù hot dishes including a chicken broth that‚Äôs ‚Äúyour mum‚Äôs hug in a bowl‚Äù.

Xi‚Äôan Biang Biang is ‚Äúa utilitarian, great value enterprise posited on high-volume trade‚Äù with ‚Äúuncompromising punch‚Äù in the cooking. Jay had been asked to consult on the future of Chinese restaurants in London, and was reassured by his visit here.

recommends a visit to Loughborough pub The Hammer & Pincers for the grazing menu ‚Äì itself recommended to him by a reader . Many more hits than misses, especially the pig‚Äôs cheek croquette (‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù) and with ‚Äúno fewer than three puddings‚Äù, including a peanut butter cheesecake that was a ‚Äútotal joy‚Äù.¬† (****1/2)

visited The Kitchen in an area of Falmouth ‚Äúthat‚Äôs visibly blistering in the white heat of culture-led regeneration‚Äù. His lunch, from a ‚Äúmaddeningly vague‚Äù, ‚Äúveg-led‚Äù menu, ‚Äútrod a tightrope between messy youthful exuberance and grown-up bourgeois- bohemianism‚Äù.

He‚Äôd heard that The Kitchen was ‚Äúa tiny, quirky, shabby-chic, low-waste, no-menu, ¬≠ultra-locavore‚Äù, and nothing about his experience suggests that it was bad (in fact many elements were ‚Äúsuperb‚Äù), although he was decidedly snarky about the decor, the presentation and the menu. Maybe taking a teenager along (his 13-year-old daughter) wasn‚Äôt the best idea‚Ä¶ (****)

review of Jamie‚Äôs Italian at Westfield Stratford starts off badly, with her wanting to ‚Äúswear and kick something‚Äù just looking at the menu, with its ‚Äúham-fisted translation‚Ä¶ solecisms ‚Äî pesto made with almonds? ‚ÄúItalian nachos‚Äù? ¬†‚Ä¶ and a rash of adjectives‚Äù.

She‚Äôd ‚Äúliked the chain when it first launched, fresh and feisty, like its owner‚Äù. But a Twitterstorm of violent reaction from her followers when she reported of Oliver‚Äôs ‚Äòheroic‚Äô rescue of the failing chain sent her in investigative mode to the branch in east London. ‚ÄúKettled by our lugubrious server into the only bit that‚Äôs occupied‚Äù, she noted vast empty spaces beyond and upstairs.

Starters were ‚Äúnot bad‚Äù and ‚Äúfine‚Äù, but mains were ‚Äúappalling‚Äù ‚Äì even a special (she just has to try ‚ÄòNonna Marina‚Äôs Salina chicken‚Äô) was ‚Äúdismal‚Äù. Customers¬† are ‚Äúled to expect more from Jamie‚Äôs name‚Äù than lovely loos and an ‚Äúexpensive fit-out‚Äù: ‚ÄúI am, of course, being paid to eat here. You‚Äôd have to pay me quite a lot to come back.‚Äù

had nothing but praise for Brigadiers. The decor is ‚Äúexquisitely and expensively wrought, an Indian Art Deco delight of polished marble, lacquered wood and unashamed opulence‚Äù and the food has ‚Äútrue culinary integrity but a sly sense of fun‚Äù ‚Äì not surprising for JKS Restaurants, who ‚Äúcreate restaurants that never cease to delight‚Äù.

Starters (‚Äúthe quintessence of the Friday night curry made posh‚Äù) and mains, fresh from teh fire, are ‚Äúbeautifully blackened¬†‚Äú. ‚ÄúForget pink gin and punkah wallahs ‚Äì this place is modern to its core‚Ä¶ What could have been a braying, overblown City booze hole turns out to be yet another jewel in the JKS crown.‚Äù (****)

reported on our London Restaurant Awards, which were attended several reporters, including Fay Maschler who accompanied her sister, Beth Coventry, whose Wells Tavern was nominated for Best Pub or Bar.
visited Gjelina, in California‚Äôs Venice Beach, California: ‚Äúit‚Äôs muscular dude-food meets healthy eating, with an Italian accent‚Äù.

Comfortably decorated in style imitating the coffee bars of the ‚Äòswinging Sixties‚Äô, this Little India basement restaurant offers food that‚Äôs perfectly acceptable, but not obviously better than at many neighbouring establishments.

The Noon family has a bit of a name for its curries (available in supermarkets everywhere). So far as we know, however, this is the family‚Äôs first stab at an actual curry house. The eponymous Zeenat Harnal is ‚Äòthe daughter‚Äô of the family.

This is a smart and professionally turned out basement operation, whose rather late-60s orange-themed d√©cor nods elegantly to the period when these streets to the west of Euston station first became known for inexpensive Indian restaurants (especially of the veggie variety). Staff were pleasant too, and trying hard. Prices are not demanding.

The food, however, consistently failed to excite. And not just on the palate. Our lunch companion was one of those obsessives who photographs dishes, and we particularly couldn‚Äôt help noting that our array of starters ‚Äì veggie fritters, and a soft shell crab ‚Äì made a totally unrelieved symphony in brown. Not much of a picture, you might say.
For the main courses, a whole poussin maintained the sepia theme, so the odd glimmer of colour in evidence on the vegetarian platter ‚Äì also a main dish option ‚Äì was especially welcome.

This last plate turned out to be the highlight of the meal. Even here, though, those dazzling moments when texture and spicing can come together ‚Äì allowing the best Indian cuisine to transcend its often-humble ingredients ‚Äì were notable mainly by their absence.

This is the second of two Continental-style steak-houses to open in Marylebone in recent months. Both offer essentially the same fixed menu ‚Äì salad, steak ‚Äòn‚Äô chips ‚Äì and both make a big deal of their respective secret sauces. The first to open (Relais de Venise) was praised in this column, but has subsequently been slated by most other critics. If popularity is anything to go by, however, the punters are with us.

Part of de Venise‚Äôs success is no doubt due to the fact that it is an authentic ‚Äì and so far one-off ‚Äì replica of the Parisian original, and comes complete with a good dose of joie de vivre. This newcomer, however ‚Äì an offshoot of an outfit from Geneva, and with outlets in Lisbon and Dubai ‚Äì just seems like an authentic replica of uninspired restaurants everywhere. If they didn‚Äôt just inherit the interior here, the person who designed it ‚Äì in a style 20 years out of date ‚Äì should be shot.

The food does little to raise the spirits. The salad ‚Äì marginally better than at de Venise ‚Äì lost its advantage by being served up with dull bread. Steak/frites were a pretty much total disappointment. It does not help that your dinner plate arrives with the chips already on board ‚Äì a school-diners style of service that has no place in even the humblest bistro. That special sauce ‚Äì which had separated ‚Äì seemed to add little to a pretty pallid bit of beef. If you try this place, we‚Äôd certainly recommend a good dose of Dijon to spice it up. A cr√®me br√ªl√©e was pleasant enough, but we left our coffee undrunk.
Service ‚Äì presided over by a man with a wonderfully lugubrious moustache ‚Äì is something of a saving grace. Whether it will be a sufficient saving grace, however, we somehow doubt.

Unchanged from the days when it was called De Cecco, this long-running Italian is now even more appropriately named, serving up an above-average ‚Äòlocal‚Äô formula to the lucky inhabitants of Parson‚Äôs Green.

The change of name of the establishment long called De Cecco drew us back to this Parson‚Äôs Green Italian, which was established over two decades ago. It turns out that we‚Äôd been drawn on false pretences: there is no change of r√©gime. It‚Äôs just that the Italian pasta company of the same name finally noted that their branding had, in their view, been appropriated. Needless to say, they didn‚Äôt take it as the compliment no doubt intended.

The restaurant management decided that the line of least resistance was therefore simply to change the name. If a place has enough of a local following to have lasted as long as De Cecco, it seems to us that the name probably doesn‚Äôt matter much anyway.

Anyway, our visit this wasn‚Äôt a ‚Äòfull inspection‚Äô (whatever that means), just lunch with a mate. Your critic‚Äôs meal kicked off with a well-made bloody Mary, followed by a satisfying plate of risotto liberally garnished with lobster and king prawn, and a bite of light cheesecake. Companion had spaghetti al vongole which inspired much praise,as did the cheesecake. Bread and coffee were pretty good too. All in all, a meal that was ‚Äòfit for purpose‚Äô, and more.

Claiming to be ‚ÄòLondon‚Äôs first Bollywood restaurant‚Äô, this Covent Garden newcomer occupies the ground floor above a glamorous pan-Asian basement called Tamarai (reviewed here a month or two ago).

Sitaaray feels as if it has had to make do with what was left of the building‚Äôs floorplan after the other occupants ‚Äì not least the New London Theatre ‚Äì had been taken care of. The best has been made of the small space, however, not least by inserting a couple of small mezzanines. These would be quite suited to romance, were it not for the fact they appear to have been earmarked for parties (of up to a dozen). The very red decorative style contributes to a feeling just the right side of claustrophobic, and a scattering of small TV screens showing Indian movies support the theme without being intrusive.

Can you hear the alarm bells ringing? Theatreland location and ‚Äòtheme‚Äô are not generally a whiz-bang formula for quality dining. The proprietors, however, also own Chor Bizarre in Mayfair ‚Äì which has long been an Indian restaurant of some note ‚Äì and a real effort seems to have been made. The emphasis is on grills, at reasonable prices. Good-value lunch and pre-theatre menus (all for ¬£14.50 or less) are a speciality, and in the evenings parties can dine from an all-in selection for ¬£18. On our visit, seafood ‚Äì in particular king prawns and salmon ‚Äì made a particular impression, and a rasmalai (cheese dessert) was also a hit. Service is charming too, if sometimes a bit slow. We never really drink wine in Indian restaurants, but, if you do, the selection here has received more attention than usual.

Much improved by a general ‚Äòloosening up‚Äô, an eminent dining room offers unusually intriguing and tasty dishes in a setting of almost Scandinavian understatement; the set lunch (as so often in Chelsea) is a bargain well worth seeking out.

What a great job you have! Well, how hard can it be drifting round restaurants, and scribbling a few words down about it afterwards? Not that hard, obviously. But nor is it quite the unmitigated joy many people seem to imagine. Yes, it‚Äôs always nice to be fed, but the number of places you  feel you‚Äôve had an experience which is in any way special is, in truth, pretty small.

The joy of finding such a place is also, of course, greater if the discovery is to some extent unexpected. Not to say that Tom Aikens hasn‚Äôt already shown he can be a great chef ‚Äì we still remember a wonderful lunch we had, almost a decade ago, at his original restaurant on this site.

But there have always been negatives too. His presentation has always been a bit Michelin-pleasing, with dishes teetering on the brink of being over-wrought. The former d√©cor never quite ‚Äòworked‚Äô either. And there have been lacklustre spin-offs (successful as some of them have commercially been). Then there was that little difficulty with the suppliers‚Äô

But, hey, here he is, dusted down, with new Turkish backers, and with a new look and feel. The tonality of the dining room is dark, but the look is now understated and informal, with well-spaced tables and comfortable chairs ‚Äì all very agreeable, in a slightly Scandinavian way. In accordance with the general loosening up, the staff from the former r√©gime, mainly charming Frenchmen, now wear jeans ‚Äì clean and pressed Chelsea-style jeans, but jeans nonetheless. They seem to have benefited from their liberation.

We‚Äôve saved the best till last, though. Two of us tasted everything from the lunchtime menu, and had one of the most innovative and most enjoyable meals we can remember having in London, or anywhere else for that matter, for a very long time. There was almost nothing which was not a delight, from the choice of bread with the choice of butters with which the meal began, to the generous and perfectly ripe cheese selection and the artistically-presented range of petits-fours at the end ‚Äì a meal with as much variety and interest as anyone could reasonably want (and all for ¬£29 a head).

In between were starters of squid consomm√© with squid (cooked sous-vide), and a salad of pickled mushrooms with sourdough toast, and main courses of poached cabbage (with smoked bone marrow and poached bacon) and roast John Dory. Only this last dish failed to evoke total satisfaction, but it ‚Äì like everything else ‚Äì was presented with style and wit.

A surprisingly charming Russian restaurant, in a kitschly-decorated townhouse; service is exemplary, but the cuisine displays the traditional tendency to heaviness, and prices fully reflect the Knightsbridge location.

So, you arrive at a new Knightsbridge restaurant to find your guest in one corner of the room and a splendidly-attired Russian Orthodox priest in the other. Turns out he is about to begin a Service of Blessing of the restaurant (and all who sail in her). What would you do? Short of shouting ‚ÄòI am a Satanist‚Äô¬ù, overturning your table, and storming out, there‚Äôs not much you can do.

So you just sit there quietly, fuming rather, until a sprinkling of the diners with Holy Water signifies that it‚Äôs all over. After nearly a quarter of a century in this business, it‚Äôs nice to know that restaurant reviewing can still harbour the occasional surprise.

In the circumstances, it hardly needs stating that this is No Ordinary Restaurant. It is, as it turn out, a member of a chain with outlets in Moscow and New York, as well as the mythical Ms Vanna‚Äôs spiritual home, St Petersburg. Having, courtesy of the internet, toured her empire, we can confirm that the kitsch ‚Äì think the worst Victorian dusting-nightmare you could imagine ‚Äì is laid on with the same trowel throughout.

The surprise is that such a standardised formula seems to ‚Äòwork‚Äô. Indeed, this particular cosy restaurant  ‚Äì perhaps helped by contrast to the bombast of neighbouring Candy Towers ‚Äì succeeds in feeling quite a haven. The easy-on-the-eye staff also do much to sooth away the pressures of 21st-century London.
Our meal mainly consisted of the salads, pierogi and blinis you might expect ‚Äì on the evidence here, Russian cuisine does not harbour many surprises.

Taken individually, the dishes were all pretty good ‚Äì highlights included a crab with salad and poached egg, and the pierogi were tasty too. Animal fats,however, seem omnipresent, creating an overall effect which can just be rather numbing.

It did not help that the p√É¬¢tisserie Napoleon with which we concluded turned out to be the richest sort of millefeuille-variant you could possibly imagine ‚Äì tasty enough, but even a half portion was a source of some regret afterwards.
There‚Äôs another reason too, incidentally, to try to eat relatively lightly ‚Äì drinking modestly, our protein-light lunch for two came to nearly ¬£120. On our visit, no set menu was offered.

Fish and chips is a national symbol.¬†The reason I say so is because everybody has their own personal experience of it. If you ask someone where their favourite chippie is, you‚Äôll get this long gaze (like he‚Äôs going down memory lane),¬†with a lowered voice,¬†they go¬†‚Äòi‚Ä¶

For some reason, new-wave Old English food is something you normally only find in pubs. There is of course a famous exception ‚Äì the founder of the movement, St John of Smithfield. But the vast majority of St John‚Äôs imitators and inspirees are pubs, or dining rooms attached to pubs.

The logic of this (or lack of it) may have struck the owners of this newcomer ‚Äì opposite Covent Garden‚Äôs Masonic Temple ‚Äì many of whom also backed the Anchor & Hope, the most prominent gastropub of recent years. It isn‚Äôt a pub at all. But this fact almost seems to have given them cold feet ‚Äì so what was in former days a bar has been decked out to look like the dining room of a clapped-out boozer.

The great thing about GQS, as opposed to the A&H,is that you can book. The less good thing is that the food is less good. The manifest aim ‚Äì as is evident the second you look at the A4 Xeroxed menu ‚Äì is simplicity. Amen to that. Our choice ran crab on toast, beetroot salad, grilled plaice, cherry cake and cr√®me caramel. But with simplicity, you do risk raising the issue: ‚Äòcould I make it at home‚Äô¬ù. And while the answer wasn‚Äôt in any case a yes, the skill in evidence by no means made the question absurd. There was none of the sense of genius-at-work in the kitchen that‚Äôs made the A&H such a mad success.

But let‚Äôs be positive. Prices are modest enough to defuse any serious criticism of the place. And service is very personable. The gastropub revolution has yet to infiltrate the West End properly, and this faux-boozer represents a very respectable start.

The BB&K is a new concept, in the British Film Institute ‚Äì an impressive cultural complex, by Waterloo Bridge, that‚Äôs currently in the process of being re-launched. Unlike its caf√© ‚Äì whose open-air tables are hard to miss when strolling along the South Bank ‚Äì the smartly decked-out BB&K, up on the first (main) floor takes a bit of seeking out.

It‚Äôs well worth the finding, though, as a fine example of the bar ‚Äòn‚Äô kitchen concept ‚Äì which seems to mean you get gastropub-type food in a hip, but somewhat more restaurant-style, setting; typically in an emerging or trendy area (such as Camden Town, Waterloo, Hoxton, Balham or Marylebone).

It‚Äôs difficult to see simple dishes of this type being realised much better than they are here. It might not have been fancy, but our steak ‚Äòn‚Äô kidney pie, for example, was exceptional. Starters such as carrot soup, and risotto cake, were likewise fine examples of their type. There were only two puddings on offer the day we visited, but everyone on our table for three demanded a go at the attractively presented, and delicious, lime and lemon posset. For those with truly insatiable appetites, Neal‚Äôs Yard cheeses are also available.
Weaknesses? Service still settling in, and coffee on the cool side. Hardly grievous; certainly not at these sort of prices. The main problem with the BB&K? There should be more like it‚Äô

at New York import Red Farm, which is ‚Äúa different dumpling entirely‚Äù from A Wong and Jen Cafe, but never tries to be anything else. The decor has a ‚ÄúWilly Wonka‚Äôs farmhouse‚Äù feel, ‚Äúall decked out in red gingham‚Äù, with ‚Äúincessantly upbeat staff ‚Äú.

territory at North London‚Äôs latest hang-out, Jolene ‚Äì not just the Nordic decor, with its ‚Äúflame-flickered darkness‚Äù, but also the ‚Äúancient grain-focused food‚Ä¶ invokes the intensely hearty, medieval grub that would fuel dynastic wars in Westeros‚Äù.

this week took her to The French House, ¬†the restaurant ‚Äúabove a boozer‚Äù where¬†Neil Borthwick of Merchant‚Äôs House was recently installed, the latest in a long line of famous chefs here.

reviewed Andrew Wong‚Äôs City newcomer Kym‚Äôs, named after the restaurant that his parents used to own in Pimlico (now his restaurant, the acclaimed A Wong), which was itself named after his grandmother; the food was ‚Äújust like Grandma used to make‚Äù.

also reviewed Kym‚Äôs. He described the room as ‚Äúdiscreetly, expensively handsome‚Ä¶ like the Hong Kong penthouse of an achingly metrosexual James Bond baddie‚Äù with the ‚Äúintense, frantic buzz of an old-school Hong Kong dim sum parlour‚Äù.

You never quite know what to expect at a Gordon Ramsay establishment. Within a mile or so of each other, you can have places which are very good (P√©trus, say), and places which are mediocre (Foxtrot Oscar). It‚Äôs one of the mysteries of the celebrity-chefdom lark that these famous ‚Äòbrands‚Äô have transcended the need to offer any particular level of quality or consistency. Aren‚Äôt brands supposed to have brand values?

Gordon‚Äôs latest outpost, we were told, was to be a bit like Bread Street (of the City of London, and now HK). Fortunately, it isn‚Äôt really. Occupying a congenial space just off Regent Street, once a branch of Piccolino, it‚Äôs a much more intimate affair than the echoey and under-charged City operation. Technically we‚Äôre in Mayfair, but spiritually not: Savile Row may be just around a couple of corners, but its hand-worked threads are not sported by the punters here.

If you‚Äôre looking for similarities with Bread Street, though, glance at the menu. The first thing you notice is that simplicity is not the order of the day, in the sense that many dishes need a sentence to describe them, rather than a phrase. The second thing you notice is that even when dishes sound as if you could do this at home, they come with impressive prices. A rib-eye steak, for example, is ¬£34, Mutton pie ¬£21. Our simple lunch, for one, making economical choices for each of three courses, with a glass of wine and an espresso, came to ¬£55.

The food is not bad. Bread rolls have good taste and texture. A tuna tartare was nicely piquant. The ‚Äòcuisson‚Äô of ¬†the sea bream (‚Äúwith smoked aubergine, savoy cabbage, Castelluccio lentils and roast pumpkin‚Äù) was well enough judged, but finishing the dish was ultimately a bit of a chore. Perhaps a bit of crunch somewhere would not have gone amiss. The pear tart ‚Äì the pudding most strongly recommended ‚Äì was entirely as described, with no particular refinement or point of difference from a competent deli, and coffee likewise. The dishes came and went quickly: this is not really food to linger over.

So nothing particularly to criticise then, and nothing particularly to celebrate either. Perhaps, in an establishment where a couple could so easily spend ¬£150 and up, one could hope for a little more? But at least you could be in and out within an hour, no problem.

Given that London ‚Äì as we all know ‚Äì is the great melting pot of our times, it supports very few European restaurants that fall outside the known and usual French and Italian models. Even Spain ‚Äì with its diverse regions and cuisines ‚Äì¬†has few outposts aiming much above the tapas bar level. (And as to Germany‚Äô) It‚Äôs pleasing to note, then, the success in recent years of Lundums (the Danish restaurant in South Kensington) and of the Swedish Glas.

The new setting for Glas is very different.  Moved from its ‚Äòsmall and percussive‚Äô¬ù premises ‚Äì as noted in an excellent guide we often use ‚Äì by Borough Market, it now sits above Islington‚Äôs Antiques Market on the former site of Lola‚Äôs. It is light, lofty and well-spaced, and ‚Äì for those well-disposed to Scandinavian-style understatement ‚Äì possibly quite romantic.

On the culinary front, the main attraction is that the menu is different without being scary (herring excepted, obviously). One of the four breads offered, for example, is a very good home-made ryebread: Ryvita, eat your heart out. Starters, too, have rarity value. Sometimes that‚Äôs all they have: beer-battered beetroot with walnuts and thyme foam, for example, was just rather odd. A venison carpaccio, however, with a mushroom pannacotta (more a mousse) was a delicious dish, with a good range of tastes and textures (especially if you count the berries and nuts which seem to garnish almost everything).

Main courses such as laxpudding ‚Äì a lasagne-like layering of salmon and potatoes ‚Äì tend to fall in the solid-but-enjoyable category, and puddings likewise. A chocolate fondant with white chocolate tasted a little less exciting than it sounded, but the espresso was pretty good.

travelled down to Penzance to visit the Mexico Inn, a ‚Äúfun pub for families‚Äù, whose name ‚Äúis perhaps unhelpful if you stop by hoping for enchiladas and tequila‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs a traditional Cornish pub run by an ex-Gurnard‚Äôs Head couple who have clearly set up ‚Äúthe type of intensely relaxed, gastro-ish pub they‚Äôd like to hang out in themselves‚Äù.

A ‚Äúpleasantly cluttered‚Äù place with service that‚Äôs ‚Äúlovely: warm and knowledgeable‚Äù, and food that‚Äôs ‚Äútwists on pub classics made with produce sourced from local Penwith suppliers‚Äù supplemented by ‚Äúlittle lovely extras‚Äù like ‚Äúcrisp whitebait with a rich harissa mayo, sweetcorn fritters with runner-bean chutney or plates of ham hock‚Äù, not to miss out the Asian-style slaw she described as ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs own garnish‚Äù. (24/30)
mused on what makes a restaurant great (‚Äúthe accretion of details done right over time‚Äù) but then visited Cornerstone which ‚Äúseems to have arrived in the world fully formed‚Äù.

With a Nathan Outlaw prot√©g√© at the stoves, Cornerstone has ‚Äúa clear understanding of the essentials‚Äù: Tom Brown is able to take ‚Äúthe good stuff and make it shine through wit, technique and good taste‚Äù ‚Äì in this case, fish, that notoriously ‚Äútricky‚Äù ingredient.

Cod brandade is ‚Äúa dish so handsome it almost feels like vandalism to slip in the knife‚Äù, skate wing ‚Äúcomes with a deeply savoury and luscious roast chicken butter sauce‚Äù and millefeuille of pear is ‚Äúa seriously classy piece of work‚Äù.

It‚Äôs not all perfect ‚Äì the industrial look could be a little harsh, and the wine list has nothing under ¬£35, but overall, Cornerstone is a winner (and as it recently won an OFM Award for Newcomer in Food & Drink, it has the trophy to prove it).

visited Gridiron, in the space that formerly housed ‚Äúmembers-only playpen‚Äù The Met Bar. It‚Äôs been brought back by the ‚Äúhospitality equivalent of a rock supergroup‚Äù ‚Äì a team from Hawksmoor, The Clove Club and Three Sheets, with a new look that‚Äôs ‚Äúbutch and broodingly dark, with ‚Äúleaping flames‚Äù in the open kitchen.

He was equally floored by the eventual bill (or ‚Äúfinancial velvet rope‚Äù?) of over ¬£200 for two, which ‚Äúfeels unmistakably Mayfair‚Äù, despite the ‚Äúeast London roots of some of Gridiron‚Äôs creative team‚Äù. (6/10)
, felt that she and her companion were ‚Äútreated like escapees from a care home who have never come across an aubergine before‚Äù.

The ‚Äúartfully downbeat‚Äù Soho spot has a ‚Äúterrific look‚Äù but Fay was fairly stingy with compliments about the food, apart from the breads (‚Äúcarb-swervers should go elsewhere‚Äù) and ‚Äúhouse rice with tadig, that brilliant conceit of topping the fluffy grains with the crisp disc from the bottom of the cooking pot‚Äù. visited Amelie in Cambridge, a new spot from the Crepy family (of The Great House, Lavenham fame) serving Flammekueche, a traditional French dish from Alsace. He had a ‚Äúquick, fun lunch like you‚Äôve probably never had before‚Äù. (****)

took a former boss to Coal Office and declared it to have ‚Äúimmense character and muted glamour‚Äù.
