is back eating Chinese food, this time in the presence of an expert, a lady he met at Kaki a few weeks ago, who has given him a list of the six best Chinese restuarants she goes to in London ‚Äì obviously he then claims these as his own, instantly doubling his three reviews per week.

They ate together at Bin Bin Q, a supermarket-barbecue stand hybrid in Chinatown, where they ate chicken gizzards that were ‚Äúcrunchy and full of zip‚Äù and chicken hearts that were ‚Äúeggy and rich‚Äù, ‚Äúutterly transporting‚Äù lamb skewers and ‚Äúdynamite‚Äù steamed oysters.

As well as providing the bulk of this week‚Äôs column, Jing also set Giles up on the Chinese social media app Weixin (WeChat), so we look forward to more recommendations for ‚Äúall the great little Chinese restaurants in this country that we English don‚Äôt normally get to know about‚Äù‚Ä¶ once he learns how to read Chinese. (8/10)
was actually in new territory this week, at a place that none of the other nationals have covered yet. Bath might not exactly be out of his comfort zone, but it‚Äôs an impressive effort all the same.

The Beckford Bottle Shop‚Äôs new Bath sibling is a wine merchant with a restaurant ‚Äúserving up ‚Äòsmall plates‚Äô, as well as a ‚Äòcurated selection‚Äô of British cheese and charcuterie‚Äù. While he mocked it as being ‚Äúachingly on-trend‚Äù and a little bit Hackney, TPB loved it.

It‚Äôs a ‚Äúhandsome Georgian house, with‚Ä¶ a surfeit of space and light, and comfortable leather chairs‚Äù. You can drink any bottle in the shop for a corkage charge, but the wine list is ‚Äúimmaculately selected‚Äù, with ‚Äúnothing over ¬£40‚Äù. And the food? ‚ÄúThe menu‚Äôs so beguiling that we order the whole damned lot. And not a dish disappoints.‚Äù
‚ÄúYoung head chef Harry Russell‚Äù is ‚Äúa talent to watch‚Äù: his food is ‚Äúsimple, straightforward, and joyously confident‚Äù ‚ÄúBath has a new star. Get there, before everyone else does.‚Äù

A brilliant marketing wheeze ‚Äì all possible fresh produce is sourced from the immediate environs of the capital ‚Äì has already assured many column inches of coverage for this new restaurant in a former pub.

Thanks to the location, they do indeed need all the PR they can get. Even the most accomplished estate agent might have to concede that this corner site ‚Äì opposite a massage parlour, ten minutes‚Äô walk from King‚Äôs Cross ‚Äì is ‚Äòdifficult‚Äô. The interior ‚Äì cobalt blue, and swathed with festoons of chainmail ‚Äì is certainly ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô, though, and pleasing too. It positively shimmered the sunny lunchtime I visited. Initial service impressions were also favourable.

As it turns out, the only thing wrong with this place is the food. Wandsworth-baked bread, brought immediately, was fine ‚Äì white, chewy and, in a good way, very English. But who in their right mind would serve olive oil with bread like that? It made no sense. Neither, really, did Chesham goat‚Äôs cheese nettles  pirogi, which tasted as unappetising as they looked; a few greasy breadcrumbs on top did not help. A Canvey Dover sole was plated up complete with head, skin and roe. The flesh had admittedly been grilled to perfection, but the accompanying spinach verged on inedible. A baked cheesecake was a great wodge of a thing, with a claggy base, and accompanied by an ungainly dollop of rhubarb jam. After this multiple assault, only a strong post-prandial filter coffee stopped me feeling slightly queasy.

So, as you‚Äôll gather, I can‚Äôt really recommend this brave new venture, which is a shame. But chefs who build their PR on the metropolitan associations of their food need to ensure that it is not dished up in a style which verges on agricultural.
A true neighbourhood restaurant, hidden away near the Thames in Battersea, offering simple Gallic fare; we found the cuisine generous, but rather lacking in finesse.

When you see menu of this notably unpretentious all-day joint, which opened up near the Battersea riverside early in 2007, you may feel that you have stumbled into some sort of Francophile heaven. This double-page job ‚Äì printed up freshly every day ‚Äì offers dishes ranging from pancakes and croques-messieurs to quite ambitious plats du jour ‚Äì perfect, it seems, for everything from lunch with the kids to an informal romantic dinner (if you avoid the football evenings, that is). There is an excellent range of French wines (and other drinks) too, all at reasonable prices.

Sadly, on our visit, the food just did not live up to the promise. Bread set a upbeat note, and a reasonably-priced kids‚Äô pasta special was also good, but there were just too many duds. That‚Äôs not to say that there‚Äôs any want of generosity ‚Äì if anything, portions are too big ‚Äì but a seafood chowder was impossibly salty, and both a venison plat du jour and a floating island would have benefited from being half the size and twice as subtle. Coffee was also indifferent.
Run by the eponymous Otto, a straight-down-the-line Gallic restaurant, offering classic cooking of good quality, in an attractive and characterful Bloomsbury setting.

The idea that a restaurant is an extension of the personality, even the home, of its proprietor is common in France. Witness the number of restaurants called ‚ÄòChez‚Äô quelqu‚Äôun. But you see it surprisingly rarely here. In London, the aim of mid-market restaurants often seems to be de-personalised good taste, rather than any expression of character, or still less of personality.

So we noticed when Otto (for it was he) greeted us as we entered this Bloomsbury restaurant, and was there as we left, too ‚Äì discussing the menu for that evening with one of his staff. We also noticed that the interior, in a light and airy period room in Bloomsbury, is decked out with that quirky, slightly domestic, taste that the French often apply to restaurants, but which an Englishman would somehow find embarrassing.

As at so many French restaurants, the aim is to do classic dishes well rather than to aim for any particular novelty. Thus our lunch menu for two comprised terrine and scallops, steak and seabass. Nothing to startle, then, but it was striking that everything ‚Äì from the decent crispy baguette (for once) to the coffee ‚Äì was done consistently well, and sometimes very well indeed.

For a lunchtime discussion in an unhurried and restful setting, we doubt that ‚Äì anywhere in the centre of our great city ‚Äì you could have done very much better than we did on on the day of our visit. And, by night, we fancy this must be quite an old-fashioned-romantic place too.

Harden‚Äôs regular round-up of the restaurant critics‚Äô musings, from the week ending 21 April 2019. Happy Easter! Xier, London W1 Grace Dent for The Guardian is always ‚Äúquestioning the entire point of modern haute cuisine‚Äù ‚Äì especially lengthy tasting menus ‚Äúoften done badly: too pompous, too many petals, too few carbs, not a lot of [‚Ä¶]

Fishmarket, Edinburgh When in Edinburgh Jay Rayner for The Observer always heads to Ondine, and its ‚Äúpitch-perfect seafood‚Äù; you can imagine how delighted he was to discover a sibling restaurant, ‚Äúa collaboration between Ondine chef Roy Brett and his long-time suppliers¬†Welch Fishmongers,‚Äù on the docks at Newhaven. At Fishmarket there‚Äôs a ‚Äúclassic metal takeaway counter‚Äù [‚Ä¶]
Larger, if a touch less hip, than its Covent Garden sibling, the third member of this fashionable chain brings its impressively consistent steakhouse formula to a larger scaled City basement.

Anyone familiar with the Hawksmoor formula is going to have few surprises at the latest incarnation of the steakhouse mini-chain, tucked away near the Guildhall. The large dining room manages to look remarkably like its similarly subterranean Covent Garden sibling, and the menu, prices and the styling generally are all similarly faithful to the n-1 version (although the crowd, obviously, is rather less hip).

With about the same number of seats as the Wolseley, though, it‚Äôs the largest member of the group, now three-strong, but the panelled main dining room was already getting a lot of traffic on our early days visit. Not exclusively male, either.

Quite what the ladies find they want to eat on this comprehensively manly menu, though, it‚Äôs difficult to see ‚Äì for our taste, the smallest steak on offer (a sirloin, ¬£20) already verged on overwhelming. No denying the quality of the meat though, or the correctness of the cooking.

Particularly given the scale of the operation, service ‚Äì plaid-clad, as elsewhere in the group ‚Äì was both friendly, and impressively efficient. Lunching alone, your reporter was even offered a variety of newspapers ‚Äì the sort of personal touch that helps you understand why the group continues to do so well.
has ‚Äústumbled across the living definition of the word ‚Äúprecious‚Äù: a seafood restaurant, a fishmonger and a champagne bar in ‚Äî where else? ‚Äî Chelsea‚Äù.

Fromthe people behind Bonnie Gull, this ‚Äúgenuinely exciting‚Äùfish-shop-deli-bar-restaurant (‚Äúevery bit as much of a lifestyle mall as Westfield‚Äù)is a ‚Äútiny space‚Äù (‚Äúrefreshingly free of nautical kitsch‚Äù).There was no sign of ‚Äòexecutive chef‚Äô Leandro Carreira, but the chef incharge was a fine stand-in: ‚Äúwe start falling silent at the arrival of atray of immaculate oysters‚Ä¶ with each successive arrival, we‚Äôre more and moreschtum‚Äù. Innovative pairings (hazelnuts with oysters, sashimi withraw potato noodles) are hailed as ‚Äúsuch a smart move‚Äù.

The ‚Äúhousestyle‚Äù is that ‚Äúthe seafood is allowed to shine: pure, sparkling,pristine‚Äù; ‚Äúit‚Äôs all so simple, so clever, so glorious to eat‚Äù(Marina apologised for gushing at this point). Her favourite dish was ‚Äúmonkfishliver, aka foie gras of the sea‚Ä¶ whipped through with sorrel and somethingcitrussy ‚Äî yuzu?‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a borderline insane collection of flavours that makesme gasp with pleasure‚Äù.

The restaurant is named after an Iris Murdoch novel that was reviewed as ‚Äúas ludicrous as it is brilliant‚Äù, which is equally appropriate to this strangely ‚Äúmonastic‚Äù, bijou Chelsea spot. ‚ÄúThe Sea, the Sea won‚Äôt be for everyone, but it will thrill those of us devoted to sparky-fresh seafood.‚Äù

is on the opposite of a roll, review-wise. Last week‚Äôs disastrous meal at Ashburn SW7 has been followed up with one even stranger, if that‚Äôs possible. Named for its ‚Äúon-trend interest in pickling, fermenting, brining and the like‚Äù, The Soak is the newly-installed restaurant at The Grosvenor in Victoria.

‚ÄúAt times it feels as if there are two kitchens back there. Cross your fingers and hope you get food prepared by the good one.‚Äù Will you ‚Äúcoo and purr‚Äù over your dish, or will it leave you with ‚Äúaching eyeballs from all the rolling‚Äù?

Fromthe good kitchen came ‚Äúsweet-salty picked‚Äù veg (‚Äúcrunchyand thrilling without being wince-inducing‚Äù),‚Äúcured venison with a pleasing bite and intensity‚Äù, lamb belly fritters with blackgarlic mayo that are ‚Äúa huge hit of meaty lanolin‚Äù, a ‚Äúsilky‚Äùcauliflower soup, ‚Äúsmoked kohlrabi laid on a bold pea-green risotto ofspelt‚Äù, a ‚Äúmeaty roasted wood pigeon‚Äù and a ‚Äúmasterfuldark chocolate and honeycomb baked Alaska‚Äù.

And the ‚Äòother‚Äô kitchen served up a ‚Äúgrim‚Äù, 1970s-esque boiled egg salad, a ‚Äúdull plate of crunchy, rubbery things‚Äù described as ‚Äúhot and sour pickled prawns‚Äù, ‚Äúfloppy and underseasoned‚Äù tomatoes, aubergine tempura that was ‚Äúan insult to deep frying‚Äù and a ‚Äúflavourless fillet of cured trout‚Äù served with ‚Äúbland and uninspiring‚Äù accompaniments. The pudding was ‚Äì of course ‚Äì ‚Äúa failed rhubarb souffle‚Äù; ‚Äúit feels like the cook responsible for the pigeon dish popped outside for a fag while this one was being knocked up‚Äù.
‚ÄúFor the money spent, which is significant, thewhole experience is deeply unsatisfactory. But it‚Äôs also something else: it‚Äôsjust seriously, inexplicably weird.‚Äù
enjoyed the plain-looking but punchy biang biang noodles (‚Äúsubstance deliciously overriding style‚Äù) at a surprisingly empty Master Wei (although ‚Äútrade was roaring via Deliveroo‚Äù).

The biang biang noodles delivered ‚Äúan assertive culinary hug‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúcomforting carbohydrate with a kick that creeps up on you‚Äù, and the other ‚Äúauthentic Xi‚Äôan food‚Äù was good, too ‚Äì hand-shredded spicy chicken was ‚Äúremarkable‚Äù and thinly sliced kelp with ‚Äúface-twisting‚Äù kimchi was ‚Äúmagnificent‚Äù. Service from the ‚Äúcheery waitresses was of that comedic level of neglect that you can‚Äôt even be cross at‚Äù.

Mews of Mayfair. The very name is presumably supposed to reek of sophistication, an impression intensified on entering the first floor dining room, which has the sort of very light d√©cor which ‚Äì in a house ‚Äì you might be invited to enjoy only after taking your shoes off. We didn‚Äôt find it especially welcoming, and, when winter comes, it‚Äôs difficult to imagine that it won‚Äôt just look drab and tatty.
Or perhaps they just propose to redecorate monthly? When our lunch for two effortlessly breaching the ¬£100 barrier, the prices would certainly seem to allow for such an extravagance.

So what did we enjoy for this princely sum? First up, some rather hard and waxy bread rolls: we declined the offer of a second. Then starters of deep-fried courgette flowers and cold soup. Neither impressed. Then a wait: the sort of wait during which you become conscious that you‚Äôve nearly finished your bottle of wine, and there‚Äôs still no sign of the food. Just as we despaired, our main courses arrived: some slightly greasy tuna rolls and some grilled sea bream. We finished both out of duty rather than pleasure.

Puddings provided a modest uplift. You might hope, though, for rather more from a ¬£9 brownie. In fact, it turns out that it‚Äôs not a brownie at all, but rather the sort of chocolate fondant that‚Äôs available for roughly half the price in any competent gastropub. Ice creams passed muster, but then it was a hot day.

So is there anything nice we can say? Well, the service was very pleasant. Otherwise this seems the sort of place which, up North, they would describe as ‚Äòall fur coat and no knickers‚Äô. When the WAGs hit town, it‚Äôll surely go down a storm.
So why was it so quiet? ‚ÄúIt is a riddle,wrapped in a mystery, in a spicy dressing, with a loyal audience that‚Äôs toolazy to visit.‚Äù (19/30)

went to Islington to check out the new kitchen team (Four Legs) at The Compton Arms, ‚Äúa tucked-away, hallowed former local of George Orwell, retooled and reopened last autumn‚Äù. It‚Äôs said to be the inspiration for Orwell‚Äôs ‚Äúfictional, idealised pub called The Moon Under Water‚Äù, and is a staunchly Arsenal-supporting pub.

Four Legs (two chefs called Ed McIlroy and Jamie Allan) have brought ‚Äúa gently surprising,unapologetically carnivorous, quicksilver take on pub food‚Äù to The ComptonArms, which ‚Äúis ‚Äî for the most¬†part ‚Äî immensely cheering‚Äù.

Food envy, watching another table order a cheeseburger, made him order one too ‚Äì and it was ‚Äúhonestly one of the best burgers I‚Äôve ever had‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúnostalgic, restrained and almost psychedelically beefy‚Äù. Unfortunately, after that, ‚Äúthe rest didn‚Äôt fully hang together‚Äù ‚Äì the ‚Äúfantastically crisp fried chicken pieces‚Äù and asparagus dishes were oversalted. ‚ÄúRespite‚Äù came from a ‚Äúhillock of buttermilk pudding with the mellow tartness of poached rhubarb (the sole dessert)‚Äù.
After promising to cover more of the ‚Äúkeenly priced, accessible, local little places‚Äù he‚Äôs reviewed recently, Giles Coren for

went to Hide Above, from the ‚Äúone-time wunderkind, now London fine-dining stalwart, Ollie Dabbous, which opened this time last year and was so widely reviewed that I felt like I‚Äôd been about 15 times when I hadn‚Äôt been at all.‚Äù Not really on a budget, then‚Ä¶ ‚Äúthe menu is ¬£115 without supplements and the wine pairings go from ¬£95 to ¬£495 and THEN they add service‚Äù.

There was a long ramble about sustainability and addressing foodwaste, which he believes he invented, before the review started. No worriesabout food waste at Hide, though ‚Äì ‚Äúeverything is teeny-tiny‚Äù(although ‚Äúvery nice‚Äù), with ‚Äúdivine mouthfuls that leave yousatisfied but unfilled‚Äù from the ‚Äúcompulsorytasting menu‚Äù that was thankfully ‚Äúnot an excessively long one‚Äù.

Giles ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt like the cheese board with the bell jars over everything‚Ä¶ it looked medical and grim, like a 19th-century surgical trolley‚Äù and found the ‚Äúpuddings a bit disappointing after the earlier fireworks‚Äù.

‚Äú; the ‚Äúdreary oak tables‚Äù upstairs in Above are ‚Äúdressed with the fanciest glassware (towering wine tulips and coiled glass carafes of insane pretentiousness, like the glistening intestines of unicorns)‚Äù. The ‚Äúwonderful‚Äù staff are equally oddly dressed, in ‚Äúextraordinary, off-white, full-body aprons like celestial butchers‚Äù.
‚ÄúA great place to go and eat hardly anything with some verygood wine, safe in the knowledge that nothing, absolutely nothing will bethrown away.‚Äù (28/40)

was, once more, the first to make it to Myrtle, the new solo venture from ‚ÄúDublin-born‚Äù chef Anna Haugh; she declares it ‚Äúa restrained tribute‚Äù to Myrtle Allen (‚Äúthe matriarch of Irish cooking‚Äù) of Ballymaloe House.

‚ÄúThecombination of her skills and the espousal of¬†prime Irish produce and traditions‚Ä¶ is acaptivating notion.‚Äù Haugh hasintroduced ‚Äúingredients like Clonakilty blackpudding‚Ä¶ and recipes like boxty‚Ä¶ into the slightly constipated techniquesand tropes that tend to gather¬†Michelin stars‚Äù with ‚Äúbrio, generosity, aloosening of stays, maybe even a nip of recklessness‚Äù.

Myrtle is a ‚Äúsimply decorated, pastel-painted two-storey space‚Äù in World‚Äôs End, staffed by ‚Äúpeculiarly formally attired front-of-house staff‚Äù. Prices are on the steep side, with‚Äúexacting‚Äù wine mark-ups and portion control that ‚Äúcomes across as stingy ‚Äî not an Irish characteristic‚Äù. It needs work before it settles in as the neighbourhoodrestaurant Haugh has envisioned.

Fayate ‚Äúblack pudding neatlywrapped in potato strings before frying served with with apple pur√©e‚Äù,‚Äúroasted beef fillet withBurren beef-stuffed boxty‚Äù (‚Äúrather priggish in presentation‚Äù) andfollowed it up with ‚Äúbuttermilkpanna cotta with rhubarb jelly and cinnamon doughnuts‚Ä¶ a superb assembly,light and wibbly and painterly‚Äù.
‚ÄúMyrtle Allen might have also said ‚Äîbut since she didn‚Äôt I will ‚Äî that in your own restaurant you can¬† affordto make it seem like an extension of home.‚Äù (***)

(and her family) stopped off for a meal at the year-old Mara. It‚Äôs an unlikely venue for an impromptu wake ‚Äì it‚Äôs ‚Äúofficially a takeaway, you can‚Äôt make bookings and there isn‚Äôt a toilet‚Äù. But the food made up for that.

Mara is‚Äúa two person operation‚Äù, a husband-and-wife team serving upfish and seafood in ‚Äúeco-friendly boxes‚Äù. Gaby ate ling in a‚Äúrich iron red tomatoey and coconut milk sauce‚Äù; other dishesincluded coley with ‚ÄúArran venison chorizo and pea risotto‚Äù, Skipnesssmoked mackerel croquettes, served with ‚Äúgarlicky kale chimichurri‚Äùand hand cut chips), Skipness hot smoked salmon mac and cheese and fish tacos.
They ended the meal with white chocolate cookies, a ‚Äúgummy-centred chocolate brownie‚Äù and ‚Äúthe best coffee on Arran‚Äù. A fitting, fishy, farewell. (85%)

walked to his latest review (‚Äúanother posh pub-restaurant (PPR)‚Äù in the Cotswolds) through ‚Äúimpossibly, paradisaically beautiful‚Äù countryside. The Feathered Nest in Nether Westcote ‚Äúdoes that classic PPR thing of being small and cosy and publike in the front, but expansive and glassy and view-affording at the back‚Äù.

At ¬£55 forthree courses (cheaper during the week), it‚Äôs a ‚Äúspendy‚Äù option(especially with few wines under ¬£30); the ‚Äúfoodlooked not just appealing but imaginative, with a few Polish touches enliveninga fairly archetypal PPR line-up‚Äù. One such Polish touch was thepierogi with rabbit, ‚Äúthree little stegosauri of joy, the meat rich andrendered, and delicately spiced‚Äù.

The Feathered Nest serves ‚Äúbig food made small‚Äù; not everyone will appreciate their local being turned into an upmarket restaurant, but those seeking out ‚Äúa warm, effusive welcome, and mostly excellent cooking, grounded in the familiar but full of ¬≠personality and surprises‚Äù will be happy ‚Äì if considerably poorer. (****1/2)

this week. No, not a review that gets something other than four stars, but a Mexican restaurant we‚Äôd previously not heard about (even though it‚Äôs been around since 2016, starting ‚Äúas so many places do‚Äù, as a food truck), in Woking, of all places.

Tom describes Araceli as‚Äúbriskly utilitarian‚Äù with ‚Äúa polished concrete floor, whitewashed walls and a queuewinding out of the door‚Äù; it breaks free from the norm of suburban ‚Äúturgid Tex Mex, with comedy sombreros,cheap tequila slammers, sizzling fajitas and wincingly awful puns‚Äùwith ‚Äúserious Mexicanstreet food, served up with lashings of warmth and soul‚Äù.The menu of tacos (‚Äúwiththree different fillings‚Äù), empanadas, ‚Äúvast burritos, decent margarita‚Ä¶fresh, home-made salsas and icy hibiscus juice‚Äù is delivered by ‚Äúitstwo Mexican owners‚Äù ‚Äì service is ‚Äúas swift as it is charming‚Äù.

Beef brisket taco is ‚Äúa six-napkin taco, as thejuices stream down my hands and arms, staining the front of my shirt‚Äù.He describes other dishes using the Mexican names, without translation orexplanation, just to show that he‚Äôs been to Mexico. A ‚Äúcochinita pibil,stained orange with annatto‚Äù is ‚Äúas good a taco as I‚Äôve eatenanywhere in this country. Hell, it could hold its head high in Yucat√°n.‚Äù
was in Norwich, at Benedicts, ‚Äúan integral part of this elegant city‚Äù; ‚Äúit‚Äôs prime asparagus season: take full advantage of this all too temporary treat‚Äù.
reported on the demise of Manchester‚Äôs Curry Mile ‚Äì there‚Äôs now just eight restaurants left from a high of 50 in the 1990s. They have been replaced ‚Äì and improved upon ‚Äì but places like

in Hazel Grove, which has ‚Äúbeen steadily gaining a loyal following since 2015‚Äù. ‚ÄúCurries span the subcontinent‚Äù, Kashmiri lamb chops were cheaper (and better) than Dishoom‚Äôs, ‚Äúsides provide a strong supporting cast‚Äù, staff were ‚Äúversed in every minutiae of the menu‚Äù, they have even ‚Äúbothered to source some local beers‚Äù: it‚Äôs ‚Äúpure gold‚Äù.
On the former Chelsea site of Aubergine, a welcoming and elegantly-styled new Italian restaurant; the cooking, though, is tame.

Honey, we forgot the food! Are we imagining it, or is there a bit of a spate of restaurant at the moment which are very nice in every way‚Äô except that the food is entirely unremarkable? The new Italian restaurant on the Chelsea site that was formerly called Aubergine (same ownership), would appear to be a classic example.

Our initial impressions were that the interior has been given a radical ‚Äì but elegant and comfortable ‚Äì make-over, of the type you might describe as being suitable for ‚Äòcivilised family parties‚Äô, and that the all-Italian service is utterly charming. These impressions only became stronger as the meal progressed.

Concerns that the food might not live up, however, started right at the beginning. We have a theory ‚Äì doubtless we‚Äôve shared it with you before if you read our reviews with any regularity ‚Äì that you can usually tell everything you need to know about a restaurant from its bread. This was a classic example ‚Äì the basket of brown and white breads which arrived was undistinguished in both taste and texture, and owed nothing obvious to Italy.

The meal which followed was not bad, but it was, pretty much all of a piece with the bread ‚Äì not bad or unpleasant, but safe, standard and somewhat uninspired. The best dish was a pannacotta that was almost too generous. But it was too late by then. The feeling that this is a restaurant where they‚Äôd forgotten about the food was, by that point, inescapable.

Modestly revamped, this lake-view Barbican restaurant offers an interesting menu in a room still rather redolent of the ‚Äô70s; while the cooking is of good quality, the bravely English menu perhaps lacks the general appeal that you‚Äôd expect for the dining facility of a cultural centre.

There‚Äôs a lot of refurbishment going on at the moment. Perhaps it‚Äôs because restaurateurs can‚Äôt, in current market conditions, cash out advantageously from properties they‚Äôd otherwise be happy to exit, so they decide that the next best thing is to have a bit of a wash and brush-up.

We don‚Äôt know anything, however, about the specific motivations of Searcy‚Äôs 1847 (as they are now called) in refurbishing their property which enjoys a view of the Barbican ‚Äòlake‚Äô. The former caterers ‚Äì who are now seeking to make quite a name as restaurateurs too ‚Äì have not only refurbished it, they have also ‚Äòrelaunched‚Äô it. That, it seems, happens when you not only brush up the d√©cor, but also the culinary format.

First problem, however, was that we couldn‚Äôt actually see any obvious physical changes. We were therefore very grateful to our helpful and engaging waiter for pointing out that the carpet had changed colour, and that there was now a new dining bar where solo diners can eat watching the goings-on by the lake. For a place that had just been ‚Äòrelaunched‚Äô, though, we‚Äôd have to say the overall impression was one of continuity (and, let‚Äôs be frank, just a little bit dreary ‚Äì these ‚Äô70s spaces take quite a lot of livening up). It didn‚Äôt help that the place, admittedly in the first week of its new guise, was pretty much empty for lunch.

If the setting still seems a little retro, however, the menu has been brought bang up-to-date, in the sense that it is defiantly English. We do wonder about the general appeal of this style. Most of us ‚Äì and this will apply particularly to the less metropolitan sort of diner you may find in a cultural destination like the Barbican ‚Äì have been brought up to  feel happier with a French, Anglo-French or Italian menu than we do with a thoroughbred English one.

The result of all this Englishness, can, in short, be a menu which lacks ‚Äòeasy‚Äô appeal: there was nothing on the menu that our (professional-diner) lunching companion really wanted. That‚Äôs not to denigrate the aim, which is a worthy one, but we suspect that this whole English thing ‚Äì it its extreme form ‚Äì may be a bit of a fad, and that we‚Äôll shortly all go back to the sort of Anglo-French stuff that‚Äôs done quite nicely for the last century or so (if, perhaps, with more English dishes, and a bit more emphasis on local provenance). That‚Äôs not to criticise the realisation or presentation of the food  we tried, though, which was thoroughly good, if not, of itself, a sufficient reason to seek the place out.

And there‚Äôs the rub. We do see getting the punters in as a bit of an issue here, and we do wonder if the absence of a keenly-priced set lunch and pre-theatre menu isn‚Äôt just a little bit barmy. This is quite a big restaurant, and ‚Äì particularly with its slightly ‚Äòacquired-taste‚Äô menu ‚Äì it‚Äôs difficult to see how they‚Äôre really going to build the custom up any other way.

The former Balham Bar & Grill, modestly revamped, and now owned by Sam Harrison of Sam‚Äôs Brasserie (W4) fame; it remains a friendly and stylish spot, but the food is still rather an incidental attraction.

Nick Jones is one of the most successful club-proprietors of our day, and his Soho Houses ‚Äì recently acquired by Scotts-proprietor Richard Caring ‚Äì have become default media glitterati boltholes in both London and New York. He‚Äôs no slouch as a restaurateur either, and has brought a trendy vibe to establishments such as Cecconi‚Äôs in Mayfair. Even he, though, was defeated by Balham. Well, no, that‚Äôs not really true. Having been part of the early-wave operators that made Balham the bijou destination it is today, he decided last year that the sarf London suburb establishment no longer really fitted with his NyLon portfolio. The solution was to job the place on to Sam Harrison. The latter is, of course, the Sam of eponymous Chiswick brasserie fame, and he‚Äôs now put the other half of his name over the door in Balham.

Given the fact that Harrison‚Äôs is, spiritually speaking, the son of two trendy(ish) local destinations where the food is rather a secondary attraction, the new establishment is exactly what you would expect. A Saturday brunchtime visit found quite a buzzy place (not attracting a particularly beautiful crowd, it would have to be said) with pleasant (but sometimes slow) service and food which was very much a supporting attraction. Burger and chips seemed to be the local dish of choice ‚Äì ours was in no way remarkable, and the other dishes were broadly in keeping.
Children are well looked after, but don‚Äôt dominate, making this a real all-the-family destination. We still left, though, regretting that the food was not that little bit better.

Mrs Harden was not happy. Like her sister-in-law (also Mrs Harden) she knows by now that restaurant critics don‚Äôt just spend their lives checking out the latest Knightsbridge hotspots. But trekking to Brixton on a cold and windy night? Well, really.

The many clouds overhanging our visit darkened further when the restaurant didn‚Äôt seem to be at the appointed address. Mercifully it didn‚Äôt take too long to find the entry ‚Äì on Branscome Road ‚Äì even though it is only marked, speakeasy-style, by an Entryphone.

The buzzer whirred, and the door opened onto a winding staircase. Up we go to find a small bar, and then up again to a tiny dining room with a Lilliputian real fire. The room, surprisingly, has a view, of which the distant focal point is an illuminated building of some grandeur. ‚ÄòIt looks like Parliament, but isn‚Äôt‚Äô¬ù, said the charming French waitress. Actually, it is.

The menu is Gallic, and, given the small scale of the operation, sensibly short: three choices per course, plus the odd ‚Äòspecial‚Äô. Everything is simply but nicely presented. Overall, my good lady did better than I did. In fact her first two courses ‚Äì scallops, followed by lamb with a carrot and swede mash ‚Äì even persuaded her to have a pudding: a rare mark of approval. My meal ‚Äì ballotine with brioche, then polenta with raclette and finally a chocolate mousse ‚Äì blew a bit hot and cold, but was never less than competent. The bread rolls tasted as if they had been made on the premises, and the coffee was pretty good too.

So, can this brave and quintessentially downtown sort of restaurant last? The locals ‚Äì lucky they ‚Äì seem to be supporting it. One can‚Äôt help feeling, however, that if it‚Äôs a real success, uptown migration can‚Äôt be far away. (When they‚Äôve got their geography sorted out, naturally.)

visited Angelina despite the ‚Äúacute flashbacks‚Äù he suffered when told it was a fusion of Italian and Japanese food; it took him right back to the ‚Äúunmitigated disaster‚Äù that was Shumi in 2003.

Luckily for him, and us, Angelina avoids any such disaster: it ‚Äúfeels like a beautifully intentioned, low-key experiment‚Äù. In fact, ‚Äúit‚Äôs like being invited round for dinner by your mate; the nerdy one who can really cook‚Äù.

Aren‚Äôt sashimi and crudo closerelatives?‚Äù

Angelina is a ‚Äúsweet venture‚Äù serving ‚ÄúItalianfood, with intriguing Japanese grace notes. This time round I give thanks thatthere appears to be space in the market for something so curious and thoughtful.‚Äù

‚Äòs restaurant critic ‚Äì however his trip down Memory Lane wasn‚Äôt in place of a review, as we stated. Sorry, Jay! And sorry to Pompette, Pascal & Laura Wiedemann‚Äôs new-ish Oxford restaurant that he reviewed. Pascal worked with Henry Harris at Racine before opening Terroirs.

feeling ‚Äúpronounced, irrational envy‚Äù, because he doesn‚Äôt live 10 minutes up the road. Top Cuvee comes from an ex-Naughty Piglets chef and drinks experts from Dinner in Melbourne and Three Sheets, and has already established itself as an ‚Äúinstant neighbourhood hit‚Äù.

ate at Ottolenghi‚Äôs new-ish Fitzrovia restaurant: ‚Äúit is impossible to overstate how much Yotam Ottolenghi has changed the way we eat‚Äù.

this week, a new Clerkenwell joint from the folks behind Sager + Wilde; he describes it as ‚Äúa bit of everything‚Äù ‚Äì there‚Äôs coffee in the morning, all-day pizzas and evening wines and cocktails on tap (all with accompanying, and duly named-checked, bits of kit).

visited Rohit Ghai‚Äôs street food venture at Wembley‚Äôs ‚Äúcorrugated steel-clad street food market‚Äù ‚Äì she thought, as many did when it was announced not long after the opening of Kutir, that ‚Äúit‚Äôs not where most people imagined Ghai heading next‚Äù.

on Saturday was in deepest Surrey, ‚Äúclassic commuter-belt ¬≠terrain, extra-urban yet sub-rural‚Äù, to ‚Äúdive headlong into the delights of Jos√© Pizarro‚Äôs new tapas-tastic pub-restaurant‚Äù.

A no-nonsense English bistro, near Camden Town tube; a friendly sort of place, it offers plain cooking ‚Äì in a style which, until recently, might have been called ‚Äòdomestic‚Äô ‚Äì at reasonable prices.

First, in the early ‚Äô90s, we had what we now call gastropubs. By the late-‚Äô90s, a retro-style of English cooking was beginning to evolve (or, more accurately, be rediscovered), which might be described ‚Äì for want of any better term ‚Äì as gastropub-style cooking. Then, by the mid-00s, people were beginning to figure out that there wasn‚Äôt any

Recent times have seen the creation of establishments such as 32 Great Queen Street, which ‚Äì being asssociated with the famous Anchor & Hope ‚Äì has all the style of a gastropub, but no pub. In a different way, the smart modernist Canteen chain has also made quite a success by disassociating gastropub-style cooking from the gastropub-style environment.

And so things go full circle, and we now see establishments such as Market, which is for all the world like a classic no-nonsense Gallic bistro (or caf√©, as the French might call it), except for the fact that everything about it is resolutely English.  Mackerel p√É¬¢te ‚Äòn‚Äô toast, pollack ‚Äòn‚Äô chips, fruit crumble ‚Äòn‚Äô custard ‚Äì that‚Äôs the sort of fare you find done here. And all ‚Äì on the basis of our lunch for three ‚Äì consistently done very well here.

A small and tightly-packed East End dining room, entered via an art gallery, where Maria Elia (who has a bit of a name, from her time at the Delfina Studio Caf√©) cooks up food of proper restaurant quality.

London‚Äôs galleries and museums tend to offer little of interest on the food front. Part of the problem is that, big and institutional bodies as they are, they tend to appoint big, joyless catering companies to do the job for them.

All credit, then, to the relaunched Whitechapel Gallery, which has taken an independent approach to its in-house restaurant. The result is an establishment which doesn‚Äôt feel at all institutional. It may be symbolic that, though you enter through the gallery entrance, the restaurant overlooks a busy (and not especially attractive) streetscape, which tends to suggest that this is a ‚Äòreal‚Äô restaurant that just happens to be attached to an art gallery. (Perhaps this really is the ‚Äúace cafe with a museum attached‚Äù of which the V&A once famously boasted.)

On our early-days visit, the place was already busy for lunch, and deservedly so. Perhaps it helps that the chef knows a bit about cooking in a cultural environment. Whatever the reason, the food was much better than one might expect.

And pretty too. Dishes here are carefully plated, and nicely balanced. A ham hock terrine, for example, comes elegantly laid out, and accompanied by nicely-timed quail‚Äôs eggs and still-warm asparagus. Bream comes similarly well presented, with mash and beetroot. Even the few elements involved in a dish of good treacle tart and cr√®me fra√É¬Æche are carefully composed. Bread and coffee are well above average.

There are niggles. Space is tight. Prices are just a touch higher than you might hope. Bread does not come gratis. Service rather comes and goes. But all these are details. This is a gallery restaurant seemingly run as a restaurant, rather than as an  afterthought. Surely this is an idea that might just ‚Äì finally ‚Äì catch on?

A vehicle for a chef of undoubted talent, this ostentatious Mayfair ‚Äòbrasserie‚Äô offers perfectly acceptable food and service but on our early-days visit any sort of excitement was signally lacking.

Eric Chavot cooked at Knightsbridge‚Äôs Capital Hotel for a decade (ending in 2009). This really tells you everything you need to know about his skills and dedication, as no other hotel in town has shown quite the same determination, over the long haul, to keep its dining room in the city‚Äôs very first rank.

Now he‚Äôs popped up again, trading under his own name at Mayfair‚Äôs Westbury Hotel. Odd in a way ‚Äì the hotel already has an excellent, if too little-known, fine-dining room, presided over by Marcus Wareing-prot√©g√© Alyn Williams. The space for Chavot is the large and ornate street-entrance dining room formerly known as the Gallery.

Though the life of the previous incarnation was quite short, so much money had been lavished on its fit-out that they‚Äôve decided to leave the interior substantially as it was. For our taste, the impression is still that of dining at the finest hotel in Ruritania ‚Äì opulent, certainly, but not cosy or stylish. Fellow lunchers on the day of our visit seemed largely to be hedgies; wealth, it seems, does not necessarily equate to glamour.

The establishment is touted as a brasserie, by implication a Gallic one, but it isn‚Äôt really. The menu lacks many obvious staples, and the presentation of oysters, for example, is plain wrong. How can they present them other than nestling in a beguiling bed of ice, ideally on a stand? An unadorned china plate, albeit with six little subdivisions, is a sad and lazy substitute. And what about the bread, which is charged for? Two types were presented: both seemingly home-made‚Äô by someone who had not yet quite mastered the oven.

Other reviewers have tended, in not invariably, to find main courses the highlight of the cooking here, and a dish such as duckling √É¬† l‚Äôorange with endives was notably elegantly plated and tasty too, if perhaps rather ‚Äì like the whole concept ‚Äì lacking heart. Puddings, on the other hand, have not been seen as a strong point, but we enjoyed our rum baba, and the coffee was fine, if nothing remarkable.

Service kicked off on the wrong note, but presumably the establishment believes the revenue derived from the ‚Äòstill or sparking‚Äô¬ù force outweighs the poor impression it gives. Otherwise, though, there was nothing to complain about, and the solicitous ma√É¬Ætre d‚Äô asked several times if everything was OK. Well, it was all broadly acceptable, but he never asked the key question: why on earth would you ever come back?

From the upper deck of our City AM limousine, we saw an impressive place we‚Äôd not previously noticed. Once a grand banking hall, it looked ‚Äì with its fancy lighting, smartly-dressed tables and a menu outside ‚Äì for all the world like the sort of place readers ought to know about.

So we hopped off, and returned to receive a warm welcome. Close up, though, we couldn‚Äôt help noticing a certain lack of customers. How come? The location is handy, the tables comfortably appointed, and the interior well enough spaced for most sorts of business discussions.

When we actually perused the menu, however, we began to understand the thin house. Its style (we subsequently learnt) is ‚ÄòModern European comfort food‚Äô¬ù, which seems to mean that it was designed by a committee with at least one oriental member. So it seemed rude not to try out the sushi and sashimi starter. This foray into multi-culturalism was not a success, however as the tempura salmon nori roll ‚Äì if thankfully only part of the dish ‚Äì was every bit as horrid as it sounded.

The most striking thing about the meal was a burger. Not just any old burger you understand, but a burger with no fewer than five enormous onion rings piled on top of it, four and a half of which return to the kitchen uneaten. The chips weren‚Äôt much cop either. The burger itself, however, was flavoursome and accurately cooked. Puddings are quite decent too, and coffee, for once, was thoughtfully served with hot milk. It‚Äôs not as if there‚Äôs no hope, here.
On leaving, we caught sight of the DJ‚Äôs decks, which suggest that ‚Äì by night ‚Äì this place lives up to its name. With a few tweaks, though, it could be useful by day too.

Old Spitalfields Market ‚Äì one of east London‚Äôs most iconic and treasured sites ‚Äì will relaunch its food offering on 13 October with a whole host of street food vendors. It may be unrecognisable as the meat, fruit and veg market it once was 200 years ago‚Ä¶ but back then the area around Commercial Street and Brick Lane was considered rural!

The all-star line-up of traders known as ‚ÄúThe Kitchens‚Äù, opens on 13 October, and will modernise the market floor. The newly designed stalls will house 10 of the hottest names in London‚Äôs street food scene, including:

, With a focus on flavours and ingredients from the Middle East and North Africa, co- founders Josh Katz and Mattia Bianchi will serve Rolled shoulder of lamb Mechoui, blackened chilli sauce and bread & butter pickles on flatbread alongside favourites from their Haggerston arch including Cauliflower Shawarma with tahini, pomegranate and rose.

, from humble origins in a Hackney carpark, one of London‚Äôs most popular taquerias will feature their own unique brand of Mexican cuisine. They‚Äôll be grinding masa corn fresh every day for their BBQ duck, tamarind, piloncillo and burnt onion tacos.

, a new offering from Hugh Thorn and Luke Clarkson will explore the diverse flavours throughout Asia and the sub-continent. Far from traditional fare, Barbarian will showcase simple dishes incorporating Asian flavours and technique, made using local and seasonal produce. At the market, the hero of their menu will be Sichuan classic Mapo Tofu. The team have specifically sourced top quality ingredients from Chengdu province to give an authentic interpretation of this dish.

, cult street food traders with a loyal following, John Li and Yee Li have spent three years perfecting their dumpling recipes. Their specialty is outstanding Shengjianbao dumplings but they‚Äôll also be showcasing home-made dan dan noodles, a Chinese street food classic.

, transporting his Brighton-born residency to London, creative young chef Tom Griffiths will focus on nose to tail beef cookery over open fire. His menu will be peppered with an exciting array of seasonal British dishes such as Wild Mallard with fermented peanut.

, one of the winners of at the 2017 Young British Foodie awards, Terri Mercieca has already gathered a cult following for her creative range of ice cream sandwiches & desserts. Creations such as ‚Äòthe Naughty One‚Äô ‚Äì Salted caramel and miso parfait between fine layers of chocolate Guinness cake ‚Äì have had tongues wagging across the capital.

, these Shoreditch natives will serve up a range of Nordic inspired dishes with a strong focus on preservation. Matt Young has transformed classic dishes into a street food format with their Smoked duck leg bun with lingonberry jam forming part of a wider offering of fish, meat and plant based vegetarian dishes. R√∂k will also offer for the first time low alcohol home brewed mead, fennel wine and cider.

, a new offering from the team behind Dalston Japanese restaurant and music venue Brilliant Corners. Connoisseurs on every level, they‚Äôre known for Japanese small plates, natural wine and cocktails served to the sound of music from all genres. At the market Thousand Knives will continue this theme, specialising in both vegan and non-vegan Japanese food made using traditional techniques.

, an east London pop-up restaurant serving seasonal fresh pasta dishes such as amatriciana and radicchio, gorgonzola tortelloni and breakfast brioche buns with guanciale. They will also offer authentic Italian products such as burrata, cheeses and cured meats.

, a regular feature in ‚Äòtop street food‚Äô lists, Yum Bun will bring their fluffy pockets of flavour to Old Spitalfields market and launch a new dish ‚Äì a Spiced fried chicken, salted celery slaw and Szechuan Mayo bun.

The revamp of the market and selection of the Kitchens traders has been overseen by Ten Ten, a creative organisation headed up by chef Nuno Mendes and hospitality consultant Stephen Macintosh. Together with the market owners, their vision is that the new market becomes a hub for creative and entrepreneurial talent, serves the local community and celebrates its East End origins.

A new line-up of traders representing small, independent and local businesses will join the community over the course of the next six months. The completed market will feature in excess of 100 market traders and a new events programme, all to be unveiled in spring 2018. Eventually supporting a community of 114 traders across the Kitchens, food and retail stalls, the remodelled Old Spitalfields Market aims to give small and independent operators a much-needed platform to showcase their brands.

was searching for somewhere easy to eat near the Royal Albert Hall, and stumbled upon a gem in Tozi, a Venetian cicchetti (small plates) spot that‚Äôs attached to the Park Plaza Hotel (he wasn‚Äôt aware of this when he booked). It‚Äôs unmistakably ¬†‚ÄòLondon‚Äô ‚Äì ‚Äúan echoing space of huge white-washed walls and high ceilings‚Äù, with ‚Äúterrific‚Äù service from the ‚Äúyoung all-Italian front of house staff‚Äù.

Cured meats were ‚Äúexceptionally well looked after‚Äù and some of the dishes remind him of Bocca di Lupo and Radici ‚Äì ‚Äúhigh praise‚Äù indeed. Another dish, of hand-cut taglioni, is ‚Äúadult nursery food‚Äù (a good thing). A ‚Äúclassic saltimbocca‚Äù and a ‚Äúgoblet of tiramisu‚Äù end a meal tinged with Brexit-related sadness and regret.

visited Kitty Fisher‚Äôs little sister in Covent Garden, ‚Äúthe tourist theme park that is trying hard to join the cool foodie gang‚Äù. It‚Äôs ‚Äúa space almost as awkward as Kitty‚Äôs‚Äù and the bar-kitchen basement was so ‚Äúrammed‚Äù that he was ‚Äúpractically eating off neighbours‚Äô laps‚Äù.

The food? ‚ÄúNothing at Cora is particularly adventurous‚Äù, but well realised and ‚Äúreally tasty‚Äù: Chef George Barson ‚Äútakes things people really like and cook them‚Äù ‚Äì a cheesey crouton floating in fish soup is ‚Äúchildishly yummy‚Äù.

Any ‚Äúflaws feel forgivable‚Äù and he left ‚Äúfeeling deeply content‚Äù. Overall, Cora Pearl (named for another courtesan, this time Victorian) is summed up as ‚Äúa ramshackle dinner party in a slightly too small room hosted by someone who loves food but¬†isn‚Äôt going to mess up your evening with pipettes of nettle juice and obscure bits of offal no one actually likes‚Äù.

ate dishes that were ‚Äúreminiscent of something an antihero in a Bret Easton Ellis novel would order‚Äù at Gazelle, a ‚Äúvery, very cool new restaurant‚Äù in Mayfair ‚Äúwhere the vibe is experimental and gastronomically challenging‚Äù.

Her experience can be summed up with a stern recommendation to go to Gymkhana if you‚Äôre in the area on someone else‚Äôs expense account. In fact, that‚Äôs exactly what Grace did, even after sharing seven courses of Gazelle‚Äôs (admittedly delicious) food, which was served in portions that ‚Äúwould struggle to cover the floor of a Barbie paddling pool‚Äù.
, and the newly opened Amano in West Malling, which he describes as a ‚Äúnice-looking place, streaming with natural light and bursting with greenery‚Äù.

He was slightly dreading the Italian cuisine, which he says always ‚Äúmakes me feel bloated, or sleepy‚Äù, so he opted for protein-rich dishes, then enviously watched his family wolf the fritto misto (‚Äúoutstandingly light and bubbly‚Äù), pappardelle with mushrooms (‚Äúterrific‚Äù) and torta della nonna (‚Äúsumptuously tart and elegant‚Äù). So maybe not ideal for carb-dodgers, but perfect for the rest of us.

review took her to Native, recently moved from Covent Garden to a bigger and batter Southwark site. After a disappointing visit to sample the new vegan fare at Bob Bob Ricard (‚Äúsub-Cranks offerings‚Äù), Native was a pleasant surprise ‚Äì despite being unimpressed with the ‚Äúforaging and wild food and crowdfunding‚Äù ethos.

A starter of food that would otherwise be wasted (‚Äúhow unalluring does this sound?‚Äù) is ‚Äúnot just snowflaky worthiness, each little morsel is gorgeous‚Äù. Grouse is served with all its favourite foods and the ‚Äúcumulative effect of these dishes is bosky, exciting, thrilling‚Äù: ‚Äúeven sweet things that seem like perfect madness come off ‚Äú.

The co-owner‚Äôs ‚Äúinfectious, joyful enthusiasm, brimful of knowledge‚Äù combines with the ‚Äúfireworks happening on the culinary front ‚Äù to make a place that‚Äôs ‚Äúlittle short of ravishing ‚Äú.

trekked out to the ‚Äòburbs (by train, no less) in search of Dastaan ‚Äúon a pretty unlovely, nondescript stretch of Surrey dual-carriageway ‚Äú. It can‚Äôt be claimed as a discovery, for Dastaan originally appeared in a national newspaper back in April 2017, when Marina O‚ÄôLoughlin reviewed it for The Guardian, and several big-name chefs have praised it lavishly.

But (as you can tell by the five star rating) Tom was just as blown away as Marina ‚Äì the chef-patron Sanjay Gour formerly worked at Murano, and was briefly head chef at Gymkhana. From the very start, ‚Äúthe food here is leagues removed from your usual Brit-Indian curry house ‚Äú, indeed it‚Äôs ‚Äúsublime‚Ä¶ seriously knock-out ‚Äú. Dastaan ‚Äúgets all the small details right‚Äù ‚Äì a duck and guinea fowl kebab, is ‚Äúa splendid cylinder of expertly spiced joy‚Äù, and the spicing on the marinated lamb chop is ‚Äúso precise that it seems laser-guided‚Äù.

TPB declares that Dastaan (‚Äúa national treasure‚Äù) serves ‚Äúsome of the best regional Indian I‚Äôve eaten in years‚Äù And all at suburban prices, too: ‚ÄúIt may share chefs and exalted ingredients with Gymkhana, but it sure doesn‚Äôt share those prices.‚Äù
Giles Coren for The Times reviewed Village Castigno in south-west France, a rambling hotel complex with three restaurants.

rejoiced in the ‚Äúsheer chutzpah‚Äù of chef Alex Bond at Alchemilla even before she ate a bite of the ‚Äúveg-centric‚Äù menu. Bond has turned a huge, ‚Äúcrypt-like space‚Ä¶ an abandoned coaching house‚Äù that had ‚Äúsat unloved and festering for more than 100 years‚Äù into ‚Äúa capacious, open brushed aluminium kitchen‚Äù ‚Äì doing much of the work himself.

With a solid background at places like Auberge du Lac and Restarant Sat Bains, Grace felt that Alchemilla is Bond‚Äôs ‚Äúbid to fly unfettered‚Äù ‚Äì and doing so, he has created ‚Äúa sort of semi-fine, fermentation-focused, Japanese-influenced, feasibly Michelin-star-luring experience‚Äù. It‚Äôs still experimenting and finding its feet, but ‚ÄúAlchemilla feels to me like a restaurant at the start of a long and important journey‚Äù.

It‚Äôs a tasting menu-style operation, with ‚Äúbright, drilled and knowledgeable‚Äù staff. Dishes are a decent size, some inspired with ‚Äúwonderful oddness‚Äù like the ‚Äúenoki mushroom‚Ä¶ draped over duck mousse‚Äù and an unforgettable miso-baked aubergine. Properly veg-centric food. She left ‚Äúfull, cheerful and determined to come back again‚Äù ‚Äì what more could a restaurant critic ask? (24/30)

magazine is a regular at The Old Butchers, which he calls ‚Äúthe best restaurant for many miles around‚Äù. It‚Äôs ‚Äúmostly a fish place‚Äù ‚Äì the lobster (or Prawn Transformer as his son calls it) is ‚Äúbloody good‚Ä¶ served with perfect, slender, partly skin-on fries‚Äù. He always has their ‚Äúincomparable tempura oysters‚Äù too, which come ‚Äúpiping hot, crispy and golden as the sun itself‚Äù and his daughter invariably plumps for the ‚Äústaggeringly good‚Äù cheeseburger.
And the price? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fish, it‚Äôs the high Cotswolds, it‚Äôs a grown-up wine list ‚Äì it‚Äôs quite expensive. But it‚Äôs not madness.‚Äù He mentions the wine quite a bit‚Ä¶ (36/40)

visited the newly opened Soane‚Äôs Kitchen at Pitzhanger Manor, the country retreat built in1804 by British architect Sir John Soane (although it‚Äôs now not so much in the country as in suburban Ealing). The restaurant within is a ‚Äúhandsome setting, with indoor olive trees‚Äù and ‚Äúglass doors flung open to the original walled produce garden‚Äù, serving ‚Äúbrunchy British fare‚Äù with ‚Äúthe odd healthful,¬†Ottolenghian¬†twist (hello cauliflower steak)‚Äù from ‚Äúeager young staff‚Äù.

So far, so good ‚Äì and then the food arrived. Starters of ‚Äúnothingy, murmured‚Äù flavours ¬†and ‚Äúneedless‚Äù decoration had Jimi reaching for the salt. And it was the same with his main course, which was ‚Äúunderseasoned and fairly dismal‚Äù (although his companion had a ham hock salad which ‚Äúwas good in a clodhopping, sausage-fingered sort of way‚Äù. Simple puddings rescued a menu that felt ‚Äúpitched awkwardly‚Äù, but with a good deal of potential. Let‚Äôs hope it‚Äôs just teething problems. (6/10)

paid a visit to the latest Instagram sensation to arrive in London‚Äôs Covent Garden ‚Äì Red Farm, where a simple dish of prawn dumplings becomes a play on the retro video game PacMan, that Fay described as ‚Äúdaft‚Äù but enjoyed the ‚Äútightly packed‚Äù and ‚Äúbouncy‚Äù prawn filling.

‚ÄúAttention-grabbing dishes ‚Äù such as soup dumplings (with straws) and three-colour dumplings that were a ‚Äù masterpiece of construction‚Äù followed, then a ‚Äúravishingly crisped, magically seasoned‚Äù shrimp-stuffed chicken from the specials board. However, the experience was marred by ‚Äúballsy‚Äù pricing (even in soft launch week and with complimentary dishes sent her way) and a ‚Äúfondness for extraneous garnish‚Äù. (***)

assures us that London does need another piri piri chicken place ‚Äì specifically Caso do Frango, which he called ‚Äúdelightful‚Äù. It‚Äôs a ‚Äúhuge, airy space hard by Borough Market‚Äù that‚Äôs ¬†‚Äúeffortless shabby chic‚Äù and has ‚Äúan inside-out feel‚Äù.

Gazpacho is ‚Äúfull of garlic astringency and sunshine‚Äù, and the main event ‚Äì piri¬† piri chicken is ‚Äúsmall, meaty, very flavourful‚Äù and ‚Äúsalty and spicy in all the right places‚Äù. A side order of rice comes with crispy chicken skin (‚Äúsounds to me like a great night out‚Äù), and the custard tarts ‚Äì made in-house ‚Äì are that ‚Äúperfect mix of flaky caramelised pastry and deep eggy custard‚Äù. The communal seating suits the ‚Äúelbows-out, face-down‚Äù cuisine, and took Jay back to a Portuguese holiday of his youth.

in The Telegraph also recommends a visit to Caso do Frango in Southwark, which he describes as an airy spot serving authentic Algarvian cuisine that‚Äôs perfect ‚Äúif you‚Äôre not a ‚Äòcheeky Nando‚Äôs‚Äô sort of person‚Äù but have a hankering for piri piri chicken and Portuguese wine. (****)

enjoyed a trip down (gap year) Memory Lane during a visit to Xi‚Äôan Biang Biang Noodles in east London (sibling to Xi‚Äôan Impression by the Arsenal stadium), which ‚Äúoffers authentic regional Chinese cooking from a region that isn‚Äôt represented much in Britain‚Äù ‚Äì where ‚Äúcumin, chilli and salt rather than soy, sugar and ¬≠anise‚Äù are the ‚Äúdominant seasonings‚Äù.

It‚Äôs ‚Äúfairly cheap‚Äù, serves ‚Äúlarge‚Äù portions of ‚Äúrobust, substantial rustic cooking‚Äù in ‚Äúa brightly lit, utilitarian, ground-floor space‚Äù and service is ‚Äúfriendly, fast and informal‚Äù. The menu is ‚Äúa laminated tour of Xi‚Äôan cuisine‚Äù and the food ‚Äúa happy contrast of ¬≠textures and temperatures‚Äù. (***)

review took her to Edinburgh, but ‚Äúaway from the bustle of Edinburgh‚Äôs handsome, tourist-thronged centre‚Äù; instead, she was ‚Äúfollowing in the footsteps of some of the world‚Äôs most creative chefs, hotshots from Hong Kong to Oslo‚Äù. It‚Äôs easy to understand why when you learn that co-owner Ben Reade was Noma‚Äôs head of research and development at the Nordic Food Lab.

Formerly only a research hub (‚Äúthis is food intellectualised, the spoddiest, nerdiest, most obsessive of pursuits.‚Äù), Edinburgh Food Studio is now also a ‚Äúregular ‚Äî if also very irregular ‚Äî restaurant‚Äù. New head chef, James Murray is ‚Äúacing that school of deceptively simple, stripped-back, produce-driven cooking‚Äù ‚Äì his food is, simply, ‚Äúawesome‚Äù. (There‚Äôs also a ‚Äúwow, wow and

It‚Äôs ‚Äúa celebration of the sheer hedonism of putting unspeakably delicious things into your mouth‚Äù ‚Äì with ‚Äúa sense of fun and excitement‚Äù, too. Only the communal table leave Marina cold (‚Äúthe only thing that stops this being an unseemly, dribbling rave‚Äù) ‚Äì they‚Äôre just not her thing. But the locals seem to like it ‚Äì ‚Äúand how‚Äù.

enjoys a few paragraphs describing the out-of-the-way, accessible-only-by-boat ¬†beachfront restaurants he‚Äôs patronised around the world, and then (rather unfairly) compares them to ‚Äúwannabe beach shack‚Äù Bucket in west London ‚Äì ‚Äúa brutal battle zone‚Äù for restaurants, that can ‚Äì and do ‚Äúdisappear overnight, never to be seen again‚Äù.
Bucket ‚Äúaspires towards distant, wave-lapped beaches‚Äù, but like the most exclusive of beaches, was ‚Äúalmost entirely empty‚Äù. The ‚Äòeverything comes in a pail‚Äô concept

The best things TPB ate were the lobster, prawn and cheese toastie, which ‚Äútasted divine‚Äù, and mussels which were ‚Äúfat, sweet and hot‚Äù. The rest? ‚Äù In parts it‚Äôs actually rather decent‚Ä¶ Bucket means well. But I do fear for its future.‚Äù (***)
ate at Castell Peralada in Girona, Spain: ‚ÄúA dish described as a ‚Äòliquid summer salad with basil and olives‚Äô seemed pure El Bulli‚Äù
waited for 20 minutes at Restarant 92 before any food arrived on the table ‚Äì and that was just bread. He‚Äôd been delayed on the train and was very cold ‚Äì not the best start.

Luckily, Micheal Carr‚Äôs cooking won him over, with its ‚Äúfun ideas‚Äù, ‚Äúenthusiasm‚Äù and ‚Äúadmirable risks‚Äù. Even the bread was ‚Äúto be taken seriously‚Äù, rich in animal fat and ‚Äúluscious‚Äù. There were distinct moments of ‚Äúunevenness‚Äù ‚Äì not really acceptable at ¬£55 for three courses.

Jay‚Äôs starter (45 minutes in) of rabbit and carrots was ‚Äúwhimsical, but also unembarrassed about huge flavours‚Äù, but two fish dishes came overcooked (with undercooked potato). And ‚Äúdesserts feel like initial sketches, in need of further thought‚Äù ‚Äì in fact, ‚Äúmostly, there is the feeling here of an ambitious restaurant which could be great, but which right now isn‚Äôt quite sure how to become so.‚Äù
plumped for this Mayfair Italian (imported from Milan) over bleeding vegan burgers, crazy golf, caviar and Japanese-Italian fusion (all genuine recent openings in the Big Smoke).

She didn‚Äôt receive the warm embrace of Italian cuisine and hospitality that she craved: ‚Äúthe interior is as brooding and formally unwelcoming as the staff‚Äù, the food‚Äùisn‚Äôt actively bad‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just defiantly mediocre‚Äù and ‚Äúwines are marked up with all the enthusiasm of a rogue plastic surgeon‚Äù.
‚ÄúCamillo Benso is a truly special place. It has the remarkable effect of making me feel retroactively better disposed towards Jamie‚Äôs Italian.‚Äù
until she visited Hicce, above a shop that‚Äôs just one of the ‚Äù ‚Äúcurated‚Äù brands residing among the elegant Victorian brick walkways ‚Äù of the new-look King‚Äôs Cross.
Hicce is, thankfully, an ‚Äúentirely separate entity, and a beautiful one, too‚Äù, with ‚Äù the feel of a capacious, repurposed Manhattan loft‚Äù.

The menu, split into lots of different sections, is ‚Äúchallenging‚Äù: ‚Äúeach dish is a cacophony of new flavour combos‚Äù such as mackerel with kumquats or squid with apple pork collar and reblochon. But she liked it ‚Äúvery much‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúcocktails are marvellous; the new, young, bright-eyed staff are warm and attentive‚Äù and Pip Lacey‚Äôs muscovado creme caramels are ‚Äúmagical‚Äù and ‚Äúlife-changing‚Äù. And that mackerel is ‚Äúan enjoyable, bittersweet slap across the face‚Äù. (25/30)

A word of warning, though: it‚Äôs a ‚Äúhectic, intensely casual experience‚Äùand a ‚Äúcommunal, clamorous, anathema-to-dining-traditionalists sort of a place‚Äù, possibly even a ‚Äúnoisy, churning scrum‚Äù.

The food offering is a ‚Äúcannily selected mixture of beloved outfits, covetable spin-offs and fledgling concepts‚Äù, with the exception of a few mis-hit dishes. Jimi recommended seasonal vegetable agebitashi¬†from Koya Ko (‚Äúa mottled, ginger-rammed wonder of a broth‚Äù), Devilled fried potatoes from¬†the Marksman¬†pub‚Äôs Bunshop (with ‚Äúan addictive, lip-prickling kick‚Äù) and pretty much everything from Roti King.¬†(7/10)
visited the new first-floor brasserie within ‚Äúaspirational department store‚Äù Selfridges (there‚Äôs also an entrance on Duke Street).

Brasserie of Light is ‚Äúthe latest offering from Richard Caring‚Äôs Caprice Holdings‚Äù ‚Äì effectively it‚Äôs ‚Äúanother Ivy but one under another name‚Äù ‚Äì and ‚Äúout-of-towners‚Äô delight‚Äù with ‚Äúan immense crystal sculpture [of Pegasus] by that triumphant chancer
‚Äú. In fact, ‚Äúno expense has been spared in making sure the brasserie delivers‚Äù, from interiors to the formally dressed staff.

Food ranged from ‚Äúnothing to startle‚Äù to ‚Äúreally good ‚Äù via ‚Äúenjoyable‚Äù (The Ivy ‚Äòs classic dishes have been omitted to make the place seem more upmarket) and drinks were ‚Äúfairly priced‚Äù. (****)

From ‚Äúmeltingly dreamy‚Äù scallops from the ‚ÄòCurious‚Äô menu and risotto that was ‚Äúfat cheesy blobs of pleasure‚Äù on the ‚ÄúSubtle‚Äù menu, everything at Caract√®re is ‚Äúreally good‚Äù ‚Äì they just don‚Äôt ‚Äù need the gimmick‚Äù with the menu. And ‚Äúthe ‚ÄòGreedy‚Äô puddings, incidentally, were excellent‚Äù. ¬†(****1/2)

magazine) was a little startled at the bill for 6 people at Casa Cruz, a three-year-old restaurant in Notting Hill (‚Äúwhere all the rich foreign weirdos who live round there go for dinner most nights‚Äù). It came to (just) over ¬£1000 ‚Äì ‚ÄúI think the other diners were as surprised and horrified as we were‚Äù.

Yes, ‚Äúit‚Äôs got a bowler-hatted doorman, copper walls, mirrors everywhere and is all kind of nightclubby‚Äù (or, alternatively, ‚ÄúMoscow karaoke brothel decor‚Äù), ‚Äúa glamorous owner‚Äù and celebrity clients, but is anything worth that bill? (9/30)

To help him recover from the shock, Giles ‚Äì what else? ‚Äì went to another restaurant, this time Shoreditch‚Äôs Leroy ‚Äúfor a swift hipster lunch‚Äù. visited the dining room above veteran Soho pub The French, ‚Äúthe anti-Wetherspoons, an idiosyncratically Gallic honeypot around which buzz Soho‚Äôs eternal fl√¢neurs‚Äù, where Neil Borthwick (ex-Merchants Tavern) ‚Äúrecently slipped in with the minimum of fuss‚Äù.
‚ÄúFrench bourgeois classics‚Äù are done brilliantly from a menu that‚Äôs ‚Äúshort, curt and to the point‚Äù, making for a ‚Äúgloriously old-fashioned lunch in a gloriously old-fashioned pub‚Äù.
in its ‚ÄúCharts of the Year‚Äù feature on 2018 said ‚ÄúDiners say ‚Äòno thanks‚Äô to high street chains: shops and restaurants alike suffered a difficult year marked by site closures‚Äù.

Well, the credit card bill from our New York trip has just arrived, and we see that ‚Äì in real money ‚Äì lunch for one at the latest outpost of New York‚Äôs biggest-name chef cost us all of ¬£31.77. (And that was at ¬£=$1.51.)
One of the great treats a leisure visitor to New York ‚Äì or to London, for that matter ‚Äì can enjoy is the top value offered by lunches, especially if you seek out the less obvious locations.

The setting of this latest addition to the Jean-Georges Vongerichten empire is certainly quite a surprise, as the literally correct description of its location ‚Äì the West Village ‚Äì doesn‚Äôt entirely prepare one for an airy ground floor of a new apartment building, whose large windows give a panoramic view of the West Side Highway.

The dining room ‚Äì which felt rather like a better proportioned version of St Alban ‚Äì seemed a bit odd initially, as we were the first luncher to arrive, but as the place filled up, which it largely did, it ‚Äòworked‚Äô surprisingly well.

For $48 all-in (including tip), we enjoyed two light and delicious courses ‚Äì essentially western, but presented with a degree of eastern sensibility ‚Äì as well as a splendid pudding, bread, coffee and two glasses of wine. Really nice touch: a special, short, lunchtime wine list offering wines by the glass at special prices, so you don‚Äôt destroy the whole budget-stretching virtues of a bargain set lunch menu.
Whatever the exchange rate may prove to be if one visits New York, this is a lunchtime destination well worth checking out.
On the Belgravia/Pimlico fringe, the former Ebury has been relaunched as a good-all-round bar/restaurant, offering food of no particular ambition, but realised with solid consistency.

It‚Äôs ‚Äòrather picniccy‚Äô¬ù, said the young Miss Harden. As good a word as you‚Äôre going to find to describe the bright and effortfully informal mismatched d√©cor of this large, light and airy Pimlico bar/restaurant, on the site long known as the Ebury. (Those with longer memories may recall it was once a pub where the highlight was stripper nights. How areas change.)

The same adjective could also be applied to the cuisine. This is, they say, intended to be a female-friendly sort of establishment, and the menu is long on snack-style dishes, including salads. That‚Äôs by no means to say they‚Äôre all lo-cal ‚Äì our chicken schnitzel and chips was very good on both counts, though the portions might not satisfy a true trencherman. Bread was very good too, and came in a nice variety, even if they do charge for it. Prepare yourself for a real sugar high, but the rhubarb roulade ‚Äì again, no real economiser on the calories ‚Äì was a real highlight of a visit in which none of three people found anything really to fault.

As the dishes we‚Äôve mentioned suggest, it‚Äôs clear that this is a place whose pretensions might be characterised as ‚Äòwholesome‚Äô rather than ‚Äòfoodie‚Äù and the friendly service is very much in keeping with the general tone. But what‚Äôs wrong with the sort of establishment which, back in Mrs Thatcher‚Äôs day, we might have described as a ‚Äòwine bar with food‚Äô? When everything‚Äôs done well, nothing in our book.

Zakudia, as you will know, is a Zambian word, meaning the enjoyment of food and drink. It‚Äôs also the name of this bar by Southwark Bridge, which is of note as the only non-chain outlet in a string of places to have opened over the last couple of years around Shakespeare‚Äôs Globe.

Stairs lead up from an office-like foyer to the first-floor bar. It‚Äôs a long, thin, low-ceilinged space, saved from feeling like a corporate conference chamber by a fabulous Thames panorama: from Tate Modern, past St Paul‚Äôs to Southwark Bridge itself.

At the arrival of the cocktail list and menu, my heart sank. While the former was a lavish full-colour production full of sexily-named enticements to kill off the rest of the day, the latter was a tatty photocopied sheet, with a selection ‚Äì notwithstanding the odd nod to Africa ‚Äì almost exclusively composed of standard bar and grazing fodder. A thirst-quencher arrived in the form of one of their fresh-fruit blends, which delivered a refreshing kick. The wine list being practically non-existent I opted for one of the two beers ‚Äì a Finnish Lapin Kulta ‚Äì whose distinguishing feature seemed to be a total lack of taste.

The arrival of my bread ‚Äì a huge plate with dips ‚Äì reinforced the notion that the grub here is just to soak up the brews. That said, it was tasty enough. Perfectly OK fishcakes and chips, for example, suggest that the food ‚Äì if not the main thing ‚Äì ‚Äúdoes the job‚Äù, and in generous portions to boot.

With its laid-back service and attractive-going-on-neutral modern decor there‚Äôs certainly nothing earth-shattering about Zakudia. With its fab views, easygoing charm and quality cocktails, though, this is a useful place to know about on the ever more-trendy South Bank strip.

was back in London this week after reviewing several remarkably low-priced restaurants across the UK. Scully is in direct contrast to those places ‚Äì ‚Äúthe only way you can get out of there for less than ¬£100 at dinner is by not doing it properly‚Äù.

‚ÄúBut oh my, it‚Äôs good.‚Äù It‚Äôs worth saving up for ‚Äúcitizen of everywhere‚Äù Ramael Scully‚Äôs ‚Äúravishing dishes‚Äù ‚Äì if it‚Äôs Jay‚Äôs current recommendation for the ‚Äúmust-go place in London‚Äù, just go, and don‚Äôt complain about the price, you were warned.

Ottolenghi-trained,Scully ‚Äúcooksfrom the broadest of larders‚Äùat this St James‚Äôs Market venture that has noticeable ‚Äúshine andpolish‚Äù ‚Äì the ‚Äúcrockery is in artful shades‚Äù and the chefs (visible in theopen kitchen, of course) have identical facial hair.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs with the first proper snack that the fireworks gobang‚Äù ‚Äì crispy beef tendon with oyster cream is ‚Äúumami squared‚Äù.It‚Äôs a ‚Äúvery meaty dish‚Äù that‚Äôs also clever ‚Äúmisdirection‚Äù:‚Äúthe menu at Scully is more interested in non-meat cookery than anythingwith a pulse‚Äù.

Jay ordered a range of dishes, but ‚Äúin retrospect‚Äù, hewould have been happier plotting ‚Äúa glorious non-meat route‚Äù throughthe menu. The meat and fish dishes were ‚Äúimpressive‚Äù and executedwith clear skill, but highlighted the fact that ‚Äúanimal protein in thecentre of the plate gives the kitchen a more straightforward ride‚Äù.

Veg-based delights included an ‚Äúexquisite‚Äù salad ofyellow and red tomatoes, strawberries, young coconut and edible flowers, with a‚Äúvivid sweet-sour dressing in shades of‚Ä¶ rust and green‚Äù. It was‚Äúthat very rare thing: a beautiful dish that is both worth looking at andworth eating‚Äù.
‚ÄúScully feels like a rarity, because here it is the cooking ‚Äì vivid, inventive, idiosyncratic ‚Äì that is front and centre.‚Äù

, first to visit the ‚Äúaesthetically splendid renovation‚Äù of Cheyne Walk Brasserie, still under the ownership of Sally Greene, who has ‚Äútransformed it into an elegant, grown-up safe space from life‚Äôs beastliness‚Äù. Not that many locals need protecting ‚Äì it‚Äôs noticeably quiet around there at weekends ‚Äì ‚Äúif you can afford to have it as your local, there‚Äôs a strong chance you have other homes to flee to come Friday‚Äù.

There‚Äôs now a ‚Äúwomb-like, windowless cocktail snug‚Äùand also a ‚Äúpanelled, bejewelled, sofa-strewn lounge‚Äù upstairs fromthe 70-seat French restaurant, which somehow creates the ‚Äúthe perfectstorm of very posh yet also pub-like‚Äù, helped enormously a the lack oftasting menu rigidity. It‚Äôs ‚Äúdefinitely romantic‚Äù, too, with‚Äújolly, prompt and unobtrusive‚Äù service.

You‚Äôre never left in doubt as to exactly where you are,though ‚Äì prices start at ‚Äúposh gastropub‚Äù and soar to ‚ÄúJesus Christ, howmuch?‚Äù in a very SW3 manner, but with portionsthat ‚Äúerred on the side of healthy, rather than stingy‚Äù to make upfor it.

All three starters ordered were ‚Äúquite brilliant‚Äù,with a Grace-pleasing vegan option that was a ‚Äústrongforay into the tricky world of dairy-free fine dining‚Äù.Mains, too were ‚Äúlargely faultless‚Äù ‚Äì Grace‚Äôs vegan dish of braisedhispi cabbage was a ‚Äúbold, rural romp‚Äùwhile her companion‚Äôs aged beef fillet with smoked bone marrow was‚Äúdictionary-definition largesse‚Äù. Desserts from the pastry chefincluded a ‚Äúperfectly executed‚Äù rhubarb concoction.

Corbin & King‚Äôs skill at creating restaurants ‚Äúwith instantaneous‚Äúhistorical‚Äù provenance‚Äù meant that she already can‚Äôt recall the site‚Äôspredecessors (most recently a Carluccio‚Äôs, in case you were wondering, and shelater remembered an All Bar One, aided by a Google search). Kathryn steppedinto an already ‚Äújumping‚Äù and clearly ‚Äúwildly successfulCorbin-and-Kingerie‚Äù.

Inside,Soutine is ‚Äúsmaller, woodier, more intimate‚Äù than The Wolseley, withsuch attention to ‚Äúevery pristine design detail‚Äù in the ‚Äúartsand crafts-inspired interior‚Äù that she felt ‚Äúas though I was walkingstraight into the 1890s‚Äù, and kept one eye out for ‚ÄúToulouse-Lautrecnodding out over a bottle of absinthe in the corner‚Äù.

‚ÄúThemenu is C&K at¬†their most comforting: it may be predominantly French,but no horses were frightened‚Äù ‚Äì or cooked. There‚Äôs the signature‚Äúfly-by nods to Mitteleuropa‚Äù too. Kathryn‚Äôs food ‚Äúsatisfiedperfectly (a hummingly minty puddle of great soup, a meltingly good duck, aproud cluster of perfectly stiff-upper-frites)‚Äù.

Teething troubles with hovering service, unavailable desserts andtop-heavy furniture are hardly worth mentioning, as they‚Äôll have been sortedbefore the real opening, and ‚Äúabsolutely on it‚Äù by now, a mere three weeks from launch. (****)

visited the Covent Garden newcomer that was so recently the hottest ticket in town ‚Äì or more accurately, the hottest queue in town ‚Äì for the famed xiao long bao. ‚ÄúIt is a measure of the warp-speed churn of modern news that the Mild Hysteria of¬†Din Tai Fung¬†already feels like it happened actual years ago.‚Äù

Everything else remains the same from that first flush of critics‚Äôvisits: the ‚Äúperspex aquarium kitchen‚Ä¶ with huddles of CSI-maskedtechnicians‚Äù, the ‚Äúthe exclusively cold starters‚Äù and ‚Äúthemain event‚Äù.

‚ÄúHeretical‚Äùas it may sound, Jimi‚Äôs ‚ÄòXLB‚Äô experience was ‚Äúa little underwhelming‚Äù‚Äì a ‚Äúmini gush of clean, richly seasoned soup‚Äù followed by ‚Äúmincedmeat that felt cheaply sausagey‚Äù. He much preferred the vegetarian jiao ziwith their ‚Äúpea-green colour, immaculately crimped edges and lastingmushroomy depth‚Äù and ‚Äúmassive plate‚Äù of crispy prawn and porkwontons.

Jimi‚Äôs maincourses were ‚Äúseasoned so faintly that any flavour was almost subliminal‚Äù,although he learned that this is deliberate: ‚Äúdishes are blank canvases,designed to be personalised with soy, vinegar and‚Ä¶ chilli oil‚Äù.Understandable, but just not his thing.

‚ÄúPrettysatisfying‚Äù puddings finished off the meal at this ‚Äúquick,neurotically controlled, slightly pricey canteen‚Äù that was populated with‚Äúgiddy tourists‚Äù and ‚ÄúEast Asian Londoners visibly savouring ataste of home‚Äù. (6/10)

this week that DTF are bringing their ‚Äúsignature salted egg yolk custard lava buns‚Äù to London ‚Äì but only 200 a day, and only at weekends. A cynic might suggest that they are trying to revive that early ‚ÄúMild Hysteria‚Äù‚Ä¶

has been busy ‚Äì it‚Äôs another three-review special. First up was Buoy & Oyster, the ‚Äúswanky new fish restaurant I ate in with my family on the beachfront at (beautiful) Margate‚Äù, ‚Äúall new and big and glass-fronted on the second floor above a fish shop‚Äù. 104 Restaurant has replaced ‚ÄúMarianne Lumb‚Äôs ratherexcellent little teen-weeny bijou Michelin-focused Notting Hill secret romanceplace‚Äù. Another diversion, and straight into his third review, XR,downstairs from Xier. ‚ÄúLike most places in Marylebone, XR is all a bitmonochromatically up itself‚Äù, but the food ‚Äúis colourful andperfectly okay‚Äù

was the first to visit this new, celebrity-backed Fitzrovia pub (formerly The Lukin); owned by Guy Ritchie and David Beckham, her first impression was that ‚Äúit looks like the sort of pub a rich man might have built on his estate to have somewhere to entertain friends‚Äù. Inside, everything has been ‚Äúexpensively stripped then dressed and distressed‚Äù, along a makeover theme of ‚Äúrusticity with a capital R‚Äù. But the ‚Äúwelcome is notably warm‚Äù.

TheLOTL is all pub downstairs; her companion describes the cask pale ale (brewedby the Gritchie BrewingCompany)as ‚Äúbright, freshand showing evidence of excellent conditioning‚Äù. The restaurant (with open kitchen, ofcourse) is upstairs, and centres around a sharing plates menu somewhat at oddswith the ‚Äúperiod feel‚Äù of the room.

Fromthe smaller plates (‚Äúbites‚Äù) section, her companion enjoyed the crusty sourdough with walnut,treacle and Marmite butter (‚Äúthe vegetarian‚Äôs answer to the lusciousnessand rigour of bone marrow?‚Äù). Other dishes had been ‚Äúsmashedabout‚Äù and liberally scattered with predictable pomegranate seeds.

Larger(‚Äúmeat‚Äù) dishes can be divided into undersized portions and‚Äúweird culinary decisions‚Äù, although the sticky lamb bun (Marksmaninspired?) was ‚Äúmuch liked‚Äù and the ‚Äúveg‚Äù dishes and retropuds more than made up for any disappointment.
The‚Äúwell-groomed food‚Äù is replaced on Sundays by roasts and food moresuited to the decor, suggesting a split personality that might need someattention. (***)

was in Belfast, at the recently remodelled James Street. His evening started poorly with no water, the wrong wine, and nothing that could be even loosely described as ‚Äòservice‚Äô, but it improved when his guest ‚Äì and a new waiter ‚Äì arrived.

visited this new St Andrews hotel restaurant in suitably bad weather ‚Äì a ‚Äòhaar‚Äô is cold sea fog on the East coast of Scotland. The restaurant (not the fog) is run by MasterChef: The Professionals 2019 finalist Dean Banks.

The interior is quite ‚Äúromantic‚Äù ‚Äì all ‚Äútactile velvety chairs, antiqued tiles and a suitably misty colour palette‚Äù. The food is ‚Äúquite pricey‚Äù (but there‚Äôs a good-value prix fixe option) and the menu is based around sharing plates of different sizes, apparently to ‚Äúeliminate food envy‚Äù, although Gaby still wanted what the other tables were having.

One smaller dish of Arbroath smokie was presented, smoking, under a glass cloche with ‚Äúa nice theatrical touch‚Äù (but the dish itself was oddly served chilled like ‚Äúsort of like a take on vichyssoise, except with seaweed‚Äù). North Sea cod and BBQ duck were ‚Äúlovely‚Äù.

Just two puddings were offered, which ‚Äúlooked beautiful‚Äù but maybe had too many touches of the ‚Äúpowder, foam or puree‚Äù style of cooking ‚Äì ‚Äúthe essence of banoffee had been exorcised. We saw its spirit drifting, to join the haar‚Äù. (75%)

gave a solid four stars to the ‚Äúmostly Mekong‚Äù cooking of his friend, chef Tania Knott, who hosts the current pop-up at Soho‚Äôs Sun & 13 Cantons‚Äô gastropub-guest-chef-carousel.
