Tom‚Äôs an expert in the region, of course, so could give us a proper analysis of the food, whose flavours ‚Äúshout and holler, jostling boisterously around the mouth‚Äù. There‚Äôs his trademark farmyard noises in the ‚Äúdeep, rich umami grunt‚Äù of the eponymous jeow (dipping sauce), and the declaration that Tania ‚Äúcaptures the spirit of Laotian food in every bite‚Äù.

He also ate a ‚Äúgloriouslarb with pork and brown crab meat‚Äù and a ‚Äúclean, lithe andbracingly sour‚Äù version with Arctic char, a ‚Äúproperly hot andstinky som tu‚Äù and ‚Äúbest of all‚Ä¶ a devilled lamb faggot‚Ä¶ in atamarind broth of delirious brilliance‚Äù.
‚ÄúJeow Jeow is a bracing blast of brow-beading, lip-smacking, palate-cheering delight. A little Mekong magic, in this most British of Soho pubs.‚Äù(****)
s is dominated by The Rich List. Maybe Marina O‚ÄôLoughlin will be back with restaurant recommendations for them all next week.

reviewers were travelling again, at Elkano in Spain (‚Äúprobably the best fish restaurant in the world‚Äù) that‚Äôs ‚Äúbeen serving exceptional fish since 1964‚Äù and Fagn in Trondheim, Norway, where the crustacea are caught ‚Äúabout 200m from your plate‚Äù and the food ensures ‚Äúa spiralling dive of flavour intoxication‚Äù.

, newly opened in Grand Central. restaurant: Freddy Bird has now left, and has been replaced by ‚Äúquite a formidable team with enormous experience‚Äù, including 2008 MasterChef winner James Nathan. that‚Äôs serving up‚Äúrestaurant-level food‚Äù with an ‚Äúirreverent attitude‚Äùand ‚Äúexpertly madecocktails‚Äù. The ‚Äúhottest new Bristol bar opening so far this year.It‚Äôs downright dirty in the best possible way.‚Äù

From an operator with some big-name experience behind him, a low-key fast-food chain-prototype, in Victoria, offering standards which ‚Äì at least in the early days ‚Äì are impressive.

Not a tweet, still less any reviews can we find: the opening of Scoffs seems to have been met with total media disinterest. Odd, really: until not so long ago, when this particular operator opened a new establishment, the food pages ‚Äì and even the gossip pages ‚Äì used to be filled with the news.

Who can it be? Ah yes, step forward Chris Hutcheson ‚Äì Gordon Ramsay‚Äôs father-in-law, and a man who really seems only to be of interest to the Daily Mail nowadays (and then more on account of his family affairs than his culinary ones).

Perhaps the lack of more general interest in the establishment is all to to with the modesty of the its aim ‚Äì this is clearly a ‚Äòfast food‚Äô joint, and in a dull (but improving) Victoria Street location. And the premises are pint-sized too ‚Äì we assumed the staircase led down to a dining room, but no it‚Äôs ‚Äòstaff only‚Äô.

Quite busy staff, too, on the basis of our lunchtime visit. The fare here may be relatively simple, and mainly served in boxes and cartons but there‚Äôs a good range of fresh and interesting (and sometimes moderately intricate) dishes. We enjoyed our spicey chicken salad, and the bean ‚Äòcassoulet‚Äô was pretty good too. A banana loaf, seemingly made on the premises, also pleased, as did a generous Americano.

Prices ‚Äì our meal came to around a tenner ‚Äì are somewhere around the Pret level, and standards broadly comparable (which, in our book, is a compliment). For a proto-chain, though, this struck us as a labour-intensive exercise: it‚Äôs going to be a challenge to maintain standards when the no-doubt intended ‚Äòroll-out‚Äô ensues.

. She admits to feeling ‚Äúproprietorial‚Äù about the chef, having been the first to review his reincarnation of his parents Pimlico restaurant in 2012, delighting in the ‚Äù¬†skill, wit, inventiveness, subversion and astonishment‚Äù of the dim sum (and, yes, she squeezes in mentions of Patio, Otto‚Äôs and Riva that regular readers will be only too familiar with).

is the latest critic to rock up at Tom Kerridge‚Äôs London outpost, and he (unsurprisingly) awarded the food a full five stars. Just four stars for the ambience, though ‚Äì he didn‚Äôt seem to love the ‚Äúgrandly pillared room that had been painstakingly pubbified‚Äù as much as his peers, and found the service ‚Äúslick, if a little clenched‚Äù.

The much-mentioned Claude‚Äôs mushroom risotto with Daniel‚Äôs crispy egg was ‚Äúa masterful, head-spinning balance of delicacy and gluttonous excess‚Äù. Butternut squash soup ‚Äúset off contrasting fireworks (salty! sweet! fragrant!) with every spoonful‚Äù. The mains have been much talked-about already: the trio of condiments that come with the ‚Äúcrunchy, hefty chips cooked with Hadron Collider precision‚Äù; the omelette lobster thermidor ‚Äúwe admired it from afar‚Äù; and rotisserie-cooked rib of beef ‚Äúdisappeared so quickly‚Äù.
Yes, it‚Äôs an ‚Äúunmistakable blockbuster‚Äù, featuring ‚Äúcooking with an exhilarating lack of compromise‚Äù but possibly too ‚Äúcraftily promoted and laser targeted‚Äù? ¬†(9/10)
visited Essex, and The Flitch of Bacon (‚Äúunder the purr of the Stansted flight path‚Äù), a fine-dining former pub from ex-Midsummer House chef Daniel

The dining room itself has been ‚Äúpurged of any historical features‚Äù, leaving a space that‚Äôs ‚Äúneutral, contemporary and comfortable‚Äù (and possibly a bit boring?) But the menu is ‚Äúexpertly balanced‚Äù, ‚Äútangibly grounded in hearty cuts of meat and fish‚Äù and ‚Äúarranged artfully‚Äù ‚Äì with not ‚Äúa single bum note‚Äù in the whole meal. visited the new home of ‚Äúintriguing half-Jamaican half-Scottish chef‚Äù James Cochran, the ‚Äúterrific cook‚Äù whose rights to his own name have been unfortunately (but quite legally) retained by his former backers.

There is ‚Äúan air of just-managed chaos‚Äù about this new place, with dishes arriving in ‚Äúa weird order‚Äù and service that ‚Äúcomes and goes‚Äù ‚Äì which is acceptable when the food is fantastic, but less so when ‚Äúsome are brilliant and some are total head-scratchers‚Äù. Luckily, overall ‚Äúthere‚Äôs enough interesting stuff going on here‚Äù for it to be a real problem.

Recommended dishes include jerk spiced hake (a ‚Äúbrave and brilliant dish‚Äù), caramelised cauliflower with fermented bagna cauda (‚Äúa pleasing bruiser‚Äù) and ‚Äì ‚Äúthe star dish‚Äù ‚Äì an ‚Äúumami bomb of pork fillet, topped with battered and deep-fried smoked eel‚Äù. Even desserts warrant a Rayner ‚ÄúOoh, yes please and thank you‚Äù.

hotel; possibly the less said about it, the better, but starters were ‚Äúminimum effort‚Äù affairs (‚Äúnothing more than shopping and assembly‚Äù), followed by ‚Äúa bunch of grills for the best part of ¬£30‚Ä≥ and desserts that are just a ‚Äù broken promise‚Äù. magazine went a little off-topic for a while (what‚Äôs new?), ruminating about the disproportionate number of Jewish restaurant critics. Near Liverpool Street, an airy, well-spaced and business-friendly contemporary restaurant offering Indian food of good quality; as at the parent establishment, the Cinnamon Club, however, prices give nothing away.

Airy and spacious, but darkly-furnished, there‚Äôs something very American about this new Indian restaurant near Liverpool Street. With its unconcealed ducting, it might, say, be a downtown NYC steakhouse.

This is, however, very much not a steakhouse, and the style of its refined Indian cuisine ‚Äì often described as being twinned with a European approach to presentation ‚Äì will be familiar to anyone who has ever eaten at the parent establishment, Westminster‚Äôs celebrated Cinnamon Club.

One almost wonders why it‚Äôs taken them so long to get here. The Cinnamon Club ‚Äì a brave opening seven years ago, in what to this day is something of a void for decent restaurants ‚Äì has always been known as quite a business/Establishment hang-out, so the City might seem to be a natural location for a second branch. The new premises certainly have plenty of space for business discussions, and service is friendly and discreet too.

You do pay for it all though. We visited a first few after opening, when a limited menu was still being offered, but prices were already pretty much in line with Westminster. In the short term, that‚Äôs a bit of a cheek ‚Äì if you‚Äôre not sorted out to the extent you‚Äôre offering a full menu, don‚Äôt charge full prices. Even when they are fully up and running though ‚Äì by now, presumably ‚Äì prices struck as as being too high to gather much of a following during a deepening recession. And the standard of the cooking was generally high, but not invariably so.
For lighter meals ‚Äì but then the food is pretty light to start with! ‚Äì you can also eat in the smart bar area, which trades as ‚ÄòAnise‚Äô.

Julie‚Äôs restaurant and champagne bar has finally announced a date to reopen, some four years after abruptly closing its doors.

The famous celebrity haunt shut to much dismay in 2015, and while the food was never all that great, it was long a favourite with locals and celebs alike ‚Äì as reporters attested, its ‚Äúcubbyholes saw a lot of action‚Äù.
But 2019 is approrpriate: the restaurant is now in its 50th year and it will relaunch this September. An announcement said it will do so while maintaining its ‚Äúrenowned celebrity atmosphere.‚Äù

And hey, if you were lingering on the food ‚Äì London dining, of course, being of an altogether different standard now than in the ‚Äô70s and ‚Äô80s, when Julie‚Äôs was in its heydey ‚Äì it has been addressed.
The Goring hotel dining room in January, has been brought in to oversee the menu. A former Michelin-star winner, his ‚Äúmodern British cuisine‚Äù may yet put Julie‚Äôs firmly back on the A-list map.

A plain Smithfield establishment on the former Rudland & Stubbs (RIP) site, bearing the name of a former Caprice group executive chef; our early-days sampling of the meat-heavy English menu showed signs of promise, but the performance overall struck us as complacent.

OK. So, for years, you‚Äôve been a chef of some eminence (if perhaps not quite a household name), but always cooking for other people (the Caprice group). You‚Äôve pumped out a cookbook a year in recent times, and write a newspaper column. You‚Äôve become something of a hero of the English culinary renaissance. And you finally decide it‚Äôs time to go it alone. The moment has come to launch an establishment with your own name above the door.

Where do you spend the weekend before the launch? In the kitchen, fine-tuning the menu? In the dining room anxiously ensuring everything is ready to receive the punters? Or perhaps on a stepladder outside, making sure they‚Äôve got your name up right? Er, no. If you‚Äôre Mark Hix, you spend it at a conference in New Orleans.

This single fact tells you almost everything you need to know about the priorities of the modern chef/media persona. It doesn‚Äôt matter that you‚Äôre on the very brink of opening your first solo restaurant, bearing your very own name ‚Äì what‚Äôs most important is to be off hob-nobbing with other foodie luminaries.

Now, if Mr Hix‚Äôs Smithfield restaurant had actually been ready to open, firing on all cylinders, on the appointed day, such commentary would be irrelevant. But, even towards the end of the first week, its performance was still very ragged indeed. The table layout was still being tinkered with, service was still very slow (and notably disjointed), and deliveries (such as that all-important ironing board) were still being received through the front door.

Mr Hix‚Äôs contribution? Well, obviously, he was swanning around the dining room, lapping up the adulation from his mates in the trade for the undoubted success he clearly presumes this will be. So far as we could see, such friends got ‚Äòcomped‚Äô (ie their bills torn up). As the early-days feeling of the enterprise so clearly called for the sort of first-week/soft-opening discount which is pretty common nowadays, we therefore awaited the arrival of our own reckoning with particular interest.

No luck: full prices already, undeservedly, being charged. And it‚Äôs not as if some of the prices couldn‚Äôt stand a bit of pruning. A ¬£6.75 pudding, for example, comprised a ‚Äòscone‚Äô (pancake), a small ball of ice cream and some honey. And, if you‚Äôre running a (full-price) Oyster & Chop house, shouldn‚Äôt you already have your sourcing sorted out, to the extent that you can offer a ‚Äòchoice‚Äô of more than two types of oyster?

The actual quality of what we consumed was actually pretty good, but ‚Äì though meat was impressive ‚Äì there was little remarkable about our meal. A pennywort ‚Äòsalad‚Äô was composed of items presented together, rather than having been brought together, and an incidental dish of bubble ‚Äòn‚Äô squeak was totally without interest.
So, from us, rather a guarded welcome for Mr Hix‚Äôs newcomer. Let‚Äôs just hope it settles in to be as good as he clearly expects it‚Äôs going to be.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.
A no-nonsense English bistro, near Camden Town tube; a friendly sort of place, it offers plain cooking - in a style which, until recently, might have been called domestic - at reasonable prices.

First, in the early 90s, we had what we now call gastropubs. By the late-90s, a retro-style of English cooking was beginning to evolve (or, more accurately, be rediscovered), which might be described - for want of any better term - as gastropub-style cooking. Then, by the mid-00s, people were beginning to figure out that there wasnt any

Recent times have seen the creation of establishments such as 32 Great Queen Street, which - being asssociated with the famous Anchor & Hope - has all the style of a gastropub, but no pub. In a different way, the smart modernist Canteen chain has also made quite a success by disassociating gastropub-style cooking from the gastropub-style environment.

And so things go full circle, and we now see establishments such as Market, which is for all the world like a classic no-nonsense Gallic bistro (or caf√©, as the French might call it), except for the fact that everything about it is resolutely English.  Mackerel p√É¬¢te n toast, pollack n chips, fruit crumble n custard - thats the sort of fare you find done here. And all - on the basis of our lunch for three - consistently done very well here.

OK, they seated a table for 20 just before we came into this large pizzeria. But the number of would-be Saturday lunchers we saw turned away suggests that this South Kensington newcomer would have been jam-packed anyway.

So what are the attractions? Well, friendly staff with a can-do attitude make up one part of the package. And the lofty and spacious interior is smartly decked out too, if in the slightly bland sort of way that says this hopes to be a chain one day. The food is rather in keeping with the d√©cor, but the pizzas and pastas were generally reasonably satisfying.

So ‚Äòjust‚Äô a goodish all-rounder, then. But a reasonably priced one too, in an area that is rather lacking in such things at the moment. (There‚Äôs no PizzaExpress, for example, within easy walking distance.)
An intended co-launch at Westfield ‚Äì where, we‚Äôre told, there‚Äôs quite a lot of competition ‚Äì has apparently been put on hold.
A smash hit in the making, this NYC-Downtown-chic Italian offers perfectly judged tapas/small-plate dishes in an atmosphere of old-style Soho conviviality.
We keep reading that this much-lauded Soho newcomer ‚Äì fronted by Russell Norman, once a bigwig at the Caprice group ‚Äì is some sort of Venetian snack bar (or, to impress you with our research,
). Has anyone looked at it? This is a New York restaurant, pure and simple. Or, more specifically, a Downtown restaurant.

The only wonder is that it‚Äôs taken so long for this particular style of deconstructed chic to make the jump from SoHo to Soho: Polpo immediately reminded us a of a particular SoHo-fringe operation, Peasant, which opened as long ago as 2000. Mr Norman readily admits such restaurants (if not that specific one) have provided just as much inspiration for him as anything in La Serenissima, and will even tell you the name of the particular firm of Big Apple architects whose work has inspired him: Avroko.

True to the Avroko spirit, Norman has opened up some beautifully distressed brickwork (heading for three centuries old), and some tiles (we‚Äôd guess Victorian) to create an interior which ‚Äì though on a modest scale compared to many Downtown establishments ‚Äì has a rather similar vibe. As in NYC, that vibe manages to be trendy but not exclusive. We couldn‚Äôt help noticing how, in the pretty much full house by 1pm, there were lots of people ‚Äì yes, even including old people -who weren‚Äôt classic modern-times Soho lunchers at all. Early days, but the tone may well last.

It isn‚Äôt just the styling, of course (not generally commented on in the very positive early-days reviews elsewhere) which is responsible for the crush, but also the much-complimented food. Not that the cuisine is in any way astonishing, it‚Äôs just that it is generally very well done, and amazingly, well,

. The cicheti (Italian tapas) are very tasty, as well as remarkably economical. The highlight for us (lunching in the singular) was a delicious pile of green tapenade on a piece of toasted bread, but arancini (rice balls) also satisfied. To follow, fegato alla Veneziana, a small but very adequate dish for around ¬£6, was well complemented by a plate of zucchini dressed with olive oil. Add a plate of roast autumn fruits (the best dish, dressed with a sprinkle of crumble), and you‚Äôve still, with modest wine, had a very pleasant lunch for ¬£25. Which may be another reason the place is already humming.

The obvious problem is that, with value like this, either prices will rise or tables will be impossible to get. Or both. So how long till the successor restaurant? As you‚Äôve probably gathered, this is not the sort of place where a known reviewer is likely to be able to maintain any sort of anonymity, so we can tell you what Mr Norman told us ‚Äì start looking out for number two some time next year.
It‚Äôs stressful choosing a restaurant for friends. If you write about restaurants for a living, then mates are not generally especially forgiving when you take them somewhere that‚Äôs rubbish.

This Indian caf√© on Hammersmith‚Äôs scruffy main drag certainly doesn‚Äôt impress visually. With its tiny shop-conversion premises, I could see the thought bubbles over my guests‚Äô heads: ‚Äòwhy the hell are we here?‚Äô¬ù Even the assured charm of the single waiter did nothing to dispel a general flatness of mood.

And then our first starters arrived: small cups of puri filled with a spicy vodka sauce. Eating them initially produced coughs and splutterings, which quickly morphed into big beamy smiles all round. Phew, all was going to be OK. But actually OK would in no way do justice to the cooking here.

Gowtham Karingi has cooked at Veeraswaamy and Zaika, and his food avoids the westernised feeling of some ‚Äònouvelle Indian‚Äô cuisine. I‚Äôll spare you the blurb about the ayurvedic principles behind Agni (which means ‚Äòfierce determination‚Äô). Suffice it to say, for intelligent, flavour-packed cuisine, this is the real thing.

The menu combines brilliant realisations of old favourites with more exciting evolved dishes. Starters included some excellent chaat and delicious fried squid.  Among the main dishes, the stand-outs were Fish Balchao ‚Äì where tilapia fish had been cooked in a beautifully-spiced sauce ‚Äì and a deeply intense lamb curry (it‚Äôs Roghan Josh Jim, but not as we know it). Unusually for any kind of Indian restaurant, the best was kept till last with a magnificent finale of red chilli ice cream.

If the proof of the pudding is in the eating though, perhaps the true success of the evening was that my friends were so delighted they picked up the bill. At least I‚Äôd chosen somewhere for them with bargain prices.

A King‚Äôs Road pub, relaunched ‚Äì and much tarted-up ‚Äì by the Martin brothers (of Gun etc fame); the food can be pretty good, but we do wonder if ‚Äì as an eating place ‚Äì the formula quite ‚Äòworks‚Äô.

, on the Isle of Dogs, back in 2004, Tom and Ed Martin have become leading lights in London‚Äôs gastropub/English bistro scene. (It seems to us that this is a distinction that‚Äôs becoming pretty much irrelevant: many pubs are now really informal restaurants, and some restaurants are now adopting ‚Äògastropub‚Äô style. What, apart from architecture, is the meaningful distinction between the two?)

Originally thought of as East End operators, the brothers are coming progressively West into what‚Äôs arguably their more natural ‚Äì which is to say, affluent ‚Äì heartland. After all, once you‚Äôve turned a corner of Sloane Square into a money-making machine ‚Äì how we wished we owned

Well, now the brothers have ventured into Chelsea proper, opening the Cadogan Arms as their eighth establishment. Like all their old boozers, it‚Äôs been made a bit squeaky-clean in a way that isn‚Äôt necessarily totally congenial. That‚Äôs not to deny, however, that the overall effect is smart, and comfortable enough: as much like a spruced up gentleman‚Äôs club as a pub (and, indeed, there are some billiard tables upstairs). The service, however, is matey, in an Antipodean sort of way.

The menu is more in keeping with the d√©cor than the service.  Though shorter than the one at the frankly brasserie-like Botanist, just up the road, it‚Äôs not so different in style, which is to say it is not notably pubby at all. Our meal for one included some good and interesting bread, an elegant pea soup, a pretty good cheesecake and a decent espresso. The only dull moment was a rather salty chicken pie, with an unimpressive hat, which came with a slick of not especially appealing mash.

Despite food that‚Äôs ‚Äì on balance ‚Äì pretty good, however, we do have some questions whether, in a part of town which does not want for ‚Äòproper‚Äô restaurants,  this non-pubby pub really quite works as a concept. The boys‚Äô success to date, however, suggests it probably will.

There‚Äôs no Sheldon Square in the A-Z, or on streetmap.co.uk. All I could tell from the Yakitoria press release was that it was at the heart of the ginmormous new development that looms over the A40 by Paddington Station.

Expecting a faceless corporate jungle, I was pleasantly amazed by the whole area. You leave the rear of Paddington Station (by the Hammersmith & City line), to join a network of recently-built paths around the Grand Union canal, some areas of which have apparently been opened for the first time in 200 years. In less than 10 minutes, you can now stroll from Paddington into impossibly cute Little Venice.

And on the way, you pass this chic-looking new Japanese. Huge picture windows give the ground floor (there‚Äôs also a basement) a fine view of the canal, while the very airy interior is a stylish medley of slate, dark-stained timber, and green velvet drapes. If I hadn‚Äôt known that it was the creation of a Russian restaurant group, I would have thought that it was a third opening by Rainer Becker of Roka and Zuma fame.

The fashionable Japanese menu is reminiscent of Roka‚Äôs with its emphasis on skewers from the charcoal robata grill, alongside a wide selection of sushi and main dishes. I went for a catholic selection incorporating five kinds of skewer and some trendy sounding ‚Äòspicey red-eye‚Äô and ‚Äògarden‚Äô sushi ‚Äî the former spiked with chilli pepper, the latter using ingredients like burdock. None of the items were disappointing, but equally all fell short of being inspirational.

Service was charming but a little keystone kops-ish (or whatever it is that Russians say for being disorganised and amateurish). Surely they can sort that out? Because if they can, the beautiful interior, picturesque setting and decent food are a strong incentive to venture a stroll in Paddington Waterside.

On the 33rd floor of the Shard, an ambitious Chinese restaurant that was still giving a slight impression of settling in on our visit; we had an enjoyable lunch, though, and prices are not unreasonable, considering.

It used to be easy. High-rise restaurants in London were few, small and expensive, and everyone knew they were primarily there to rip off tourists, birthday celebrants and romantics. Yet, as London reaches for the stars, such restaurants have suddenly become so numerous as to seem almost unremarkable. Take the lift to the 33rd floor of the Shard, for example, and you find a complex comprising not one but two Aqua-group restaurants (Aqua Shard, British in style, as well as Hutong), and also a brasserie-style operation (Oblix) run by Rainer Becker of Zuma fame ‚Äì the bars and dining rooms can accommodate hundreds of guests in total. (And that‚Äôs before a Shangri-La hotel opens in the same building at the end of the year.)

The landlords must have been cutting good deals, because space is used at these new establishments in a lavish way which those of us used to the West End‚Äôs cosy ways can find it difficult to adjust to. Indeed, these vast air-conditioned expanses often just feel rather dead. And how can the actual dining rooms compete with the views, anyway? On our daytime visit, none of the Shard restaurant interiors filled us with any great excitement. Of the three, however, we suspect that the dark and dimly-lit interior of Hutong ‚Äì the swankiest of the establishments ‚Äì is the one that would work best by night. By day, leaving the view out of the reckoning, we felt as if we were lunching in one of the more upmarket of Mr Disney‚Äôs resort-hotel dining rooms (and not an especially comfortable one either).

The dim sum menu ‚Äì not especially helpfully divided up, in the way you‚Äôd find in Chinatown ‚Äì seemed a good place to try a range of tastes, but the affable waiter steered us to the pre-chosen steamed selection from the main menu. These came prettily colour coded, not something we can really recall before, but the differences of hue among the selection was more pronounced than the differences of taste ‚Äì in every other way they hit the spot, though, and they certainly delivered quite a chilli kick.

Duck in two services was impressive ‚Äì the first service very definitely not the dried-out shreds so typically found, but elegantly pink slices ‚Äì and even better than we remember from the (merely) 10th floor operation at the excellent Min Jiang, in Kensington. By then we were pretty much full, so pudding was steamed custard buns, presented as mice or, quite possibly porcupines ‚Äì quite amusing, though the taste was not particularly remarkable.

With a couple of glasses (125ml) of wine apiece ‚Äò‚Äù Austrian for the white, and Hungarian for the red ‚Äì plus a pair of rather ordinary espressos (the altitude perhaps?), the bill of an enjoyable lunch came to just over ¬£100 for the two of us. Given the setting ‚Äì with St Paul‚Äôs, in particular, looking very lovely in the sunshine ‚Äì it was a cost hard to begrudge.

On the Belgravia/Pimlico fringe, the former Ebury has been relaunched as a good-all-round bar/restaurant, offering food of no particular ambition, but realised with solid consistency.

Its rather picniccy¬ù, said the young Miss Harden. As good a word as youre going to find to describe the bright and effortfully informal mismatched d√©cor of this large, light and airy Pimlico bar/restaurant, on the site long known as the Ebury. (Those with longer memories may recall it was once a pub where the highlight was stripper nights. How areas change.)

The same adjective could also be applied to the cuisine. This is, they say, intended to be a female-friendly sort of establishment, and the menu is long on snack-style dishes, including salads. Thats by no means to say theyre all lo-cal - our chicken schnitzel and chips was very good on both counts, though the portions might not satisfy a true trencherman. Bread was very good too, and came in a nice variety, even if they do charge for it. Prepare yourself for a real sugar high, but the rhubarb roulade - again, no real economiser on the calories - was a real highlight of a visit in which none of three people found anything really to fault.

As the dishes weve mentioned suggest, its clear that this is a place whose pretensions might be characterised as wholesome rather than foodie and the friendly service is very much in keeping with the general tone. But whats wrong with the sort of establishment which, back in Mrs Thatchers day, we might have described as a wine bar with food? When everythings done well, nothing in our book.

In the heart of Mayfair, a very useful corner gastropub, open 365 days a year; sibling to the House (Islington) and Bull (Highgate), it offers similarly solid cooking, and ‚Äì in this part of town ‚Äì the prices demanded for it seem eminently reasonable!

It‚Äôs not just in Mayfair that there are still ‚Äì yes, still ‚Äì far too few decent places for an unpretentious, affordable meal. All credit then to this corner gastropub newcomer ‚Äì from the same stable as the House and the Bull ‚Äì which not only offers precisely that formula, but is promising to do it 365 days a year.

We stopped by a for a quick lunch in the ground floor bar (largely given over to tables). It‚Äôs had a bit of a makeover, but the most eye-catching thing about  the place ‚Äì some of whose windows have false bottle-glass ‚Äì is that it still feels as if it should be in a Surrey high street, rather than one of the priciest postcodes in the world. Perhaps that‚Äôs part of its charm. The crowd on the day of our visit was also less glitzy than such a location might suggest.

The editorial ‚Äòwe‚Äô in this case comprised just one luncher, and we just had a quick lunch of haddock ‚Äòn‚Äô chips, treacle tart and coffee. Perhaps we were just lucky, but it really was just the job. The chips were particularly interesting. Fat chips can be horrible, but these were exemplarily moreish in both their taste and their crispy texture. The tart also rated mention, steering that difficult middle course between being heavy handedly rustic on the one hand and too poncey on the other. Incidentals such as bread (made, for once, on the premises) and coffee were also well up to scratch.
The only problem, we suspect, is that this thoroughly useful but quite small place ‚Äì open all day as well as all year ‚Äì is going to be far too popular at peak times.

Julie‚Äôs restaurant and champagne bar has finally announced a date to reopen, some four years after abruptly closing its doors. The famous celebrity haunt shut to much dismay in 2015, and while the food was never all that great, it was long a favourite with locals and celebs alike ‚Äì as reporters attested, its ‚Äúcubbyholes [‚Ä¶]

A case-study in ‚Äòhow not to do a restaurant opening‚Äô (and that was leaving aside the ultra-mean portions); the design of this City newcomer is great, but is the current environment going to be receptive to this ostentatious spin-off from a West End original that was never such a ‚Äòrave‚Äô in the first place?

It‚Äôs a question restaurant reviewers ask themselves (and each other) a lot. Our attitude can be summarised, ‚Äòif you‚Äôre charging full prices, expect to be judged accordingly‚Äô¬ù. So we were a little nonplussed by the performance of this pricey City newcomer.

Not an accusation you could level, by the way, at the design. Perhaps stung by the comparisons its dusky West End forebear has drawn to Hakkasan, the style here ‚Äì and they‚Äôve spent a packet on it ‚Äì avoids dark hues for a light colour scheme. A large shimmering bar dominates the space, which is cleverly subdivided into a cocktail area and a main dining area, saving the room from feeling like the box it basically is. Who‚Äôd have thought a few years ago that you‚Äôd get a place like this somewhere as boring as Angel Court?
We had been warned at the time of booking that full restaurant service was not yet available. However, having checked out the bar menu, we‚Äôd decided to press on regardless. More fool us.

Perched on plush white leather in the luxurious bar, it quickly became apparent to us that our rather beautiful waitress had no great command of English, or, indeed, any feeling at all for what she was serving. ‚ÄòCobra‚Äô¬ù, she explained ‚Äì unwrapping for us an arcane mystery of the East ‚Äì ‚Äòis an Indian beer‚Äô¬ù.

Don‚Äôt blame her, though. Blame the powers that be, who ‚Äì in a top dollar joint like this ‚Äì should have given her a bit more basic training. They should also, while they were at it, have made sure that the coffee and credit card machines were working, and avoided the numerous interruptions by various members of staff updating us on their bungling progress in trying to rectify matters.

And the food? OK, this was the bar menu. Even allowing for this, portions are outrageously dinky. A ¬£6.50 portion of asparagus, involved maybe two spears (or was it three?) pretentiously chopped up and served skewered by multiple cocktail sticks on a tiny little mound of coconut rice ‚Äì the sort of portion you might feed to a mouse in a cartoon. Stuffed peppers? ¬£7!

A ¬£28 seafood sharing platter for two might have fed two Lilliputians, but for two regular-sized adults it looked so tiny, we initially presumed it was for just one of us, and they were about to go back for the same again. What a hoot! One cute, litte spicy seafood parcel each. But how to divide the last of the three prawns? If they wanted to starve us, at least they could do so with evenly numbered bites. And, yes folks, that‚Äôs over ¬£5 per morsel.

The chef came over earnestly to enquire what we thought. So we told him. The food is really enjoyable, spicey, carefully put together, but there just ain‚Äôt enough of it. He nodded, said he might make some changes, and scuttled off looking a bit uncertain.
Needless to say, no one dreamt of offering us anything off the bill, despite being new customers who couldn‚Äôt have made their underwhelm-ment clearer.

The value equation here would be extremely doubtful even had we had the slickest of experiences. But the casual arrogance with which some operators expect customers to pay top dollar for their learning curve is baffling. Haven‚Äôt they heard of opening-month discounts? Or, if you‚Äôre going to rip people off, couldn‚Äôt you at least do it competently?
A classic Gallic brasserie style St James‚Äôs newcomer, on the former Fiore (RIP) site; despite some auspicious backing, it falls surprisingly flat across the board.
**Note (27 June): We hear that, since this review was written, the ‚Äòlaunch‚Äô chef has left, and Pierre Koffmann himself is ‚Äì at least for the time being ‚Äì in charge of the stoves.**

If you know who‚Äôs ‚Äòbehind‚Äô a forthcoming restaurant, you‚Äôre unlikely to go that far wrong as to what the end product is like. So if you know that a new brasserie is to be opened by Claudio Pulze (whose 50 previous establishments include everything from Aubergine and Zafferano) you expect something pretty useful. And all the more so when he‚Äôs in league with Pierre Koffmann.

Koffmann may not be a household name nowadays, but ‚Äì if you take out the empire-building, self-promoting and foul-mouthed bits ‚Äì he was the Gordon Ramsay of the nineties. His Tante Claire restaurant ‚Äì on the site now the Ramsay HQ ‚Äì was invariably London‚Äôs best. Then he moved TC to the Berkeley Hotel site which is now P√©trus, and didn‚Äôt prosper. He dropped out of sight for a while, and his return has long been rumoured.

Amazingly, however, almost everything about the new restaurant manages to some extent to be wrong. It doesn‚Äôt help that this is a site with poor proportions, and a bit of a chequered history to boot. (To make it all the more confusing, it‚Äôs not so long ago that it was called P√©trus.) It‚Äôs been done over as a straight down-the-line Gallic brasserie which, without any patina of age, just looks a little bit cold and univiting.

The service was often pleasant, but it seemed to come and go rather. And couldn‚Äôt the waiter have mentioned we were over-ordering? Our main dish came not only with the spuds and greens we had ordered, but also with some unadvertised rice and vegetables which, as it turned out, were included anyway. It added insult to injury when the unnecessary bowl of spinach came at ¬£1 per teaspoonful.

Pretty decent bread included a good pain de campagne. Unfortunately, however, this was also served as the complement to the foie gras terrine, when the traditional brioche would have been infinitely better. A main course of kidneys was perfectly workmanlike, but ‚Äì for ¬£16 ‚Äì didn‚Äôt have the feeling of coming with a great deal of Tante Claire heritage, even if, garnished, it arguably made a decent-value dish, at least by St James‚Äôs standard. The same could not be said of the uninviting, soggy rum baba.

So, ¬£60 for a pretty basic lunch for one, with two glasses of wine and one cup of coffee. Regular readers will know we‚Äôre big brasserie fans, but we can‚Äôt say this is one we‚Äôll be rushing back to.

Wine, dine and then recline. It‚Äôs a perfect combination. After all, how often have each of us wished we weren‚Äôt facing a car ride or train journey home after a great meal? But ‚Äòrestaurants-with-rooms‚Äô are more than just convenient, they are destinations. A way to get out of the city or to celebrate an occasion and, of course, to experience dining out as part of a total experience ‚Äì always more difficult among the clamour of competing attractions in a city. So, this week, we bring you some of the best restaurants-with-rooms.

‚ÄúAbsolutely perfect, not cheap but worth it‚Äù ‚Äì the cost issue may be ever-present, but Raymond Blanc‚Äôs ‚Äúfabulous‚Äù manor house hotel and restaurant remains THE destination for those in search of a ‚Äúfantastic all-round experience‚Äù; make sure you leave time for ‚Äúwandering round the garden‚Äù.

‚ÄúDeservedly a legend‚Äù; for reporters of a more traditional bent, ‚Äúnothing can beat‚Äù the Roux family‚Äôs ‚Äúperfect‚Äù Thames-side haven; ‚Äúshocking‚Äù prices notwithstanding, it‚Äôs the ideal destination to mark a major birthday or anniversary‚Ä¶ or ‚Äúone‚Äôs investiture at Windsor Castle‚Äù.

‚ÄúThis ‚Äúravishing‚Äù Palladian country house hotel offers a ‚Äúfantastic experience, starting from the second you walk through the door‚Äù; Hywel Jones‚Äôs cooking is ‚Äútop class‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äújust what an award winning restaurant should be about‚Äù.

‚ÄúMichael Wignall‚Äôs ‚Äúphenomenal‚Äù food (with ‚Äúinventive combinations‚Äù and ‚Äúsuperlative attention to detail‚Äù) is beginning to put this ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù and ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù country house hotel dining room very firmly on the map; the experience? ‚Äì ‚Äúnot too stuffy‚Ä¶ but formal enough to feel special!‚Äù

‚ÄúThe best place to eat in Scotland‚Äù (and, for some reporters, ‚Äúin the UK‚Äù too) ‚Äì a visit to Andrew Fairlie‚Äôs ‚Äúdark‚Äù dining room, within the famous Edwardian golfing hotel, is summarised in almost all reports as an experience that can only be described as ‚Äúphenomenal‚Äù.

‚ÄúAn extraordinary experience in all respects!‚Äù; this culinary Shangri-La ‚Äì again, the UK‚Äôs foodie No. 1 ‚Äì occupies a plush Tudorbethan mansion, set in ‚Äúglorious‚Äù scenery (and gardens), on a remote fringe of Dartmoor; Michael Caines‚Äôs ‚Äúbeautifully crafted‚Äù cuisine is ‚Äúunbelievably excellent‚Äù, and matched with a ‚Äúvast selection‚Äù of unusual wines.

‚ÄúA blissful oasis‚Äù; this imposing country house hotel offers a ‚Äúrelaxing and top class experience‚Äù combining Charlie Lockley‚Äôs ‚Äúoutstanding‚Äù cuisine, with ‚Äúexcellent and very obliging‚Äù service, in a ‚Äúvery elegant‚Äù setting.

‚ÄúThe finest fish restaurant in the UK‚Äù, according to this year‚Äôs survey ‚Äì Nathan Outlaw takes ‚Äúzingingly fresh‚Äù seafood and treats it ‚Äúwith respect and intelligence‚Äù, to create ‚Äúsimple, yet beautifully crafted‚Äù dishes; the interior is a touch ‚Äúanodyne‚Äù, but the views of the Camel estuary are ‚Äúfabulous‚Äù.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a delight to watch the experts at work‚Äù, and to sample Matthew Gillan‚Äôs ‚Äúdivine‚Äù and ‚Äúinspiring‚Äù 7-course menu, say fans of a dining room which seems ‚Äúvery modern‚Äù in the setting of this 19th-century country house hotel ‚Äì Lord Grantham would certainly not approve of the way the chefs pass dishes directly to diners!

‚ÄúMaintaining the highest standards in all respects‚Äù, this long-established manor house restaurant-with-rooms Messrs Bancroft and Haworth‚Äôs ‚Äúflagship‚Äù impresses almost all who report on it with its ‚Äúsuperbly executed‚Äù menu, its ‚Äúold-fashioned customer service‚Äù and its ‚Äúextensive‚Äù selection of wines.

‚ÄúA wonderful riverside setting, a relaxed yet discreetly attentive atmosphere and food that takes eating to an altogether different plane‚Äù ‚Äì the many reports on Chris & Judy Bradley‚Äôs ‚Äúfantastic‚Äù restaurant-with-rooms remain quite remarkable in their consistency.

A ‚Äúbeautiful location on a peninsular jutting into Rutland Water‚Äù sets the scene for Tim Hart‚Äôs ‚Äúimpeccable‚Äù (and slightly ‚Äústiff‚Äù) country house hotel, where Aaron Patterson‚Äôs ‚Äúcomplex‚Äù and ‚Äúwonderfully confident‚Äù cooking achieves an ‚Äúutterly consistent‚Äù standard.

Simon Rogan‚Äôs sheer ‚Äúartistry‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúmixing innovation, tradition and local produce‚Äù in an ‚Äúastonishing range‚Äù of dishes, delivered by ‚Äúpassionate‚Äù staff ‚Äì produces one of the UK‚Äôs most ‚Äúdivine‚Äù culinary experiences, at this ‚Äúbeautiful and remote‚Äù former Lakeland smithy.

‚ÄúOMG, what truly amazing food‚Äù!; Frances & Gerald Atkins‚Äôs grand inn is a ‚Äúpicture-postcard building‚Äù with a ‚Äúbeautiful location‚Äù in a ‚Äúquiet Dales village‚Äù; for once it‚Äôs Mrs who‚Äôs the chef, and her ‚Äúbrilliant attention to detail‚Äù shines through in ‚Äúperfect‚Äù seasonal cuisine.

‚ÄúUnder the flyover and pylons is a strange setting‚Äù for this renowned restaurant-with-rooms, near the city limits; Sat Bains is ‚Äúa really down-to-earth guy‚Äù, but his cooking is ‚Äústunning‚Äù and ‚Äúcontinually surprising‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúinventive without being plain stupid‚Äù; ‚Äúit‚Äôs expensive for the Midlands‚Äù (and this location) however.

‚ÄúFast becoming a destination of choice‚Äù once again ‚Äì this rural restaurant-with-rooms (in the middle of nowhere) is re-establishing its reputation for ‚Äúall-round excellence‚Äù, with ‚Äúdivine‚Äù cuisine and all-round attention to detail; even fans, however, note prices are a bit ‚Äúdaft‚Äù.

‚ÄúFor a ‚Äúluxurious experience‚Äù full of ‚Äúold-fashioned graciousness‚Äù, this ‚Äúcomfy‚Äù (if windowless) dining room ‚Äì in an unusually grand hotel, next to the city‚Äôs iconic Eastgate clock ‚Äì makes a fine destination; service is ‚Äúimmaculate‚Äù and the cuisine ‚Äúconsistently first class‚Äù (with a ‚Äúmassive‚Äù wine list to go with it).

‚ÄúA true find‚Äù with food ‚Äúreally to shout about‚Äù; Bryan & Susan Webb‚Äôs ‚Äúsuper-comfortable‚Äù (‚Äútraditional‚Äù and quite ‚Äúlow key‚Äù) rural bolthole wins acclaim for the ‚Äúinspired simplicity‚Äù of its cooking (served in ‚Äúcomforting-sized portions‚Äù) and ‚Äúexcellent wine list‚Äù.

‚ÄúFish simply-served‚Äù and ‚Äúseafood as it should be‚Äù ‚Äì Rick Stein‚Äôs ‚Äúoutstanding‚Äù but ‚Äúunpretentious‚Äù (and sometimes rather ‚Äúcramped‚Äù) waterside HQ has waxed and waned over the years, but is currently on a high ‚Äì ‚Äúas devoted fans of his on TV, this place is The Holy Grail for us, and it was everything we hoped for!‚Äù

‚ÄúA ‚Äúhigh class‚Äù of cooking that‚Äôs ‚Äúunexpectedly good‚Äù wins top marks for this ‚Äúcharming and historic‚Äù inn, which has ‚Äúexceptional staff to boot‚Äù; some nights see the service only of a simple bar menu, but it‚Äôs ‚Äústill good‚Äù.

‚ÄúA little bit of chintz and old-fashioned good manners‚Äù never go amiss, and the Pitchford family‚Äôs ‚Äúdelightful‚Äù long-running venture (est. 1977) put in a ‚Äúfabulous‚Äù showing this year, winning enthusiastic praise for its ‚Äúmemorable‚Äù cooking and its ‚Äúthoughtful‚Äù service.

After a spell running celebrated ‚Äòrestaurant-with-rooms‚Äô The Crown at Whitebrook, James Sommerin has set up his own place, set on the seafront on Penarth‚Äôs Esplanade. The restaurant has just opened and rooms will be available from June. Could well be one to watch. Survey reports gratefully received!

Generally speaking, London doesn‚Äôt ‚Äòdo‚Äô wine bars or bistros and nowadays: the terms just seem so ‚Äô60s. Here we do ‚Äògastropubs‚Äô. When all‚Äôs said and done though, a gastropub is really no more than a bistro-in-a-pub.

What to call this new concept near Smithfield? With such a strong lunchtime food emphasis and nowhere to stand around with a glass, ‚Äòwine bar‚Äô wouldn‚Äôt do. The term ‚Äòbistro‚Äô can sound rather dated. So the solution the owners of this Farringdon newcomer have opted for is to call it a ‚ÄòBar and wine shop‚Äô¬ù. With its bare tables, daily-changing blackboard menu and open kitchen, however, the place looked for all the world like a ‚Äòcontemporary bistro‚Äô on our lunchtime visit (and an instantly-popular one at that).

The chef here once worked at Bibendum ‚Äì which is appropriate enough, as that Chelsea landmark made its name with haute bistro fare and a strong wine list ‚Äì and the cooking is very much in the no-nonsense Simon Hopkinson tradition. The food is workmanlike and reasonably priced. Service is informal but efficient, too, which is, of course, in the best bistro tradition.

The venture‚Äôs backers are both wine trade men, and, as the description they have chosen for their establishment suggests, this is where their hearts really lie. Dishes come twinned with interesting and reasonably-priced wine suggestions by the glass. If you want to do the thinking, the list is 200-strong, and has a sensible mark-up policy. At the bottom end, you‚Äôll pay the standard three times retail, but, if you drink better, the proportional mark-up, never exceeding ¬£25, falls away sharply. By night, you can stop by just for a drink ‚Äì for consumption sur place, or to take away.

Back in 1979, with a civil war raging back home, chef Marouf Abouzaki arrived in London from Lebanon. He soon set up the first Maroush, in Edgware Road and since then his stable of establishments has grown pretty steadily. There are now half a dozen Maroushes proper, and roughly the same again of spin-off brands such as Ranoush and Beirut Express. Like many successful restaurateurs, Mr Abouzaki likes to keep his operations geographically ‚Äòtight‚Äô ‚Äì mostly within half a mile of Marble Arch.

His latest venture adds a new ‚Äòconcept‚Äô to the empire. The Kensington premises formerly known as the Catherine Wheel have certainly banished any recollections of their days as a smoky old boozer. The new look, complete with mezzanine, makes much use of back-lit glass, to create an interior which ‚Äì by Lebanese standards ‚Äì is on the understated side of glitzy.

By day, this makes a smart and comfortable destination, and it is the daytime menu (noon-5pm) which is the particular attraction here. For ¬£12, you get tasty olives, a huge and impressively fresh salad and vegetable bowl, bread, two hot and two cold starters, a meaty dish of the day with rice, and some pastries. Even with a glass of wine and an extremely passable espresso, you can still get away around the ¬£20 a head mark (plus a tip). By night, when broadly the same meal would cost twice as much, the attractions of the perfectly palatable but fairly unremarkable cuisine would be rather less apparent.

Ending on a seasonal note, Christmas is now less than three months away. Maroush group establishments are generally open throughout the festive season ‚Äì including December 25th ‚Äì so if you‚Äôre looking to escape the seasonal banalities without leaving town this place, or one of its siblings, might be well worth considering.

Polpo is a fun environment but its not cheap.  I love the variety of the menu and feel it just about presents value for money.  Service is decent but Ive marked it down because one of our dishes was forgotten and only delivered towards the end of our meal after a reminder was issued.  I certainly see the attraction but Im likely to explore other places in this price range before my next visit
A smash hit in the making, this NYC-Downtown-chic Italian offers perfectly judged tapas/small-plate dishes in an atmosphere of old-style Soho conviviality.
We keep reading that this much-lauded Soho newcomer - fronted by Russell Norman, once a bigwig at the Caprice group - is some sort of Venetian snack bar (or, to impress you with our research,
). Has anyone looked at it? This is a New York restaurant, pure and simple. Or, more specifically, a Downtown restaurant.

The only wonder is that its taken so long for this particular style of deconstructed chic to make the jump from SoHo to Soho: Polpo immediately reminded us a of a particular SoHo-fringe operation, Peasant, which opened as long ago as 2000. Mr Norman readily admits such restaurants (if not that specific one) have provided just as much inspiration for him as anything in La Serenissima, and will even tell you the name of the particular firm of Big Apple architects whose work has inspired him: Avroko.

True to the Avroko spirit, Norman has opened up some beautifully distressed brickwork (heading for three centuries old), and some tiles (wed guess Victorian) to create an interior which - though on a modest scale compared to many Downtown establishments - has a rather similar vibe. As in NYC, that vibe manages to be trendy but not exclusive. We couldnt help noticing how, in the pretty much full house by 1pm, there were lots of people - yes, even including old people -who werent classic modern-times Soho lunchers at all. Early days, but the tone may well last.

It isnt just the styling, of course (not generally commented on in the very positive early-days reviews elsewhere) which is responsible for the crush, but also the much-complimented food. Not that the cuisine is in any way astonishing, its just that it is generally very well done, and amazingly, well,

. The cicheti (Italian tapas) are very tasty, as well as remarkably economical. The highlight for us (lunching in the singular) was a delicious pile of green tapenade on a piece of toasted bread, but arancini (rice balls) also satisfied. To follow, fegato alla Veneziana, a small but very adequate dish for around ¬£6, was well complemented by a plate of zucchini dressed with olive oil. Add a plate of roast autumn fruits (the best dish, dressed with a sprinkle of crumble), and youve still, with modest wine, had a very pleasant lunch for ¬£25. Which may be another reason the place is already humming.

The obvious problem is that, with value like this, either prices will rise or tables will be impossible to get. Or both. So how long till the successor restaurant? As youve probably gathered, this is not the sort of place where a known reviewer is likely to be able to maintain any sort of anonymity, so we can tell you what Mr Norman told us - start looking out for number two some time next year.

‚Äì one of the UK‚Äôs best dining destinations and a top scorer in our annual survey for many years ‚Äì has been put up for sale for a reported ¬£1.75 million. The 16 bedroom¬†‚Äúold coach house/shooting lodge which enjoys a fabulous, picturesque setting‚Äù¬†near Pateley Bridge, North Yorkshire, was bought by chef Frances Atkins and her husband Bill more more than 20 years ago.

There‚Äôs a toytown quality to the grid of freshly-scrubbed warehouses you find just over Tower Bridge. Nice, but somehow not entirely real ‚Äì the area gives the appearance of being a model community for shiny young people, whose lives are on their way to somewhere else.

In the heart of the grid sits this two-level outfit, which, somehow, doesn‚Äôt seem quite real either. Why? Perhaps because it‚Äôs trying to be a sort of beast you don‚Äôt see very often ‚Äì a quality (read pricey) Indian restaurant, attached to a serious bar operation. It‚Äôs an act that might be easier to pull off in the West End, but, even there, we can think of only one place ‚Äì Mint Leaf ‚Äì which answers to that description.

There are various ways they try to square the, er, circle here. One is by having friendly service which- having allowed diners to enjoy a drink downstairs ‚Äì efficiently shepherds them to the restaurant above. Another is banning smoking throughout. Diners get to share some of the vibe of the bar operation, but no fug.

When you reach the elegant dining space, you find more friendly service ‚Äì mainly Russian, mainly female. The food is from a serious chef, Bhuwan Batt, who worked in top Indian hotels, before coming to London diners‚Äô attention at Tabla, near Canary Wharf. The style of the dishes, and their presentation, is perhaps a bit more ‚Äòstandard‚Äô than one might expect ‚Äì hotel experience coming through, perhaps ‚Äì but there are some unusual dishes, All those we tried ‚Äòworked‚Äô, and they all came in generous quantities. (Puddings, however, are weak.)

Can this formula work in this location? As we left, mid-evening, the bar was busier than the restaurant, and we had no feeling that the barflies were going to end up dining above, so we‚Äôd have our doubts. If we are wrong ‚Äì and this is a case where we‚Äôd be pleased to be so ‚Äì London‚Äôs dining-out scene is getting very mature indeed.

The street food bar, serving up banh mi (filled baguettes), noodle bowls and buns, will take over 9 Poland Street, once home to the Burlington Caf√©. The menu includes classic banh mi like mortadella, pork floss, house chicken liver [‚Ä¶]

From the team behind Wahaca, the bright and buzzy Mexican street food chain, comes an all new venture to Brick Lane‚Äôs Old Truman Brewery. Well, we say all new, the concept is still very much centred on Mexican food, but with a (now commonplace) American twist. The US influences at DF/Mexico, which opened on 24 [‚Ä¶]

On 4 April from noon until¬†9.30pm, a total of 27 vans and stalls will line the space behind the Southbank Centre on Belvedere Road for the entire weekend. Craft beer bar, The Cellar, [‚Ä¶]

We always want what we can‚Äôt have. As kids, we wanted to be allowed in with the grown-ups. As grown-ups, we want to make it into the VIP lounge. And so on. It‚Äôs a mindset that‚Äôs well understood by the owners of the Theatreland‚Äôs latest hot ticket, Christopher Corbin and Jeremy King. It may be a few years since they sold out their interests in The Ivy and Sheekey‚Äôs, but they were the men responsible for the modern-day success of both of these celebrity magnets.

The duo‚Äôs talents have, in recent years, been tied up at the Wolseley ‚Äì a prominent site that‚Äôs much more visible from the street than their other creations. Perhaps it‚Äôs in reaction to this that the newcomer we review today takes them back to their roots. You could walk past its forbidding black double doors on a curiously nondescript patch of (Lower) Regent Street every day without realising there was a restaurant there. The windows are almost opaque. This place is called a restaurant, but it‚Äôs really a club.

That of course, is the joy of the duo‚Äôs previous creations. They are clubs open to all‚Äô if you‚Äôre famous enough, or book months ahead. BBC Bigwig Alan Yentob, was the famous face on our lunchtime visit during half-price review week, so presumably the rest of media land cannot be far behind. And Jeremy and Christopher were much in evidence, assiduously working the room in that effortless style of theirs.

Unlike The Ivy or Sheekey‚Äôs, the calming, Scandinavian-style interior here is a masterwork of understatement. This is simplicity to the point of being stylishly nondescript. The confident presumption is that the Beautiful People will come ‚Äì which they surely will ‚Äì and furnish the room.

Originally just a basement venue, Zima has proved so popular that the first and ground floors of the building will now also offer Alexei Zimin‚Äôs contemporary Russian dishes, including borsch and beef stroganoff, alongside a range of unique vodka infusions.¬† Open from noon until 1 am Tuesday-Saturday, Zima offers visitors lunch, dinner or a night cap.

has found his new happy place: after two hours at Yeni (‚Äù¬†a new London sibling for one of Istanbul‚Äôs hottest¬†restaurants‚Äù), all of his ‚Äúcontorting stresses and life worries had melted away‚Äù. He even compared the new Anatolian restaurant to a spa-break, ‚Äúalmost certainly the best place I have eaten in so far this year‚Äù.

Familiar dishes served in the¬†‚Äúcompactand understated‚Äù Soho room ‚Äúare modernised and reappraised withoutlosing any‚Ä¶ grit, soul or assertive, rough-hewn deliciousness‚Äù. The √ßigkofte tartare was an ‚Äúincredible‚Ä¶ ¬†densely herbed, bolshily piquant patty‚Äùand the lamb shank ‚Äúhad that perfect mix of crackled skin and blushingsucculent flesh‚Äù. Even though some dishes were ‚Äúmerelyfine‚Äù and the bill ‚Äúreflects the realities of rent in one of the morefinancially brutal parts of town‚Äù, Jimi loved it all.

He loved that ‚Äúthe only¬†coffee¬†available is of thesoil-like, Turkish rocket fuel variety‚Äù and the ‚Äútoasted slabs ofsourdough‚Äù and the ‚Äúfrizzy-haired little custard fritters we had forpudding‚Äù: ‚ÄúYeni soothed and pleased me greatly, and I cannotwait to go back.‚Äù (9/10)

also reviewed Yeni; as is often the case when two critics review a place at the same time, his opinion was very different, even to the point of comparing it to a traffic accident ‚Äì ‚Äúright now it really is a pile-up; the sort that leaves debris scattered across all three lanes‚Äù ‚Äì and hoping (in a ‚Äúgodless‚Äù way) for ‚Äúdivine intervention‚Äù.

Hedoes go out of his way to praise (‚Äúexonerate‚Äù in terms of the ‚Äòincidentenquiry‚Äô) the front-of-house team ‚Äúwho deliverboth their script and the often calamitous dishes with a touching grace‚Äù.

Jay has spent time in Turkey, and in the many, joyful, Turkishrestaurants in London. He readily welcomed another that promised ‚Äúa moreevolved take on such a culinary tradition‚Äù; sadly that promisewasn‚Äôt delivered.

‚ÄúTurkey has a thrilling way with breads‚Äù‚Äì so why serve an inauthentic sourdough? One starter is ‚Äúa study in beige,and tastes beige too‚Äù, others are fridge-cold and the one ‚Äúengaging‚Äùdish provides two scallops. For ¬£17. A main course is described as ‚Äúlessfood than a traumatic experience designed to be character forming‚Äù.

‚Äù Yeni weds underwhelming, occasionally disastrous dishes with the kind of in-yer-face pricing that gives the entire restaurant business a wretched name.‚Äù The whole review is a Sunday morning gift to his readers, full of classic Rayner-esque wit and derision.

, at Legna, an ‚Äúexpensively hewn, prettily lit, innovative Italian restaurant‚Äù from chef Aktar Islam who has also opened Opheem across the road (‚Äúa sort-of-Indian restaurant that uses European technique‚Äù).

When a paragraphstarts with a phrase like ‚ÄúLegna really does feel as if it should be awinner‚Äù, you just know there‚Äôs a ‚Äúbut‚Äù on the way. Thisparticular ‚Äúbut‚Äù was an unfortunate one: ‚ÄúIslam was not himselfcooking that evening‚Äù. Which was a real shame as everything elsewas near perfect, from the ‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù bar to the dining areadecorated with cherry blossom (‚ÄúI can think of few prettier restaurantsI‚Äôve visited in the past 12 months‚Äù) and the ‚Äúwarm and effusive‚Äùservice.

The food startedwith ‚Äúpromise‚Äù, but the lack of head chef was soon noted in the antipasti(‚Äúneither hideous nor delicious; it simply existed‚Äù) followedby a ‚Äústodgy fritto misto‚Äù, ¬†‚Äù slightly sickly‚Äù celeriacpasta, a caponata that Grace described as a ‚Äúratatouille autopsy‚Äùand ‚Äì to finish ‚Äì ‚Äù ¬†a tiny, inelegant panettone pudding that‚Ä¶would have left you feeling shortchanged if you‚Äôd bought it at M&S‚Äù.

magazine is really branching out ‚Äì last week he was in Leamington Spa, and this week‚Äôs reviews finds him in Shipley, just outside Bradford. It won‚Äôt surprise anyone to know he‚Äôd never been before.

The Waterside Inn is a canalside spot, a ‚Äúsetof low rooms with wooden ceilings that make it feel like the bottom deck of aboat‚Äù that‚Äôs ‚Äúreally quite cosy‚Äù. It‚Äôs a family affair,with chef Paul Hutchinson‚Äôs father-in-law serving, and his uncle recommendingthe place to snooty London restaurant critics.

From the winter menu that was ‚Äúexceptionally well balanced‚Äù,Giles had ‚Äúlovely rare pigeon breast, full of gamey flavour, with a goodcrispy, spicy pigeon samosa‚Äù, ‚Äúcute, rare, sweet noisettes ofbutter-poached local venison loin‚Äù and ‚Äù Bakewell tart made toPaul‚Äôs gran‚Äôs recipe‚Äù ‚Äì and then ‚Äúa really first-rate‚Ä¶rhubarb cheesecake‚Äù; ‚Äúall presented really, really prettily‚Äù.

‚ÄúThis place has not just charmbut a real touch of class. Good local ingredients, modern ideas, regionaltwists, the odd gentle joke, first-class presentation, incredibly friendlyservice.‚Äù Way to go, Bradford. (22/30)

was in London this week, reviewing Clerkenwell ‚Äòs The Drunken Butler; did she like it more than Fay Maschler on her early-days visit? Marina also visited early on, ‚Äúand thought the owner, Yuma Hashemi, had immense talent, but that place and menu were a little unformed‚Äù. She went back for a Sunday visit, when the ‚Äúdecorative, tweezery dishes‚Äù of French cuisine with Persian influences go out the window in favour of ‚ÄúPersian Sundays‚Ä¶ the kind of food ‚Äúyou would usually eat in a Persian home‚Äù.

Food‚Äúarrivesin a delicious wave‚Äù; there was ‚Äúcoucousabzi‚Ä¶ a kind of dense frittata‚Ä¶ is like being gently slapped around thechops with garlands of aromatics‚Äù,‚Äúballs of soft feta rolled in mint and rose petal‚Äù, an auberginedish with ‚Äúintense, vegetal flavour‚Äù, ‚Äúgorgeous, pillowyflatbread‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúand that‚Äôs just the starters‚Äù.

‚Äù It‚Äôs allsuch an adventure‚Äù from a ‚Äúmenu that reads like a hauntinglullaby from a faraway bedside‚Äù; it‚Äôs also the ‚Äúbest kind ofmenu: horizon-broadening and grin-inducing‚Äù. The ‚Äúfamily-style‚Äùservice and a pace that‚Äôs ‚Äúunhurried, almost languid‚Äù (‚Äúnone ofit feels like London‚Äù) make a meal ‚Äúvery special indeed‚Äù.
Hashemi‚Äôs version oftahdig (‚Äúthe emperor of rice dishes‚Äù) is ‚Äúthe best I‚Äôve tried‚Äùand roast chicken was ‚Äù sensational‚Ä¶ its meat insanely juicy, its skincrisp‚Äù
revisited the Sixties at Vivi, the themed restaurant from caterer Rhubarb that has soft-launched at Centrepoint. It‚Äôs not always god to revisit the past, she found.

Authentic Sixties dishes are on offer in the ‚Äù glazed bridge‚Äù location, which was ‚Äúmore or less empty‚Äù on the day Fay visited.None of the dishes were authentically realised, though: the prawn cocktail used‚Äúmiserable little de-frosted prawns, aMarie-Rose sauce with no edge, and stale bread‚Äù,there was no exciting ‚Äúgarlic butter bursting forth‚Äùfrom the chicken Kiev and (at a later visit, for bar snacks), the devils onhorseback were described by her companion as ‚Äúprobably the worst dish I‚Äôve ever eaten‚Äù. (**)
paid a visit to the ‚Äúsparkling, twinkling palace of chandeliers and mirrors‚Äù that is Brasserie of Light in Selfridges, where ‚Äúevery dish has bells, or should I say crystals, on‚Äù. (****)
From the ‚Äúdrop dead gorgeous‚Äù interior to the ‚Äúsmashing food‚Äù , a visit to Tom Kitchin‚Äôs new Leith restaurant was a ‚Äúlucky‚Äù treat for

The menu has simple modern British classics ‚Äì ham, egg andchips is on the menu, albeit for ¬£19.50 and presented on a wooden platter withpineapple salsa ‚Äì plus a few specials. Gaby‚Äôs dining partner had ‚Äúa beautiful piece‚Äù of cod with broccoli three waysand toasted peanuts. Her treacle tart pudding was a ‚Äúbeautifully rendered classic‚Äù.
Bonnie Badger has ‚Äúdouble height ceilings and theoriginal beams‚Äù ‚Äì an ‚Äúespecially special setting‚Äùfor that smashing food. (88%)

, doled out a rare 2-star review for Wild Rice, the recently refurbished and renamed Soho Thai (formerly Janetira). He loved the previous incarnation, and found this one ‚Äúmore slick‚Äù but with many ‚Äúforgettable‚Äù dishes.
Even with ‚Äúgood‚Äùingredients and ‚Äúsweet‚Äù service, he wants Janetira back: ‚Äúroughenthose edges, char those chillies, and bring back the fury and the filth. (**)
, London, where it‚Äôs ‚Äúglee-inspiring to see the Soho institution reconnecting so comfortably with its own tradition‚Äù: ‚Äúno twists, just unexpected brilliance‚Äù.

Julie‚Äôs restaurant and champagne bar has finally announced a date to reopen, some four years after abruptly closing its doors. These days sustainability doesn‚Äôt mean sacrificing quality as great produce can be found locally or through fair trade importers.¬†Partake of some fantastic food as you do your bit¬†for the environment by choosing your dining destination with a little help from our friends at the
‚ÄúUnique flavours focussed on nutritious ingredients from Peru‚Äù help win a thumbs-up for this ‚Äútrendy‚Äù Shoreditch newcomer; ‚Äúthe clubby downstairs is the place to sit‚Äù.

‚ÄúExtraordinary to have trees, streams and flamingos, up above Kensington High Street!‚Äù ‚Äì these ‚Äúcool‚Äù (‚Äúblingy‚Äù) 8th-floor dining rooms, overlooking the roof gardens, make ‚Äúsuch a romantic summer location‚Äù; perhaps best to visit for lunch, when there‚Äôs a ‚Äúvery good-value 3-course set option‚Äù.

‚ÄúGood luck to the whole project!‚Äù; you too can be a ‚Äì temporary ‚Äì guest of Her Majesty at Brixton nick, at this intriguing new rehabilitation project; ‚Äúthe food‚Äôs nothing special, but the experience is quite something‚Äù.

‚ÄúAbsurdly juicy‚Äù steaks and ‚Äúfirst-class cocktails‚Äù underpin huge acclaim for Huw Gott & Will Beckett‚Äôs ‚Äúcasual and laid-back‚Äù temples to meat; even fans admit prices are ‚Äúeye-watering‚Äù, though, and ratings are beginning to fall some way behind those of its main rival, Goodman.

‚ÄúExcels in every way‚Äù; this ‚Äúenterprising‚Äù and ‚Äúpleasant‚Äù favourite, near Balham station, is a ‚Äúwonderful‚Äù and ‚Äúsensibly priced‚Äù operation ‚Äì ‚Äúmore relaxed than Chez Bruce, but snapping at its heels in terms of quality‚Äù.
A Brockwell Park institution, still celebrated for ‚Äúexcellent‚Äù fish ‚Äôn‚Äô chips; ‚Äúmanaging to sustain its quality over the years is a great achievement ‚Äì long may it stay the course!‚Äù

With its ‚Äúbuzzing bar on the ground floor, upstairs dining room and dining conservatory‚Äù, this Maida Vale gastropub wins all-round praise, including for its gourmet food at ‚Äúneighbourhood prices‚Äù.

‚ÄúClassy‚Äù and ‚Äúinventive‚Äù food in a ‚Äúgreat countryside location‚Äù is the formula for success at this ‚Äúwonderful‚Äù gastropub, not far from Henley; service, though, ‚Äúsometimes lacks the finesse you see in the food‚Äù.

‚ÄúWorth the 300 mile round trip!‚Äù; for ‚Äúspectacular‚Äù food in a ‚Äústunning‚Äù setting, Raymond Blanc‚Äôs ‚Äúimpeccable‚Äù country house hotel and dining room offers ‚Äúa sublime experience‚Äù that‚Äôs ‚Äúworth pushing the boat out for‚Äù; ‚Äúmake sure you leave time to explore the gardens before dinner!‚Äù

‚ÄúA little out of the way, but worth the effort to visit‚Äù, this New Forest country house dining room wins particular acclaim for its ‚Äúvery chilled‚Äù style and ‚Äúenthusiastic‚Äù staff, although the ‚Äúimpeccably sourced‚Äù food (with pork dishes a speciality) is good too.

‚ÄúGiles Coren was right!‚Äù ‚Äì with its ‚Äúattractive staff, attractive menu and attractive prices‚Äù, this ‚Äúbustling‚Äù not-for-profit caf√© is seen by reporters as a worthy antidote to the city‚Äôs ‚Äúmany chain eateries‚Äù; it offers ‚Äúdelicious‚Äù organic fare, which comes with a ‚Äúsustainable edge‚Äù.

‚ÄúThis Gallic charmer never waivers!‚Äù; this ‚Äúsecret gem‚Äù of a New Town bistro is ‚Äúa perfect place for older romancing‚Äù, and the ‚Äúrefined‚Äù cuisine it offers is realised to generally ‚Äúreliable‚Äù standards too.

With its ‚Äúpostmodern industrial setting‚Äù, this former costume store, near the Traverse Theatre, is now the ‚Äúcoolest‚Äù venue in town; sample its ‚Äúimaginative‚Äù menu (strong on ‚Äúunusual locally-foraged vegetables‚Äù), and then ‚Äúrelax with a post-prandial drink by the wood-burning stove‚Äù.

Fewer reports of late on a city-centre basement that has had quite a name for its fish and seafood in recent years; it‚Äôs still tipped for its ‚Äúcompetent‚Äù cooking, albeit ‚Äúat a price‚Äù, but there has been the odd gripe about ‚Äúunexciting‚Äù fare of late. Review it in this year‚Äôs survey.

‚ÄúWithout a doubt, one of Britain‚Äôs best restaurants‚Äù; this renowned dining room ‚Äúspells luxury from the moment you enter its fashionably muted and spacious interior‚Äù, and its cuisine is ‚Äútruly outstanding‚Äù ‚Äì it is also ‚Äúfrighteningly expensive‚Äù, though, and there were a couple of ‚Äúanticlimactic‚Äù reports this year.

‚ÄúA little gem of a restaurant tucked away in this small village‚Äù ‚Äì using ‚Äúlocally-sourced‚Äù and ‚Äúseasonal‚Äù ingredients, it ‚Äúmaintains a consistently high standard all year round‚Äù; the caf√© offshoot (with sea view) is ‚Äúabove average‚Äù too.

‚ÄúSet in a restored orangery in a lovely walled garden, with views across the valley to the Mendip Hills‚Äù, this ‚Äòethical‚Äô restaurant ‚Äúuses only local produce, a lot of it from their own garden‚Äù; no good if the food doesn‚Äôt measure up, of course, but all reports say it‚Äôs ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù, with ‚Äúvivid flavours‚Äù, and ‚Äúserved with love‚Äù.

‚ÄúIn a stunning location overlooking the sea‚Äù, Alex Aitken‚Äôs contemporary-style venture continues to win praise for its ‚Äúreally good choice of super-fresh fish straight from the quay‚Äù; ‚Äúsuperb puddings‚Äù too.

A ‚Äúmost memorable experience all-round‚Äù ‚Äì the ‚Äúmagisterial‚Äù dining room of this large country house hotel makes a ‚Äúvery romantic‚Äù backdrop in which to enjoy Stephen Bulmer‚Äôs ‚Äúexquisite‚Äù cuisine, matched with a ‚Äúproper‚Äù wine list.
Here‚Äôs a smattering of environmentally friendly restaurants that haven‚Äôt yet been reviewed in our annual survey. If you would like to review any of these restaurants in our 2016 survey,

Sustainability‚Äô always seems to have been a bit of a King‚Äôs Cross speciality; Jamie Grainger-Smith made quite a hit of a sustainable restaurant with Acorn House (now RIP), so perhaps he can do the same again at this summer-2014 newcomer.

Brighton has embraced former St John Bread and Wine chef Douglas McMaster‚Äôs radical zero waste, pre-industrial food vision, with tables and chairs made of chipboard and plates fashioned from recycled plastic bags. Homemade is taken to the extreme here with butter, yoghurt and curd all made in house. They even mill their own flour from rare ancient varieties of wheat for the superlative sourdough.

We hear good things about this tapas joint (founded by a former Moro chef) which aims to ‚Äòcreate a sustainable business model‚Äô by sourcing produce locally from organic farms and ethically from fair trade importers.

(2-6 July) has been a fixture of the English summer since 1839 and, 175 years later, Londoners still flock to Oxfordshire to watch the rowing. In the spirit of this enduring event (or if you just fancy a day out in the Thames Valley) we have decided to bring you the best restaurants to be found ‚Äòon Thames‚Äô in Oxfordshire, Berks and Bucks as you wend your way up river‚Ä¶
Handily situated for visitors, near the bridge, an atmospheric large boozer with an ‚Äúattractive conservatory‚Äù, generally tipped for its ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù menu and its ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù service.
An ‚Äúelegant and tasteful‚Äù riverside restaurant, offering ‚Äúwonderfully inventive‚Äù Indian cooking (with ‚Äúsuperb breads‚Äù a highlight); service is typically ‚Äúexcellent‚Äù too.
‚ÄúGenuine Italian food, served with Italian charm‚Äù makes this well-established venture ‚Äúone of the few places in Henley you can be sure of a good meal with service to match‚Äù.

‚ÄúDeservedly a legend‚Äù; for reporters of a more traditional bent, ‚Äúnothing can beat‚Äù the Roux family‚Äôs ‚Äúperfect‚Äù Thames-side haven; ‚Äúshocking‚Äù prices notwithstanding, it‚Äôs the ideal destination to mark a major birthday or anniversary‚Ä¶ or ‚Äúone‚Äôs investiture at Windsor Castle‚Äù.
‚ÄúA top tip for a sunny day‚Äù ‚Äì this waterside operation has a magnificent location, perched on the Thames; the cheaper brasserie is a better bet than the downstairs restaurant.

‚ÄúThe star here is the cooking‚Äù ‚Äì Adam Simmond‚Äôs cuisine offers ‚Äúa true culinary experience‚Äù, not least a ‚Äúwonderful‚Äù tasting menu ‚Äì at this ‚Äúspacious‚Äù Thames-side dining room (‚Äúyou could drive a coach and horses between the tables!‚Äù); service though can grate, and contribute to a ‚Äúlack of ambience‚Äù.

With its ‚Äúimpeccable‚Äù service, and ‚Äúexcellent views over the Thames‚Äù, the ‚Äúposher‚Äù of the two restaurants in this luxury hotel is ‚Äúexpensive, but otherwise hard to fault‚Äù; tasting menus come particularly recommended.

‚ÄúEvolved from the cheap ‚Äôn‚Äô cheerful boathouse of my student days‚Ä¶‚Äù; the ‚Äúimpossibly romantic‚Äù riverside setting has always been the killer feature of this stalwart venture, but the ‚Äúimproving‚Äù food more often lives up to the other ‚Äúparticular highlight‚Äù ‚Äì a wine list ‚Äúwith great variety and some fantastic prices‚Äù.

A ‚Äúfamily-friendly‚Äù venue, with a lovely waterside setting on the fringe of the city, with a ‚Äúgreat summer garden‚Äù, where food can be ordered picnic-style ‚Äì results are ‚Äúdecent‚Äù if, on some reports, ‚Äúa bit pricey‚Äù.
in The Observer enjoys a knowing attempt to bring the street inside at Borough Market‚Äôs El Past√≥r (from Barrafina founders, the Hart bros)‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs ‚Äúa fun space of bare brick and shiny metal and colourful murals; a knowing attempt to bring the street inside‚Äù, with¬†‚Äútequilas in worryingly large servings‚Äù and¬†¬†‚Äúpork shoulder, marinated and roasted for 24 hours until it‚Äôs so much tangle and thread, with the sweet hit of caramelised pineapple, more guacamole and white onion‚Äù. All in all you get¬†‚Äúthe sense you could mislay an evening here very easily‚Äù.

This new venture from chefs Lucy Pedder and Natasha Cooke, who met working at Medlar, is¬†‚Äúutterly simple, completely seductive‚Äù,¬†‚Äúthe house style comes across as less true Brit and more West Coast US‚Äù- but ‚Äúthis is a find‚Äù. And the food?¬†‚ÄúCornish crab thermidor, oligarch-rich with cream and cheese, spiky with mustard, as over the top as anything at a Victorian banquet.¬†Even that bastion of clean-eating probity, the courgette, is lubricated with ricotta, jolted with chilli and fried into crisp little croquettes, virtue most emphatically and successfully sullied.¬†Desserts follow the classics-with-a-good-zhuzhing formula. The restaurant in Finsbury Park‚Äôs Arts Building ‚Äúfeels bright, spacious and welcoming, for once a truly industrial adaptation rather than a stylistic affectation‚Äù and¬†‚Äúthe menu has the essentials.‚Äù ‚ÄúA¬†substantial plateful of terrific, small, halved, char-grilled chorizo sausages from Dingley Dell Pork in Suffolk, served with a yolky aioli (¬£4.50), was an immediate delight.¬†The food is rich, parmesan and truffles re-appearing, not shy of unctuous cream and butter. did not enjoy her trip to Dinings‚Äô new SW3 outpost, delivering a scathing 2/10 review about the ‚Äútriumphantly terrible food‚Äù‚Ä¶

heads to Levanter Fine Foods in Ramsbottom in search of thick-cut Galician beef steaks. Unfortunately they hadn‚Äôt arrived yet, but that didn‚Äôt stop him enjoying everything else that Joe Botham‚Äôs Spanish restaurant had to offer.
is won over by Borough Market‚Äôs latest meat and tapas joint LOBOS ‚Äì despite her initial shock at its determinedly grungy, dive-y first impression.
reflects on how heart-wrenching it can be to have to write a negative review. Luckily he loved Islington newcomer Oldroyd (well, apart from the name).

heads to The Newman Arms in Fitzrovia. Thought to be the setting of Orwell‚Äôs ‚Äòproles pub‚Äô in 1984, this old boozer has been taken over by the owner of The Cornwall Project and The Cornish Grill pop-up, Matt Chatfield.
sets out to review the new Cafe Murano and ends up neatly skewering the problem facing independent restaurants in London.
