group is to continue its creep into the mid-market with the launch of a new Cecconi‚Äôs restaurant in Shoreditch, East London.

The company already has two Italian restaurants under the brand, and this latest opening marks an intent to take Cecconi‚Äôs out of its natural heartland and into the East End‚Äôs new restaurant frontier.

And, at a time when ‚Äì in characteristically gung ho fashion ‚Äì Soho House is spending untold gazillions on Shepherd‚Äôs Bush TV centre project, while also expanding its private members‚Äô clubs internationally; it indicates a continued appetite to open more restaurants in the UK.
Cecconi‚Äôs in Shoreditch will, we are told, be more akin to the glamourous Mayfair original (founded in 1971 by Sgr Cecconi) rather than the spin-off Soho pizza spot.

To any restaurant which offers a dessert of Jerusalem artichoke cheesecake we say ‚Äòrespect‚Äô. With all due regard to Alain Ducasse and his somewhat bizarre recent boosterism of London as the restaurant capital of the world, the capital‚Äôs scene has been pretty dull of late.
The likes of Lutyens, say, or the mobbed Dean Street Townhouse, may be hugely successful, but ‚Äì particularly on the gastronomic front ‚Äì do we not all know in our hearts that they are a teeny bit
? This repetition and re-invention of Anglo-French classics may be a worthy enough aim, but is that all there is to our restaurant scene? It does sometimes seem so at the moment.
So again we say respect to Gemma Tuley, and her new Fulham operation, where the aforesaid cheesecake turns out to implausibly delicious.

Gemma not a name known to you? Well, she first came to attention when she was ‚Äòpositioned‚Äô ‚Äì forgive the terminology ‚Äì as one of ‚ÄòGordon‚Äôs babes‚Äô. That was the point at which she was presented with the ultimate poisoned chalice ‚Äì the re-launch r√¥le at the stove of the uninspired and dreary Foxtrot Oscar, which she occupied only briefly. (Amazing fact: FO
Having fled the Sweary One‚Äôs coop, she soon bobbed up again at a new restaurant, Arch One, by Waterloo Station. Again a gig which didn‚Äôt last long.

We hope Ms Tuley will last longer in Fulham: the heaving crowd we found on a Monday night visit certainly suggested that she may have cause to stay. The attraction can‚Äôt be the interior ‚Äì pleasant enough, but feeling as much like a low-lit wine bar as it does a restaurant of ambition. We suspect that the pleasant staff are not the principal attraction either.

No, it must be something to do with the food, which shows a grounding in the classics of just the type you‚Äôd hope a Ramsay prot√©g√©e would possess: indeed, as soon as you taste the bread rolls (a variation on fougasse), you know this is not a Fulham wine bar of any known and usual type. (Fair to say, you‚Äôll be reminded of this when the bill arrives too.)

Similarly of a quality that you‚Äôd normally hope for in a smart Mayfair establishment, rather than in Fulham, was a classic simple scallop starter ‚Äì perfectly timed and full of taste. A game hot pot was impressive too, but arguably open to criticism for being a bit too West End-elegant in style for a dish presented in a peasant pot.

It was the dessert, though, that really caught our attention. The combination of the Jersusalem artichoke cheesecake (a conceit of David Everitt-Matthias, of Cheltenham‚Äôs Champignon Sauvage, it seems)  with peanut ice cream and a knob of peanut butter was truly inspired ‚Äì one of those rare dishes where the whole really does end up tasting of more than the sum of its parts.

To be able to do the classics is a necessity for any cook with ambition, and novelty is good too. But to be able with a sure hand to combine the two ‚Äì¬†well, then, you might just a chef of real note in the making.

Michelin finally woke up and awarded Mitsuhiro Araki‚Äôs Mayfair restaurant, The Araki, three stars at a ceremony in London this week, making it the first Japanese restaurant in the UK to hold the rating. The Araki was named London‚Äôs Top Gastronomic Experience at Harden‚Äôs annual London Restaurant Awards ceremony

and this ‚Äúworld class‚Äù sushi spot has, for a second year, scored the highest food-rating of any restaurant in the UK in our annual survey. So it seems that our reporters have long seen it‚Äôs three-star potential, even if the tyre men did not.

Even if you think Michelin is an irrelevance, three stars is still a big deal mainly due to the rarity with which it is bestowed upon UK restaurants. The last time London saw three stars was in 2010 when Alain Ducasse at the Dorchester won the accolade. Before that you have to go back to 2004 when Heston‚Äôs Fat Duck got its third star. The Fat Duck, we get. But Alain Ducasse at the Dorchester? As our survey reporters say it‚Äôs simply ‚Äúnot in the same league‚Äù and how it retains its three-star rating year-after-year is a mystery.

Other new stars awarded this week included Bibendum (now helmed by Claude Bosi) which received two stars, while the tyre men liberally sprinkled a further 16 one star accolades at venues across the UK (full list below). Perhaps the guide editors were feeling a bit nostalgic about Bibendum‚Äôs home in Chelsea‚Äôs iconic Michelin Building, because the reports we have had this year don‚Äôt point towards a two-star performance. Overall it received a 2/5 for food in our survey and many seem to think the more ambitious culinary regime has led to ‚Äúridiculous prices‚Äù.

Notable new one stars include Jamavar, Leela Palaces‚Äôs stunning new Mayfair Indian, which was named London‚Äôs Top Newcomer at our annual awards last month; Phil Howard‚Äôs Elystan Street, which was shortlisted by us for London‚Äôs Top Gastronomic Experience; and La Dame de Pic (City) and Aquavit (St James‚Äôs), two newcomers we shortlisted in out Best for Business category at this year‚Äôs Harden‚Äôs London Restaurant Awards.

It‚Äôs good to see A Wong getting the recognition of a star from Michelin. Our reporters say, and we agree, that Andrew Wong‚Äôs new-school Chinese in Pimlico provides some of ‚Äúthe most exhilarating food in London‚Äù. However there are a couple of omissions that (we feel) continue to rankle. Gauthier Soho lost its star in 2012 and its continued absence from the list is baffling and starkly calls into question the judgement of the tyre men. And while we‚Äôre on the subject, why was Chelsea‚Äôs Medlar stripped of its star? Perhaps most confusing though is why Michelin continues to ignore Bethnal Green‚Äôs Typing Room? As one survey reporter says: ‚ÄúHow this place doesn‚Äôt have a Michelin star is beyond belief!‚Äù
In the heart of Soho, a bistro of rare ‚Äì perhaps unique ‚Äì decorative brutality, offering a short and ever-changing menu, realised to a high standard.

Are you a ‚ÄòBobo‚Äô? Do you combine a bourgeois love of fine food with a bohemian contempt for tablecloths and all the other traditional appurtenances of catered quality dining? Congratulations. A restaurant precisely honed to your tastes has suddenly arrived ‚Äì far from its natural Hoxton or Shoreditch milieu ‚Äì in the very heart of Soho.

Indeed, short of being actually sited in a multi-story car park, it‚Äôs difficult to imagine that a restaurant could be much more deconstructed than this one. Furnished, seemingly, from a car boot sale, its small interior features principally a large bar at which the seats, thanks to an almost total absence of leg room, are fearsomely uncomfortable. And the Muzak? iPod, eat you heart out ‚Äì it‚Äôs from vinyl. How ‚Äònow‚Äô is that?

This is not a natural setting, you might think, to enjoy a beautiful plump partridge, precisely cooked, accompanied perhaps by a tasty pumpkin mush with chestnuts and cream cheese. Or a decent chocolate mousse. Or to taste from the short but interesting range of wines, scrawled almost illegibly on a whiteboard. The aim here seems rather like that of Paris‚Äôs much-f√™ted Chateaubriand ‚Äì to offer simple food of a quality which transcends the setting, to a degree which is perhaps supposed to be ironic.

That aim has substantially been achieved so, needless to say, the place has been a great hit with the foodie world ‚Äì on our visit, the the Terroirs boys were in, seeing what all the fuss was about. In the longer term, however, quite how such a profound lack of comfort will play with the wider market, it‚Äôs really quite difficult to say.

AA Gill‚Äôs Table Talk column in the Sunday Times is back after a summer hiatus and we discover he‚Äôs been in Italy all this time ‚Äì lucky him. Perhaps the holiday has brought out his softer side as he gifts the reborn Locanda Locatelli at the Hyatt Regency hotel a rare five out of five [‚Ä¶]

No egg puns were used in the writing of AA Gill‚Äôs review of Egg Break in the Sunday Times, but no punches were pulled either. He hated the place, from the bottom of its ‚ÄòFritzl memorial lounge‚Äô basement to the top of its ‚Äòcounter-cultural, recycled, reclaimed, ironic‚Äô name sign. And is this the least appetising [‚Ä¶]

The Indy‚Äôs Tracey Mcleod heads to Marlow to review Tom Kerridge‚Äôs new venture, Coach It doesn‚Äôt take bookings and ‚Äúlike the new-look Tom Kerridge himself, is much smaller than you‚Äôre expecting‚Äù but the food doesn‚Äôt disappoint and would be worth waiting for. ¬† Telegraph critic Zoe Williams says Great Portland Street‚Äôs Portland is ‚Äòa breath [‚Ä¶]
In a small and perhaps slightly subdued space, just off Carnaby Street, a corner barbecue specialist offering a small range of dishes of very high quality.

So much wanted to hate this new corner spot, just off Carnaby Street . Trendy menu (American barbecue), street food origins (under Hungerford Bridge, since you ask), bloggers‚Äô delight‚Äô What could there possibly be to like about it?

Almost everything, it seems. First surprise is that ‚Äì far from the self-conscious streetiness and din of, say, MEATLiquor- this bright and tightly-packed corner spot has a rather old-fashioned style that‚Äôs something remarkably close to teashop-prim, especially by Soho standards.
Second surprise is that the service ‚Äì rather than attempting to be too-cool-for-school ‚Äì is just very efficient and helpful.

Third surprise? Well, how many ‚Äòproper‚Äô restaurants actually offer food such that, the next day, you feel you‚Äôd like to go back and eat it all again? Such was the status achieved by our pulled pork (which is one of the house speciality dishes). A changing range of interesting ‚Äòsides‚Äô, such as marrow mash, is also included. The food all comes on white and blue enamel workmen‚Äôs tin dishes but, hey, nowhere‚Äôs perfect.

Our one-course lunch, including a glass of the house red (in a Duralex tumbler) and service cost ¬£18 for one ‚Äì perhaps not the very cheapest available in this part of town, but certainly one of the best.

On the Regent‚Äôs Park fringe of Camden Town, Gordon Ramsay‚Äôs glamorous conversion of a palatial boozer; food and service are good (rather than anything more), but the overall experience is highly suited to a celebration or romance.

Many people have been a bit mystified by this Gordon Ramsay group restaurant, bar and small hotel, in a converted pub on the outmost fringe of Camden Town. What‚Äôs it for? Why would anyone want to go/stay there?

These are fair questions. Particularly on foot, it‚Äôs not obviously on the route to or from anywhere, and ‚Äì even if much of the West End is within a 20-minute walk ‚Äì one can think of more obvious places to stay.

The key to it all, of course, is celebrity, which could in theory kick-start the virtuous circle ‚Äì crowds-buzz-more crowds ‚Äì to make the place a self-sustaining ‚Äòdestination‚Äô. The trick, of course, is to make it  good enough to be more than a five-minute wonder.

The early signs, we‚Äôd suggest. are that its standards are good enough. Indeed, in at least one respect, they are more than that ‚Äì this is a beautiful building, and it has been handsomely converted to create a very attractive ground-floor dining room (plus less interesting basement), and an unusually seductive bar area ‚Äì a combination ideal for a celebration or for romance.

The food and service play rather a supporting r√¥le. That‚Äôs not a particular criticism ‚Äì history suggests that it is a major challenge for spin-off celeb-chef-branded establishment even to achieve and maintain good/average standards, and that challenge is achieved impressively consistently here.

Admittedly, if you believed the Ramsay hype, and went expecting something special on the food front, you might be disappointed ‚Äì go in a party or romantic mood, though, and you‚Äôll probably have a very good time here.

Scott Hallsworth is certainly a busy bloke. After opening his Kurobuta pop-up on the King‚Äôs Road, Chelsea, (and later a permanent premises in Marble Arch), he moved on to Japanese-inspired members‚Äô restaurant¬†Ramusake in South Ken (which he later left). And ow the Antipodean chef has moved his latest venture¬†Joe‚Äôs Oriental Diner¬†from west London our east. [‚Ä¶]

visited the latest Neapolitan pizzeria to import itself into London (following on from L‚ÄôAntica Pizzeria da Michele, which recently opened in Baker Street ‚Äì the first branch in Stoke Newington is no more). had nothing good to say about Laurent, from¬† French chef Laurent Tourondel who‚Äôs made a great name for himself in New York, opening ‚Äúbuzzy urban brasseries‚Äù under the BLT name (Bistro Laurent Tourondel, geddit?).

From the very beginning, the proposition, according to Jay, is ‚Äútwisted, overworked, underthought‚Äù; the notoriously difficult space is chilly and overlooked by the first floor gallery (‚Äúsocial Siberia‚Äù). Jay‚Äôs kale Caesar salad was ‚Äúbitter and sour and relentless‚Äù, he ‚Äúcould not even begin to finish‚Äù Wagyu beef short ribs that ‚Äúdissolved into hot, tongue-coating grease‚Äù, and a meringue and strawberry dessert was ‚Äù spectacularly ordinary‚Äù.
All of this, and ‚Äúdizzying‚Äù prices too. No wonder Jay ends his review declaring ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt for the life of me imagine why anyone else will ever go there.‚Äù

this week, with a visit to Bucket, which offered plenty of scope for bucket-related puns. A good thing, as the food (mostly fish and seafood) was largely a disappointment ‚Äì not least because many dishes came served on plates, not in buckets, which is the entire concept (‚Äúif that‚Äôs not too grand a term ‚Äú).

Credits for sustainable sourcing, friendly staff and decent wine couldn‚Äôt outweigh a meal where¬† the ‚Äúrecurring note of the whole dining experience was the hollow clang of a truly misbegotten idea‚Äù ‚Äì especially ‚Äúon a street excessively well-stocked with restaurants‚Äù (and ‚Äúpicky patrons‚Äù).

, with a return visit to Masala Zone‚Äôs original branch, which opened in 2001. in The Guardian has been trying to get to Carters of Moseley for years, but was, until now, unable to persuade anyone to accompany her on ‚Äúan experimental tasting odyssey in south Birmingham
But the lucky guest who finally agreed to go shared in a meal that was ‚Äúa little bit magical‚Äù and ‚Äúwonkily, weirdly, pretty much perfect

Unusually for a place ‚Äúoffering tasting menus to a suburban clientele‚Äù, it‚Äôs been a huge success, thanks to ‚Äúa large dose of maverick‚Äù and also to a menu that actually fills you up:‚ÄùCarter conducts the sort of tasting menus that restore your faith in fine dining.‚Äù Even more impressively for Grace, ‚Äúthey can do the whole thing vegetarian ‚Äì backwards in heels, if you will ‚Äì without so much as turning a hair‚Äù. She loved the ‚Äúmeaningful dance involving sharp umami thrusts and creamy, fruity bursts‚Äù.
peculiarly down to earth. Service is drilled and absurdly knowledgeable, but also warm and twinkly‚Äù ‚Äì her ‚Äúfavourite type of discovery‚Äù.

, and the newly revamped Parker‚Äôs Tavern, part of the University Arms Hotel. The menu, like the revamp, is ‚ÄúBritish classics with the occasional twist‚Äù ‚Äì such as tandoori roasted Norfolk quail that was ‚Äúgently tangy‚Äù (and looked like ‚Äúa phoenix that didn‚Äôt quite make it out of the flames‚Äù).

magazine also visited Parker‚Äôs Tavern. His truffle risotto was ‚Äúa forest floor in autumn, thick with a carpet of shaved Somerset fungus‚Äù, and he also reserved high praise for the puddings: ‚Äúthe kind of magical adult nursery food Mary Poppins might have conjured up on cook‚Äôs night off‚Äù.

discovered ‚Äúa charming local restaurant offering generous portions of tapas‚Äù amid ‚Äù quintessential ¬≠Englishness‚Äù of Wargrave, a ‚ÄúThames-hugging Berkshire village‚Äù. revisited the original Chick ‚Äòn‚Äô Sours after a revamp. It may once have been the restaurant equivalent of the film trope ‚ÄòManic Pixie Dream Girl‚Äô but it has settled into being¬† a ‚Äúkeeper‚Äù, with its ‚Äúgutsy, messy street-food‚Äù and ¬†bumper cocktails.

review took her to the London outpost of the late Joel Robuchon. Up front, she admitted she‚Äôd almost forgotten about the place, which seems ‚Äúless and less relevant to the new breed of restaurant-goer ‚Äù and was really there to ‚Äúhelp bury him‚Äù rather than pay homage.

Regular readers can guess where this is going. Instead of finding much to deride in the ‚Äúdimly lit carnival of black lacquer ‚Äú, she enjoyed it: ‚Äúover the years, its intense kitsch has come into its own‚Äù. ¬†Starters arrive with ‚Äúa full armoury of stuff I normally scoff at: tweezers, squeezy bottles, micro herbs and edible flowers‚Äù , main courses are ‚Äúa Marie Antoinette idea of rustic ‚Äú, served with that famous buttery mash, and desserts, including ‚Äúair-light baba drowned in a pirate‚Äôs ration of rum ‚Äù are ‚Äúlittle short of perfect‚Äù.

There‚Äôs no hipsters or buzz words to be found: ‚Äúdon‚Äôt come here for foraging and fermenting, katsu sando or larb or seafood crumpets‚Äù. ¬†But there are many happy customers. It‚Äôs ‚Äúlike being transported to another era, or the best restaurant in a provincial French city‚Äù. And at ¬£45 a head for the set lunch, excellent value too.

in The Daily Mail loves a bit of Thai food. This week, he ventured north to The Heron, in a London pub ‚Äúwhose undoubtedly ugly exterior hides a boozily handsome heart‚Äù. The UK‚Äôs top 100 restaurants are revealed in Harden‚Äôs¬†Best UK Restaurants 2018 published today ‚Äì the country‚Äôs most comprehensive restaurant guide available in bookshops, with approximately twice the number of entries as The Good Food Guide. We‚Äôve got used to restaurants which claim outlets in New York ‚Äì or Paris ‚Äì and London‚Äô¬ù. But the proud boast ‚ÄòToulouse and London‚Äô¬ù is a novelty. (Indeed, the only recent provincial-French incursion into the capital that springs to mind is by the Michelin-bedecked Pourcel brothers from Montpellier, whose West End opening W‚Äôsens is thought in many quarters to make no sense at all.)

Far from being your clich√© sleepy Gallic outfit, the Toulouse original is the sort of place which aims to be a bar as much as a restaurant, complete with a website playing groovy ambient beats. The aims and appearance of its new dark ‚Äòn‚Äô lilac City namesake are in the same vein. There is an ‚Äòafter-work party every day‚Äô, and the classic regional dishes on offer include a smoked salmon ‚Äòn‚Äô vodka combo. You may be in Broadgate, but spiritually you‚Äôre supposed to be in St Tropez: the place advertises itself as the ‚ÄòFrench Riviera in London Heart‚Äô¬ù (sic). (Toulouse‚Äôs connection with the Riviera is not explained.)

Many aspects of the place have Gallic authenticity. The smiley staff all seem to have been imported from HQ. The large carte is amusingly packed with mis-spellings and mis-translations, and its diverse offerings are a reminder of just how much France‚Äôs huge culinary repertoire tends to be abbreviated for rosbif consumption.

Unlike so many London menus, prices differ materially from dish to dish, giving the impression that it‚Äôs the food you‚Äôre really paying for. This promise, however, was only inconsistently realised. A steak ‚Äì generous by British standards ‚Äì was satisfying, but two other main course meat dishes were little more than pricey meatballs. Bread and puds impressed, and coffee too, while wines include an unusual selection from B√©arn (on the fringe of the Basque Country).

chef Scott Hallsworth will officially open in Marylebone on 23 April. Another in London‚Äôs ever-growing list of ‚Äòpop-up-turned-permanent-restaurants‚Äô, Kurobuta started out as a temporary spot¬†on the Kings Road in October 2013.

The 16 bedroom¬†‚Äúold coach house/shooting lodge which enjoys a fabulous, picturesque setting‚Äù¬†near Pateley Bridge, North Yorkshire, was bought by chef [‚Ä¶]

Gordon Ramsay‚Äôs comfortable and welcoming ‚Äì if rather beige ‚Äì Belgravia dining room, offering dextrous cuisine of impeccable standards (reminiscent of Murano‚Äôs early days); a closer approach to real ‚Äòfireworks‚Äô, however, is perhaps to be found at Marcus Wareing‚Äôs establishment, three minutes‚Äô walk away.

The recent history of Gordon Ramsay, his group and its recent financial travails is too well known to repeat here. Let‚Äôs just say that we‚Äôre not the only people to believe that a lot hangs on the success of this Belgravia newcomer. (It‚Äôs being needlessly promoted as a relaunch, but the earlier P√©trus at the nearby Berkeley Hotel ‚Äì now trading under the name of the original chef, Marcus Wareing ‚Äì  stopped bearing that name over a year ago. This is for all intents and purposes a new operation, with both a new location and a new chef.)

Will P√©trus mark the beginning of a new chapter? Can Ramsay clearly demonstrate that, after all the ups and downs, his new restaurant launches are consistent with his status as the most famous chef in the English-speaking world?

Short answer: maybe. The new establishment was already hitting an impressive stride at lunch on the second day of operation. Admittedly, one of our party was known to the ma√É¬Ætre d‚Äô (and we were therefore subjected to a blinding charm offensive), but the staff managed to create an impression that was keen and caring, rather than oleaginous. The main complaint was the longeur before the arrival of the main course‚Äô but then it was day two.

As you‚Äôd hope with Mark Askew ‚Äì executive chef of the Ramsay empire for almost a decade now ‚Äì in charge of the stoves that day, the food was very sure-footed. Our meal came with a whole battery of amuses and inter-courses: fancy popcorn, small cup of velout√©, scallops with tempura-ish cauliflower, tiny lemon-cream cone, cheese with beetroot, ice lolly served with dry ice‚Äô!

We couldn‚Äôt quite work out how many of them reflected the presumption that anyone dining with the lady so well known to the ma√É¬Ætre d‚Äô must be on some sort of critical mission, but all these freebies certainly contributed to the range of sampling opportunities ‚Äì between us, something approaching 20.

There really wasn‚Äôt a dud among them. Highlights which remain in the memory include the marvellous meat in a dish of duck in ginger sauce; a classic but perfectly executed dish of pork and black pudding; and a superbly sinful ‚Äòchocolate sphere‚Äô. Ooghs and aaghs, though? These were notable by their absence.

The menu has that unmissable Ramsay stamp. This is true not only in the literal sense ‚Äì in that the group‚Äôs menus tend to look very similar, even down to a house font ‚Äì but also in the nature of the dishes themselves. Riffs on Gallic classics, you might say. It‚Äôs a can‚Äôt-go-wrong style, perfect for entertaining investments bankers anywhere. But, for us, that feeling ‚Äì go on Gordon, surprise us a bit; inject a bit of drama into our lives ‚Äì went unanswered.

The impressions of ‚Äòsafety first‚Äô ‚Äì but a lack of any real progression ‚Äì is reinforced by the dining room. Although different designers were employed, P√©trus both looks and feels just like its Mayfair stablemate Murano, which opened 16 months ago ‚Äì indeed, arguably a little less luxurious. Despite the expensively cylindrically-glazed wine ‚Äòcellar‚Äô in the centre of the room, the d√©cor has anonymity which would suit a small upmarket hotel in any part of the world where gold or black Amex cards are the usual method of payment.

But let‚Äôs step back and look at the big picture. The f-word chef ‚Äì not in evidence on our visit, as he was apparently dropping in on his new Maze in Doha (was he trying to make a point?) ‚Äì has remotely launched a restaurant which shows that he can, with the help of some of his longest-serving staff, launch a new establishment of an unimpeachably high standard.

To that extent, the first step in consolidating around the strengths of brand Ramsay have been taken. But does the brand ‚Äì or the man ‚Äì have the wish or the desire ever to escape from the past, and do something truly innovative, different and, ultimately, memorable?

This spring, street food collective KERB will launch a new outdoor market that‚Äôs sure to have foodies swarming all over London‚Äôs Southbank. is on a roll; last week he discovered Gezillig, and this week he was in east London at the the new split personality venue from celebrated mixologists Alex Kratena and Monica Berg plus Zijun Meng and Ana Gon√ßalves, the Chinese-Portuguese couple behind TƒÅ TƒÅ Eatery.

It didn‚Äôt bode well that shestarted her review with an etymology lesson; ‚Äúa siren is a mythical creature, half-bird,half-woman, who with her enchanting music lures‚Ä¶ sailors to shipwreck on a rockycoast. Alternatively, of course, in everyday life it is a warning device, analarm‚Äù.

was a little late to the party with his review of Emilia, which has been open long enough for most of the critics to have been through.

gave his trademark four stars to a ‚Äúwonderfully ramshackle barn‚Äù in the ‚Äúback garden of the back of beyond‚Äù in Somerset this week.

Yeni, London W1 Jimi Fanuwera for The Evening Standard has found his new happy place: after two hours at Yeni (‚Äù¬†a new London sibling for one of Istanbul‚Äôs hottest¬†restaurants‚Äù), all of his ‚Äúcontorting stresses and life worries had melted away‚Äù. One day it‚Äôs closed. Then open again. Then it really is closed: the builders are in. This long-established bistro has been through some ups and downs of late. It turns out that Luc, the founder, had been out of the picture for the past few years, but the r√©gime he put in place only finally hit the buffers a few months ago.

Now, it really is all-change. The new gaffer is none other than Simon Binder who, one of the staff told us, has launched no fewer than 80 restaurants. As he set up the Caf√© Med group, this apparently implausible claim is quite possibly true. Philippe Lhermitte ‚Äì  scion of the family which has run the Covent Garden bistro Mon Plaisir for over half a century ‚Äì is general manager. With these sorts of people behind the place, you‚Äôd think it couldn‚Äôt go wrong, and fortunately you‚Äôd be right.

The new team has tinkered with the layout and d√©cor of these upper-floor rooms, but the traditional style and charm of the place has mercifully been left intact. In its tightly-packed way, this remains one of London‚Äôs more convivial dining spaces. It has been made a dash more feminine, but, at least in the early days, the client√®le remains resolutely chappish.

Given the management changes, it‚Äôs perhaps odd how closely the menu of the ‚Äònew‚Äô establishment resembles that of the old. It remains straightforward and carnivorous (perhaps helping to account for the modest number of ladies present).

Standards, both on the food and service fronts, are briskly professional. There‚Äôs quite a varied Gallic wine list too, which includes some quite reasonably-priced regional choices. So, all in all, the new, 21st-century Luc‚Äôs remains a happy haven for those who wish to lunch well into the afternoon.

Lacking the sense of excitement implied by the name, this South Bank wine bar is perhaps of most note for offering free Mediterranean-style nibbles to early-evening drinkers.

The rather intriguing name drew us to this South Bank newcomer, near Blackfriars Bridge. It turns out that it‚Äôs a handy enough destination if you should find yourself in that neck of the woods, but ‚Äì with the qualification at the end of this short piece ‚Äì we would find it difficult to recommend any sort of trip.
Firstly, it‚Äôs not at all theatrical. The space is carved out of a building otherwise occupied by a Travelodge. Let‚Äôs just say it does not transcend its location.

Secondly, the wines ‚Äì though perfectly adequate ‚Äì fell well short of any sort of distinction. As a sweeping generalisation, the wine lists in London‚Äôs restaurants are probably of greater note, by international standards, than their menus. In the face of such competition, the list here, frankly, doesn‚Äôt cut it.

Thirdly, the food. Let‚Äôs just pose one question: why would any restaurant which wasn‚Äôt avowedly ‚ÄòFrench‚Äô offer a ‚Äòclassic‚Äô (cotton wool) London baguette, when almost any other type of bread ‚Äì from ciabatta to wholemeal ‚Äì  would almost certainly be done much better? What followed at our three-course lunch for one was not particularly bad, but nothing about it really upset the mundane impression that had been made by the bread basket.

But let‚Äôs end on an upbeat note. What we didn‚Äôt get to sample was the early-evening menu (5.30pm ‚Äì 8pm), but it apparently offers buffet nibbles ‚Äì to those drinking modest quantities of wine ‚Äì free, gratis and for nothing. That sounds like the sort of value that really might be worth crossing bridges for.

Oddly situated on an island site near the south end of Tower Bridge, a singular first solo venture by a young chef who worked with Tom Aikens; it offers dishes as interesting and attractive as we have found in London in recent times, and very charming service too.

It‚Äôs fortunate that this island-site Borough restaurant, not far from Tower Bridge, has had some good early-days reviews, as it‚Äôs certainly not a destination that‚Äôs ever going to make much of a living from its passing pedestrian traffic! And those who do stroll by are hardly likely just to pop in for the entry-level menu ‚Äì six courses for ¬£45.

The interior of the newly-built structure is similarly a bit of a surprise. It felt a bit like a smart, Scandinavian-style ski-lodge, decorated with bookshelves (complete with artfully disorganised volumes) and G-Plan furniture. We never particularly warmed to this interior, perhaps largely because it seemed to be the sonic equivalent of a black hole ‚Äì voices often just disappeared, even over distances where this would seem impossible.

The table appointments, however, are all rather charming ‚Äì in an rough-hewn way ‚Äì and all seemingly commissioned by the patron, Tom Sellers, himself. You soon learn that that‚Äôs the nature of things here ‚Äì the Story is all about Tom Sellers, the still-young chef/patron, who used to work with Tom Aikens.

Like all good stories, the actual meal begins with the arrival of an old fashioned lighted candle. But in this story, you eat it; we won‚Äôt spoil it for you. And then the amuse-bouches arrive. If your meal is anything like ours, this is the point at which you may begin to believe that this is one story which will have a happy ending. The nibbles are all carefully-crafted, and not at all what they initially seem, such as a sliver of cod skin that‚Äôs been toasted to the consistency of a cracker. Or there‚Äôs an Oreo-style number that‚Äôs actually largely squid‚Äôs ink. Each item is not just a surprise, but a nice surprise too. And the meal hasn‚Äôt really begun yet.

What‚Äôs remarkable is that almost everything that follows similarly twins interesting presentation, often a real delight to the eye, with surprisingly good taste and texture. So often, experimental cooking is code for ‚Äònot actually very nice‚Äô, but here the position is precisely the opposite ‚Äì everything is very nice. Almost every dish you could eat again. That‚Äôs rare enough in any multi-course meal, and perhaps even rarer where, as here, the dishes aren‚Äôt in an entirely known and usual mould. In fact, the only thing we didn‚Äôt like from six courses was one of the dishes which make up the ‚ÄòThree Bears‚Äô porridge‚Äô ‚Äì pretty much everything else was a triumph.

There are irritations of course. The whole ‚Äòstory‚Äô story can grate. Fortunately, however, even if you really try, you usually can‚Äôt hear the staff ‚Äì who are all very charming ‚Äì presenting their dishes and the, er, stories supposedly behind them. So all you can do anyway is smile and nod. But that‚Äôs the only obvious problem. This really is a story you don‚Äôt want to end.

North of Liverpool Street, an understated (to a fault) bar/restaurant offering the cuisine of Kyoto; despite the best efforts of the charming staff, and the beautiful presentation of the dishes, our early-days lunch was very dull.

We were rather excited by the idea of Chrysan ‚Äì the first non-Hakkasan-branded outlet of the group founded by Alan Yau (and from which he has now substantially sold out). Yau (currently launching the Bangkok-styled Naamyaa Caf√© in Islington) has a knack of not offering just really good food, but an atmosphere that‚Äôs often characterised as ‚Äòsexy‚Äô. He famously pulled off this trick at Hakkasan, and ‚Äì at a lower price point ‚Äì at Busaba Eathai too. This new establishment, surely,  would carry his spirit on, offering not just the refined cuisine of Kyoto, but also a good dose of slick style.
The entrance ‚Äì next to L‚ÄôAnima, a great City success-story ‚Äì  is certainly discreet. How subtle, we thought, to offer so little external hint of the excitements that undoubtedly lay within.

First impression on entering: unusually decorative staff, and they were trying very hard too. So far so good. Second impression: what happened to sexy? The bar is Japanese as if conceived by Scandinavians; it had no atmosphere at all when we swung by for a pre-lunch drink. Indeed, it was quite difficult to imagine how it ever could. Even for a business rendezvous, it seemed a cold and vacant space.

The long dining room was rather in keeping ‚Äì more elegant, but just as dull. It‚Äôs really not so hard for a restaurant to be understated in an upbeat way, as L‚ÄôAnima convincingly demonstrates. Why did Hakkasan, with all its experience, not succeed in injecting some of the same pizzazz here?

Perhaps Kyoto is supposed to be dull? Japanese culture is much too impenetrable for any outsiders like us to pronounce on authoritatively, but we have been to Kyoto, and do not recall restaurants being totally unatmospheric. If anything, rather the reverse.

Someone must have decided that this was a venture which was all about the food. The Bento boxes were a key part of the menu, so two standard boxes and a veggie one seemed the way for our party of three to get a wide choice of the kitchen‚Äôs output.

It turned out that each menu consisted of a bowl of miso soup (meaty, in the non-veggie option, which was not necessarily an advantage) plus two Perspex trays, each displaying  some of the prettiest food we have ever seen ‚Äì perhaps 20 highly-wrought mouth-sized bites.

Sadly, though, the clich√© about being ‚Äòtoo pretty to eat‚Äô turned out to be more a piece of practical advice. This was one of those lunches where, half way through, one of us asked if anyone had really tasted anything, and the answer from the rest of the party was a pretty consistent ‚Äònot really‚Äô. The only thing we can remember from the box was a superb lobster claw. The disparity between the effort which had gone into presentation, and the results on the taste front was overwhelming.

Despite the efforts of the well-meaning staff, then, we couldn‚Äôt really think of a single sort of lunch or dinner party ‚Äì Citified or otherwise ‚Äì for which this establishment could really be recommended in preference to, say, L‚ÄôAnima.

In fairness we should note that we have read very positive reviews, and that we have a suspicion that we might have done better choosing from the (relatively short) √É¬† la carte selection. The Bento boxes, however, were hardly a budget choice, and surely a natural, for a City lunch.
A pretty (but quite noisy) pub dining room, right by Borough tube, offering an enjoyable menu that‚Äôs not especially ambitious, but interesting enough to be thoroughly enjoyable.

The dining room of the Trinity public house, next door to Borough tube station, has recently been relaunched with its own name and its own identity. Be aware, though, that its signage is discreet almost to the point of invisibility ‚Äì all part, presumably, of a supposedly speakeasy-style charm.

When you do summon up the courage to venture up the anonymous stairs, and along the anonymous corridor, you come across a surprisingly attractive dining room, which looked at its very best on the sunny lunchtime we visited ‚Äì window tables are definitely to be preferred. Despite the successful prettification, however, this is a room which still shows its pub heritage, and all those hard surfaces can make it noisy.

The menu is mainly composed of straightforward food with a modest twist, but we started off with the simplest of dishes that‚Äôs all about sourcing, freshness and presentation ‚Äì the oysters passed those tests with flying colours. Two of us then eschewed the meatier main course options, preferring to share half a dozen small plates between us. And a very convivial lunch it was, even with just a modest glass of wine apiece. Nothing was trying too hard, everything was enjoyable, and some dishes ‚Äì such as scallops in filo pastry with harrissa mayo ‚Äì were really very good. Surprise highlight, though, was a notably light pear and almond tart.

We visited in the first week (an offer period), and service was still rather ebbing and flowing. Everyone was trying hard, though, and we‚Äôd be surprised if they don‚Äôt ultimately settle in to a more even rhythm.

We did wonder if prices might have seemed just a fraction high, as we spent just over ¬£40 for two‚Äô with all the food half price. All the more reason, then, to seek out the set lunch menu now available, which offers two of those small plates, plus a side, for just a tenner.

was in the Cotswolds, seeking out normality in the form of Sri Lankan street food, as a way of re-establishing what‚Äôs good after the recent atrocities. ‚ÄúTalking about the country‚Äôs vivid food ‚Äì its way with coconut, turmeric, cardamom and chillies ‚Äì is so very much better than talking about all the other stuff we‚Äôve heard from Sri Lanka recently.‚Äù

The Coconut Tree is a ‚Äúbare-bones fit-out‚Äù of ‚Äúaknackered old pub on the St Paul‚Äôs Road in the student area‚Äù, owned by fivefriends from Colombo (via Croydon). was at The Rose in Deal, a ‚Äúrecently tarted-up pub, restaurant and boutique hotel‚Äù that‚Äôs proof positive that London has arrived in the seaside town.

It‚Äôs a ‚Äúplutonium-grade revampment‚Ä¶ fromrough-and-ready‚Ä¶ old-school boozer to chic magnet for mini-breakers‚Äù,although locals may not agree. Those dishes that were on the menu were a letdown, too, from‚Äúhugely overdone smoked haddock‚Äù to ‚Äúbland‚Äù skordalia(Greek garlic and potato mash), while puddings were of the type that‚Äúcontestants choose on MasterChef when they either cannot cook or arebeing strong-armed into making a pudding‚Äù.
. After three decades and three additional restaurants since the Hammersmith original, ‚Äúthe group¬†has stayed true to its vision on seriously tasty food‚Äù.

wanted ‚Äì and expected ‚Äì to dislike Gloria, a ‚Äúgreat, fat fake, not so much restaurant as stage set, a cod-Italian import from a French company called the Big Mamma Group‚Äù. ‚ÄúSerious isn‚Äôt the house style‚Äù ‚Äì and Marinawas sucked in on both her visits, diving right in to the ‚Äúlarger than life‚Äùattitude and decoration. has had great feedback on some of the ‚Äúkeenly priced, accessible, local little places‚Äù he‚Äôs featured recently, so this week, as well as taking his wife to Soutine, the new Corbin & King arrival, on a pre-launch visit, he also visited ‚Äúan inconspicuous little pizza joint‚Äù in the Holloway Road (listed in

was the first to re-visit Bonham‚Äôs, where the restaurant space has been taken over by the group that owns Quality Chop House, Portland and Clipstone, ‚Äútwo young restaurateurs at the top of their game‚Äù.

Thebar, with sunny courtyard, has a separate snacks menu, which ‚Äúmay be the placefor those who are not given regularly to bidding for fine art‚Äù. (****)

visited the new hotel restaurant from Mark Greenaway who closed his eponymous place last year; he‚Äôs now opened up in the space that previously held Galvin Brasserie de Luxe. ‚ÄúAt his own restaurants ‚Äì Bistro Moderne and Restaurant Mark Greenaway ‚Äì there was theatre and a sense of occasion. This feels a bit like the stifled and lite version of his cooking/style.‚Äù (70%)

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.

A very good all-rounder, this money-no-object conversion of a grand Georgian house, near Canary Wharf, offers Indian cuisine of high quality, and efficient service, in an elegantly contemporary setting.

There have been a couple of attempts at turning this very grand Georgian house into an Indian restaurant. Neither lasted very long, but ‚Äì undaunted ‚Äì new proprietors have spent a great deal of money to turn this into quite a palace (if not one, to any obvious extent, of an Indian variety).

The new r√©gime has even tacked an impressive new glazed annex, overlooking a garden, on to what‚Äôs already quite a considerable building. The result is an interior which is as attractive as any in the purlieus of Canary Wharf (but one which, contrariwise, is going to have to build up quite a following if it‚Äôs not always to feel a little empty).

Food and service on our early-days visit were both very good. The cuisine is perhaps a step down in inventiveness from the West End haute-Indians, but it‚Äôs none the worse for that ‚Äì we enjoyed our meal from beginning to end, and everything was attractively presented, without tipping into prissiness.

For business entertaining  ‚Äì or, by night, quite possible even for romance ‚Äì we think we might just be seeing the emergence of new star in the East. And, at lunch, the prix fixe menu offers value that‚Äôs well worth seeking out.

Our reviews are based on an annual survey of ordinary diners which runs in Spring each year. But this establishment has not yet gathered enough feedback for our editors to write it up.

Write a quick review now using our restaurant diary service. That way it might catch our attention. Next survey, you can transfer your diary entry into our survey system. Everyone who contributes 5 or more reviews in our survey will qualify for a free guide.
For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.
In a small and perhaps slightly subdued space, just off Carnaby Street, a corner barbecue specialist offering a small range of dishes of very high quality.

So much wanted to hate this new corner spot, just off Carnaby Street . Trendy menu (American barbecue), street food origins (under Hungerford Bridge, since you ask), bloggers delight What could there possibly be to like about it?

Almost everything, it seems. First surprise is that - far from the self-conscious streetiness and din of, say, MEATLiquor- this bright and tightly-packed corner spot has a rather old-fashioned style thats something remarkably close to teashop-prim, especially by Soho standards.
Second surprise is that the service - rather than attempting to be too-cool-for-school - is just very efficient and helpful.

Third surprise? Well, how many proper restaurants actually offer food such that, the next day, you feel youd like to go back and eat it all again? Such was the status achieved by our pulled pork (which is one of the house speciality dishes). A changing range of interesting sides, such as marrow mash, is also included. The food all comes on white and blue enamel workmens tin dishes but, hey, nowheres perfect.

Our one-course lunch, including a glass of the house red (in a Duralex tumbler) and service cost ¬£18 for one - perhaps not the very cheapest available in this part of town, but certainly one of the best.

Alongside tapas classics, dishes at Barullo will include ‚Äòkiko‚Äô fried chicken (‚ÄòKFC‚Äô, get it?), which is brined in sherry and dusted with corn nuts and served with an alegria pepper chutney; paella with giant prawns, confit pork belly and tail, and piquillo peppers; and toasted and pressed suckling pig with salsa verde, kohlrabi, and green apple coleslaw.

Garvey told Harden‚Äôs: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really excited to be opening in the City and on such a great site. I love having restaurants in the West End but the Square Mile has a totally different energy to it that I think will work really well for a place like Barullo.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an area under-served by good independent restaurants and I think people who live and work around there, as well as tourists, will welcome somewhere that‚Äôs offering something different.‚Äù

An instant smash-hit, this convivial Parisian-inspired steakhouse, on the site of the old Stock Exchange building, offers an excellent all-round fixed-price formula.

Rarely have the massed ranks of Britain‚Äôs finest national restaurant critics talked such unadulterated tripe as they did on the launch of London‚Äôs original outpost of a Parisian steakhouse, back in 2005. Very sensibly, the public took no notice at all, and the Marylebone restaurant has been a hit since day one.

The group has now launched a bigger, and even better, branch, in the heart of the City. Bigger it may be, but it‚Äôs already heaving. Well, what‚Äôs not to like? A tasty salad is followed by a hearty portion of steak (in two services) with ‚Äòspecial sauce‚Äô and unlimited frites, in a cosy, convivial and convenient setting.
And at eminently reasonable prices too. The basic all-in meal is ¬£19 plus service. Recession or not ‚Äì hey, even depression or not ‚Äì that sounds to us like a pretty much perfect formula.

Grand hotels are supposed to be timeless and unchanging. Not the Dorchester, though, which always seems to be spending money like water, re-jigging and re-doing, in a never-ending quest for‚Äô well, who knows?

The hotel used to have the good-but-extremely-dull Chinese restaurant, The Dorchester Oriental, which closed last year. This is its replacement, but in a new site, in the basement, where the Dorchester Club ‚Äì a sort of Annabel‚Äôs that never quite made it ‚Äì used to be.

The ‚ÄòTang‚Äô in the new venture comes from famed Hong Kong designer, David Tang (personally much in evidence on our visit). At the entrance, he‚Äôs created a ‚Äòclassic‚Äô Art Deco cocktail bar, which makes a knockout initial impression. You then pass by a luxurious suite of private dining rooms. After all this build-up, the dining room itself is a big let-down. If the lighting had been better, perhaps it wouldn‚Äôt have felt just one step up from Chinatown. It doesn‚Äôt help that the seats and banquettes are not especially comfortable.

The lunchtime menu is mainly dim sum, of a quality varying from good to very good. Dishes by their nature are not large, but the prices (typically ¬£4-¬£10) are such that you could have a light lunch here quite reasonably. Beware, though. When we asked for a ‚Äòcouple of extra dishes‚Äô, the waiter  ‚Äì without asking if it was OK ‚Äì raided the top end of the menu to bring us suckling pig (¬£16) and rather boring salt-baked chicken (¬£26). Including the 12.5% service, this puffed the bill up from around ¬£130 for three (which would have been good value) to ¬£180 (which wasn‚Äôt).
As a dinner destination, you‚Äôd pay at least ¬£60 a head for a meal we‚Äôd guess would be good, but a bit on the dull side. Now didn‚Äôt the Dorchester used to have‚Äô

Food-with-a-conscience is at the heart of this wholesome new diner-concept, now housed in a large basement, down the hill from St Paul‚Äôs. It is ‚Äònew‚Äô in the sense that the popular first branch, in the West End, was apparently deemed too small to display the backers‚Äô vision properly. We still can‚Äôt work out, though, whether ‚Äì here or at the original branch ‚Äì the concept really works or not.

Plus points include: an unusual range of well-sourced food that‚Äôs fresh and sometimes interesting; staff who seem to have borrowed Pret A Manger‚Äôs happy pills; and a greater level of style than you can generally expect for a lunch that will probably cost less than a tenner.

The biggest negative is the inherently chaotic, fast-food counter-service of such a wide range of dishes and drinks. It just about works while everyone‚Äôs trying their hardest, but on a bad day‚Äô? (At night, in contrast, ‚Äùrelaxed‚Äô table service‚Äô¬ù is offered.) And ‚Äì call us old-fashioned ‚Äì we don‚Äôt like having our salad served in a greasy cardboard box, with plastic knives and forks.

What really makes the place a critical nightmare is that many of its features teeter between being brilliant and inspired, and contrived and irritating. These include both the look of the room ‚Äì like Central Perk (√É¬† la Friends) gone garage ‚Äì and of the menu. The latter apes a student newspaper, complete with matey tone ‚Äì ‚ÄòBig kiss to you all this autumn‚Äô¬ù ‚Äì and its look has a spurious informality that must have cost thousands to achieve. And is the name Spanish? And why are in-house posters done as if in Barcelona, circa 1935? And so on.
So, is it the next big thing? The backers are about to test their offering on Knightsbridge and Strand, so we won‚Äôt have to wait too long to find out.

is the latest critic to visit Tom Kerridge‚Äôs long-awaited London home, and she ‚Äúwas delighted with everything‚Äù, even the fish ‚Äòn‚Äô chips which cost almost ¬£33 but came with ‚Äúspecial, once-in-a-lifetime chips‚Ä¶ triple-cooked with an ethereal, golden shimmer‚Äù.

magazine enjoyed his¬† meal at Kaki so much, he went back for more the very next day. Portions are gargantuan (the waiter laughed when he ordered three dishes), but the fare is authentically Chinese ‚Äì there‚Äôs ‚Äúno Anglo-Cantonese crowd-pleasers‚Äù here ‚Äì or even a wine list in English.

warns us of the dangers of a ‚Äúlane swerve‚Äù. He‚Äôs mostly thinking about Spandau Ballet, but also about Yotam Ottolenghi, whose new Fitzrovia (geddit?) opening is indeed a lane swerve ‚Äì ‚Äúa subtle one, but a swerve all the same‚Äù.

doesn‚Äôt so much review Plaquemine Lock in Islington as write it a love letter. The Cajun-Creole-influenced pub comes to us courtesy of¬†Jacob Kenedy (of Bocca di Lupo fame)‚Ä¶
‚ÄúA celebration of the food of the Louisiana basin‚Ä¶¬†The walls are painted a hot, sultry yellow overlaid by naive murals of life on the bayou; of plantation houses and river boats.‚Äù

‚ÄúGumbo, by the cup and bowl, is as it should be: a deep, luscious stew of sausage and chicken, with crawfish added late on so they don‚Äôt tense up, in a reassuringly thickened liquor so profound it can give focus to an aimless life.¬†Southern fried chicken ‚Ä¶comes with a vibrant slaw of the sort deep-fried food demands, and the revelation of pickled watermelon.‚Äù

in The Guardian this week as she heads to the City‚Äôs latest hotel and restaurant hub The Ned (reviewing all nine restaurants in two days!)‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThere is a sweet story behind this crowd-funded operation in one of the three railway arches that make up Fount London‚Ä¶ Luca and Gianni have been friends since they were eight, growing up together in the hamlet of Carimate near Lake Como. ‚ÄúThe product turns out to be exceptional, with vivacious personality and a whiff of the soft crumb of just-baked bread missing in other pastas‚Ä¶¬†risotto alla Milanese, a rippling golden pond flecked with saffron.¬†Parmigiana di melanzane is aubergine, tomatoes, garlic, cheese and herbs scooped from a large baking tray rather than sealed into a little dish of its own and is all the more succulent, successful and homely for that.‚Äù
Has every critic now been to Chinatown‚Äôs new Xu (from¬†the estimable JKS Restaurants stable)? It seems like there has been a review a week for this Taiwanese venture. This week its the

‚ÄúA few of the 200 or so restaurants that plop annually on to London‚Äôs landscape arrive fully pre-imbued with hotness. They ping to life festooned with praise, laden with influencer-driven merry piffle, often before the stoves have been fitted. Xu, a Taiwanese 1930s-style restaurant/teahouse on Rupert Street, is such an arrival.

‚ÄúTiny lunchtime foie gras terrine ‚Äògold coins‚Äô embossed with a layer of Shaoxing wine jelly, a terrine of wobbly, glistening, numbing beef tendon‚Ä¶ tea is available, but the cocktails are serious. Try a Daiga, a tiny, fearsome, delicious sipping glass of amontillado sherry, cognac, Chinese mushroom and liquorice root. I guarantee the world will feel better within two tiny mouthfuls.‚Äù

‚ÄúAlmost everything about Xu makes my heart thump at its chutzpah. The set-up is undoubtedly a huge labour of love for the owners.¬†I wish I‚Äôd loved the food more than I did‚Ä¶¬†Xu is both one of the most important openings of 2017 and at the same time disappointing.‚Äù
‚ÄúOne of a fringe of excellent, no-nonsense seafood specialists running up the UK‚Äôs east coast‚Ä¶ a¬†citadel of bourgeois solidity.‚Äù

‚ÄúInto the smoke go, for the most part, local fish and seafood of impeccable pedigree. If you don‚Äôt like fish, they also do succulent duck breasts and a rubicund smoked ham‚Ä¶¬†there wasn‚Äôt a huge amount of cheffery on display ‚Äì just sure judgment and patient craftsmanship over time.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe pi√®ce de r√©sistance, really, was my smoked fish hors d‚Äôoeuvres ‚Äì just several chunks, and a few entire specimens, of eel, mackerel, salmon and more, arrayed on a biggish plate, with not much adornment beyond a bit of horseradish for the eel.¬†All around you, earth and water (both sweet and salt) are seeking balance. Fire and air, in the¬†tiny temples of the Orford Smokehouse,¬†complete a timeless elemental package.‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything was wonderfully fresh and meltingly good, especially the lovely, brightly coloured tuna. And it wasn‚Äôt just the raw stuff that was delicious. The black cod was great; perfectly cooked and with a subtle amount of miso.‚Äù
in The Daily Mail reviewed the Wife of Bath, a quintessentially English Kent inn which was taken over by¬†Mark Sargeant (Rocksalt) and turned into a restaurant inspired by northern Spanish cuisine‚Ä¶

‚ÄúSargeant has taken over this pretty house in the pretty Kentish village of Wye, and made it his own. The room is daubed in a discreetly expensive grey, with lots of blonde wood, Spanish woodcuts and the odd cast-iron bull. Iberia, by way of Conran‚Ä¶¬†the [flamenco] music doesn‚Äôt irk, thanks, perhaps, to the radiant warmth and charm of the service, and the easy, unpretentious feel of the place. It‚Äôs been open only a few months, yet already seems lived-in, and comfortable in its own skin.

‚ÄúA plump ‚Äòbon bon‚Äô doesn‚Äôt ooze in the Barafina style, rather¬† clads chorizo ‚Äì studded mashed potato, light as a wink, in a crisp crust.¬†Rather like the morcilla croquette, gently spiced and mildly ferric, with a rich tomato sauce.

‚ÄúThrow in a wine list that offers real value, plus the heaven-sent service I‚Äôve already banged on about. And you have a restaurant to relish‚Ä¶¬†Just like Chaucer‚Äôs eponymous lady, this Wife of Bath is a real goer.‚Äù

Paddington Basin. The Final Frontier. Well, perhaps not quite. But you do feel as though you are boldly going where no one has been before, when you enter central(ish) London‚Äôs last major bit of in-fill development. It‚Äôs hard to find: the easiest way is to start at Paddington station‚Äôs Heathrow platform, and to follow the signs to ‚ÄòMarks & Spencer‚Äô (whose new HQ is the development‚Äôs anchor tenant).

Once you‚Äôre there, this canalside development is, in an Americanised kind of way, surprisingly attractive ‚Äò given that it‚Äôs dominated by a flyover (the Westway). It helps that the landlords ‚Äì no doubt with lavish incentives ‚Äì have attracted a critical mass of restaurants, including an already-popular Japanese (Yakitoria), an airy gastropub (The Union), a soon-to-open fish specialist, and the Chinese restaurant we review today.

The rambling dining room occupies a lower level of the development. It‚Äôs short on natural light, and the designers have run with a sort of opium-den chic. The overall effect is comfortable, even if the chair/table heights/depths don‚Äôt quite work, and the acoustics are tricky. While we‚Äôre on negatives, the service does not make up in efficiency what it lacks in charm.

The food, though, is a redeeming feature. Dim sum are a speciality (served lunch and dinner), and come at a prices reminiscent of Chinatown, and up to the same standards as the best operators there. Larger dishes ‚Äì such as Peking Duck and steamed sea bass ‚Äì were also realised to a superior standard. Puddings included an oddly satisfying, blue blancmange-y number. In fact, everything was consistently above par.
So, when you‚Äôre next passing (just kidding) give the place a try. Or, if you‚Äôre a real fan of Chinese cooking, you might even find it positively worth seeking out.
For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.
A pretty (but quite noisy) pub dining room, right by Borough tube, offering an enjoyable menu thats not especially ambitious, but interesting enough to be thoroughly enjoyable.

The dining room of the Trinity public house, next door to Borough tube station, has recently been relaunched with its own name and its own identity. Be aware, though, that its signage is discreet almost to the point of invisibility - all part, presumably, of a supposedly speakeasy-style charm.

When you do summon up the courage to venture up the anonymous stairs, and along the anonymous corridor, you come across a surprisingly attractive dining room, which looked at its very best on the sunny lunchtime we visited - window tables are definitely to be preferred. Despite the successful prettification, however, this is a room which still shows its pub heritage, and all those hard surfaces can make it noisy.

The menu is mainly composed of straightforward food with a modest twist, but we started off with the simplest of dishes thats all about sourcing, freshness and presentation - the oysters passed those tests with flying colours. Two of us then eschewed the meatier main course options, preferring to share half a dozen small plates between us. And a very convivial lunch it was, even with just a modest glass of wine apiece. Nothing was trying too hard, everything was enjoyable, and some dishes - such as scallops in filo pastry with harrissa mayo - were really very good. Surprise highlight, though, was a notably light pear and almond tart.

We visited in the first week (an offer period), and service was still rather ebbing and flowing. Everyone was trying hard, though, and wed be surprised if they dont ultimately settle in to a more even rhythm.

We did wonder if prices might have seemed just a fraction high, as we spent just over ¬£40 for two with all the food half price. All the more reason, then, to seek out the set lunch menu now available, which offers two of those small plates, plus a side, for just a tenner.

Recently refurbished, one of London‚Äôs most artistically impressive dining rooms, offering a dining experience well above the cultural-destination average, plus a wine list of some note.

Society artist Rex Whister was in his early 20s when, in 1926, he was commissioned to decorate a new dining room at the National Gallery of British Art (which went on to become known as the Tate half a decade later). Having survived the early misfortune (1928) of being flooded, this is London‚Äôs most obviously ‚Äòartistic‚Äô restaurant dining room by far. Where else could you lunch entirely surrounded by a sylvan mural such as ‚ÄòThe Expedition in Pursuit of Rare Meats‚Äô?

The setting being a very special one (even if the room is oddly bisected by a row of sturdy columns), the natural fear is that the rest of the experience will be a bit of a let-down. That, however, was far from being our experience on a visit on New Year‚Äôs Day.

The menu ‚Äì traditional in spirit, historical in theming, and with the occasional gentle twist to stop it being boring ‚Äì is nicely judged both for the setting and for the crowd the place is likely to attract. Our family party enjoyed everything served, with the exception of some palid p√É¬¢tisserie ‚Äì the cheese plate was much the better option.

There was the occasional real highlight too ‚Äì such as the bread, and a surprisingly excellent plate of lemon sole goujons. And wines, in accordance with long-standing precedent, remain impressive ‚Äì the sommelier-selected matching options, not expensive, were interesting and appropriate, offering a refreshing change from the known-and-usual trap into which most diners naturally tend to fall.

Only one real irritation: is anyone at all tasked with the job of sweeping up used glasses? The otherwise charming and efficient staff seem quite blind to the build up of the detritus of dining. By the end of our meal the unsightly litter on the table still included not just all the wine glasses, but even the remnants of our pre-prandial drinks.
A room like this cries out for the proprieties ‚Äì perhaps even including a bit of gentle ‚Äòbrushing down‚Äô? ‚Äì to be properly observed.
Next week is not only British Tomato Week and Vegetarian Week, it is also London Wine Week. There are absolutely loads of events, tastings and pairing dinners happening across the capital (

). With all this talk of sipping Sancerre and quaffing Crozes Hermitage as got us thinking ‚Äì where are London‚Äôs most interesting wine lists? Here are 20 of our favourites, in no particular order‚Ä¶

‚ÄúA new and fantastic experience every time‚Äù; with its menu of ‚Äúquirky‚Äù small-plate dishes (usually meaty) and ‚Äúcheapish and unusual wines‚Äù, this ‚Äúnoisy‚Äù Shoreditch canteen is ‚Äúalways a joy‚Äù; indeed, the survey rates it more highly than its fabled Smithfield parent.

‚ÄúA weird and wonderful wine list with some corkers‚Äù (and ‚Äúsome like home brew!‚Äù) is the undoubted star at this ‚Äúreassuring‚Äù Gallic bistro, near Charing Cross; its ‚Äústrongly flavoured‚Äù small plates inspire more diverse reactions than they used to, though, and service can sometimes be ‚Äúchaotic‚Äù. Also check out Caves de Pry√®ne‚Äôs East Dulwich yearling

‚ÄúAmbitious‚Äù, ‚Äúmeticulously executed‚Äù cuisine and ‚Äúan interesting and varied wine list‚Äù (presided over by an award-winning sommelier) make this Chelsea spot ‚Äúmore than just a neighbourhood gem‚Äù; fans say the ambience is ‚Äúlovely‚Äù too, though critics find it ‚Äúunremarkable‚Äù.

‚ÄúA hidden gem, only 100m from the Millennium Bridge‚Äù, and offering ‚Äústunning‚Äù views from the outside tables; its culinary appeal is ‚Äústraight down the line‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúexcellent steak‚Äù plus ‚Äúamazing South African wines‚Äù, so ‚Äúbe sure to walk through the temperature-controlled cellars‚Äù.

‚ÄúAn oasis of peace‚Äù, ‚Äútucked away‚Äù in a Mayfair mews with ‚Äúdiscreet‚Äù service, where Arnaud Bignon‚Äôs ‚Äúinventive but un-gimmicky‚Äù cuisine is the counterpoint to an ‚Äúenormous‚Äù, ‚Äúconnoisseur‚Äôs‚Äù wine list; apart from the fact it‚Äôs ‚Äúcripplingly expensive‚Äù, what‚Äôs not to like?

‚ÄúAn outstanding all-rounder‚Äù ‚Äì Gordon Ramsay‚Äôs Belgravia dining room may be a bit ‚Äúcorporate‚Äù in feel, but no one‚Äôs complaining about its ‚Äúwonderful culinary creativity‚Äù, ‚Äúlegendary wine list‚Äù or ‚Äútip-top‚Äù service.

‚ÄúAstoundingly good‚Äù ‚Äì the food in the upstairs room of this relaunched Soho wine bar can come as a ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù‚Ä¶ until you learn that it is now overseen by Hedone‚Äôs Mikael Jonsson; on the ground floor, you get ‚Äúfantastic biodynamic and natural wines‚Äù too.

‚ÄúGet a seat in the cave ‚Äì it‚Äôs about as interesting a place to get drunk as there is!‚Äù; by Embankment tube, this cellar wine bar, which also boasts a huge terrace, is a ‚Äúfun‚Äù spot, with an ‚Äúexcellent and varied‚Äù wine list; ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt really go for the food‚Äù.

‚ÄúLimited but fascinating‚Äù, the wine list is the ‚Äústar‚Äù at this ‚Äúconvivial‚Äù Covent Garden two-year-old, explaining why its ‚Äúcrowded‚Äù quarters are so ‚Äúbusy, busy, busy‚Äù; ‚Äúdecent‚Äù food plays a supporting role.

‚ÄúTake the wine flight‚Äù, if you visit the famous grocer‚Äôs basement wine bar, where you can ‚Äúsample a huge variety of very good wines‚Äù ‚Äì their whole list is available, plus ¬£10 corkage; the tapas-style platters also make it a decent ‚Äúsnack lunch‚Äù option.

‚ÄúThankfully Leicester Square is not totally lost to chain restaurants‚Äù, and this ‚Äúquirky‚Äù ‚Äô70s basement ‚Äúfeels like a step back in time‚Äù (even after recent refurb); the food‚Äôs not the main event, but ‚Äúyou‚Äôre spoilt for choice for wines‚Äù.

‚ÄúThe best Loire wine list in the world‚Äù has long been the special appeal of this remarkably consistent stalwart, near the National Theatre; it would win few prizes for interior design, but service is ‚Äúefficient‚Äù, and the food is ‚Äúdependable‚Äù and ‚Äúreasonably-priced‚Äù.
‚ÄúThe perfect place to entertain all wine buffs!‚Äù ‚Äì a lively bar, offering a ‚Äúvery large assortment‚Äù of wines by the glass; the food is ‚Äúprobably of secondary interest‚Äù.
A ‚Äúhuge range of wines by the glass‚Äù garners plenty of praise for this pub-conversion near Notting Hill Gate ‚Äì the food is rather incidental.

A ‚Äúone-off‚Äù; these ancient City cellars offer ‚Äúa place for wine lovers to explore and relax‚Äù, and their ‚Äúeclectic and expert array of wines‚Äù (at cost plus a small mark-up) is the ‚Äústar of the show‚Äù ‚Äì the picnic-style buffet is ‚Äújust so you can say you had something to eat while you drank‚Äù!
A Haggerston ‚Äúoasis‚Äù ‚Äì a ‚Äúpersonal‚Äù operation, where an interesting wine list, including some ‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù finds, is backed up by ‚Äúa good small selection of food‚Äù.

It doesn‚Äôt fully live up to its cathedral-like setting under South Bank railway arches, but this caf√© attached to a museum of wine served some ‚Äúsurprisingly good‚Äù meals this year ‚Äì recommended pre-theatre, and for Sunday lunch. Catch it while you can, Cantina Vinopolis will close in December to make way for a shopping centre.

This ‚Äúunder-the-arches foodie destination‚Äù ‚Äì in the ‚Äònew‚Äô Borough Market ‚Äì offers a ‚Äúmost interesting selection of bio and small producer wines‚Äù, complemented by ‚Äúoutstanding‚Äù small-plate dishes; ‚Äúget there early as it‚Äôs full by 8 pm‚Äù.

‚ÄúHeaven for wine lovers‚Äù; these ‚Äúcramped‚Äù bars are run by staff ‚Äúwith a real passion for inspiring their customers‚Äù with their ‚Äúcreative‚Äù and very ‚Äúsensibly-priced‚Äù list; the ‚Äúsimple‚Äù bistro fare? ‚Äì ‚Äúsound but unexciting‚Äù.

‚ÄúThe food is fine, but the real story is the wine‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúinteresting selections by the glass‚Äù, and a ‚Äúkiller collector‚Äôs list of old and rare bottles with modest mark-ups‚Äù are making a big hit of this growing bistro chain; it‚Äôs often hailed as ‚Äúa good choice for lunch‚Äù.
From the owners of the ‚Äúbuzzing‚Äù Truscott Arms in Maida Vale comes a new wine bar in Belsize Park with Aidan McGee (formerly of Dinner) spearheading the kitchen.

A welcome addition to Mile End‚Äôs Roman Road that‚Äôs winning a devoted following among locals for its carefully selected wines from small, indy growers. There‚Äôs also a small but tasty menu of French and Italian dishes, excellent coffee too.

A tiny and crammed Fitzrovia parlour, specialising in hot dogs and champagne; we couldn‚Äôt quite rationalise the appeal on our early days visit, but it was certainly already drawing in the punters.

A small neon sign above an unimposing street frontage announces the name of this discreet newcomer. Might we be in Greenwich Village? Er, no ‚Äì it‚Äôs Fitzrovia. The feeling of dislocation increases as, having gone down the small entrance corridor, we approach the actual dining room. It‚Äôs full of people, almost all of the same age (25-35), many standing, most drinking champagne. Just after noon.

A corporate party? Someone filming a homage to Sex and the City? Was our journey therefore in vain? Turns out not: we could be squeezed into the last available ‚Äòspace‚Äô (by a shelf, pictured); this is just a normal day at a newcomer which has captured the imagination of the local media-world worker bees with a bizarrely improbable formula billed as ‚Äòhot dogs and champagne‚Äô.

Can it really mean that? Well, the hot dog bit is true enough. Three sorts of sausage (beef, pork, veggie) come about a dozen different ways. The one we tried ‚Äì a Fourth of July seemed appropriate ‚Äì was certainly tasty enough (if perhaps not of any great character), and we had it with some very good tater tots (potato croquettes), which is one of the tiny range of accompaniments. No puds (yet). No coffee.

And the drink they push really is champagne. Our glass of Gaston Chiquet ‚Äì the same one they pour at Sheekey‚Äôs ‚Äì was ¬£6.50. There‚Äôs a wide choice of other ‚Äògrower‚Äô champagnes, as they call them, too plus ‚Äì and here the hype does give way to reality a bit ‚Äì a range of not inexpensive still wines and beers too.

Notwithstanding this basic failure, does the formula seem to work? Well, it certainly seemed to be keeping the punters happy on our lunchtime visit. But a younger colleague, a New Yorker, who subsequently went on a Saturday evening, found the hot dog too bland and well-mannered, and the appeal of the overall formula difficult to see.

Perhaps, then, this really is one of those, mercifully quite rare, reviews where the only answer is recommend you go and see for yourself. It‚Äôs not  a huge investment ‚Äì a glass of champagne, a hot dog and a basket of tots weighs in at a fraction under ¬£20.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.

Grand hotels are supposed to be timeless and unchanging. Not the Dorchester, though, which always seems to be spending money like water, re-jigging and re-doing, in a never-ending quest for well, who knows?

The hotel used to have the good-but-extremely-dull Chinese restaurant, The Dorchester Oriental, which closed last year. This is its replacement, but in a new site, in the basement, where the Dorchester Club - a sort of Annabels that never quite made it - used to be.

The Tang in the new venture comes from famed Hong Kong designer, David Tang (personally much in evidence on our visit). At the entrance, hes created a classic Art Deco cocktail bar, which makes a knockout initial impression. You then pass by a luxurious suite of private dining rooms. After all this build-up, the dining room itself is a big let-down. If the lighting had been better, perhaps it wouldnt have felt just one step up from Chinatown. It doesnt help that the seats and banquettes are not especially comfortable.

The lunchtime menu is mainly dim sum, of a quality varying from good to very good. Dishes by their nature are not large, but the prices (typically ¬£4-¬£10) are such that you could have a light lunch here quite reasonably. Beware, though. When we asked for a couple of extra dishes, the waiter  - without asking if it was OK - raided the top end of the menu to bring us suckling pig (¬£16) and rather boring salt-baked chicken (¬£26). Including the 12.5% service, this puffed the bill up from around ¬£130 for three (which would have been good value) to ¬£180 (which wasnt).

Atop Centre Point, a surprisingly ‚Äì but not disagreeably ‚Äì plain and straightforward dining room, with one of the finest vistas in town.

To visit the landmark which is Centre Point is to be taken back to a different, poorer London. The building (completed in ‚Äô66) may at the time have been perceived as a sign of thrusting optimism, but today‚Äôs visitor‚Äôs immediate impression is how poor the building ‚Äòspec‚Äô was compared to what we accept as the norm today. Call that sad little thing an entrance? Where‚Äôs the atrium?

And so it is when you ascend to the 28th floor. The low ceiling. The lack of finish. Did you know that, back in the ‚Äô60s, they apparently regarded emulsion (paint!) as an acceptable wall finishing, even in ‚Äòprestige‚Äô projects?

Even dolled up for its new life as a restaurant (having recently been a club), this is still a plain space, with plain d√©cor and plain (and very ‚Äô60s-looking) furniture. If this has been the original executive lounge after the construction of the building ‚Äì we know it wasn‚Äôt, as the building famously remained vacant for many years ‚Äì one imagines that this is just how it might have felt. (Compare with Madison Avenue ‚Äì as recently depicted in ‚ÄòMad Men‚Äô¬ù ‚Äì and you can see just how much more comfortable ‚Äô60s office life must have been in New York than it was in London.)

Whereas the dining room, however, could convincingly pass for ‚Äô60s in a movie, the view could not. The vista here ‚Äì of the ‚Äònew‚Äô City, and Canary Wharf in full panoply ‚Äì is ‚Äòup there‚Äô with the one from Galvin at Windows. It makes a great setting for a business lunch.

Indeed, the place seems all the more practical as a business lunch venue because the lack of fuss that surround the whole operation is entirely in keeping with the d√©cor. The service is pleasant, and efficient enough, but devoid of pretensions, and the food is likewise.

Our entirely straightforward lunch included a chicken salad (which, for those of us of a certain age,was a bit too reminiscent of what we used to see on mum‚Äôs Robert Carrier cookery course cards), a decent soup, an excellent pork chop and a reasonable bit of skate.

How would the formula stack up at night? We‚Äôd be interested to go back then, when the vista will change, the d√©cor will fade to relative insignificance, and, √É¬† la carte bills will be higher. But, for first-time visitors, we suspect that view will always carry the day.

In the late-‚Äô90s, mega-scale restaurants such as Mezzo and Quaglino‚Äôs were taken as proof that London was becoming the centre of the culinary world. But funnily enough, none of those spaces ever made you want to say ‚Äòwow‚Äô.

‚ÄòWow!‚Äô is a word that easily springs to mind as you enter this vast newcomer, in the offbeat location of Camden Market. You don‚Äôt need to have read the press release about the 500 covers, the 10,000-strong Indian design team, or the longest bar in the world (hand-carved from Lapis stone) to realise that someone has just dropped shed-loads of cash creating this place.

Huge wood carvings span from floor to ceiling. Down one side, a glass curtain-wall looks ‚Äì bizarrely ‚Äì onto a heavy good line (with the odd passing freight train for added amusement). Do we sound impressed? We were! And also by the affable service. Inevitably, though, the sensation is of eating in a huge venue or nightclub rather than a restaurant ‚Äì something the huge bar and prominent DJ did nothing to dispel.

How could the pan-Asian food live up? And especially at prices, which certainly don‚Äôt aim to attract passing Goths, punks or whatever Camden trendies call themselves nowadays. The initial crowd looked more staid than you might expect for such a scene, presumably having heard that Ian Pengelley (ex E&O and the doomed Pengelleys) was at the stoves.

All our dishes were beautifully presented, and the sushi and sashimi in particular passed muster. Overall though, awareness of the hefty prices stifled some of the enjoyment, as did a middle-of-the-road quality in many dishes. Puddings were extremely boring.

All that said, the place delivers a very different Big Night Out. So we‚Äôve awarded this brave but batty venture four stars. Can it succeed? Well that‚Äôs the $64,000 ‚Äì no, if the rumours are true make that the ¬£12 million ‚Äì question.

Expected classic salumi to accompany smaller plates such as gazpacho and Cornish crab, pea and summer vegetable ragu, and grilled peach salad with smoked almonds and ricotta. Produce is to be predominantly British and and a nose-to-tail approach will be adopted.

Leach said: ‚ÄúDavid and I have spent many evenings cooking, eating and drinking together, and always shared the same philosophy and approach to restaurants. For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.

Paddington Basin. The Final Frontier. Well, perhaps not quite. But you do feel as though you are boldly going where no one has been before, when you enter central(ish) Londons last major bit of in-fill development. Its hard to find: the easiest way is to start at Paddington stations Heathrow platform, and to follow the signs to Marks & Spencer (whose new HQ is the developments anchor tenant).

Once youre there, this canalside development is, in an Americanised kind of way, surprisingly attractive  given that its dominated by a flyover (the Westway). It helps that the landlords - no doubt with lavish incentives - have attracted a critical mass of restaurants, including an already-popular Japanese (Yakitoria), an airy gastropub (The Union), a soon-to-open fish specialist, and the Chinese restaurant we review today.

The rambling dining room occupies a lower level of the development. Its short on natural light, and the designers have run with a sort of opium-den chic. The overall effect is comfortable, even if the chair/table heights/depths dont quite work, and the acoustics are tricky. While were on negatives, the service does not make up in efficiency what it lacks in charm.

The food, though, is a redeeming feature. Dim sum are a speciality (served lunch and dinner), and come at a prices reminiscent of Chinatown, and up to the same standards as the best operators there. Larger dishes - such as Peking Duck and steamed sea bass - were also realised to a superior standard. Puddings included an oddly satisfying, blue blancmange-y number. In fact, everything was consistently above par.
So, when youre next passing (just kidding) give the place a try. Or, if youre a real fan of Chinese cooking, you might even find it positively worth seeking out.

has announced plans for a fourth London outpost. The ‚Äúcool‚Äù and ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù chain has chosen shopping hub Carnaby Street for its next venture, just a few doors down from Cinnamon Soho on Kingly Street.
