A basic Covent Garden bistro offering an ever-changing wine selection, and a menu of brutal simplicity; an early-days visit suggested this appealing-sounding formula is in need of a little refinement.

The idea sounds so attractive. A bistro named after its ever-changing wine selection: ten whites and ten reds, all bought in (at most) ten case parcels. Offer straightforward food to go with it, and serve it in a cramped and decidedly no-nonsense setting handy for, say, the Royal Opera House. Et voil√É¬†!

Well, not quite: we found the reality less compelling. Let‚Äôs start with the ‚Äòmarquee attraction‚Äô: the wine list. There‚Äôs just one house champagne, from a little producer called‚Äô Mo√´t & Chandon. Wouldn‚Äôt your typical oenophile hope to be introduced to some marque rather less grande than the world‚Äôs biggest fizz? It seemed an odd start.
Rather similarly, the list of still wines seemed disappointingly straightforward for a place that plays on its wine appeal. But the main impression was how expensive the wines were by the glass.

Surely the joy of a place like this is to sample? Yet 1/6-bottle glasses of wine are generally priced somewhere round one third the price of a full bottle. Why a premium approaching 100% for samplers? And if you‚Äôre going to offer just one dessert wine, should it be a Sauternes at ¬£10 a glass?

The blackboard menu is short to the point of brutal. Three main courses always available, and a changing, but very small, selection of more transient plats, most so straightforward that their description requires no more than a couple of words. Puddings were tarts ‚Äì pear or lemon?

It makes perfect sense for a small kitchen to do a few things well, but results here were variable. Starting at the end, with those tarts, the one we chose (pear, as it happens) was dull and a bit flabby.

Earlier dishes had their highs and lows. The house salad ‚Äì a warm affair with pancetta and a duck‚Äôs egg on top ‚Äì was described by a guest as a ‚Äòwarm mush‚Äô. A tranche of salmon, however, was unusually well cooked ‚Äì evenly all through, which is no easy feat. A chicken terrine was straightforward, and none the worse for that.

Bread was pretty horrible. Hardly surprising: baguettes in London are almost always like cotton wool. But this isn‚Äôt a French restaurant. Why not give people the best local-style bread? Or, in London, pain rustique is invariably a better choice. The coffee was unremarkable too.

So a rather muted welcome from us for an operation we rather expected to like. It seems to us that if you hone your operation down to the essentials, you better be pretty damn sure that you‚Äôve got those essentials right. Quite a lot of work required, we think, to reach that position here.

Chef Tommy Banks, together with his family and their friend and restaurateur Matthew Lockwood, will open Roots in York this September.

Roots, Banks‚Äô second restaurant, has been hotly anticipated for some time. But we now know more about it. Unsurprisingly, the 28-year-old chef will continue to commit to seasonality and self-reliance: the farm-to-fork ideal that‚Äôs upheld in earnest at Banks‚Äô amazingly successful Black Swan in Oldstead.

It means a homage to vegetables ‚Äì whether fermented, pickled or fresh ‚Äì and dishes with the same creativity as at The Black Swan, with a delicate use of fish, and a bold, sparing ‚Äì though not ungenerous ‚Äì use of meat.

At the time of opening, September 2018, the daily menu will be centered around preservation ‚Äì as per Banks‚Äô guidelines. Dishes will include lamb with fermented turnip; cured trout with fennel kimchi and apple; beef tartare with fermented chilli and smoked bone marrow; and smoked eel doughnuts.

to announce the top 5¬†trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London.¬†Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on what¬†people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets per¬†week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

You‚Äôve probably noticed on Twitter on the left hand side of your ‚ÄòHome‚Äô¬†page there‚Äôs a ‚ÄòTrends‚Äô list. Twizoo has built the same thing, but solely¬†for London restaurants. Our number crunching detects the rate of change of¬†influential mentions on Twitter.¬†For example, ‚ÄòChristmas‚Äô is currently¬†trending on Twitter, which means there‚Äôs been a spike of mentioning¬†Christmas now compared with the rest of the year.

Applying this to Twizoo‚Äôs algorithms: if X restaurant usually gets on¬†average 10 tweets per week, but this week it gets 32 tweets‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a¬†pretty big change, so it‚Äôs a good indicator something notable is going on.¬†The algorithm notes restaurants that have the highest rate of change and ranks them based on which places‚Äô tweets are the¬†most positive collectively and then it takes the top of those based on¬†how influential the individuals are who tweeted. Simple see?

Yes it‚Äôs that time of year again, lights are being turned on by Z list celebrities in towns up and down the country, Amazon has announced their busiest ever Black Friday and the John Lewis advert has sent Twitter into meltdown ‚Äì Christmas is almost here. ‚ÄúUp high, overlooking London is breathtaking‚Äù, at this ‚Äúslick and¬†graceful‚Äù 33rd-floor perch; but while fans find the Chinese cuisine¬†‚Äúastonishingly good‚Äù for a room with a such an ‚Äúexceptional‚Äù view,¬†others find it ‚Äúunspectacular‚Äù especially given the ‚Äúcrazy prices‚Äù.

The whole roast goose feeds up to five guests and you‚Äôll need to order in advance. It‚Äôs marinated in Chinese spices for 12 hours and served with butterfly buns, accompanied by roast goose gravy, black pepper sauce and home-made plum sauce. Sounds quacking delicious.

‚ÄúFirst class‚Äù steaks and ‚Äúcool‚Äù styling win fans for these Hawksmoor-lite¬†spin-offs, which now have Stoke Newington, Chiswick and Balham branches as well¬†as the Clerkenwell original; ‚Äúprices add up quickly‚Äù however, results¬†can be ‚Äúunspectacular‚Äù, and ‚Äì while ‚Äúedgy‚Äù ‚Äì the decor is a tad¬†‚Äúfunctional‚Äù.

It‚Äôs hard to outdo Scandinavia when it comes to Christmas. Twinkling night-time markets; fur-filled lodges and a smorgasbord of pickled, cured and smoked fare to feast upon. At KuPP you‚Äôll find a range of Scandi-style menus. There‚Äôs the sharing menu, which includes a¬†selection of sharing boards of salmon, trout, pickles and more with a complimentary glass of Gl√∂gg (Nordic mulled wine) for ¬£12.50 pp (minimum group of 10). The full festivities offers a two course lunch (¬£25 pp) or three course dinner (¬£30 pp) with a complimentary glass of Gl√∂gg. Or you can choose a menu of canap√©s for ¬£35 pp.

. So what‚Äôs in a name? Well, it seems that chef-patron Pratap Chahal is keen to use a fusion of flavours ‚Äì gleaned from his time at Ramsay‚Äôs Claridge‚Äôs, Chez Bruce, Cinnamon Club and Galvin Bistrot ‚Äì to create an international menu with ‚Äòno attempt at authenticity‚Äô. Hence, we suppose, Flavour Bastard.

The restaurant, founded by restaurateur Vic Singh alongside chef Pratap Chahal, has taken over the former site of Arbutus in Soho and will open in September. Chahal describes his small plates menu as ‚Äòcuisine-agnostic‚Äô,¬†combining¬†flavours and techniques from different cuisines and cultures.

Dishes include: white lentil, chorizo and pecorino doughnut; steamed rice cake with house kimchi, sesame and ssam;¬†miso and mango glazed aubergine with peanut crumble and smoked aubergine relish; clouds of curds with pear and saffron chutney, pickled chilli and puffed rice; bergamot, lemon and cardamom tart with Japanese red bean, macadamia praline and banana ice-cream; and mayan-spiced milk chocolate and brownie mousse with bitter chocolate aero and lavender ice cream.

Drinks at the 20-seater bar will be overseen by Nick Jones, founder of Wines of Momentary Destination ‚Äì a pop up winemaker providing support to young winemakers globally. There will be a¬†Flavour Bastard own brew beer alongside wine, cocktails and sake.

to announce the top 5¬†trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London.¬†Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on what¬†people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets per¬†week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

You‚Äôve probably noticed on Twitter on the left hand side of your ‚ÄòHome‚Äô¬†page there‚Äôs a ‚ÄòTrends‚Äô list. Twizoo has built the same thing, but solely¬†for London restaurants. Our number crunching detects the rate of change of¬†influential mentions on Twitter.¬†For example, ‚ÄòChristmas‚Äô is currently¬†trending on Twitter, which means there‚Äôs been a spike of mentioning¬†Christmas now compared with the rest of the year.

Applying this to Twizoo‚Äôs algorithms: if X restaurant usually gets on¬†average 10 tweets per week, but this week it gets 32 tweets‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a¬†pretty big change, so it‚Äôs a good indicator something notable is going on.¬†The algorithm notes restaurants that have the highest rate of change and ranks them based on which places‚Äô tweets are the¬†most positive collectively and then it takes the top of those based on¬†how influential the individuals are who tweeted. Simple see?

ventured to Islington and James Cochran‚Äôs new restaurant, who has ‚Äúonce again plundered his Scottish and Saint Vincent heritage (plus the influence of a childhood in Whitstable)‚Äù. A ‚ÄúKentish-Scots-Caribbean‚Äù blend may sound like ‚Äúthe stuff of a disastrous ‚Äòfusion cuisine‚Äô‚Äù, but in Cochran‚Äôs hand ‚Äù it makes mad, brilliant sense‚Äù.

1251 and James Cochran serve up ‚Äúsoulful, foot-on-the-amp cooking, touched by a sense of joyous, grinning nostalgia‚Äù. (7/10)
paid a visit to Redcliffe newcomer Pasta Ripiena, sibling to Bristol‚Äôs Pasta Loco (owned by cousins Ben Harvey and Dominic Borel) in more ways than one ‚Äì head chef Joe is Ben‚Äôs brother.

Ripiena takes much inspiration from Loco: the same ‚Äúcute, unfussy atmosphere‚Äù, open kitchen, the drinks list (‚Äúspritzes, negronis‚Äù) and ‚Äúexcellent Italian produce, simply served‚Äù ‚Äì including ‚Äújoyous, oily, springy, utterly seductive‚Äù focaccia.

The ‚Äúmain event‚Äù is stuffed pasta: ‚Äúedible origami‚Äù: spinach ravioli ‚Äúare stuffed with parmesan-rich polenta ‚Äî double-carb heaven‚Äù, while triangoli are filled with a ‚Äútrawler‚Äôs worth of wild prawn, crab and mussels, all bound together with rich shellfish bisque‚Äù. It‚Äôs ‚Äúmessy, chaotic, sloppily delicious, with flashes of real sophistication‚Äù.

Is it really Italian? Dishes are ‚Äúcomplex and overloaded, qualities I‚Äôd sniff at in an actual Italian restaurant‚Äù. But it‚Äôs also ‚Äúa whole lot of fun: cooking designed to make you happy, not adhere to rules or stick to agendas‚Äù.
Having recently declared that ‚Äúit turns out that all you have to do to eat quite fantastically well in Brighton is‚Ä¶ go to Hove‚Äù,

visited Brighton‚Äôs Cin Cin ‚Äì which also has a branch in Hove ‚Äì and happily ate her words, along with Italian cured meats, Moretti, taleggio and ‚Äúeasily the best arancino I‚Äôve had this decade‚Äù.

The Brighton ‚Äúmother ship‚Äù, a former pop-up (and now ‚Äòbibbed‚Äô by the tyre men) may be ‚Äúa no-frills converted MOT ¬≠garage‚Äù but has ‚Äúa Roux-grad head chef‚Äù, who cooks ‚Äúright there next to you quietly and unfussily in a non-suffocatingly-hipster manner‚Äù and ‚Äúdemonstrates only passion and professionalism‚Äù; service is ‚Äúimpeccable‚Äù and the dining space is ‚Äúcool and relaxed‚Äù. (****)

was in Manchester, visiting the sibling to El Gato Negro. Unfortunately, Canto was not the same slick, delicious experience. Portuguese rather than Spanish,¬† with ‚Äúrandom outbreaks of fusion‚Äù in the small-plates menu.

had an odd experience at the celebrity-backed Zela, newly opened in the ME hotel in Aldwych. Christiano Ronaldo,¬†Rafael Nadal¬†and Enrique Iglesias have chucked ‚Äúso much money at a restaurant that they claim to have invented an entirely new cuisine‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄòMeppon‚Äô ‚Äì apparently ‚Äúan exquisite, original fusion of the best Mediterranean produce with Japanese techniques‚Äù.

But was it exquisite and original? Certainly not the latter, as it reminded Ms Dent of her recent meal at Tast in Manchester. Dishes like gnocchi with miso halibut, usuzukuri toro with pan con tomate and ‚Äúmany other raw things flecked with caviar or truffle‚Äù are challenging, poorly put together (‚Äúthe standard of sushi rolling is sleeker at the¬†Sushi Daily stand in Waitrose‚Äù) and service is either ‚Äù mob-handed‚Äù or entirely absent.

The interior leaves a lot to be desired too ‚Äì lots of greenery everywhere is nice but invites an unfortunate comparison: ‚Äúfor all the millions spent, Zela feels exactly like the West End hell portal¬†Rainforest Cafe‚Äù

, but not for just ‚Äúanother bloody gastropub. Rather, a restaurant to truly relish‚Äù. At The Bell Inn in Langford, Tom and his family enjoyed a ‚Äúbustling Saturday night‚Äù meal, with ‚Äúcharming staff‚Äù .

visited London‚Äôs hot new quarter, Coal Drops Yard, where one of the ‚Äúprecisely curated places to eat and drink‚Äù is Vermuteria vermouth bar, from Wild Honey owner Anthony Demetre.

ate at small-plates restaurant Heritage in Liverpool, where he ‚Äúordered as if we‚Äôd just spent six weeks in the Sahara‚Äù. (****1/2)

magazine must have received a fair amount of grumbles about his recent reviews ‚Äì either that or he felt like eating out three times this week, as he provided his readers with a trio of reviews, in order to (attempt to) satisfy everyone.

Gamma Gamma‚Äôs ‚Äúmenu is stone-cold mental, being a fusion of Japanese and Indian styles‚Äù (cue a series of wordplay japes from Mr Coren, describing the other global cuisines represented). But the chef can ‚Äù unquestionably cook‚Äù, serving up the unusual proteins (‚Äúzebra, ostrich and kangaroo‚Äù) with style; banana spring rolls were ‚Äúsensational‚Äù. Also, the ‚Äúartwork is bonkers‚Äù.

If that all sounds far too much like a ‚ÄúBalearic knocking shop with sweeties‚Äù, there‚Äôs always Rovi, ‚Äúa proper modern restaurant for grown-ups‚Ä¶ from the pomegranate seed king himself, Yotam Ottolenghi‚Äù. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúdaffy fusion here‚Äù,¬† just ‚ÄúOttolenghian sincerity, veracity and admirable commitment to eating vegetables‚Äù, albeit with ‚Äúmodern tweaks ‚Äì such as open-fire grilling and fermenting‚Äù, and a touch of the Orient.

Readers outside London who are after a ‚Äúdecent plate of proper old-fashioned grub‚Äù are directed towards a new Windsor pub, The Greene Oak ‚Äì ‚Äúa friendly dog-walker‚Äôs pub with good beer, perfectly decent cooking and a serious Sunday roast‚Äù ‚Äì which already ‚Äúhas the feeling‚Ä¶ of a format conceived to be rolled out‚Äù.
, Pep Guardiola‚Äôs new restaurant in Manchester; ‚Äúthis latest foray reveals his love of good Catalan food and wine but the space lacks excitement ‚Äú.

On a Kensington site that‚Äôs had a somewhat chequered history of late, a smart but somewhat subdued bistro offering food English dishes of very high quality, under the auspices of Square chef Philip Howard.

Philip Howard is one of those blameless chefs who beavers away doing what chefs are supposed to do ‚Äì for younger readers, that‚Äôs cooking ‚Äì year after year. It‚Äôs no particular surprise, then, that standards at his grand Mayfair restaurant, the Square, are a model of consistency. His has proved to be a nothing-to-scare-the-horses cuisine that has long made this one of the top destinations for grander business dining.

Now he‚Äôs decided to branch out, going into partnership with Rebecca Mascarhenas, best known as proprietress of the long-established Sonny‚Äôs in Barnes. Her efforts to make a go of the Kensington site she‚Äôs also owned for some time ‚Äì once called Abingdon Road, and more recently Bistrot Eleven ‚Äì never seem to have been crowned with great success.

Part of the problem is that these are premises which just don‚Äôt have zing. Though they are in a street long associated with restaurants (and one that leads into one of the most chichi Kensington backwaters), Abingdon Road has always struck us as rather a forlorn thoroughfare, and the recent establishments on this site have never managed to transcend their location.

The recent (fairly modest) make-over hasn‚Äôt really made much difference: objectively this is a perfectly comfortable dining room, but it is still rather lacking in spark. On our lunchtime visit, the service was one stage better than the d√©cor ‚Äì fine, perhaps even a bit better than that, but not really with enough ooomph to create what you might call a soul.

Perhaps, though, the cooking here will make it ‚Äòthird time lucky‚Äô for Ms M. It‚Äôs certainly of a very high quality (and it‚Äôs already driving the foodie end of the Twitterati to heights of ecstasy). On our meal the bread was splendid (we‚Äôd suggest the sourdough), and an autumnal soup was as rich and as satisfying as you could hope for, and came ‚Äì rather unusually ‚Äì with a mini-kebab or two. We can‚Äôt remember precisely what they consisted of, but they certainly added interest! A duck leg from the set lunch menu was precisely cooked, the meat falling from the bone but not at all overcooked. A small but perfectly-formed pear financier (sponge pudding, not a chap who tears up ¬£50 notes) was clearly the work of a master.

A guest was equally happy with his meal. His elegantly-plated ox-tongue ‚Äì surely an oxmoron? ‚Äì certainly looked like the sort of dish you‚Äôd fine in a much fancier sort of joint, and he expressed delight both with it and the rabbit terrine which preceded it. Coffee and chocolates were also excellent. Both the menu and the wine list are extensive and reasonably priced (and the latter offers a good choice by the 25cl carafe).

One very much senses here the inspiration of Arbutus, a seminal West End success of recent times. Kensington, however, is emphatically not Soho: only if the food here succeeds in attracting a dedicated ‚Äì and hopefully animated ‚Äì following does there seem any real hope of a breakthrough on the atmosphere front.

For restaurant critics, offbeat formulas make for easy copy. Reviewing this ambitious-looking new Clerkenwell venture ‚Äì which prominently advertises its ‚ÄòThai-Indian cuisine‚Äô¬ù ‚Äì therefore looked set to be a cinch.

My old friend obligingly set about ordering a Thai set lunch to complement my Indian one. I began to congratulate myself on how easily the column was to be filled up with descriptions of the varying national styles of dishes (interspersed with the occasional insightful point of comparison between the two).

But it was not to be. Those enticed in by the prominently advertised Thai set lunch (or, indeed, the √É¬† la carte) are told ‚Äì without much in the way of apology, or explanation ‚Äì that Thai cuisine is now ‚Äòoff‚Äô. For good, it seems. So this performance, it turned out, was to be Hamlet very much without the Prince.

What remained was a far cry from the quirky culinary experience with which I had hoped to regale you. In fact, remove the Thai ‚Äòangle‚Äô, and what‚Äôs left is a pretty unremarkable Indian restaurant, of the type which continues to colonise many environs of the City. The cooking ‚Äì rather at the level you might have expected if the kitchen had been struggling to cope with two great cuisines at once  ‚Äì seemed undistinguished for a brigade that now only needs concern itself with one. The service was fine, if not especially engaging, but looked as if it might get rather over-stretched as the place filled up.

So is there any postive reason at all seek this restaurant out? Mercifully, it does turn out that there is at least one: an unusually light and grand function room (for 25), which would make a pleasant and good-value venue for private dining. But any culinary adventure is very definitely off the menu.

A-Head London 2018 aims to raise awareness of the benefits of art therapy on mental health through a programme of eclectic and artful events taking place over a few days. Dinner and a show ‚Äì it‚Äôs a classic combination ‚Äì but not a particularly cheap one most of the time. Luckily we‚Äôve rounded up the best places to find pre and post-theatre menus. Whether you fancy fine dining at temples of gastronomy like Koffman‚Äôs and Gymkhana for a fraction of the price, or you‚Äôre looking for some cheap ‚Äòn‚Äô cheerful brasserie fare in Covent Garden we‚Äôve got it covered. ¬†So if you‚Äôre off to see a play, a musical, a comedy night, or you just want to enjoy an early or late dinner, let Harden‚Äôs be your guide to the West End‚Äôs best evening set menus‚Ä¶

‚ÄúDelightful and meticulous‚Äù delicacies ‚Äì eaten on high stools, many beside the open kitchen ‚Äì help justify the vertiginous prices (the ‚Äústeal of a set lunch‚Äù aside) at this ‚Äúglamorous‚Äù Covent Garden outpost of the Parisian √É¬ºber-chef; as the formula dates, though, reporters find the place increasingly ‚Äúoverrated‚Äù.

‚ÄúHigh-end Indian food cooked to perfection‚Äù and ‚Äúincredibly helpful‚Äù staff help win rave reports for this ‚Äúextremely civilised‚Äù and ‚Äúclassy‚Äù Mayfair stalwart; if there is a reservation, it‚Äôs the basement setting.

‚ÄúAtul Kochhar is a master of spicing‚Äù and ‚Äúcontinues to delight with the innovative interpretation of Indian cuisine‚Äù, at his ‚Äúslick and showy‚Äù Mayfair operation; its ratings slipped a notch this year though ‚Äì perhaps there‚Äôs just more competition than once there was?

‚ÄúMasterful chef‚Äù Pierre Koffmann ‚Äì the man who made La Tante Claire London‚Äôs best restaurant of the ‚Äô90s ‚Äì is truly back with a vengeance at this Knightsbridge venue, though nowadays his ‚Äúfaultless‚Äù Gallic gastronomy seems more ‚Äúgutsy‚Äù than of old; the deep-basement setting, though, will never truly sparkle.

‚ÄúMuch improved‚Äù since the recent refurbishment, this ‚Äúrelaxed but classy‚Äù Mayfair spot is a ‚Äúgood but pricey‚Äù fixture, where the food is ‚Äúreliably interesting‚Äù, and whose ‚Äúclubby, wood-panelled intimacy‚Äù suits business in particular.

‚ÄúColours, tastes and textures are beautifully combined‚Äù to create ‚Äúexciting and delicious‚Äù dishes, at Pied √É¬† Terre‚Äôs Marylebone offshoot; shame about the interior, though ‚Äì critics say it has ‚Äúall the ambience of a railway caf√©‚Äù.

‚ÄúLike Ol‚Äô Man River, just keeps rolling along!‚Äù ‚Äì this ‚Äúunderstated‚Äù ‚Äô80s brasserie, behind The Ritz, ‚Äúalways make you feel like a million dollars‚Äù; its ‚Äúrobust‚Äù comfort food ‚Äúwon‚Äôt let you down‚Äù, but it‚Äôs not as dazzling as it once was ‚Äì the ‚Äúpeople-watching‚Äù is the more reliable sparkler.

Straight into the super-league of London‚Äôs nouvelle Indians, this ‚Äúunstuffy‚Äù yearling, near The Ritz, offers a ‚Äúsensationally subtle‚Äù cuisine, including some ‚Äúwonderfully original game and other dishes‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs ‚Äúworth the hassle to get a table‚Äù.

‚ÄúGreat hearty British food‚Äù ‚Äì majoring in ‚Äúmeat, meat and more meat, plus a little fish‚Äù ‚Äì makes this ‚Äúfantastic and buzzy‚Äù gastroboozer a very popular City standby, even if at times it‚Äôs ‚Äúso noisy it‚Äôs impossible to chat‚Äù.

‚ÄúSo good my eastern European wife got homesick!‚Äù; this ‚Äúbeautiful and airy‚Äù (but sometimes ‚Äúvery noisy‚Äù) former warehouse, in Borough, offers some ‚Äústylishly executed‚Äù (mainly) Polish fare; beware the vodkas though ‚Äì ‚Äúthey‚Äôve crushed many an after-work drinker‚Äù.

Maurizio Morelli‚Äôs ‚Äúsubtle‚Äù venture remains ‚Äúone of the best Italians in central London‚Äù; it stars ‚Äúterrific‚Äù Roman cooking (‚Äúmagnificent ravioli‚Äù), ‚Äúcourteous and respectful‚Äù service, and a wine list ‚Äúthat‚Äôs an attraction in itself‚Äù.

The ‚Äúopulent‚Äù setting may be ‚Äúamazing‚Äù, but this Italian dining room, near Trafalgar Square, has put in a mixed performance since its launch a few years ago; of late, however, it has begun to garner more praise, especially for the ‚Äúexcellent-value‚Äù set lunch, and ‚Äúcharming‚Äù service too.

‚ÄúUnpretentious, and reasonably-priced for Covent Garden‚Äù ‚Äì this ‚Äúreliable‚Äù basement Italian restaurant may give little hint nowadays of its fashionable past, but it‚Äôs a ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù sort of place, and still with a fan club among reporters, especially pre- or post-Royal Opera House.

‚ÄúWho can resist a date with Nelson?‚Äù ‚Äì the ‚Äústunning view‚Äù from this top-floor dining room in the heart of the West End is its particular attraction; fans are ‚Äúpleasantly surprised‚Äù by the cooking too, though the less starry-eyed can find it ‚Äúuninspiring‚Äù.

From autumn 2016, the ‚Äúhall‚Äù is to be chopped from its name; and its renown for dining, currently under Gareth Ward (who re-gained its Michelin Star), rather than accommodation will be underlined by no longer offering stays on Sunday and Monday, and denominating itself as a ‚Äúrestaurant with rooms‚Äù rather than a ‚Äúhotel‚Äù (there are ten bedrooms).
The 26-cover restaurant offers two 14-course tasting menus, both priced at ¬£95 per person. There is also a six seater chef‚Äôs table, with a ‚Äòsurprise tasting menu‚Äô priced at ¬£130.
Since his arrival in 2013, Gareth Ward has championed Japanese techniques within his tasting-menu-based approach, including sourcing Welsh Wagyu beef from a farm in Montgomeryshire.

The property, once owned by Queen Victoria, has a longstanding gastronomic reputation. The current shift in emphasis follows the passing away earlier this year of its founder Joan Reen (who opened  the hall as a hotel with husband Rob in 1989) and its purchase by longstanding guests, John and Jenny Talbot.
From a major Oriental operator, a competent but, on our visit, almost deserted Japanese restaurant, decorated in nightclub style, five floors above Regent Street.

Intrigued by our recent visit to the neighbouring Spanish restaurant, aqua nueva, we felt the need to hot-foot back across town to see how the neighbouring Japanese restaurant had turned out. There‚Äôs not much point in us setting the scene again, so if you haven‚Äôt read that

Our early lunching experience of the Japanese operation was just like the Spanish one: perfectly competent, but nothing to get excited about (if with perhaps a bit more atmosphere here). The details hardly matter, though, as the key point is that it was pretty much empty; the sort of empty that makes you feel sorry for the staff (who were charming, and trying hard). And, if anything, the Spanish part, which we revisited, was even emptier than it had been on our first visit.

Causes are not hard to find. The absurdly discreet entrance doesn‚Äôt look like a restaurant at all: even a nightclub like Annabel‚Äôs is less of a shrinking violet than this place is. There is no menu outside ‚Äì isn‚Äôt that illegal anyway? And why, when so many restaurants which don‚Äôt need doormen have them nowadays, does this place ‚Äì which desperately does ‚Äì not have two? (Hey, one in Spanish dress, one Japanese ‚Äì at least they‚Äôd be noticed.) If you do summon up the courage to go in, the Stygian ground floor lobby feels positively spooky. We were half way across the apparently deserted room when a voice demanded to know our business. Well, to go to the restaurant; the lifts from the lobby go nowhere else.

The whole approach is so wrong that it makes you wonder how anyone ‚Äì even more a highly regarded international operator with a number of outlets in the East ‚Äì can spend millions, and still not have thought properly about the basics of getting people into such an obscurely-located restaurant in the first place. We‚Äôre told that measures are in hand to put right many of the most obvious defects. But is there time? Without the mother of all relaunches, this place is fast beginning to look like the biggest pre-Christmas turkey London has ever seen.
We are but days away from the Glorious Twelfth. Soon, Britain‚Äôs rural enclaves will be rife with the sound of shotgun fire.
And after Yorkshire‚Äôs moors and sweeping Scottish hills are punctuated by gunshots, a flurry of feathers and heady glasses of whisky, grouse will be whisked to the country‚Äôs
Game is a fine tradition in the Britain. We‚Äôve long sought after pheasant, partridge, duck, pigeon. And venison, of course. But where‚Äôs best to enjoy the best of it all?

A traditional, lively pub, The Jugged Hare offers a game-centric menu when it can. Chefs will be heading out early on Monday August 13 to grab their share of red grouse and dishing up a five-course feast.
Diners can expect smoked roe deer with whisky and redcurrants, braised rabbit shoulder, and grouse with game chips. Dinner costs ¬£85 per person.
Chef and hunting man Steven Smith shoots his own birds. He‚Äôll be serving a classic three-course dinner on August 15 for ¬£65 per head.
This year, Tom Kitchen will be serving a special grouse dish of bread sauce and lingonberries, which will be available from August 14 in his Leith restaurant.
His pub, The Scran and Scallie, will start doing grouse on the 13th, if you can‚Äôt wait.¬† According to our reporters, ‚Äúif you want to see and be seen in Stockbridge, this is the place for you‚Äù.
(and business-friendly) Mayfair venture¬† will be doing roast grouse with blackberries and late summer vegetables.¬† A lighter dish, perhaps? Well, lighter, anyway.
Of course the Cotswolds has its fair share of game. And The Wheatsheaf, a 17th century coaching inn is always a prime location for the best of what the season brings. After all, the

Chefs at the pub are eager to land early birds and start serving quickly. Indeed, other pubs in the area, such as those at Ian Coley Sporting, want to be first to get their grouse with game chips on the menu. The Wheatsheaf will be serving its dish with a large glass of its ‚ÄòAre You Game?‚Äô Shiraz, for ¬£30 per person.
will both be adding the bird to their menu. Grouse will be served alongside celeriac mash, red cabbage with game sauce and will be available in both restaurants from the second week of August.
will soon also be serving partridge (September) and pheasant (October), while La Poule au Pot will feature squab pigeon and medallions of venison (September).
10 Greek Street in Soho will be serving a selection of game dishes soon after the first shoot. The restaurant, which is popular with

Dishes over the next few months include venison wellington, served with truffle mash, girolles and cavolo nero (¬£26); whole pheasant with brussels tops, roast garlic and tarragon bread pudding (¬£36 for two); hare, new potatoes, pancetta, creamed leek and spinach (¬£22) and grouse ‚Äì ah, here it is ‚Äì with a potato gallette, kale and grilled plums (¬£28). Also notable is the fact chef Cameron Emirali makes use of whole pheasant, using pluck for pate, while leftovers are turned into rillettes. Any other off-cuts are used up at their other project The Whitechapel Refectory, a caf√© and wine bar serving small plates at East London‚Äôs Whitechapel Gallery.

, where game is integral to seasonal proceedings. As well as grouse, partridge, duck and pheasant, the likes of goose, common snipe and woodcock may also make an appearance on the restaurant menu from August 13. As noted by Richard Corrigan, venison (staggered, gender-specific hunting), wood pigeon and rabbit are available year-round.

Corrigan also pays homage to fish, so expect plenty of fly-caught freshwater salmon and trout, too; you may remember his wild salmon dish on Great British Menu some years ago. Corrigan said: ‚ÄúGame was a big part of my childhood. I have been catching and cooking game since I can remember and I taught myself how to get the best flavour from it, so with Corrigan‚Äôs Mayfair, it seemed like a natural choice to make ‚Äì that, and the fact that game is delicious!‚Äù
Hot Newcomer 20 Stories in Manchester is getting in on the grouse action from the 19th floor at No1. Spinningfields in the North‚Äôs ‚Äòfood capital‚Äô.

The menu will feature press√© of Landes quail and foie gras, pomegranate and apple; poached wild halibut, shellfish emulsion, cucumber and caviar; roast Scottish grouse, boulang√®re of leg, savoy cabbage and wild mushrooms; and brillat-savarin with late summer truffle, grape chutney and walnuts.
‚ÄúGame is a wonderful wild product that tastes like nothing else. It is always varied with different flavour notes which invites exciting wine pairings.

‚ÄúThe red grouse is a completely wild bird unique to Britain and a seasonal delicacy. In the past it was traditional to eat game on the Glorious Twelfth, but we prefer to wait a few days to ensure the birds are in prime condition.‚Äù

to announce the top 5 trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London. Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on what people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets per week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

You‚Äôve probably noticed on Twitter on the left hand side of your ‚ÄòHome‚Äô page there‚Äôs a ‚ÄòTrends‚Äô list. Twizoo has built the same thing, but solely for London restaurants. Our number crunching detects the rate of change of influential mentions on Twitter. For example, ‚ÄòChristmas‚Äô is currently trending on Twitter, which means there‚Äôs been a spike of mentioning Christmas now compared with the rest of the year.

Applying this to Twizoo‚Äôs algorithms: if X restaurant usually gets on average 10 tweets per week, but this week it gets 32 tweets‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a pretty big change, so it‚Äôs a good indicator something notable is going on. The algorithm notes restaurants that have the highest rate of change and ranks them based on which places‚Äô tweets are the most positive collectively and then it takes the top of those based on how influential the individuals are who tweeted. Simple see?

The Raby Hunt near Darlington was the biggest winner in yesterday‚Äôs (snooze-worthy) 2017 UK and Ireland Michelin Guide announcements, with chef James Close bagging his second star. Heston Blumenthal‚Äôs Fat Duck in Bray returned to three-star status, having been omitted from last year‚Äôs guide during its residency in Melbourne.

There were no other multi-star¬†promotions this year,¬†although head chef Matt Abe retained coveted three-star status for Restaurant Gordon Ramsay in Chelsea. Sharing Michelin‚Äôs top billing with Alain Ducasse at The Dorchester, Michelin continue to promote a league table totally unrecognised by London‚Äôs fooderati.

Abe‚Äôs¬†predecessor¬†Clare Smyth, who left earlier in the year and plans to open her first restaurant in 2017, received a new special award for GB and Ireland female chefs at the announcements, which were made for the first time this year at a live event¬†in London.
Michael Wignall retained two stars at¬†Gidleigh Park in Devon, where he followed Michael Caines. Wignall‚Äôs previous perch, The Latymer at Pennyhill Park in Surrey, lost its two stars.

There were 17 new single stars in the UK, including two in Wales, Restaurant James Sommerin at Penarth in Cardiff Bay and Sosbarn and The Old Butchers on Anglesea; and two in the Lake District, Forest Side in Grasmere and Gilpin Hotel in Windermere.

The other new single stars went to: The Crown at Burchetts Green, Berkshire; the Tudor Room at Great Fosters in Egham, Surrey; Thomas Carr at the Olive Room in Ilfracombe, Devon; the Wild Rabbit in Kingham, Oxfordshire; and Peel‚Äôs at Hampton Manor near Birmingham. London winners were the Five Fields in Chelsea (pictured); Celeste at the Lanesborough Hotel; Ellory in London Fields; Pidgin in Hackney; The Ritz Restaurant; Veeraswamy in Regent Street; Trinity in Clapham; and The Ninth in Bloomsbury.

By awarding a start to Trinity in Clapham, Michelin has finally recognised one of its most shocking omissions of recent years. At least with Five Fields it has only taken them three years to cotton onto the obvious.

Some say plans to gentrify the infamous Walkers Court would have the ‚ÄòKing of Soho‚Äô turning in his grave; home, as it was, to his Raymond Revuebar. But others, like Soho Estates and the developers behind the ¬£45m project, say they have no wish to sanitise the area, but¬†simply want to increase footfall to its legal businesses.

Indeed, it seems that The Box (a burlesque bar favoured by louche young Royals and movie stars) will remain in situ, in place of Paul Raymond‚Äôs Revuebar (although a neon sign will be installed in tribute to the late tycoon‚Äôs eponymous venue). And, fittingly, the man who could possibly lay claim to Raymond‚Äôs title as ‚ÄòKing of Soho‚Äô, Russell Norman, has plans to open a restaurant in the Walkers Court development.

Yes, the sleaze is slowly being wiped away by the bistros, coffee shops and high-end clothing stores, but Soho retains enough of its past identity to remain an edgier central London location than most.

Further proof that Soho‚Äôs seedy roots are being eradicated? An illegal strip club on Great Windmill Street was closed down this summer and will be repurposed as a 50-cover restaurant and Folk clothing shop. New owner Gordon Kerr may be a first time restaurateur, but he‚Äôs getting some first rate support in the form of Hawksmoor duo, Huw Gott and Will Beckett, who are advising on this new British meat concept.

We know that Russell Norman has agreed a deal on a 5,000 sq ft premises in Walkers Court but the ‚ÄòRestaurant Man‚Äô is yet to announce firm plans for his as yet unnamed new venture. A pizza joint has been rumoured.
A Soho restaurant that only takes reservations? That‚Äôs what this thoroughly British dining concept coming to Wardour Street is proposing; surely it will never catch on!
Alan Yau takes over the former site of The Endurance (RIP), with plans to open up a Chinese gastropub in the heart of Soho.

‚Äì the restaurant bloggers apparently proclaim ‚ÄúJerusalem‚Äôs coolest‚Äù came to Soho this spring and the critics cannot stop raving about it. On our visit we found a characterful little spot serving refreshing, modern cuisine.
There was much excitement in May as Mikael Jonsson ‚Äì who caused such a buzz at Chiswick‚Äôs Hedone ‚Äì took over the kitchen at this cramped Gallic operation offering ‚Äútasty‚Äù bistro staples.
Handily sited in Soho, a small but jolly Gallic-run bistro, offering tasty dishes of high quality‚Ä¶ but on a small-plate scale, with prices to match.
It all started with a three wheeled food truck ‚Äì now Pizza Pilgrims open their second permanent location in Kingly Court.

A relaunch of Russell Norman‚Äôs mega-popular Venetian-style bacaro, it‚Äôs the epitome of how London eats now. Polpetto is in here because, Lord knows, people were excited about it moving to a new, larger premises ‚Äì but we must admit the food was just okay, rather than ‚Äòwow‚Äô on our visit.

‚ÄúThe best tapas bar in London‚Äù‚Ä¶ ‚Äúpossibly the world!‚Äù; ‚Äúit‚Äôs worth the hour‚Äôs wait‚Äù to nab a perch at this tiny (23-seat) and ‚Äútoo busy‚Äù Soho phenomenon, where there‚Äôs an ‚Äúintimacy‚Äù to having ‚Äúincredible‚Äù dishes ‚Äúentertainingly prepared‚Äù before your very eyes.

Alexis Gauthier‚Äôs ‚Äúinspired‚Äù modern French cuisine goes from strength to strength, at his ‚Äúquirky‚Äù and ‚Äúfaultlessly charming‚Äù Soho townhouse (where ‚Äúringing the door to get in adds novelty‚Äù); ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt understand why they lost their Michelin star!‚Äù

‚ÄúInspired‚Äù, ‚Äúregional‚Äù Italian tapas ‚Äì ‚Äúmatched by no other Italian restaurant in London‚Äù, and served by ‚Äúpassionate‚Äù and ‚Äúunpretentious‚Äù staff ‚Äì win adulation for this ‚Äúbustling‚Äù venture, tucked away near Piccadilly Circus; ‚Äúget a counter seat to watch the brigade in action‚Äù.

‚ÄúTruly heavenly‚Äù tapas and an ‚Äúexcellent wine list‚Äù fuel the ‚Äúbusy buzz‚Äù of this stylish haunt, a sibling to Salt Yard, just off Carnaby Street; ‚Äúdespite its initial pokey appearance‚Äù, it‚Äôs ‚Äúa lovely place to spend a long afternoon‚Äù.

‚ÄúA pretty much unique experience!‚Äù; offering ‚Äúdelicious‚Äù seafood, right in the sleazy heart of Soho, this ‚Äúcosily perfect‚Äù (if ‚Äúloud‚Äù) champagne and seafood bar is ‚Äúa real gem‚Äù; ‚Äúget a window table to watch the goings-on outside‚Äù.

We‚Äôre seeing something‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a vision of bearded and bespectacled hipsters flocking in their droves in search of foodie nirvana. It can only mean one thing ‚Äì Psychic Burger has opened a second London location.

The founders are bringing their ‚Äúdown and dirty, ‚ÄòRock an‚Äô Drool‚Äô approach‚Äù to cooking to the Old Queen‚Äôs Head in Islington‚Äôs Essex Road. Head chef William Dennard will feature his infamous Horse Burger (made from 100 per cent ethically sourced horse meat) with hay-smoked American cheese, alongside the more classic burger combos.
Psychic Burger‚Äôs residency at the north London boozer begins on 24 April, and it seems it may become permanent. Happily, the Birthday‚Äôs original, in Dalston, carries on.

If ‚Äì after recent openings like One Sixty Smokehouse, Q Grill and Avenue ‚Äì you still haven‚Äôt had your fill of the cuisine du jour, you‚Äôll be really pleased to hear a new American pop-up is coming our way.¬†Ruby Jean‚Äôs Diner will kick off a run of residencies at¬†The Royal George in Charing Cross Road on 9 April.

From there the pop-up will move on to Kilburn (The Earl Derby) on 10 April, Camden (The Lyttleton Arms on 14 April and The Railway (Blackheath) on 15 April and Shepherd‚Äôs Bush (Sindercombe Social) on 18 April. Sindercombe Social is a new supper venue, opening for the first time that night on the site of a former O‚ÄôNeill‚Äôs pub in Goldhawk Road.
Ruby Jean‚Äôs Diner will serve up the usual array of US-inspired dishes like fried chicken, burgers (16 different varieties), nachos, New York-style deli sandwiches and salted caramel tart.

‚ÄúAbsurdly juicy‚Äù steaks and ‚Äúfirst-class cocktails‚Äù underpin huge acclaim for Huw Gott & Will Beckett‚Äôs ‚Äúcasual and laid-back‚Äù temples to meat; even fans admit prices are ‚Äúeye-watering‚Äù, though, and ratings are beginning to fall some way behind those of its main rival, Goodman.
) brings his talents to the Town Hall Hotel; the bar does drinks for Lee Westcott‚Äôs The Typing Room restaurant, also in the building.

Located on the 1st floor of Social Eating House, the Blind Pig has a vintage twist with antique mirrored ceilings and reclaimed wooden chairs. The bar serves a signature drinks menu created by mixologist Gareth Evans including the Thermonuclear daiquiri and Dill or no Dill.

Hidden away in the little square behind The Zetter Hotel is the Zetter Townhouse which vaunts a classy cocktail lounge ‚Äì brought to us in collaboration between the hotel, chef Bruno Loubet and mixologist Tony Conigliaro.
Situated in the station‚Äôs original¬†ticket hall, this bar and restaurant at St Pancras Renaissance Hotel is a great place to grab a drink and bite to eat before hopping on the Eurostar.

‚ÄúYummy ceviche as the name suggest‚Äù and other ‚Äútangy, tasty and well-executed‚Äù dishes ‚Äì not to mention ‚Äúexcellent Pisco sours‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúhelp extend one‚Äôs sense of what Peruvian food can be‚Äù, at this ‚Äúvibrant‚Äù and ‚Äúdistinctive‚Äù Soho rendezvous.

‚ÄúForget Nobu ‚Äì this is much better!‚Äù; ‚ÄúZuma‚Äôs little sisters‚Äù offer ‚Äúlight-hearted and creative‚Äù Japanese-fusion dishes that ‚Äúexplode on the palate‚Äù, and ‚Äúterrific‚Äù cocktails too.

It‚Äôs the ‚Äúmagical‚Äù rooftop dining area which excites reporters on Sir Terence Conran‚Äôs ‚Äúcool-looking‚Äù Shoreditch venture (which also has a spacious basement restaurant); portions can be ‚Äúsmall‚Äù, though, and service is on the ‚Äúsketchy‚Äù side.
From an ex-Gore Hotel duo, a new brasserie near Fulham Broadway which downstairs vaunts a gin bar, 510 Below, with an extensive cocktail list.

‚ÄúBurgers to die for, lethal cocktails, fantastic decor‚Ä¶ what more could you want?‚Äù ‚Äì this ‚Äúbuzzy‚Äù (‚Äúextremely noisy‚Äù) Hoxton Square outlet of the ‚ÄòMeat‚Äô franchise is, say fans, ‚Äúincredibly cheap for the quality‚Äù.
Fitzrovia speakeasy-style cocktail den opens a second location in Fulham with all-day restaurant; ex Light House (SW19) chef Michael Mannion heads up the kitchen.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.
From a major Oriental operator, a competent but, on our visit, almost deserted Japanese restaurant, decorated in nightclub style, five floors above Regent Street.

Intrigued by our recent visit to the neighbouring Spanish restaurant, aqua nueva, we felt the need to hot-foot back across town to see how the neighbouring Japanese restaurant had turned out. Theres not much point in us setting the scene again, so if you havent read that

Our early lunching experience of the Japanese operation was just like the Spanish one: perfectly competent, but nothing to get excited about (if with perhaps a bit more atmosphere here). The details hardly matter, though, as the key point is that it was pretty much empty; the sort of empty that makes you feel sorry for the staff (who were charming, and trying hard). And, if anything, the Spanish part, which we revisited, was even emptier than it had been on our first visit.

Causes are not hard to find. The absurdly discreet entrance doesnt look like a restaurant at all: even a nightclub like Annabels is less of a shrinking violet than this place is. There is no menu outside - isnt that illegal anyway? And why, when so many restaurants which dont need doormen have them nowadays, does this place - which desperately does - not have two? (Hey, one in Spanish dress, one Japanese - at least theyd be noticed.) If you do summon up the courage to go in, the Stygian ground floor lobby feels positively spooky. We were half way across the apparently deserted room when a voice demanded to know our business. Well, to go to the restaurant; the lifts from the lobby go nowhere else.

The whole approach is so wrong that it makes you wonder how anyone - even more a highly regarded international operator with a number of outlets in the East - can spend millions, and still not have thought properly about the basics of getting people into such an obscurely-located restaurant in the first place. Were told that measures are in hand to put right many of the most obvious defects. But is there time? Without the mother of all relaunches, this place is fast beginning to look like the biggest pre-Christmas turkey London has ever seen.

Selin says: ‚ÄúI love Pip and I love her cooking and style.¬† We really connect in the kitchen and I can‚Äôt wait to cook with her for this special event.¬† There are amazing women cooking in kitchens all over London right now.¬† This is our way of showing some of that off, for one night only.‚Äù

We‚Äôve chosen the name hicce, because it means ‚Äòcurrent, of the moment‚Äô in Latin and that‚Äôs exactly how we see our restaurant ‚Äì constantly evolving.‚Äù ¬†Pip worked for Gordon Ramsay Holdings including Restaurant Gordon Ramsay for three years before spending six years working her way up to the position of head chef at Angela Hartnett‚Äôs Murano.

The husband and wife team met under chef Nuno Mendes and credit a shared love of rice as the catalyst for the creation of TƒÄ TƒÄ EATERY . The name is inspired by the Mandarin words for ‚Äúhe‚Äù and ‚Äúshe‚Äù and their menus nod towards the culinary traditions of their native China and Portugal.

The project began as a street food stall on London‚Äôs Druid St. Market, before a series of pop-ups at the Newman Arms and Kitchen Table, followed by a year-long stint at Haggerston caf√© Curio Cabal.

The TƒÄ TƒÄ EATERY residency is the fourth project within the Borough Wines Chef Development Series, which has seen the retailer collaborate in the past with celebrated chef and YBFs 2015 winner Adam Rawson and former Fera at Claridges chefs Michael Thompson and Ollie Downey.

The aim of the series is to support chefs keen to develop new restaurant concepts; Borough Wines provides space and resources, as well as PR and marketing support, while working with chefs to develop a drinks offering and front-of-house experience that complements the food menu.

It is Borough Wines‚Äô first long-term residency at the Kensal Rise site and unlike previous projects within the series, not a ticketed set-menu, but an izakaya-style menu of small plates, designed to be enjoyed with drinks. Dishes will cost on average ¬£7 each and can be ordered individually, or as tapas-style sharing plates. There are specials on the menu featuring large seafood platters and charcuterie plates for two or more guests to share.

The menu includes Meng and Ana‚Äôs characteristically playful take on ngiri and tacos, as well as cult-favourite, the Katsu Sandwich ‚Äì a toast sandwich of deep-fried, slow-cooked Iberico pork neck served and Asian slaw. The handmade Toasted Rice Cream , which has been a popular feature on previous TƒÄ TƒÄ menus, also returns, accompanied by changing seasonal toppings of berries and flower blossom.

The Borough Wines-designed drinks menu features wines chosen to complement the dishes (available by the glass, carafe and bottle), specially selected craft beers and soft drinks. Cocktail serves inspired by the food menu are also available, devised by Geyan Surendran, Distiller in Chief at Surendran and Bownes. Should diners spot something they would like to try from the Borough Wines shelves, they are invited to go ‚Äòoff-list‚Äô, paying the retail price plus ¬£8 per bottle corkage for wines and ¬£1 for beer.
The TƒÄ TƒÄ Residency launched Thursday 10 May 2018 at Borough Wines & Beers, 30 Station Terrace, Kensal Rise, London, NW10 5RP . Bookings for groups of six or more can be made by email

showcasing the finest oysters, fish and seafood. Watch the chefs at work as you and your guests dine in the giant ‚Äòoyster cage‚Äô, nestled within the open kitchen.¬†The Cage¬†can accommodate 20 seating, or 35 for a standing event.

to announce the top 5¬†trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London.¬†Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on what¬†people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets per¬†week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

You‚Äôve probably noticed on Twitter on the left hand side of your ‚ÄòHome‚Äô¬†page there‚Äôs a ‚ÄòTrends‚Äô list. Twizoo has built the same thing, but solely¬†for London restaurants. Our number crunching detects the rate of change of¬†influential mentions on Twitter.¬†For example, ‚ÄòChristmas‚Äô is currently¬†trending on Twitter, which means there‚Äôs been a spike of mentioning¬†Christmas now compared with the rest of the year.

Applying this to Twizoo‚Äôs algorithms: if X restaurant usually gets on¬†average 10 tweets per week, but this week it gets 32 tweets‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a¬†pretty big change, so it‚Äôs a good indicator something notable is going on.¬†The algorithm notes restaurants that have the highest rate of change and ranks them based on which places‚Äô tweets are the¬†most positive collectively and then it takes the top of those based on¬†how influential the individuals are who tweeted. Simple see?

Sam‚Äôs, a ‚Äúconsistently good neighbourhood brasserie‚Äù, ‚Äútucked away down an alleyway‚Äù, off Chiswick‚Äôs main drag, has been in operation for over 10 years. While ‚Äúthe Balham Set‚Äù (there is such a thing, apparently) have enjoyed the ‚Äúalways buzzing‚Äù Harrison‚Äôs for the past eight years.

Sam Harrison said: ‚ÄúI have decided it is time to pass on the baton to an exciting, young and vibrant company who think the same way as I always have about restaurants, customers and staff. I can‚Äôt tell you how much I‚Äôve loved the last 10 years and am so¬†immensely¬†proud of everything we have achieved.

‚ÄúI not only say goodbye to a business but to my second family ‚Äì my staff, who have stayed with me over the years, and our many loyal customers, who treat the restaurants like a home away from home. I will truly miss you all and I thank you for your patronage and support.‚Äù

Will Beckett said: ‚ÄúWe are sorry to see Sam‚Äôs and Harrison‚Äôs close, but happy to see Sam getting his life back a bit! We‚Äôve been friends for 10 years and have been to his restaurants many times ‚Äì initially as young men enjoying a late night drink, lately as exhausted dads with our families, glad to have his amazing staff look after us and our kids.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve always really liked Sam‚Äôs restaurants and over a beer with Sam it became clear he was considering his options and deciding where the future might take him. We felt we could pick up where he left off ‚Äì opening restaurants that are a genuine part of a vibrant community, where food, drink and service are always the most important things.¬† Sam liked the idea because it meant that he could sell the business he built and loves to people he knew, who would act honourably with him and treat his staff and customers with care and attention.‚Äù

, the arrival of Sackville‚Äôs in Mayfair (an opulently expensive ode to beef and truffles) is a sure sign the hard times are well and truly over‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThere would be exposed brick, bespoke cocktails and an eating bar, we were promised, just like you‚Äôd expect to find in Dalston, but with the reassuring presence on the menu of ¬£70 steaks and ¬£38 burgers. heads to the much trendier environs of Bethnal Green‚Äôs railway arches to look in on the latest effort of foodies‚Äô darling Robin Gill (The Dairy, Clapham). And the critic is effusive in his praise of the paradoxically named Paradise Garage‚Ä¶
‚ÄúThe detail which catches my attention lies at the very bottom of the first gnarly Asiatic porcelain bowl delivered to our table at

in London‚Äôs Bethnal Green. It is a slick of lemon gel beneath an airy pillow of sweet pea mousse, served with halved radishes and some thick poppadom-like crackers, to get you started as you scan the menu. The unexpected hit of citrus makes me look up from the automatic process of dip and nibble and dip. Without it, the mousse would have been a fine thing: an agreeable and earthy way for chef Simon Woodrow to declare intent. But with it the whole bowl flashes and sparkles. Just as the palate risks being dulled by sugars, so it comes alive. It makes me think somebody somewhere likes me; it is the smart touch of a kitchen that‚Äôs happy to let details accumulate.‚Äù

gives new meaning to the phrase ‚Äòtepid review‚Äô with quite possibly the most luke-warm appraisal of a restaurant‚Äôs food, service and ambience we have ever read. All three dishes are topped with the same microherbs and mandolined radishes, an admirably pragmatic, that‚Äôll-do approach to garnishing.‚Äù

Fay Maschler‚Äôs enjoyment of her trip to Wright Brother‚Äôs new South Ken outpost is tempered somewhat by the prices. However her review for the

‚ÄúFrom the blackboard of daily specials we try grilled Cornish sardines with lemon and garlic and also white anchovies with vinegar, shallot and parsley. Six anchovy fillets, aka boquerones, of the sort that often come packed in large plastic tubs at ¬£6.50 reinforce that sensation. Bread and carefully portion-controlled butter is a side dish at ¬£2.‚Äù
AA Gill must be off on something of an extended summer sabbatical, we‚Äôve not seen a restaurant review from him for some weeks now. Instead his

column was this week filled by Tanya Gold who was the only mainstream critic to venture outside of London. She reviews Hardeep Singh Kohli‚Äôs pub-cum-curry-house, on the former site of The Vintage in Leith‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThe menu is Glaswegian-Indian, a¬†cuisine I am not familiar with. (Singh Kohli grew up in Glasgow.) It puns too, which makes me wonder if the curried cauliflower cheese could perform a five-minute bulletproof set,¬†while spiced rhubarb crumble could theoretically outwit Paul Merton on Have I Got News for You. I¬†think it could. I would like all panel shows to guest-feature sarcastic and self-loathing set meals that weep in the Green Room.‚Äù

Hildreth Street was transformed into a modern foodie hub as part of the ¬£2million makeover of Balham town centre completed last year. Balham has developed a powerful food scene in the past few years, with French, British, Indian, Nepalese, Italian, Caribbean and Chinese food offered at every level from fine-dining to street caf√© ‚Äì all within a few minutes walk from the station.

The latest recognition came this week when local legend Milk won the award for Best Breakfast or Brunch at the inaugural Harden‚Äôs London Restaurant awards, beating competition from West End institutions including The Wolseley.

Exciting news for anyone who loves pancakes (so, pretty much everyone), Shrove Tuesday is coming up (9 February)! Sometimes we have to wait until March for our flippin‚Äô pancakes but with an early Easter on the horizon Pancake Day has been pushed up the calendar too. In honour of this most delicious day we‚Äôve rounded up London‚Äôs top 10 destinations for breakfast/brunch, according to our 2016 survey‚Ä¶

‚ÄúLess hectic than the Wolseley but with all the good bits‚Äù ‚Äì Corbin & King‚Äôs ‚Äúso-very-civilised‚Äù three-year-old, on the fringe of Covent Garden, is a less showy, more ‚Äúluxurious‚Äù alternative to its bigger stablemate (and likewise ‚Äúpitch perfect‚Äù for business). The mitteleuropean cooking ‚Äúisn‚Äôt really the point‚Äù, but it‚Äôs usually highly ‚Äúsatisfactory‚Äù (in particular the ‚Äúutterly fab‚Äù breakfasts and ‚Äúmost delicious afternoon teas‚Äù).

‚ÄúGo mainly for the extraordinary views‚Äù to this 24/7, 40th-floor hang out; ‚Äúthe signature dish (confit duck with a fried egg, waffle and syrup) is better than it sounds‚Äù, but opinions are mixed on the ‚Äúmainly meaty, high cholesterol‚Äù fare and you pay ‚ÄúCity boys‚Äô drinks prices‚Äù. Maybe try breakfast or coffee.

‚ÄúCapturing the perfect brunch vibe‚Äù ‚Äì this ‚Äúbuzzy‚Äù, ‚ÄúNYC-style‚Äù haunt in Fitzrovia has a ‚Äúvery media‚Äù following that adores it, especially at breakfast (or for a business lunch), and it‚Äôs ‚Äúalways busy‚Äù; even fans concede however, that the cooking here generally is ‚Äúnothing to shout about‚Äù.

A ‚Äútop notch breakfast‚Äù with ‚Äúsun streaming through those huge windows‚Äù is the most reliable attraction in this ‚Äúlight and airy‚Äù (but ‚Äúsoulless‚Äù) dining room, over Borough Market; however at other times its British fare can seem ‚Äúseverely overpriced‚Äù given the ‚Äúun-memorable‚Äù results ‚Äì ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had better ¬£10 roasts in a pub!‚Äù.
This ‚Äúposh pub‚Äù, quietly located near Marble Arch, is proving ‚Äúa great addition to Marylebone‚Äù with ‚Äúhearty, satisfying fare‚Äù and ‚Äúa nice if noisy vibe‚Äù.

‚ÄúThe central bar is a great focal point‚Äù at this ‚Äúslick‚Äù and ‚Äúsophisticated‚Äù brasserie, whose long opening hours (from breakfast on) and flexible Italian tapas menu help make it ‚Äúa great Mayfair meeting place‚Äù (although it can feel a bit like ‚ÄúHedge Fund Central‚Äù).

‚ÄúHow did Corbin and King get things so wrong?‚Äù ‚Äì this ‚Äúbuzzing‚Äù Sloane Square two-year-old looks ‚Äúelegant‚Äù, but service can be ‚Äúappalling‚Äù and the brasserie fare is ‚Äúseriously underwhelming‚Äù ‚Äì ‚Äúit‚Äôs like an expensive Caf√© Rouge!‚Äù
Or why not have an omlette instead of a pancake? Egg white omelette with your choice of: ham, cheese, mushroom, tomato and spinach ¬£7.50

‚ÄúSpillover from the bar helps fuel the really buzzing atmosphere‚Äù at the Soho House-group‚Äôs clubby Soho brasserie, which is ‚Äúa little noisy but great fun‚Äù; its ‚Äúcomfort food‚Äù cooking is best for brunch ‚Äì otherwise ‚Äúthere‚Äôs not much actively bad about it, it‚Äôs just a bit ‚Äòmeh‚Äô!‚Äù

NYC supremo, Keith McNally‚Äôs ‚Äúpricey and flash‚Äù Grand Caf√© in Covent Garden is ‚Äúa disappointing replica‚Äù of the Manhattan original; still, even some who concede it‚Äôs ‚Äúa definite case of style over substance‚Äù say ‚Äúthe buzzy ambience is compensation‚Äù, or tip it ‚Äúfor a girlie brunch‚Äù.

is fairly picking up speed. An outpost of the barbecue joint ‚Äì specialising in American-style smoked meats ‚Äì arrived on the South Bank‚Äôs Globe Walk in June and now another restaurant has opened at Boxpark, Shoreditch.

in Knightsbridge reopened on 1 July after a multi-million pound renovation. The hotel vaunts 93 bedrooms, 43 suites and a new restaurant on the former site of Apsleys (RIP) called

to announce the top 5¬†trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London.¬†Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on what¬†people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets per¬†week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

You‚Äôve probably noticed on Twitter on the left hand side of your ‚ÄòHome‚Äô¬†page there‚Äôs a ‚ÄòTrends‚Äô list. Twizoo has built the same thing, but solely¬†for London restaurants. Our number crunching detects the rate of change of¬†influential mentions on Twitter.¬†For example, ‚ÄòChristmas‚Äô is currently¬†trending on Twitter, which means there‚Äôs been a spike of mentioning¬†Christmas now compared with the rest of the year.

Applying this to Twizoo‚Äôs algorithms: if X restaurant usually gets on¬†average 10 tweets per week, but this week it gets 32 tweets‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a¬†pretty big change, so it‚Äôs a good indicator something notable is going on.¬†The algorithm notes restaurants that have the highest rate of change and ranks them based on which places‚Äô tweets are the¬†most positive collectively and then it takes the top of those based on¬†how influential the individuals are who tweeted. Simple see?

to announce the top 5¬†trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London.¬†Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on what¬†people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets per¬†week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

You‚Äôve probably noticed on Twitter on the left hand side of your ‚ÄòHome‚Äô¬†page there‚Äôs a ‚ÄòTrends‚Äô list. Twizoo has built the same thing, but solely¬†for London restaurants. Our number crunching detects the rate of change of¬†influential mentions on Twitter.¬†For example, ‚ÄòChristmas‚Äô is currently¬†trending on Twitter, which means there‚Äôs been a spike of mentioning¬†Christmas now compared with the rest of the year.

Applying this to Twizoo‚Äôs algorithms: if X restaurant usually gets on¬†average 10 tweets per week, but this week it gets 32 tweets‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a¬†pretty big change, so it‚Äôs a good indicator something notable is going on.¬†The algorithm notes restaurants that have the highest rate of change and ranks them based on which places‚Äô tweets are the¬†most positive collectively and then it takes the top of those based on¬†how influential the individuals are who tweeted. Simple see?

In the basement of the new site, a ‚Äòfine dining‚Äô restaurant will feature. Seating just ten, Kebab Queen will be a hidden enclave within the main premises, with a more ‚Äúrefined, sophisticated‚Äù take on Middle Eastern-inspired food. As yet, no details on the menu have been released.
The new venture is a collaboration between Le Bab founders Stephen Tozer and Ed Brunet, together executive head chef Manu Canales, who was previously sous chef at

The main Maison Bab menu features eight new kebabs, which will sit alongside starter dishes, snacks and nibbles, with drinks including cocktails, Chapel Down cider, craft beer and affordable but adventurous wine. Expect Czech Pinot Noir and Moroccan Syrah.
Starters include a doner beignet and an Indo-Iranian mutton curry. The only familiar dish ‚Äì and the only one available at both restaurants ‚Äì will be Le Bab‚Äôs fondue fries.

Maison Bab will serve the likes of raclette shawarma, a chicken shish, and vegan options such as miso celeriac shish with pickled crispy onions and toum. House-made manoushe ‚Äì Lebanese pizza ‚Äì with toppings such as Yorkshire lamb, Sussex labneh and chilli and zataar is another new addition to the concept.
Yet another street food trader puts down permanent roots as purveyor of Eastern-influenced, charcoal grilled meats and fish,

, launches a standalone restaurant in the City. The 30-cover venue opens its doors next month with free food at lunchtime on 14¬†& 15 April. There will be no bookings for the soft launch so make sure you get there early!
Following a string of successful street food and pop-up opportunities, such as Night Tales in east London, Walter and Monty has snapped up a site in Bury Street.
The entire menu will be overseen by founder Alex Kaye along with head chef, Nick Ross who worked alongside the likes of Daniel Boulud and Scott Conant.

Serving choices are simple; enjoy it wrapped in a flatbread warmed on the grill or straight up with rice and salad. Choose from six house sauces which range from a flaming Scotch Bonnet to a more mellow feta and garlic.

Of course Walter and Monty will feature an open kitchen so punters can watch their meat char on the grill. The kitchen is bordered by a chunky marble counter with¬†five foot chopping board, where all meat will be prepared before diners eyes and the nerdiest foodies can ooh and aah at the chef‚Äôs cleaver skills and accomplished butchery!
The breakfast counter will serve coffee by day, and transform into a drinks cabinet by night. Walter and Monty will open¬†in two phases; initially for lunch, and later for breakfast and dinner.

Regent Street & St James‚Äôs have teamed up to launch a food waste pledge in May, featuring 11 of London‚Äôs most recognisable and acclaimed restaurants between Oxford Circus and Pall Mall.
Collectively, the group has committed to reducing food waste by 25 per cent by May next year. It is, Regent Street & St James‚Äôs  say, the first of its kind in the UK.
The pledge has been created by The Crown Estate, which owns the destinations, and is inspired by the United Nation‚Äôs Sustainable Development Goal 12.
Goal 12 focuses on responsible consumption and production and aims to reduce food waste by 50 per cent per capita by 2030.

The Food Waste Pledge launched in May 2019 in partnership with the Sustainable Restaurant Association (SRA). It includes the likes of Brasserie Zedel, Angela Hartnett‚Äôs Caf√© Murano, Hawksmoor Air Street; Hotel Caf√© Royal, ikoyi; Scully, Sketch, and Stem.
Jane Wakiwaka, sustainability manager at The Crown Estate says: ‚ÄúAt The Crown Estate we take a long-term view in everything that we do.
‚ÄúWe champion sustainable practices across our business and in partnership with our restauranteurs and retailers, The Regent Street & St James‚Äôs Food Waste Pledge is the next exciting step.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre proud to spearhead an initiative that will unite many of the fantastic restaurants on our portfolio and reduce food waste for a more sustainable future.‚Äù

MasterCard‚Äôs Priceless Cities campaign is an epic and extraordinary way to explore London and other cultural hotspots across the globe. Perfect for curious spirits like Harden‚Äôs readers who love to venture out,¬†Priceless¬†Cities is now available in more than 40 destinations accessible from over 70 countries.

Meat School exists¬†to promote the British cured meat industry. We‚Äôre based at Cannon & Cannon‚Äôs HQ in London‚Äôs Borough Market, and we run a selection of courses and events from hands-on¬†courses, which teach butchery and curing skills through to short tasting sessions and talks. Think cured¬†meat and beer or wine matching, pickles and pork, and meet the producer events. They‚Äôre mostly run on weekday evenings, and they‚Äôre all¬†educational, entertaining and, above all, meaty. Attend Meat School, and we promise you‚Äôll never look at supermarket salami or a packet of air dried ham in the same way again.

The Meat School run a series of fun and exciting tasting evenings every month, showcasing the best of British cured meat paired with superb wines, beers and spirits.¬†Our extremely popular Meat & Wine evenings, on the first Thursday of every month, are hosted by Christophe from Borough Wines and Sean Cannon. Both are passionate about drinking and eating well, and during the course of the evening they‚Äôll pass on their passion and knowledge whilst matching four different wines with a range of British cured meats and artisanal foods. The formal part of the evening lasts about an hour and a half, after which there‚Äôll be an opportunity to indulge in more of that wine and platters of the finest British cured meat. MasterCard‚Äôs Priceless customers will enhance their experience with a complimentary drink on arrival, a platter of Borough Market‚Äôs best cured meats, cheeses and pickles and an individual meet and greet with Sean and Christophe.

We love cured meat. And we love beer. Put them together and it‚Äôs a wonderful, wonderful thing. We run¬†Beer + Meat School with emerging craft breweries every month. These evenings are held at our Borough Market HQ and are hosted by ourselves and a beer expert of the month. Topics¬†include beers to match with Wild Meat; Smoked Meat;¬†Beefy Meats;¬†and London Produced cured meat. There are tasters of at¬†least five craft beers, each paired with brilliant meats. MasterCard‚Äôs Priceless London customers will be welcomed with a bottle of craft beer on arrival, a complimentary platter of Cannon & Cannon cured meats along with fine cheeses and pickles and an individual meet and greet with Sean and Christophe.
Meat + Wine School: Learn about a range of four different wines selected by our friends at Borough Wines and taste eight different cuts of British cured meat to match.
An evening of beer and meat with one of the most exciting, small, independent breweries in London, Five Points Brewing, paired with some of the finest cured meats that Britain has to offer.

After returning from a month-long barbecue ‚Äòpilgrimage‚Äô to Austin, Texas, the trio began their own story as nomadic BBQ street food traders in East London. ‚Äì told Harden‚Äôs last year that the dining room would be ‚Äúambitious and high end‚Äù but ‚Äúfun‚Äù, though at the time he couldn‚Äôt reveal much more.

While billed as an upmarket approach to kebab eating, the dining experience will be casual, the team said. Those wondering what Henry Harris has been up to since he shuttered Knightsbridge‚Äôs Racine last year need wonder no more. The chef will bring his signature, classical French cuisine to Thames-side restaurant-with-rooms,

Originally we were informed the venture would open at the end of May, however the launch date has now been pushed back until the beginning of July while Harris works on menus and assembles his kitchen team.

His menu promises French country cooking, with a few British classics on offer too, alongside a 450-bin wine list. Six luxurious suites, set inside a neighbouring Grade-II listed cottage (formerly an alehouse), are due to open this summer.

Harris was chef/patron of Racine for 13 years before he closed the restaurant in 2015. He¬†pointed to a ‚Äòrapidly shifting demographic in the Knightsbridge area‚Äô and ‚Äòoperational challenges‚Äô as reasons for its departure.

Harris was trained at Leiths before being employed by Simon Hopkinson at Hilaire and then later at Bibendum. He also cheffed at Harvey Nichols‚Äô Fifth Floor restaurant before leaving to head up Racine, where it was Tim Hayward who described him in The Guardian as ‚Äòthe best French chef with the decency to be British‚Äô. While working at The Dog & Badger, Harris will continue to act as consultant to The Groucho Club, where he collaborates with their executive chef.

Stork, a new west African restaurant from debutante restaurateurs Michael Adjovi Kalu and Nadina Grigoras, has opened in Mayfair.

The restaurant is one of the more original-sounding openings so far this year, playing on its founders‚Äô roots: ‚ÄúStork is a fresh concept that puts the spotlight on fusion dining at its finest ‚Äì modern British infused with the essence of West Africa and Eastern Europe.‚Äù

The menu is eclectic, with starters such as Scottish lobster and steam mui mui, and chicken schnitzel with new potatoes and Berkswell. They might follow snacks like ‚Äòchin chin‚Äô, a fried snack of crispy dough, and ‚Äòbeef suya‚Äô, a skewered meat ‚Äì usually chicken, goat, beef or mutton.
Main courses range from sea bass with leeks to chicken breast with gizzards. Eastern European influences come in the form of casseroles, a heavy use of mushrooms, and saddleback pork.
‚ÄúThe restaurant‚Äôs concept follows the flight of its namesake, the stork, on its journey from East to West,‚Äù say the founders.
‚ÄúThe menu‚Äôs global influences are collected along this journey, gathering taste inspiration and flavours from the countries in the Stork‚Äôs path. A true migration of taste.‚Äù
Kalu said he felt London needed a greater West African showing: ‚ÄúThere is nowhere in London to experience the true flavours of West Africa [what about

‚ÄúLittle is known about West African or Eastern European cuisine and Stork brings these global flavours to London. Stork offers a unique dining experience, a true taste sensation from a global cuisine.‚Äù
‚ÄúAdeshina has a portfolio of fine cuisine experience, starting work at Aubergine under Gordon Ramsay, followed by Marcus Wareing,‚Äù an announcement said.
‚ÄúFood and music are meant to go together.¬†Jazz, which is what I have spent most of my adult life at the keyboard wrestling with, was born in restaurants like this.

‚ÄúThe Straight and Narrow has heart. It does not occupy a pretty space. One side of Narrow Street is made of classic ancient warehouses, doubtless with interiors that glossy magazine editors would die for. The restaurant is on the other side, on the raised ground floor of a much more modern development.¬†The Straight and Narrow is the neighbourhood restaurant you want around the corner.

‚ÄúA Scotch egg, with a golden shell made of properly seasoned sausage meat mixed with cubes of apple, comes with a yolk just on the edge of running.¬†Main courses, priced in the teens, offer the kind of European-inspired, bistro cooking utilising British ingredients that is the food we really want to eat most of the time. It is roast chicken with risotto and fillet steak with chips.

‚ÄúDesserts are exceptionally good, the sort that make you wonder if there has been some grand hotel training involved (although apparently there hasn‚Äôt). A salted caramel tart has dark pastry with an echoing crunch and a deep golden filling that stays the right side of cloying.¬†Service is engaged without being stalkerish. The wine list is short and sensible.‚Äù
ain‚Äôt without faults, but I love it anyway‚Ä¶¬†the restaurant itself: hard surfaces, open kitchen, brick walls. It‚Äôs NOISY.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much heart here. And it‚Äôs enormous fun‚Ä¶¬†irresistible snacks that kick off the menu: crisp, crumbed nuggets, not chicken but sweet, fresh ‚Äòpopcorn‚Äô mussels that come topped with a cumin-clove-cinnamon-fragrant ‚Äúraz ketchup‚Äù based on ras el hanout‚Ä¶¬†the dandiest beer food known to man‚Ä¶¬†fat Barnsley double lamb chop, draped with smoky, grilled courgettes and peas in a light, creamy dressing is a splendid alliance between modernity and tradition.¬†There is, contrarily, no octopus.
‚ÄúThe bill‚Ä¶ comes as caress rather than headbutt‚Ä¶¬†I‚Äôve no doubt it will just get better and better, but in the meantime, it‚Äôs imperfectly perfect.‚Äù

‚ÄúSubstantial investment in Flavour Bastard signalled by Soho rent and rates for a fairly big site (previously Arbutus) and the involvement of AfroditiKrassa, the design company for Itsu‚Ä¶ among other operators suggests to me a template for a rollout.

‚ÄúWe expected cloud of curds with gram confetti, mint relish and guindilla ‚Ä¶ to be light, bright, ethereal even, so its dun-coloured appearance is a bit of a surprise.¬†Miso and mango-glazed aubergine, peanut-buckwheat crumble‚Ä¶ resemble a boiled sponge.
‚ÄúEvery current menu trope is hit on but, perhaps predictably, hubris outstrips execution. The name Flavour Bastard appears to be a reference to the chef‚Äôs unusual pairing of flavours.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a pub where the olives are stuffed with veal and the chips festooned with a Bloody Mary salt, which tastes like the gritty stuff from a bag of Nobby‚Äôs Nuts.
mentions of seaweed butter, hispi cabbage, posh grilled cheese and lots of other things that had a moment in foodland¬†15 months ago for regional types to order.

‚ÄúI am torn on The Wigmore as I‚Äôm glad it exists, and it appears to be making some people happy, but I never, ever want to go there again.¬†It‚Äôs like Anouska Hempel had a go designing a Toby Carvery.¬†The grilled cheese was enormous, but offered no real impetus to splurge carb-intake on it.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe cooking is not quite as pared-down ‚Äì nor quite as grown-up ‚Äì as the decor.¬†Fried artichokes were good, the leaves tawny and crunchy, the heart waxy and firm.

‚ÄúConfit old spot jowl‚Äù, though, was wonderful, hours in the cooking, served with a musty peach mostarda.¬†Pasta dishes looked great: tagliatelle with girolles, a Sicilian-style bucatini with sardines, the holy trinity of¬†aglio olio e peperoncino.¬†Swaledale lamb was beautifully cooked: two rare hunks of rump, a crisp comma of slow-cooked breast. ‚ÄúThe CHIK‚ÄôN hot burger is a serious beast, a great fat wodge of divine fried chicken, slathered in Sriratcha sour cream, loaded with a sharp tangle of spicy slaw, and wedged into a bun that manages to be both soft AND hold the whole thing together. ‚ÄúBetter still are the nacho style ‚Äòall in fries‚Äô‚Ä¶ Oodles of lurid fake cheese, studded with good bacon and pickled onion, and flavoured with a grunt of chilli, and a numbing of Sichuan pepper, poured lustily over those wonderful fries‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a messy, mucky junk food masterpiece.
